PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator McGauran (from 355 citizens) and Senator Troeth (from 326 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the pension age for women from 60 to 65.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to:

The creation of an American Health Care System in Australia through the empowerment of health insurance companies through legislation known as the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994 to conscript doctors and to dictate terms and conditions of treatment of patients with private health insurance and to exclude categories of illness from health insurance products and to divulge to the Commonwealth Government the personal details of illnesses for which hospitalisation is required.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate should reject or repeal the above legislation.

Dear Mal
Thank you for your letter of 6 February 1995 concerning the AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules No 409 of 1994.
Regulation 108

You express concern that amending regulation 36.2, which adds sub regulations (4)-(6) to regulation 108, has omitted the Note which advised of a right of appeal to the Student Assistance Review Tribunal (SART). Since the amending regulations confer these review functions elsewhere you have requested confirmation that regulation 108 decisions by the Secretary will be reviewable by the Society Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT).

I confirm that the decision to suspend or recommence payments under regulation 108 is reviewable under Part 9 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. Both internal review and external review are provided through the SSAT and then the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There does not appear to be any reason in this case as to why the Note was left out, although the drafter may have been concerned to remove erroneous references to the SART.
Sub regulation 14.3
You have requested advice as to whether the omission here was inadvertent.

Officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training have advised me that this was a minor drafting oversight. The intention of the amendment was to remove an out of date reference to the Social Security Act 1947, which has been replaced by the Social Security Act 1991. I understand that the new numbering should have been adjusted to (ii) and (iii), rather than (iii) and (iv). However, there are no legal consequences flowing from this and the matter will be addressed in future amendments.
Note to Schedule 5

Amending regulation 40 omits Schedules 4 and 5 which relate to the SART and refer to regulation 103 and 104 respectively. The regulation further seeks to amend the Note after Schedule 5 and states that `the Note after Schedule 5 ("NOTE—Higher education institutions" is to be taken to be a Note to Schedule 2.)'

You indicate that there does not appear to be a Note after Schedule 5, however comment that the Note to Schedule 6 seems relevant and query whether this is the Note to which the amendment intended to refer.

In this regard, I note that in the last official reprinting of the AUSTUDY regulations, two Notes were grouped at the end of the document after Schedules 1-5. The first note listed the Higher Education Institutions. It further provided a definition for `Higher Education Institution' as given by subregulation 33(3). It is this note to which the amendment refers. (The second note outlines the table of amendments to the AUSTUDY regulations).

The reason for the proposed amendment to the note linking it with Schedule 2 was due to the common reference to regulation 33. Schedule 2 relates to TAFE Institutions and also refers to regulation 33. For clarity the note should have followed directly after this Schedule. When Schedules 4-5 were removed, it was considered appropriate to re-establish the link between the Note and Schedule 2. Amending regulation 40 was intended to achieve this and thereby avoid any confusion over a possible link between this Note and Schedule 5.
I trust that the above comments address your concerns.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Minister

I refer to Civil Aviation Orders Part 105 AD/F27/103 Amdt 6 which amend the Schedule of Airworthiness Directives for Fokker F27 Series Aeroplanes. This Directive requires compliance with retirement lives, inspection methods, inspection periods and modifications specified in Fokker Structural Integrity Program (SIP) Document 27438 Revision 11 and subsequent Temporary Revisions (emphasis added).

In its 1993-94 Annual Report (at paragraph 3.3), this Committee expressed a preferred view of the operation of section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act, which enables a regulation to incorporate matter contained in a non-statutory instrument only as that instrument is in force at the time the regulation takes effect. This would seem to prevent the incorporation of "subsequent Temporary Revisions" in the Directive.

The Committee understands that section 98(3A) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 enables regulations made under that Act to incorporate other written instruments as in force not only at the time the regulation takes effect, but as in force from time to time.

The Committee would, however, appreciate your advice as to the effect of section 49A on instruments such as Airworthiness Directives, which are not strictly regulations, but are made by virtue of the regulations.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
28 April 1995
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mal
re: Civil Aviation Orders
Thank you for your letter dated 6 March 1995 to my Minister concerning Civil Aviation Order (CAO) Part 105 AD/F27/103, Amdt 6.

You asked if this amendment to the Schedule of Airworthiness Directives for Fokker F27 Series aeroplanes is authorised under Section 98(3A) of the Civil Aviation Act in light of your Committee's view that the operation of Section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act makes no provision for a regulation to incorporate written instruments that may come into force after the time the regulation takes effect.

I have been informed by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) that Section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 does apply to Airworthiness Directives and that Section 98(3A) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 (which excludes the operation of Section 49A in relation to Civil Aviation Regulations) does not extend to Civil Aviation Orders. Accordingly, Civil Aviation Orders cannot incorporate documents as in force from time to time.

I have been advised that the CAA has always operated on the understanding that CAOs cannot incorporate documents as in force from time to time. The reference to `subsequent Temporary Revisions' in CAO Part 105 AD/F27/103, Amdt 6 was made in error and will be corrected when Amendment List 6/95 is issued on 25 May 1995.
I thank you for bringing this matter to my notice and to the notice of the CAA.
Kindest regards

Dear Mal
re: Civil Aviation Orders
Thank you for your letter dated 6 March 1995 to my Minister concerning amendments to Section 40.1.0 of the Civil Aviation Orders made on 19 January 1995.
You asked whether the discretions conferred on the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) by the amendments to section 40.1.0 are subject to independent review.

The provisions of section 40.1.0 set out the requirements that an applicant for an endorsement must meet before the CAA is permitted under subregulation 5.23 (2) of the Civil Aviation Regulations (the Regulations) to issue an endorsement to the applicant. The Order sets out alternative requirements to be met for each endorsement. One of the alternatives is that the applicant holds an overseas aeroplane endorsement that the CAA is satisfied is at least equivalent to the endorsement sought. If the applicant does not meet any of the alternative requirements, and the CAA is not satisfied that his or her overseas endorsement is at least equivalent to the endorsement sought, it must not issue the endorsement (refer subregulation 5.23 (3)).

I have been advised that, under regulation 297A, any decision by the Authority not to issue an endorsement is subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This allows for a review of the discretion that has been exercised where the CAA's reason for refusing to issue the endorsement is that it is not satisfied that the applicant's overseas endorsement is equivalent to the Australian endorsement.
Kindest regards

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I am unable to move this motion today due to the fact that neither the coalition parties nor the government are prepared to fully support it. I understand, however, that there is considerable support, at least in government ranks, and I would not be surprised if there were support also from at least some of the senators on the coalition benches.

PARA.TAB: The Senate is very much the place to examine how the principle of separation of powers is implemented in Australia and, more importantly, the extent to which it is destroyed. The independence of the legal system and its officers is the basic protection for Australian citizens against a government, of whatever colour and at whatever level, that considers itself to be above the law.

In this situation, the terms of reference of this particular inquiry address: the independence of the legal system, by comparing the provisions at Commonwealth level with provisions at state level; the constitutional safeguards which are in place; and the adequacy of those safeguards. In these circumstances, it is essential that the Senate address those questions. It is not only the Senate's right but also its responsibility to do so in the absence of an independent judicial inquiry by Mr Kennett into the events in Victoria, which provide an illustration of what can go wrong if a government ignores the principle of separation of powers and holds itself out to be above the law.
I look forward to moving this motion on 31 May. I put it to both the government and the coalition parties that this is a matter of principle that should be addressed in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I extend my formal congratulations to you on the attainment of your eminent position. On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 336, Public business in the public interest: an inquiry into the commercialisation in the Commonwealth public sector. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome this opportunity to table the 336th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which is entitled Public Business in the public interest. At the outset, I would like to thank the committee secretariat for their sterling efforts in support of this inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The report is the result of the committee's inquiry into the commercialisation of public sector operations, which began nearly two years ago. In setting up the inquiry the committee was responding to concerns at that time about the operation of certain government business enterprises, GBEs, particularly the monopoly businesses of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. The committee was also aware of a series of reports by the Auditor-General about difficulties with the introduction of commercialisation in departments of state.

The committee decided to limit its inquiry to examining commercialisation in GBEs and business units in departments of state, and to focus on the efficiency and effectiveness of commercialisation and corporatisation, particularly in the FAC, the CAA and the Department of Administrative Services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Efficiency and effectiveness, and the framework for commercialisation and corporatisation

PARA.TAB: The committee took evidence from 14 of the Commonwealth's 19 GBEs and five of the nine departments which have business units. We concluded that commercialisation and corporatisation have been successful in increasing the efficiency with which GBEs and business units deliver goods and services. This increased efficiency and effectiveness reflects the fact that, generally speaking, appropriate frameworks for commercialisation and corporatisation have been established.

The framework that has been established for the operation and oversight of GBEs has proved functional, and was finetuned with the issue of new guidelines in 1993. The oversight arrangements will be locked in and extended to cover government companies as well as GBEs with the passage, hopefully within the next month or so, of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill.

As you may recall, Madam Deputy President, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has played a central role in the development of this legislation, first recommending that it be prepared in 1989 and then considering the bill in detail in report No. 331, which was tabled in September last year. In contrast to GBEs, business units in departments of state are more recent creations and the framework for their operation is less well established and is still being developed.

The committee believes that the Department of Finance should be taking a more prominent role than it has up to now in assisting departments to set up their business units. It should be putting more effort into monitoring the problems that arise in the course of commercialisation and identifying and disseminating best practice.

The committee also noted that business units in departments of state are currently disadvantaged by the requirements that being part of a department of state imposes. Given that corporatisation provides increased flexibility of operation, the committee has recommended that corporatisation should be extended to successful business units.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Key issues in commercialisation and corporatisation in the Commonwealth public sector

PARA.TAB: The committee examined many aspects of the operation of GBEs and business units—more than I can cover now. I have therefore selected three topics of importance on which I wish to concentrate—they are: Firstly, safeguarding the public interest functions that were once required of what are now government businesses; secondly, the need for GBEs and business units to have clearly defined, non-conflicting, commercial objectives; thirdly, whether the arrangements for ministerial oversight of government businesses are fully appropriate.

In choosing to concentrate on these topics, I do not wish to give the impression that other matters were not considered. The committee's report also covers, for example, the accountability and financial regimes that apply to GBEs and business units, their performance in competing with the private sector, and the impact that commercialisation has had on staff.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The public interest: community service obligations

PARA.TAB: Over the years the government has become involved in providing essential goods and services when they were not available under reasonable circumstances from the private sector. When the provision of these goods and services is commercialised, charges are levied for them which may be too expensive for the consumer. In this case, the consumers' access to these goods and services has been safeguarded by the government imposing community service obligations—CSOs—on those relevant businesses to supply what is necessary.

The committee examined the system by which CSOs are identified, costed and funded, and has recommended that more attention be given to defining CSOs so that the social outcomes that the government requires are precisely known, and the methods of costing and funding them are clear. This observation applies whether the CSO is being delivered by a government-owned business or by the private sector.

One avenue for monitoring the efficiency and effectiveness of CSO programs is through so-called performance audits. The committee believes that there are strong arguments for the Auditor-General, who is at present effectively barred from carrying out performance audits on GBEs, being able to examine the delivery of CSOs. Scrutiny of the operation of CSO mechanisms by the Australian National Audit Office may bring substantial improvements to the efficiency with which CSOs are delivered.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Focussing on commercial performance: avoiding conflicting objectives

PARA.TAB: One of the prerequisites for commercial success when parts of government departments are commercialised is that they are able to focus single-mindedly on their commercial activities. Thus, when a government business is commissioned to perform a social function, it is important that the business's commercial focus is not unnecessarily blurred by its social responsibility. Conversely, it is equally important that a businesses' commercial activities not impinge on its social welfare functions.

Some of the now commercialised sections of government departments formerly had policy and regulatory roles as well as social welfare responsibilities. With the introduction of commercialisation, these policy and regulatory roles need to be removed from these businesses and either transferred to other agencies or, if the government considers it appropriate, be dropped altogether.

Although it was frequently quoted to the committee, it was not clear that the full implications of this principle of separating different functions had been grasped and that adequate steps had been taken to implement it. The committee acknowledges that the government's businesses now no longer have regulatory functions in areas where they now compete with the private sector. However, the experiences of the CAA have drawn attention to the problems that can arise with the combination within the same organisation of a commercial function—for example, air traffic control—and a regulatory function that does not have a commercial focus—for example air safety. The committee found that this situation has led to confusion among the CAA's clients and within the organisation itself. The committee welcomes the government decision to separate those two functions and has recommended that agencies with similar combinations of functions should be so reorganised.

There were two other businesses that came to the committee's attention where the potential for a conflict between different objectives appeared possible. One such business is the legal practice of the Attorney-General's Department, which provides legal services to the government on both a commercial and public interest basis. The other business which is perceived as being caught in a conflict of interest is the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group, AUSLIG, with its large public interest function and a smaller commercial one. In both these instances there may be a case for separating the functions.

In some circumstances it may not be possible to separate different functions. With such cases, very clear guidance must be provided on structures that can be set up to minimise conflicts of interest and to manage any conflicts that do arise. It may be appropriate at times to provide an independent review of areas where apparent conflicts of interest are causing concern.

Prime responsibility for the oversight of a GBE's performance lies with the minister responsible for the industry sector in which that GBE operates. In carrying out this responsibility, the responsible or portfolio minister liaises closely with the Minister for Finance on the financial aspects of the GBE's performance. In this arrangement the portfolio minister has a diverse range of interests—for example, he or she is interested in the financial performance of portfolio GBEs, sets policy for the industries in which the GBEs operate, and ensures that appropriate regulation is in place. By analogy with the considerations that I have just raised in relation to the CAA, the legal practice and AUSLIG, it appears that such an arrangement may expose portfolio ministers to a conflict of interest.

The committee was interested to learn during a visit to New Zealand that in that country a different system for GBE oversight has been established. In the New Zealand system, responsibility for policy affecting state-owned enterprises rests with a different minister from the one who is responsible for their financial performance. In fact the Minister of Finance and the Minister of State-Owned Enterprises are joint shareholders of all state-owned enterprises.
At first glance, the committee felt that the New Zealand model had much to commend it. Compared with the Commonwealth's arrangements, this model appeared:

SPEECH.PARA: .to allow more consistent monitoring of GBE performance;
.to promote more efficient identification and dissemination of best practice;
.and through their separation from policy portfolios, to enable State-Owned Enterprises to concentrate on their commercial performance.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my remarks in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The committee explored these points with a number of Commonwealth agencies and GBEs and found little support for any of them.

.The agencies argued, with a consistent voice, that there should not be too great a focus on the commercial performance of GBEs. For example, a sole focus on commercial performance of the CAA's air traffic services might jeopardise its emphasis on safety and erode public confidence in the safe operation of Australia's air traffic services.

.They argued further that, with the Commonwealth's current arrangements, the strategic direction for each GBE is set by negotiation between the GBE's board and the responsible minister. This minister is said to be knowledgeable about the circumstances under which the GBE operates in a way that would not be possible for a minister who had responsibility for all GBEs.

.Furthermore, it was pointed out to the committee that the involvement of the Minister for Finance in GBE oversight provides a check on the portfolio ministers, and any conflict between them can be brought to the Cabinet and resolved there.

The committee concluded that at present there is no compelling evidence that major changes need to be made to the Commonwealth model of GBE oversight. While the New Zealand system of GBE oversight has worked well in that country, so too has the Commonwealth model in Australia. Government businesses, central agencies and portfolio departments all reported to the committee that they were satisfied with the way in which the current arrangements are working.

PARA.TAB: Before finishing I would like to refer briefly to the question of whether the government should be involved in business at all. The committee accepts that it is appropriate for the government to be involved in a range of commercial activities. For example, it is appropriate for the government to operate businesses so as:

SPEECH.PARA: .to provide services that are not available from the private sector; and
.to foster the development of emerging markets.
By being involved in business the government can also maintain the sort of expertise needed to:
.facilitate the work of the private sector through joint ventures, export enhancement and technology transfer; and
.develop effective monitoring and regulatory regimes.

However, the judgment of precisely how involved the government should be is difficult and is subject to change over time. The committee notes that in recent times the government has moved to sell a number of its GBEs. The program of asset sales is based on considerations of whether the public interest is best served by owning these businesses.

PARA.TAB: Some of the considerations are:

SPEECH.PARA: .whether significant competition already exists in the market in which the GBE operates;
.whether increased market exposure would bring improved performance;
.whether the enterprise would benefit from the sort of strategic partnerships and capital injections that can be negotiated in the marketplace; and
.whether social objectives are still dependent on public ownership.

The committee believes that the government's commitment to a continuing examination of its involvement in commercial activities is appropriate. I note in passing that the Auditor-General is currently conducting a performance audit into the efficiency and effectiveness of the procedures used in the sale of Commonwealth assets. Given the magnitude of the returns expected, and already achieved, from the asset sales program, it is important that the sales process be conducted as efficiently as possible. The committee awaits the Auditor-General's report with interest.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the committee believes that government businesses have greatly improved their level of performance since the introduction of commercialisation and corporatisation. There is evidence also that they are determined to improve further still. In this they will be assisted by the recommendations contained in the committee's report, particularly those which call on the government:

SPEECH.PARA: .to update the operating framework for government businesses;
.to clearly define, cost and fund CSOs; and
.to avoid imposing on government businesses conflicting commercial, policy and regulatory functions.
A positive response to these recommendations will ensure that public business will indeed be conducted in the public interest. I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Public Works Committee, I present the following reports: Refurbishment of Australia House, London (Committee's Fourth Report of 1995); Construction of a new laboratory complex for CSIRO Division of Food Science and Technology, Werribee, Victoria (Committee's Fifth Report of 1995); and Redevelopment of housing for service families at HMAS Cerberus (Committee's Sixth Report of 1995).

SPEECH.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's fourth report for 1995 relates to the refurbishment of Australia House, London. The proposal includes the implementation of a staged program of internal refurbishment providing tenancy conditions which meet the requirements of occupational health and safety, the replacement of outdated and obsolete equipment, and providing office accommodation which meets current data and communication needs; and the refurbishment of areas surplus to High Commission requirements for leasing to state governments and other agencies.

PARA.TAB: The committee has recommended that the work proceed at an estimated cost of $14.25 million at May 1994 prices. Australia House has been Australia's showcase in central London since it was officially opened by King George V on 3 August 1918. Peak occupancy occurred during the post-Second World War immigration boom. However, continuing staff reductions since that time have resulted in surplus space in Australia House.

Madam Deputy President, you might be aware that there was some talk a few years back about selling Australia House. That would have been an absolute disaster because it is such a fine building. But it has run into disrepair and so I am pleased to see that at last the government has seen fit to do something about it. Australia House is Australia's oldest overseas mission and a London landmark building classified by English Heritage. The building was constructed during 1913-18 using substantial amounts of Australian timbers and marble. It is the oldest originally occupied chancery of any foreign mission in London.

Over the years various parts of Australia House have been renovated on an as-required basis, but no comprehensive renovation program has been undertaken since it was completed—although the public areas have been maintained at a high level. Whilst the exterior has been comparatively well maintained, the interior condition is variable and many of the building services are at the end of their safe and useful life. At the request of the committee, the Overseas Property Group examined various options for the use of the sixth floor, which will be left vacant due to the movement of communications facilities to the third floor.

The committee has concluded that, on the evidence provided to it from the Australian High Commission in London, the sixth floor of Australia House is not suitable for conversion to provide long-term residential accommodation but is suitable for transit accommodation or office accommodation. The committee has therefore recommended that the sixth floor should be converted for use as transit accommodation or office accommodation.

The committee's fifth report from 1995 refers to the proposal to relocate the Victorian based activities of the CSIRO's Division of Food Science and Technology from Highett to the Werribee technology precinct. The proposal is part of a program of integrating food research activities in Victoria. The new facilities will be constructed in an area immediately adjacent to those of the Victorian government's Australian Food Research Institute. The complex has been designed recognising the need to develop a close working relationship with the Australian Food Research Institute. Buildings have been sited to encourage staff interaction between the two organisations. The proposal which has been recommended by the committee is estimated to cost $10.1 million at September 1994 prices.

The CSIRO advised that remaining at Highett was not considered to be sustainable because of the continued fragmentation of research for the dairy industry whilst occupying different sites; the increasing costs of support activities which are detracting from research funding; the potential for reduced support from the Dairy Research and Development Corporation; the need for a capital injection of approximately $5.8 million for refurbishment of the laboratory; and the fact that some facilities at Highett are cramped and, even with a half-life refit, the continuing location of the laboratory at Highett will isolate it from other food activities at Werribee and reduce industry focus and support.

While there was widespread support for the proposal from the Victorian government and industry groups, the CSIRO Division of the Community and Public Sector Union raised concerns regarding the proposal, particularly the impact on the research program. The committee, having carefully considered all the evidence presented to it, is of the view that relocation to Werribee is the most viable long-term option. Mr Barry Jones had quite an interest in this project and he gave evidence to our committee.

The committee believes that collocation at Werribee with the Australian Food Research Institute will lead to advantages in research collaboration and in reduced infrastructure costs through the sharing of common facilities such as the library, canteen, auditorium and workshops. In addition, relocation to Werribee offers the opportunity for collaboration with a wide range of both public and private research bodies which are or will soon be established in the Werribee area. The committee is also aware that the Dairy Research and Development Corporation has offered CSIRO a grant of $4 million towards equipment at Werribee.

While the committee accepts and understands the reluctance of staff to relocate to Werribee and also agrees that the relocation will have some temporary adverse impact on the research effort, the committee believes that the relocation will have a positive long-term impact on the work of the laboratory. In particular, the project provides opportunity to develop a coordinated research and development centre for the food industry.

The third report which I have tabled deals with the proposed redevelopment of housing for service families at HMAS Cerberus. My colleague Senator Newman would know just how long overdue that is. By way of background, HMAS Cerberus is a significant and expanding Royal Australian Navy training establishment located at Western Port. There are currently 554 families located both on board HMAS Cerberus and ashore in the surrounding area. And it is approximately five miles from the Stony vineyard.

The proposal which the committee examined is aimed to partially redress the imbalance in housing available on board compared with ashore by increasing on board housing from 109 to 152 in accordance with the DHA mission to provide defence personnel and their families with good housing consistent with community standards.

The scope of the works examined by the committee is the provision of an additional 55 houses on new and revised lots, the provision of 45 houses as replacements for existing substandard houses, substantial upgrading or replacement of 10 existing older brick houses and the retention of 27 existing houses which require less substantial works. When referred to the committee, the estimated cost of the proposed redevelopment was $14.2 million.

In recommending that the redevelopment should proceed, the committee has concluded that there is a need to replace or modernise existing on-board housing at HMAS Cerberus to match contemporary standards and expectations. Many of the on-base houses are well below acceptable community standards. I must say that some of the old brick houses that are to be refurbished should be heritage-listed; they are magnificent homes.

In terms of the overall scope of the project, the committee has concluded that it is soundly based, the extent can be justified on the grounds of reduced cost penalties associated with the payment by Defence of isolated establishment allowances, will enhance personnel efficiencies and makes good use of available land. A number of design features were commented upon during our inquiry and the committee therefore believes that the Defence Housing Authority should continue consultations with the tenants consultative group concerning the provision of features and fittings which will enhance the habitability of the houses.

It is planned that the housing area at HMAS Cerberus may be excised from the base sometime in the future. The committee has therefore recommended that before this goes ahead it will be necessary for the sewerage system serving the housing area to be connected to the Hastings system independently of the base.
I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the Housing Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 will amend the Housing Assistance Act 1989; and the First Home Owners Act 1983 and related legislation (The Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982, The Homes Savings Grant Act 1964, The Homes Savings Grant Act 1976).
First, I would like to explain the provisions of the bill in relation to the Housing Assistance Act 1989.
The Government is unequivocally committed to the principle that housing is a basic human right and that all governments have a responsibility to ensure the housing needs of all Australians are met.

As part of this commitment the Commonwealth provides untied financial assistance to the States under the Housing Assistance Act 1989 to deliver housing assistance, predominantly for building or purchase of public rental housing stock but also for home purchase, in accordance with the terms of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA). The current CSHA is at Schedule 1 of the existing act; the CSHA is up for renegotiation with the aim of having a new Agreement in place by 1 July 1996.

The CSHA requires States to match Commonwealth untied assistance on a dollar-for-dollar basis, with at least half of the matching provided through State grants and the balance through the value of loans made under home purchase assistance (HPA) schemes.

Difficulties with matching have arisen in recent years for States as a result of increased attractiveness of commercially available loans in the current economic climate and a poor public image for some State products, leading most States to reduce their home lending activities. The affected States have been unable to provide additional grant funding to meet their matching obligations.

Prior to amendments made to the act last year, the Commonwealth was required to recover financial assistance provided in earlier years from States that did not undertake sufficient lending under their home purchase assistance schemes. Similarly, where some States indicated that they were unlikely to be able to meet their matching requirements, the act, prior to amendment, required that the Minister not provide unmatched funds, reducing untied grants to the level that would be matched.

The Government considered that either to recover financial assistance already provided or to reduce funding to be provided was undesirable. It would reduce funds for public housing and disadvantage those most in need of assistance. It would also be undesirable to pursue such action where States are genuinely unable to meet such requirements because of changed market conditions.
It was for these reasons that the amendments to section 15 of the act which allowed the Minister to waive these provisions were made last year.

It was not expected at the time of the previous amendments that States would continue to have matching difficulties. The amendments outlined in this bill extend these waiving provisions for what is expected to be the final, and seventh, year of the current CSHA:

The amendment to subsection 15(2A) of the act extends its application to the seventh grant year (1995-96), in addition to the sixth grant year (1994-95) of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA).

Subsection 15(2A) of the act enables the Commonwealth Minister to authorise the full level of untied grants to a particular State, even if the Minister cannot ensure that the State can meet the balance of its matching obligation from the value of home loans provided through its home purchase assistance programs in accordance with paragraph 13(2)(b) of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.
The amendment to subsection 15A(2) of the act extends section 15A to the seventh grant year (1995-96), in addition to the fifth (1993-94) and sixth grant years (1994-95)of the CSHA.

Section 15A enables the Minister to make a determination to effectively waive or reduce a State or Territory's obligation to match the balance of untied assistance, provided by the Commonwealth to a State, from the value of home loans provided through home purchase assistance programs in a grant year where that State has not been able to meet the level required.

Any decision to waive or reduce the home purchase assistance matching requirement will be taken after careful consideration of the circumstances leading to the need for such a course of action and determined on a case-by-case basis.
The longer term issue of matching will be addressed in the process of renegotiating a new CSHA. The amendments will not result in any additional Commonwealth outlays.
I would now like to turn to the provisions of the bill relevant to the First Home Owners Act 1983 and related legislation.

In the Budget Speech of 21 August 1990 the Government announced its decision to terminate the First Home Owners Scheme as a part of its plan to restructure Commonwealth home ownership assistance arrangements. Legislation was introduced amending the First Home Owners Act 1983 so that it would not have effect in respect of homes acquired after that date. That legislation also fixed 30 June 1991 as the last date for applications for assistance under the act. However, applicants coming within those deadlines remained eligible for a stream of monthly assistance payments over five years from the date of acquiring their home.

Amendments in 1994 to the First Home Owners Regulations allowed final payments to remaining eligible clients to be aggregated and brought forward. The bulk of these payments were despatched in November 1994 and after 30 June 1995 there will be ongoing administrative activity only of a minor nature. Accordingly, this bill amends the reporting requirements of the act, to provide that no annual report on its administration and operation will be required after the 1994-95 report.

Presently, no time limit is prescribed in the act for appeals from decisions made under it. To assist in winding up the Scheme's administration this bill sets 31 August 1995 as the cut-off date for such appeals. For the few appealable decisions which may be made close to that date or thereafter, a period of 28 days from the date the decision is furnished to the applicant is proposed. Further, the bill curtails the power of the Secretary of the Department to reopen applications for reconsideration after that date. Notifications of decisions under the First Home Owners Act have always been required to include an explanation of the client's right to seek review, including by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Few decisions have been made since the two years after the cut-off date for applications. With few exceptions, applicants now have had a number of years to consider decisions affecting them and to lodge an appeal. It is now time to draw this Scheme to a close.

However, any decisions still to be made will be subject to the proposed 28 day limit to seek Departmental review; the existing right and time limit will continue to apply for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from decisions of the Department. Similarly, the legislation does not affect the review procedures available to individuals under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

I should also add that the Government will undertake appropriate action to notify clients of the time lines for the revised review procedures. This will involve advertisements in national newspapers over a two week period.

Earlier first home ownership assistance schemes are governed by the 1964 and 1976 Homes Savings Grant Acts and the Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982. These, too, contain no time limits for appeals from decisions made under them.

Accordingly, to assist in winding up their administration, the bill proposes arrangements similar to those proposed for the First Home Owners Act 1983. The bill also incorporates machinery amendments to the provisions of the earlier acts relating to making and notification of decisions under them.
Aside from modest costs associated with the campaign to publicise the cut-off date for appeals, the amendments to the first home owners assistance legislation have no identifiable financial impact.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, you will recall that at the time we were debating my amendment we were discussing the coverage of psychiatric rehabilitation and palliative care, particularly relating to outpatient services. I was making the point that the previous amendment had not covered that, and to cover that was the purpose of moving this amendment.

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is opposing this bill because it is yet another tax. It is a tax, ultimately, on the consumers of private health care. Ostensibly, it is a tax on health insurers to pay for this complaints procedure. But, like everything in life, somebody has to pay for it. Ultimately, it will be the contributors to insurance who will pay for this. It sets a precedent in so far as it is expecting consumers to pay for a committee that is established by the industry—but the consumers are the industry; so the tax is on them. For that reason we are opposing this legislation. We are not against the establishment of a complaints procedure or a complaints commissioner. Motion (by Senator Crowley) proposed:
That these bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Private Health Insurance Complaints Levy Bill 1994 does not address the major problems affecting the delivery of health care in this country. They should be well known to everybody. There is an inability of the public hospital system to cope with the demand. There is a rapidly ageing population. As an aside, this is important electorally to all political parties in so far as 40 per cent of electors are now over the age of 50. So it has relevance in that regard. Not only do we have a rapidly ageing population; we also have the increasing use of technology and the inevitable cost increase that occurs with the use of that technology.

PARA.TAB: The public hospital system in Australia is in a shambles. Waiting lists in my state have extended rapidly because of their inability to cope with the demands made upon them. This legislation introduces a number of features, one of which is casemix funding. Only time will tell whether that makes any difference in terms of an ability to constrain cost. It is almost like King Canute trying to stop the waves when this demand is being placed on the systems by an ageing population, increasing technology and the rapidly declining ability of the public hospital systems of Australia to cope.

One answer to it is to make private health insurance more attractive so that people will move into the private hospital system. We have in Australia a very well advanced and, in some respects, technologically superior private hospital system in so far as there are approximately 900 hospitals in Australia, two-thirds of which are public hospitals and one-third of which are private hospitals. But public hospitals also cope with some private demand and treat private patients.

Since this government has been in power, we have seen a rapid decrease in the number of people privately insured and accessing the private hospitals. There has been a decrease from 70 per cent to now less than 40 per cent; it was 36.3 per cent in December last year. In my state of Queensland, it is below 30 per cent. It is fatuous to say that this does not produce an enormous demand on the public hospital system. Why has this occurred? What is the reason for the decrease in the number of people who are privately insured?

The answer is fairly simple: they cannot afford the premiums, particularly young families. We have just been through the worst recession in 60 years—the so-called recession we had to have, produced by this government. More importantly, they have been ideologically driven to try to force people out of private health insurance. It is within that background that this legislation came forward.

This legislation has three principal components. Honourable senators will recall the speech given by the minister. She said that the bill was aimed at reducing premiums. It was aimed at making private hospitals cheaper, and it was aimed at lowering the return to private hospitals and the income of doctors. It was ideologically driven to a large degree.

After the introduction of this legislation, the private hospitals have contracted to insurance companies virtually throughout Australia. Some had already done so, and I suppose it could be claimed that this legislation accelerated that. The important point is that it occurred regardless of the legislation. Half the legislation will not be applicable in that regard in so far as it has been achieved. A bit like the budget a few days ago, it was smoke and mirrors. One of the large insurance companies actually increased its premiums. It changed the names and produced different tables. That was the government's own insurance company, Medibank Private. The premiums for the principal table that would give 100 per cent cover increased by $2.30 a week. It was a change of name but an increase in cost. This will inevitably lead to a decline in the number of people privately insured.

The bill does not address the major reasons why Australians are leaving health insurance. Even the Executive Director of the Australian Health Insurance Association said that all he believed it would achieve was a slowing in the increase of premiums, not that it would reduce premiums for health insurance. The secretary to the department acknowledged that he did not know the outcome of this legislation. That is a very valid point. Inevitably, as I mentioned, the prices for similar coverage have already increased. Even if private hospitals could become 10 per cent more efficient, it would potentially reduce premiums by less than $1 a week. They have already increased by that in the last week or so.

The second point is that this legislation will end community rating. The bill encourages funds to provide reduced coverage, reduced services or reduced choice. These are the only products that can possibly be made cheaper. If, as the minister says, this legislation will make less money available to private hospitals, there has to be a reduction in the quality of care provided or a reduction in the services provided.

The third point is that it delivers the private hospital industry into the hands of large private health insurers. The default payment will only mean that a hospital goes broke more slowly because it cannot exist on the default payment, which is the payment that will go to the hospital if a patient goes there and the medical practitioner and/or the hospital do not have a contract with the health insurer. If the insurer does not want to contract, the Trade Practices Commissioner can do nothing. We have had that in the letter from him. The spurious defence that there is a Trade Practices Commissioner at the end who can act as an arbiter between the two bodies does not stand up in the light of the submission from the Trade Practices Commission itself.

In any case, if an insurer acts unfairly or misuses market power, the Trade Practices Commission can certainly investigate but will find it difficult to prove. And, of course, while that is going on, the hospital has gone broke. So that defence is spurious.

The next point is that within that context of delivering the private hospital industry into the hands of large private health insurers, hospitals and doctors cannot negotiate in groups without authorisation. Authorisation takes months, it is very costly and there is no guarantee of success. The complaints commissioner—the body that we have just established by the passage of that last bill—can only recommend even if the Trade Practices Commission says that it is investigating.

The real bottom line of this legislation is that it puts hospitals and insurance companies under greater control of government—the ideological premise of which I know the government and, I suspect, the Democrats are totally supportive. They must be aware that this will occur because everything goes back to government control.

The bureaucrats love it—more bureaucracy! I notice a headline in the Canberra Times today that Mr Johns in the other chamber said that there will be less bureaucrats around. He has not seen this legislation. I think they will be compensated for by an increase in the department.

There are already 6,000 federal bureaucrats in the Commonwealth department of health pressing computer buttons—I do not know about paper. This will be another bureaucratic bonanza for them. No wonder the department is very much in favour of it.

The cost in premiums and the types of products offered have to be ratified by the department of health. It knows best, government knows best—not the marketplace, not the patients, not the doctors, not the hospitals. The department of health ratifies everything and, of course, the minister can decide what is acceptable treatment in a hospital.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you might think that fatuous and you might think that is rhetoric, but I have before me an article from the Philadelphia Enquirer of 21 March this year entitled `Shift to HMOs brings warnings on abuses', which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Critics allege that care is being delayed or denied. The Justice Department has formed a task force.

This legislation is leading us down that same path. God knows why we have to adopt American systems at the very time that they are going out in the States. We seem inevitably in Australia to believe that something done overseas has to be better.

PARA.TAB: The Australian health care system, while seriously ill, and some would say terminally ill, can be resuscitated, but it is not going to be resuscitated by this legislation. It does open itself up to an enormous number of changes—and I quote from this article again:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a growing chorus of criticism from legislators, patient advocates, consumer groups and doctors that health maintenance organisations—
you can read `preferred provider organisations' if you like because it is the same thing; the same girl, different hat—
. . . because HMOs are delaying or denying care to save money, for example.

PARA.TAB: The critics contend that the same practices that enabled health maintenance organisations to provide health care savings may also create financial incentives for providers to skimp on care so that they can maximise profits.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the direction in which we are heading.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth department receives identified, commercially sensitive data from private hospitals and private insurers, as does the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council. One amendment that we achieved on this side, with the support of the Australian Democrats, puts at least some constraints on that information. We look forward to further constraints being put in place as a result of other amendments that were carried. Privacy protection is of vital importance but it has not been sufficiently acknowledged in this legislation. We will continue to press for that when the legislation comes up for review before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee.

The bill is now largely unnecessary as contracts between hospitals and insurers are almost complete. It offers the opportunity for contracts with doctors and, provided these are voluntary and without duress, the opposition has no difficulty with them. But the bottom line is that if cost savings are to occur, as the minister believes they will, inevitably, there will be pressure on the doctors to change the types of treatment they order as a way of maximising profit. If anyone does not believe that, they only have to look at what has happened in relation to general practitioners and bulk-billing.The evidence shows that the number of radiology and pathology services ordered has raced away and that the number of patients seen in major bulk-billing clinics has also raced away.

We believe that this bill is just another fiddle by the government, pretending it is doing something about the health system when it is really doing nothing. This seems to occur every two years. I have been here for five years and there have been three health ministers in the last three years and three heads of department—the current one has only just been appointed—and here we go again. In 1989 we had the re-insurance changes. In 1990-92 we had the national health strategy. In 1993 we had the Richardson reforms. Mixed in with all of that was the attempted introduction of co-payment in an attempt to put some constraints on the system. There was a shift in the Left, factional fighting within the Labour Party and we got a new Prime Minister out of that. And here we are today with yet another fiddle.

The aim of this legislation is to let the private health insurance level fall so that more Australians have to rely on Medicare. Meanwhile, the states are screaming about extra demand and are trying to solve their lack of funding by measures such as casemix and cost shifting. We have not alluded to cost shifting in this legislation but one of the major problems with regard to health care is the cost shifting that goes on between states. There are other measures in the budget that attempt to penalise the states where they practice cost shifting, for example, by having pharmaceuticals dispensed outside the hospital system so that they become a charge on Medicare rather than on the state hospital system.

By the year 2000, if present trends continue, the Medicare levy will have to increase. It is now producing only about $3 billion of the $18 billion that is spent on health care by the Commonwealth government. With this budget we have just another Medicare tax, another burden on the taxpayer and—

TALK.START.PARA: —People like Medicare.

—People do like Medicare but they have no concept of what it is costing them. And, as the minister knows, there are complaints about Medicare, particularly with regard to waiting lists and the standard of care.

PARA.TAB: The other thing illustrated by this legislation is the fact that we have had 96 amendments in this chamber. Obviously that matter should have gone off, as I asked in my motion, to a legislation committee. We had a quick and dirty look through by a legislation committee, which reported back. Even after that—and the majority report was supported by the Democrats in that regard—we had 96 amendments introduced on the floor of the chamber, 54 of which were introduced jointly by the government and the Democrats. There should be no complaint from the Labor Party whip or the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) in this regard. Those amendments obviously should have gone off to a legislation committee, which was my original intention. That motion was not supported by the Democrats, so they cannot complain about the processes of this legislation either.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the answer?

—Senator Cook asked me, `What's the answer?' The answer, Senator Cook, is to make private insurance more equitable and more attractive to people because of this drop-off in private insurance. There is a need for an increase in private health insurance in this country, as I mentioned. Medicare has meant, of course, that the GPs are totally dependent on the government for their payments. What is happening to them? If anybody has ever been dudded, it is the general practitioners of this country.

PARA.TAB: The budget papers stated that there is going to be an increase of, I think, 1.7 per cent in the Medicare refunds—the GPs are going to get half of it and the rest is going by capitation, just as it did in the last budget. If that is not government control, nothing is. So the government is heading in that direction. We will end up with most of the population relying on public hospitals. Private hospitals will have to take public patients or they will go broke. We will get private hospitals becoming public hospitals. Specialists will spend most of their time treating patients by whatever method the government decides, and probably on sessional rates. It is a very grim picture that faces the country through the passage of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Senator.

—The minister asks me to speed it up. Minister, you do not like hearing the truth. You do not like hearing this because it is an opportunity for us to bring home to you the failure of this legislation and the fact that it will not produce the results. I look forward to the review in a year's time as to what will occur in relation to this legislation. It has no chance of achieving what you believe it will achieve. Half of it has been gutted by the fact that the private hospitals have taken out contracts.

PARA.TAB: The next point is that the minister talked about consultation. If there had been consultation, we would not have been through this process of amendment that we have had in this chamber over the last few days. The consultation did not occur. The argument that consultation had occurred was spurious. There was a long list of various people who had been notified. When we looked into that, of course, we saw that the list included bodies that had been involved in the ACTU caucus working paper, the Richardson discussions that had occurred and the various bodies that were announced. Then, out of the blue, this legislation was produced without anybody being aware. That was the evidence that we were given by everybody who appeared before the legislation committee—short as those hearings were.

It is a mishmash of legislation. The secretary to the department acknowledges that he does not know the outcome of it. The very night that we were discussing this legislation, the budget came down and the Medicare levy was increased. This inevitably puts further pressure on private health insurance because every time—and this is an historical fact—the Medicare levy goes up, the numbers of those privately insured drops. There is no way that that will not occur in the future as a result of those budget changes.

The other crazy part about it in relation to doctors is that if the funds could persuade doctors to work for no cost to the funds—that is, for only 75 per cent of the government schedule and forgoing the 25 per cent paid by the funds—premiums would be reduced by only 5.9 per cent. If the funds could persuade the doctors to take an across-the-board cut of 10 per cent in their medical fees, this would reduce premiums by approximately 2.3 per cent. The likely outcome is that in many specialties and in many regions—the minister acknowledged this—doctors will be able to win higher fees on average from the funds than they now charge. Again, it is a spurious argument that it is going to lower costs. The minister said in relation to an amendment that it will mean increased fees for many specialists, so how can you increase the fees and not produce increased cost?

As I mentioned, premiums will rise as a result of the legislation. According to the department's own figures, hospital gaps currently amount to about $200 million a year. Again, according to its figures, medical gaps amount to $136 million. The effect of offering no gaps tables will be to transfer these charges from the individual to insurance premiums for all those who take out no gaps packages.

The Australian Private Hospitals Association has always said there will be a high level of no gaps hospital contracting, so it would be reasonable to assume that in the first instance all hospital charges will remain roughly where they are now and the $200 million will be absorbed into increased premiums. That will be the effect of this legislation. It will mean increased premium costs. It will mean a drop-off in private health insurance.

Let us suppose, for example, that 25 per cent of specialists would be interested to the extent that they would be forced into signing contracts with health funds. Let us make an assumption that these doctors would contract at roughly the same level of fees that they presently charge and that they are a representative group in terms of gap medical charges. You would need to absorb another $34 million into the premium cost. So you cannot have it both ways. You cannot say on the one hand it will reduce the income of doctors and on the other hand they will be getting higher fees from this legislation. It does not make sense, just as many of the other measures in this legislation do not make sense.

If we take into account the government's own figures, the full impact of all those measures will be a cost of about $400 million and that will require an increase in premiums of at least 10 per cent. Of course, that would be a disaster for the industry. The only way in which increases could be avoided would be by reducing the range of services covered or by reducing quality. The minister will recall that I asked the then secretary to the department—three secretaries ago—how one defined quality, because the word `quality' did not appear in the department's report. Not once did the word `quality' appear. Magically, it appeared in the next annual report of the department, all over the place. `Quality' was dripping out of it next time.

Again, when I questioned the measurement of quality, it was the provision of technology. It showed complete ignorance of what occurs within private hospitals, and the rapport that doctors have with their patients and patients with doctors. You choose a doctor with whom you have rapport, or you do not. This will restrict choice of doctor because it inevitably restricts your choice to those who have contracts with private hospitals. It restricts your choice to those who have contracts with insurance companies. You cannot get around that. It restricts choice and that is another price that must be paid by this legislation.

It will increase cost shifting, as I have mentioned before. It will inevitably change the mechanism of referrals of patients to doctors. That has not been considered. It will do so because this complex process means that the condition needing treatment must be covered by a particular policy held; the preferred doctor must have arrangements with the patient's insurer; the insurer must have arrangements with a conveniently located hospital; the surgeon must have arrangements which include a convenient hospital; and an anaesthetist who visits that hospital must have an arrangement with the fund. And so it goes on and on. That is what this legislation is bringing in.

I have been asked what the opposition will do in relation to this legislation. Inevitably this legislation will pass because of the support of the Australian Democrats. We reserve our right to review and amend this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And repeal it?

—We reserve our right to review and amend this legislation. We look forward to the election so that we will be in government and we can fix the problems of this country. The minister and those people with her on the other side of the chamber are so ideologically driven that they have produced this shambles. The government has been in office for 12 years and what has it done? Where are we in relation to health care in this country? Things have never been worse in relation to the public hospitals in this country. The waiting lists have never been longer. That is the criterion on which the government will be judged. In some states patients are being shifted out into their homes. The inevitable outcome of this legislation will be the complete destruction of the health care of this country. People will be mendicants; they will be dependent on the government for their health care, and God help them when that occurs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Senate—indeed the parliament as a whole—is dealing with legislation, its primary concern must be for the sick person. I am concerned that that is not the priority in this legislation. It appears to me that the government is concerned—and probably correctly concerned—about the flight of people from the private health insurance funds. This legislation appears to be one response to that concern.

PARA.TAB: The sick, the frail aged, the chronically ill and private psychiatric patients should be distressed that matters of their welfare, health and well-being are not going to be determined by themselves, their families or their medical practitioners, but by economists in the insurance companies and by bureaucrats.

This matter has not really been addressed in this legislation. There are some unexceptional provisions in this legislation which I would support. I was hoping to be able to support the whole of the legislation, but this particular matter is of such concern to me that I would not be able to do so. This bill provides for contracts to be undertaken between insurance companies, doctors and hospitals—contracts that will be determined by the insurance industry and the bureaucrats. If we go along the case payments path the patients' well-being and health will be at risk. I say this with some feeling because I am aware of a number of people who are chronically ill and a number of people with severe psychiatric problems.

If you go along the path of a diagnostic approach, that is to say that insurers will fund the hospital for the diagnosis rather than for the care of the person and for an assessment of the extent of that person's illness, then these are matters that will be determined by health bureaucrats and insurers particularly. We will then be taking user-pays and economic rationalism to its extreme.

There are quite a number of other things that I would like to talk about but I will not do so at this juncture since this is the third reading and not the time to do this. I will give an example that has been given to me by a person whom I know quite well who is rather concerned about this situation. That person is rather concerned about the fact that there will be, as a result of this legislation, a situation where patients will be discharged before their time, when they will be discharged sooner and sicker. Of course that is not the way to deal with people; it is not a very economical way to deal with the situation in the long run in any event.

SPEECH.PARA: There could be distressed patients waiting for days for admission and treatment. There could be patients lying in unrelieved pain or discomfort. There could be patients in a wet bed for hours due to lack of nursing attention. There could be chronically ill patients who are denied admission and who are not entered into the collective data. Because of this economically-driven rationalism, there could be an inferior prothesis being used which is subject to a greater risk of breakdown. Patients could be sent home unable to care for themselves or sent to a stressed household, or left alone or entirely neglected.

Those matters that I have just mentioned appear to be matters which are ignored in the assessment of efficiency. I hope the government will correct me if I am wrong but, as I understand it, when the assessments for efficiency are taking place those matters will be ignored. That does give me a considerable amount of concern. I hope I am wrong. I hope that this legislation does not have that effect, but it appears to me at this point in time that they are the possibilities.

Another problem that I foresee is that there will be many different contractual arrangements made between insurers, hospitals and doctors. That is going to be confusing for ordinary parents—the mothers and the fathers—who make these decisions on behalf of their families. They are unlikely to have access to details of the agreements entered into between the hospitals and the health insurance funds. They certainly would find it most difficult to make those particular decisions.

PARA.TAB: There are so many burdens now being placed upon those families by the government. As I indicated in my response to the budget, these families are being adversely affected by the government's budget. In fact, this budget will have the effect of requiring more families to have both parents forced into the paid work force just to make ends meet. In those sorts of situations there does arise a great deal of stress. When decisions upon these matters need to be taken, where there will be such strength, I suppose, and such control given to economists in insurance companies and to health bureaucrats, then there will be a lack of faith in the insurance industry. As a result, this legislation will do the opposite to what the government intends. As a result of this legislation, in my view, there will be more people abandoning their private health insurance and simply going onto the public health system. The result of that will not be what the government wants. The result of that will be an extension of the waiting list for public hospitals. That is what concerns me. Again, I hope I am wrong and that that does not occur.

I will be very interested to see the results of the review of this legislation which will take place within a period of 12 months. I do not normally stand up in this place and say, `I told you so.' I sincerely hope, if I am around at that stage, that I do not have to get up in this chamber and say to the government, `I told you so.'

I urge the government to keep a very close monitor upon what is taking place between the private insurance industry and the hospitals. I ask the government to monitor this from the point of view of the immediate and the direct health and the long-term health and wellbeing of the patient and his or her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly in relation to this legislation simply to place on the public record the position of the Greens (WA). As mentioned by Senator Harradine, our primary point of reference—and I am sure the underlying motivation of all people who have contributed to the debate—is the wellbeing of community members on whom this legislation will impact. I share some of the concerns that Senator Harradine has raised.

PARA.TAB: The approach taken by the government in this legislation is not the preferred position of the Greens. However, by ascertaining, on balance, the legislation and the opposition's approach to it, we have decided that we are closer to the government's position than that of the opposition, as expressed in this place.

The Greens (WA) believe that access to a comprehensive health system is a fundamental right. We support the continued development of a publicly funded Medicare system to include dental health, mental health promotion, public health, family planning, occupational health and alternative forms of health care. Maximum diversity and choice in forms of health care is of major importance to us. In order to ensure an equitable society, the best quality health care must be equally available to all Australians. Individual health is connected to the health of all of us. Exceptional health care is both a human right and a common good.

The interrelationship of Medicare and the private health insurance industry is relevant to the Greens, primarily as this relationship affects the public health system. However, we do care that consumers of private health insurance also get the best possible health results. Reforms to the private health insurance industry are therefore necessary to empower consumers. This bill will provide individual fund members with a better capacity to complain and seek redress. The private health insurance industry needs to become more efficient and provide a better product. We believe that the accountability of the private health insurance industry will be, and should be, enhanced if this legislation is effective.

The medical purchaser-provider agreements may eliminate a privately insured patient's out-of-pocket expenses owed to a medical practitioner by providing for full payment by a health benefits organisation of the costs of an in-hospital professional service. The Greens are extremely concerned that casemix funding should be at an adequate level. We are concerned as to how patients will fare under the managed care contracts. We, too, will be monitoring the way in which this legislation is put into place.

We are even more concerned about the increasing trend to commercialise the delivery of health care. Health care cannot be made subject to the same market forces as are clothing and motor vehicles. If a two-tier system develops, the potential for discrimination against those who cannot afford the private system can result in public services being reduced, unresourced or stigmatised. The two-tiered system is anathema to Australian ideals of social justice, equality and egalitarianism. Exclusion of the poor and powerless from the highest standard of health care is an intolerable prospect. Poverty is both a cause and a consequence of ill-health.

We are concerned over the increasing trend to commercialise the delivery of health care. The dominance of economists, planners and accountants involved in social policy is leading to health care being made subject to the same market forces as fashion, restaurants and motor cars. Instead, Medicare must be strengthened and supported. Medicare offers the most positive answers to the best possible health care to all Australians. As a compassionate community, we must be ever vigilant to any erosion of human rights. In our view, Medicare must be supported and strengthened to ensure that all residents have reasonable access to basic medical and hospital treatment. It is important that the integrity of Medicare be preserved in any major reform of the system, and this includes its essential principles of universal access and a degree of public control over health service costs.

The view that has been put forward by the government is that one way of addressing the pressure on the public health system is to allow those who have the capacity for private health insurance to have an incentive—the gap payment—that will allow them to exercise both choice and that particular convenience.
