The medical profession has been trying to address some of the problems of the failure to account to the community for the fee system and fee structure of its own professionals. However, it has not been able to address it specifically from the point of view of the individual consumer. That is one advantage that this legislative system may put in place—that we can actually assess the burden that goes to individuals as a result of the different fees charged and schemes that are available.

Finally, I commend the hard work and thoroughness involved in this legislationand debate, particularly by Senator Meg Lees. I thank her for keeping me informed about the amendments of the Democrats and the government and about the submissions and criticisms that have been made. I also appreciate the information provided by the opposition and by the minister for health and her staff.

The Greens are fairly stretched in trying to cover all the portfolios. We do not believe in duplication of a job when it is being well done. We express our appreciation to our colleagues in the chamber for this debate and indicate that we will be supporting the legislation. We have kept our comments to a minimum to facilitate the passage of the bill.
Question put:
That these bills be now read a third time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.
Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill, which is now before the chamber, follows the report entitled Financial reporting by political parties which was produced by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in June 1994. This was a particularly noteworthy report by the joint standing committee in that, in the tradition of that committee, it was a bipartisan report on a very sensitive issue, the funding of parties and their disclosure rules.

PARA.TAB: The bill adopts most of the committee's recommendations to simplify and improve the operation of funding and disclosure rules. However, it has gone somewhat further than the committee report in several respects. To that extent the bill is of some concern to us. It has failed to do some things which we believe would improve the Electoral Act. However, we will move an amendment—I understand that it has bipartisan support—that will eliminate any possibility of retrospectivity in the operation of this bill. We support the bill, but with some reservations to which I will refer in my remarks.

The coalition now accepts that there is a need for some form of disclosure regime. There is no doubt that the 1992 amendments to the regime were unduly complex and placed basically an impossible burden on the political parties, which have simply not been able to meet them. It is my very strong belief and that of my party that healthy, strong, active political parties are essential to the proper and effective functioning of a democracy.

Political parties comprise thousands of ordinary Australians who volunteer their time, energy and effort to contribute to the political process and democracy. It is very important from our point of view that any legislation in this area governing the political process encourages the active participation of ordinary Australians in the political process. We regard that as essential.

It is our perspective that the 1992 amendments to the disclosure rules were a very big disincentive to grassroots involvement in Australian political parties. It is our very strong view that the law should provide incentives to grassroots involvement in the development of mass-based parties and thus reduce what we regard as the dangerous reliance of the parties on funds either from big business, unions or the government itself. It is my strong view that my party has been too reliant on big business and rich individuals. The ALP has certainly been far too reliant on the trade union movement for its funds. There was an example of this problem in South Australia—my state—recently with the controversy over the South Australian Liberal Party's acceptance of donations from rich foreign individuals.

I am also very wary about the parties becoming increasingly reliant on government handouts. It is a disturbing trend in Australian society today that increasingly more and more volunteer community groups are becoming reliant on government largesse for their very existence and thus becoming part of a dubious political process. I would be very concerned—

TALK.START.PARA: —Largesse for manufacturing plants in Strathalbyn, Senator.

—I will ignore that interjection from Senator Crowley. It is true that there is a problem in both political parties and other groups becoming reliant on government funds for their very existence. It is a trend that I do not want to see develop. To the extent that this legislation eases the burden on political parties to record and report minute details of their income and expenditure, certainly the bill is to be welcomed. It contains sensible, practical amendments to remove requirements that were often impossible for party volunteers to meet. This bill will, to some extent, assist the parties in retaining and recruiting volunteer workers into their ranks.

PARA.TAB: Specifically, this bill proposes that only where individual transactions exceed $500 will particulars of those transactions be required to be recorded. This is probably the most important change in the whole bill. It is the area that has caused the parties the most agony and problems. Our party recommended to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters that that threshold be $1,500, given that this figure is a prevailing threshold in other parts of the act. We retain the view that $1,500 is the desirable threshold. But certainly the $500 threshold in this bill is a big improvement.

However, we have a few problems with the bill. I will refer to them. The bill requires donors to political parties to lodge annual returns rather than election returns; that is, a return every year rather than simply a return after an election. It reduces the threshold for the requirement to lodge a return from $4,500 to $1,500.

This proposition contradicts a bipartisan recommendation of the joint standing committee that donors be not required to lodge a return. The ALP members agreed with us that this was an utterly redundant proposition. There should be no requirement on donors, given that the parties have to record and report all their donations. So we are concerned that this bill goes much further than the current legislation and totally contradicts what the joint standing committee recommended to the government.

It concerns us because it may operate to some extent to deter small and medium donors to political parties from making donations if they are required to lodge annual returns showing their donations. This contradicts what I was saying before. We should be encouraging small and medium donors to political parties and thus reducing reliance on the big donors. It is an unfortunate part of this bill which I hope we will look at when we are in government.

Probably the most controversial part of the bill is that which extends the disclosure requirements to `associated entities', which are trusts and other similar bodies, that contribute to the parties. Under this bill, they now have to disclose the sources of their capital. Previously, organisations such as trusts were only required, like other donors, to disclose that they donated to a political party. They were not required to disclose the sources of their funds. It was our view that that was a proper arrangement in a democracy.

This proposed extension was not recommended by the joint standing committee. We debated this issue at some length. The ALP members agreed with us that it would be improper to go down this track. We are surprised and disturbed that the government has embarked on this course. It is a disturbing extension of government regulation of the political process—the danger that I pointed to earlier. It is an example which we have seen in the United States; that is, once you start going down this disclosure path, there is no end to it. You keep having to legislate to cover your tracks. It becomes a vicious cycle. Unfortunately, this part of the bill is an example of that.

As I said in the joint standing committee hearings, requiring trusts to disclose the source of their capital if they donate to a political party is akin to requiring BHP or Fred's corner store to disclose the source of their income if they make a donation to a political party. I think this is a very dangerous path that this legislation is going down. We are not actually opposing this particular proposition in the bill in a formal sense, as long as the elimination of any retrospectivity is agreed to, which we understand is the case. This measure was not recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, and I think it takes this law into a very dangerous new area, an extension that has great difficulties.

Thirdly, in terms of our problem with this bill, it reintroduces a requirement that the parties lodge returns of electoral expenditure. We think this is unnecessary. It is a consequence of the change of public funding from a reimbursement scheme to a direct payments scheme. We welcome the abolition of the reimbursement scheme. We agree that the requirement to lodge claims for public funding is unnecessary and that a direct payments scheme is probably better. I am sure the Democrats would welcome this change as well, given a report in the Sydney Sun-Herald of 30 April which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Federal Police have recommended that at least 13 members of the Australian Democrats be charged with fraud and conspiracy to defraud over alleged misuse of $200,000 of election funding.

My understanding is that this relates to the Democrats' claims for public funding, where you are required to substantiate expenditure. I am not sure what will happen to those charges. No doubt, the Democrats will welcome the change to a direct payments system, which will mean that the parties will no longer be required to prepare claims for public funding. In principle, that is a proposition that we support.

PARA.TAB: We are not convinced that, as a consequence of the change to a direct payments system, the party should be required to lodge returns of electoral expenditure. After all, all electoral expenditure in an election year must be reported in the party's annual returns. The parties are required to lodge annual returns of their expenditure. That has been the ongoing arrangement for some time now. In an election year, all electoral expenditure will be covered in the return for that year. There is absolutely no point whatsoever in requiring the parties to lodge a separate electoral expenditure return. It serves no purpose whatsoever. There is also an idiotic anomaly introduced as a result of this: election returns have to be lodged within 15 weeks of polling day, while the annual returns, which the parties do every year, must be lodged within 16 weeks of the end of the financial year. It is stupid to have different time periods for these two returns. I hope at some stage that anomaly will be corrected.

The fourth problem that we have with the bill, although we will not be opposing it, is where the government has not addressed the adequacy at all of the current $100 tax deductibility limit for political donations. That tax deductibility provision was part of the 1992 package and was a very welcome part of that package. We have believed for a very long time that there should be an incentive in our tax system for ordinary Australians to contribute to the party of their choice and thus enhance the democratic process and the involvement of ordinary Australians in it. At that stage, a limit of $100 was set.

We have argued strongly, and did so at the joint standing committee hearings, that the tax deductibility limit should be increased to $1,500 consistent with the other thresholds in the act which are essentially on the $1,500 level and allowable for both individuals and corporate taxpayers so that small business has some incentive to involve itself in the political process and to support the party of its choice.

The $1,500 level is a general threshold in the act. The increase from $100 to $1,500 is certainly a more realistic threshold that would overcome the problem of the parties becoming far too reliant on trade unions in the case of the Australian Labor Party or big business or rich individuals in our case. So I hope the government in its remaining few months will look at this; we certainly will when we assume the reins of office within a year's time.

The fifth area that needs reference in this bill is foreign donations. Neither the joint standing committee report nor this bill makes any reference to foreign donations, but it is referred to in an interesting document which a number of us have had a look at. It is a parliamentary research service paper, No. 21 of 1994-95, entitled, `Election funding disclosure and Australian politics: debunking some myths', which is an interesting review of the operation of public funding and disclosure in Australia.

There is a reference to the issue of overseas donations in that document on pages 41 and 42. The report's author suggests that foreign donations are `an obvious future loophole and warrant continued scrutiny by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters'.

I am concerned about the possibility of Australian parties becoming reliant on foreign donations. That would be a dangerous trend for the parties and a retrograde step. With the ALP we saw the shemozzle over the Iraqi donation scandal. It has certainly been my party's longstanding view, at least since that time, that one should be extremely careful about foreign donations.

I believe very strongly in self-regulation by the parties rather than any legislative regime, which is what I think the author of this particular report is proposing. We should all resist that, but we will only resist that if we all operate with extreme care in the area of foreign donations. It is a responsibility of the parties to ensure they know exactly whom they are getting their money from and that it is all above board. In that way we will be able to prevent the further extension of the law into the internal operations of political parties.

This bill introduces some sensible reforms to the disclosure rules. It will enhance the capacity of the parties to encourage voluntary grassroots participation in their operations. But a number of areas remain where the rules could be further improved to preserve and enhance the vitality of our parties without compromising the integrity of the electoral system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to support the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill and to indicate that in committee the coalition will be moving an amendment.

PARA.TAB: The bill responds in part to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the conduct of the 1993 federal election. Some of the amendments recommended in this report are included in this bill and that is welcome. There are 86 amendments, most of which are minor non-controversial matters removing hyphens and gender specific language.

One of the most important provisions includes the increased protection for personal details of silent electors during the inspection of postal vote applications. This sort of change is most welcome in tightening up the act.

However, I would like to single out one specific proposal that is of great concern. That is where the AEC proposes to use improved security printing of ballot papers instead of the watermark system. We believe that the watermark is a considerable protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Tierney appears to be speaking to the wrong legislation. It may be that the matters to which he refers are something that he wants to include in his speech. However, I am advised that he is now addressing a bill different from the one currently before the chamber. The bill before us is the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill, which relates to funding and disclosure.
—I am addressing the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order, I would like to hear more of Senator Tierney's contribution because he may be able to bring the matters he is raising into line with the bill presently before us. It is a large and important bill and I would invite Senator Tierney to continue and to relate those matters to the bill before the chamber. They are matters of general electoral interest.
—I in no way want to stop Senator Tierney from raising those matters. I am just asking whether he was aware that he was addressing the wrong bill.
—I am thankful for that advice. I think I simply have the wrong title—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Yes, I think you do have the wrong title. I believe that the other bill is still in the House of Representatives. If you wish to continue with your remarks, I am quite prepared to allow that but you might like to leave them until the other bill actually comes before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your advice but I do want to deal with some of the more general issues arising out of the legislation before us. I want to address a number of general matters relating to the form of the electoral system. This legislation and the legislation in the other chamber do not deal sufficiently with the changes to the existing act that are actually needed.

PARA.TAB: We need to address the matter of electoral reform far more comprehensively than has been done so far. The changes in this bill and in the bill that will come to us are basically minor technical changes, tinkering at the edges. We need far more comprehensive reform to the whole electoral system.

Our electoral system is based on two fundamental principles—access to the roll and the integrity of the roll. In its approach to electoral matters, the government puts a very strong emphasis on access to the roll. It does that because it argues that in a compulsory voting system it must be as easy as possible for people to cast a vote. We do not dispute that principle but we run into trouble with what the government has done because that principle often cuts across another principle—the integrity of the roll. We have to ensure that only those people entitled to be on the roll and to cast a valid vote are on the roll.

In many cases, in the government's eagerness to allow easy access to voting, it has compromised the integrity of the roll and I will give some examples of the way that has happened over the last 12 years. There is no check on ID when people enrol in our electoral system. My daughter, who is well over 18, changed her residence and was eligible for enrolment in the very marginal seat of North Shore in New South Wales. I asked her if she was on the roll and she replied that she was not. I then went through the enrolment process with her. She picked up the forms and filled them out but at no point in the process was she required to prove in any way who she was.

There was a person who was greatly concerned about the last election in 1993—so concerned that that person carried out some tests on the integrity of the roll by actually enrolling in five different seats. This was not picked up in any way in the system because the way the Electoral Commission handles this matter is that, if you enrol with no proof of who you are, it sends a confirmation letter out to the address that you have listed as your place of residence. If the letter does not come back, the commission assumes that you live there and that you are validly enrolled and it leaves you on the roll.

All people have to do is set up this little system with a friend in that particular seat. This is what we believe—and we have evidence—happens on a fairly widespread basis. When the letter comes, the person who knows about what is happening just does not return it. What does the Electoral Office do? It just leaves them on the roll and that person can turn up in the incorrect electorate, the electorate they do not live in, and vote.

The next stage is where you turn up in the electoral booth to vote. What is the question they ask you? They say, `Have you voted today?' They do not ask you who you are. They do not ask for proof. They ask, `Have you voted today?' Most people say, `No.' One lady told me she went up to one of the polling clerks and said, `Yes, I've voted 20 times today.' The polling clerk was a little perplexed and taken aback but still handed her the ballot-paper—no questions.

Another way in which the system has been loosened which challenges the integrity of the roll is the move from having votes in subdivisions to allowing people to vote anywhere in the electorate. In theory, you could wander around to all the 50 booths in your electorate and vote in each of them. I would not have to say that I was John Tierney. I do not have to put any proof in, do I, at any point in time? I could say I was Paul Calvert, for example, and they would not require me to prove otherwise. So when the commission gets these 50 votes that I have put in under the name of Paul Calvert, it will then challenge him and he will say, `That is a nonsense.' I am trying to illustrate with those two stories how open to abuse the system is in this country.

The AEC has staff who go and check to see if people live in particular areas, and it does what are called roll cleanses. The government has made this process even more difficult for the commission in recent years by cutting back on staff. So, whereas these electoral offices used to have three people, they now have about 2.2 people and they can use the 0.2 in times of higher demand.

From the 1993 election, 6,000 cases of voter identification and address irregularities were admitted to the joint committee. How many people have been prosecuted? How significant are the 6,000 votes that are admitted? The election was lost by only 1,500 votes across about 13 seats, so the change in those votes could lead to a very different outcome in the federal election. The limp excuse given by the AEC about this violation of the roll's integrity was that there was insufficient proof and the cases were too expensive to solve. That is not good enough when a very small number of seats and a very small number of votes in each of those seats can actually change the outcome of the election.

Perhaps one of the best ways in which we can solve this problem quite easily is to improve voter identification both at the point of enrolment and at the point of voting. The present system is unbelievable in a society in which virtually anything that you do in terms of establishing your name in some sort of system or organisation requires proof of who you are. My 13-year-old daughter recently went to a bank to set up a small bank account. She had to come up with a hundred points of identification to prove who she was in order to open the account, yet the electoral system does not require that sort of proof. It does not require any proof at all.

What the coalition has advocated, particularly through the joint committee report which has looked at the whole electoral issue, is that we should trial voter ID cards. Another thing we should do is introduce subdivisional enrolment to minimise the multiple voting issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you call it an Australia card?

—No, I would not. I would call it a voting card and it would be issued just for that purpose. People have Medicare cards and licences; why not voter ID cards? There are plenty of ways in which you could provide proof, yet when we get to our electoral system we do not require any proof at all. I would like to see a government senator get up and justify that system. The government is leaving it wide open to abuse. Justice in a system must not only be done; it must be seen to be done. It is not going to be seen to be done if the system is left so wide open to fraud.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what happened in the last election with this particular problem. I have indicated that it is so easy with a small group of people organising things in a certain way to have the election result changed. How many votes does it take to change the outcome in a seat? In the seat of Bass it took 30 votes; in Page, 100 votes; in Macquarie, 167 votes; and so it goes on around Australia, with just a few hundred votes changing the outcome in each seat and then changing the government.

The other area that needs strengthening in the Electoral Act, and in our system as a whole, relates to the processes that lead up to the election. Particularly, in the case of the 1993 election, the government developed a series of ads that were totally and blatantly untrue. If this were done by some other organisation or company, many of them would find themselves in court or certainly on the program The Investigators because what they were doing was so incorrect.

We had cases where people were actually sent bogus electricity bills which showed the supposed effect of the 15 per cent GST, by adding that amount to the bill. Obviously, on any simple understanding of that proposal there would be a whole lot of cost drops and the bill would not go up by that amount. That was just one example out of thousands of examples of misleading advertising around the whole country.

There are major problems with our electoral system. It was most disappointing, having carried out a review over 18 months, having heard from witnesses right around Australia and from the Electoral Commission, that there was very little, apart from tinkering at the edges, that the government was prepared to change in relation to the Electoral Act.

Major reform is needed but every time a reform was proposed—about 40 major reforms were proposed—the Australian Electoral Commission took the attitude that they were all too difficult and hard. As a matter of fact, they produced a document for the committee in which they put down 40 different changes that could be made to the Electoral Act to strengthen and improve it. Under each one, they listed all the reasons why it could not be done; why it was not desirable. In other words, they wanted to keep the act exactly as it was. The outcome of that is an act that is totally open to abuse and one which can change who is governing the country.

That is not acceptable. We ask the government to again consider the contents of the minority report in relation to the reform of elections in Australia. Seriously, I do not expect the government to look at these matters and act on them. The system as it exists at the moment suits this government right down to the ground. The system can be rorted on the margins. It can be used to help the government win federal elections. It is regrettable that we will have to wait until we are in government next year to introduce a proper electoral amendment act containing reforms which will not only improve the system but also improve the integrity of the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments on the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995. I welcome the recognition that this bill gives to the Senate. The bill provides an equal degree of funding for each Senate vote. This situation already applies to the House of Representatives vote. I always thought that that was an anomaly and was something which did not give the appropriate regard to the Senate. I am pleased to see that that has now been rectified and I welcome that amendment to the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The second aspect that I wish to address is the more realistic approach to accountability in relation to fund raising by political parties. Prior to coming into this place I was state president of the Liberal Party in my home state of Tasmania. I recall going to seminars arranged by the Australian Electoral Commission which explained how the new disclosure rules would apply and the very strict rules that would be enforced.

It was simply beyond the realms of what the normal volunteer would seek to do in relation to, say, having a barbecue that might raise $500. In that event, the organiser would need full accountability of how much was spent at the butcher shop, how much was spent at the bakery for the bread and how much was spent at the local bottle shop for the alcohol. You then had to tick off the names of everybody who paid money and indicate how you came to the end result. You then had to have all that up at party headquarters ready for an audit.

A lot of volunteers simply found that to be frightening as well as a lot of hard work. It was of no real benefit because at the end of the day those sorts of party functions would raise only a couple of thousand dollars at the most. I could never see the reason or rationale for that.

Undoubtedly, the reason for public disclosure is to try to overcome the corruption within the political process by money being handed over for certain policy changes or for certain political actions. Quite frankly, I would have thought that anybody who was in the game of bribing politicians or who was wanting to effect certain outcomes with money would not be spending that money at a branch barbecue and trying to influence policy or direction in that area. Indeed, it has been my view that those who engage in that sort of grubby activity within politics would not be channelling their money through the political party process but would undoubtedly be channelling it through brown paper bags, or in other ways, to individuals and not to the actual party administration where it would be receipted into the accounts and could be traced in the future.

I still remember asking questions at this forum put on by the Australian Electoral Commission as to the impact of those new disclosure rules. I also recall our former state director, who was a former manager of BP within my own home state of Tasmania, having to put in the return. He had some expertise in bookkeeping and accounting and in being able to prepare financial reports. It really was a major trauma for the Liberal Party within my state—for the state director and for myself—to abide by the disclosure laws that had been previously set out.

The relaxation that now is to apply is to be welcomed. I think it is more realistic. What occurred previously I think was trying to crack a nut with a sledgehammer. Undoubtedly the Australian Labor Party found the same difficulties when its rank and file were trying to raise a bit of money through the odd raffle, barbecue or dinner. The amendments that have now been made I think are more realistic, more appropriate, and will allow those genuine volunteers—the thousands of them within all the parties around Australia—to get on with the activity again of trying to raise money for their political parties and for the causes in which they believe so passionately. In the past the requirements of the Commonwealth Electoral Act really were a great disincentive for people from all parties and of all political persuasions.

Another matter that I wish to address relates to seeking to determine where the actual capital sums came from that are in trust funds. I understand that there will be an amendment during the committee stage to ensure that there is no retrospectivity in relation to that. If that is the case, I welcome it. I look forward to the committee stage to see whether that eventuates. I trust that it will, because it is only fair that those people who donated money to a trust fund, possibly people who are now deceased, should not have their names brought up in public 30 or 50 years after they may have made a contribution on the basis that the law would not require their names to be disclosed. If these amendments now come through, then those people who give in the future will of course be on notice that their names may be disclosed.

I will briefly turn to one criticism of the legislation regarding the requirement for donors to lodge their returns each year when they donate over $1,500. I would have thought, given the reporting conditions required anyway under this legislation to put an onus on a donor to also report but on an annual basis, that that is somewhat onerous and that it will once again militate against people who wish to make small and modest donations to the political party of their choice. I would have thought in general terms that would affect mainly the Liberal Party, the National Party and, I would also assume, the Greens and the Australian Democrats because we are the parties who usually get funding from smaller-type donations.

I note, just by way of example, that in 1993 the trade union movement gave the Labor Party $2.1 million. In addition, individual unions acting as third parties spent significant additional amounts on election-related advertising. I quote from research paper No. 21 of 1994-95 headed Election funding disclosure and Australian politics: debunking some myths.

It is interesting, unlike previously—and this still occurs—that the trade union movement will not have such onerous responsibilities in relation to disclosure. It can simply make a donation and that then will be where the inquiry will stop. Nobody looks behind to see how many trade union members actually signed up or how the trade union got the money to be able to give it to the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government grants.
—My colleague and friend Senator Kemp quietly interjected to me to ascertain whether the money may have come from a government grant or some government assistance and the money laundered in that way.
—Or cheap Dasfleet vehicles.

—Or, as Senator Campbell says, with cheap Dasfleet vehicles. It is interesting that the rules that apply to small business persons or individual electors who happen to believe, say, in the cause of the Democrats or in the cause of the Liberal Party and want to give $2,000 of their hard-earned money will have to put in this disclosure and have this onus on them. They will then need to be reminded by the party to whom they give the money that they have to do this.

PARA.TAB: In the event that they do not, there may be some difficulties with the Australian Electoral Commission. The chances are that in the future they will say that it is all too hard, it is all too difficult, why bother or they will reduce the donation size to below $1,500 per annum. So that aspect is still designed to scare off the small contributors to the political parties. At the end of the day, the survival of the political parties is on the basis of the support they get from within the community and from individual electors and small businesses and enterprises who believe in a particular cause.

I am disappointed that the government has not addressed this matter in a more appropriate way to ensure some degree of equity. In relation to these donations, if the Liberal Party were to have a front of some organisation—let us say the Kemp foundation—where we could all donate money to and then the Kemp foundation gave the money to the Liberal Party, the Australian Electoral Commission would look behind the Kemp foundation to ascertain who had been funding the Kemp foundation. But no such rule applies when a trade union gives money to the Australian Labor Party. There is an inequity in relation to that within the legislation and it indicates once again this government's unacceptable favouritism towards the trade union movement.

When we are dealing with the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and legislation and amendments pursuant to that act, we ought to have principles applied equally across-the-board so that we play on a level playing field and do not continually amend the legislation to seek to hurt the cause of one side or the other for political advantage. I believe the previous amendments in relation to disclosure were clearly designed to hurt the Liberal Party and the National Party. I think it came back to haunt the Australian Labor Party as well. It found exactly the same difficulties and hence the agreement now to make the appropriate alterations, which I have previously indicated that I welcome.

I intend to make further remarks during the committee stage of the bill. In general terms, I welcome the bill and trust that it will ensure that those hundreds of thousands of volunteers around the country who work for all political parties within this country will have a somewhat easier task in administering their political parties and the functions they run to assist, ultimately, the democratic process within this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most Australians would have much sympathy with the contribution made by my colleague Senator Abetz and the thoughtful remarks that he made on a number of contentious issues.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995 gives effect to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters by proposing numerous amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. As my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) observed in the House, the June 1994 interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was very important because it was the first time since 1984—when the present government first introduced electoral funding into federal legislation—that the process had been reviewed in some detail by an appropriate committee of the parliament.

Among other things, the interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, entitled Financial reporting by political parties, recommended that section 294 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that the same amount of public funding is payable for a Senate vote as for a House of Representatives vote. The committee also recommended that the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended as necessary so that $500 is set as the threshold for disclosure of individual amounts received and paid by or on behalf of political parties. These recommendations have been given effect in the bill before us.

Despite our opposition to the retrospective element it contains, the coalition supports the basic thrust of the bill for a number of reasons. As my colleagues observed earlier in this debate, it will make reporting much simpler for political parties. Intricate details of financial transactions and annual returns will not have to be reported by registered political parties. For example, under the old rules, the annual return of a political party was required to include a list of bank interest received by every individual branch or committee, even if the amount earned by a branch or committee was just a few cents. Fundraising events such as small raffles or afternoon tea parties needed to be reported on in detail with both proceeds and expenses listed. Anything less than such a detailed reporting could render party members liable to quite draconian action under the law.

There are hundreds, perhaps even thousands, of branches and committees in political parties across Australia. Expecting ordinary Australian men and women from essentially a voluntary organisational structure to face such onerous political and legal risk is quite unreasonable and at last the government seems to recognise that.

Details of those who donate individual amounts of less than $500 now do not have to be disclosed. There are corresponding requirements in relation to payments. Donors of gifts of $500 or more, totalling $1,500 or more in any financial year, will have to be disclosed in the annual return of a political party. Donors of gifts to a political party which total $1,500 or more during a financial year must themselves lodge an annual return. The effect of this amendment is to require dual reporting of donations by having donors' returns cover the same time frames as party returns. We are at a loss to understand the public benefit of such duplication. These donors will have had details of their donations disclosed by the relevant political party and then find themselves obliged to undertake the purely administrative task of lodging a return themselves.

As I mentioned, the rate of election funding reimbursement will be amended so that a Senate vote will be funded at the same rate as a House of Representatives vote. This rate will be increased to $1.50 per formal first preference vote, indexed each six months to rise in the CPI. Based on the payments made to the 1993 election, the charges will provide an extra $14 million of public funding for registered political parties and entitled candidates.

It is acknowledged by all parties that the disclosure provisions under this act have significantly affected the willingness of individuals and organisations in the community to contribute to political parties. I thought my colleague Senator Abetz expressed it rather well when he said that the original efforts by the government to amend the act were designed to affect the Liberal Party and its traditional sources of funding. It turned out that it also affected the Labor Party. There are concerns with the disclosure provisions, which is one of the reasons why it has become increasingly difficult to raise voluntary contributions to party funds.
At the same time we have to be a bit frank about this. There is concern amongst donors about possible retribution by the ALP.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rot!

—Senator Sherry, this example will enlighten you, as you seem to be a little worried about my remarks. We remember the attacks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on some of the organisations which supported the coalition in the last election, and we well remember the sorts of threats that he made. It is just another example of the low level to which Mr Keating has brought public life in this country.

PARA.TAB: There is also concern about the issues of privacy. Many people would be happy to contribute to political parties but, for perfectly proper reasons, are unwilling to see their names bandied around in public documents. Other factors which have affected the funding for political parties include the recession that Mr Keating said we had to have. Cash flows of companies are still being rebuilt in many cases and contributions to political parties are, quite frankly, not the first priority. Finally, increasing foreign ownership in this country has made some companies less likely to contribute to domestic political parties.

Whether we like it or not, significant funds of money are required to fund the operation of political parties to maintain balance and competition in a democracy. Both the ALP and the Liberal Party, and indeed the National Party, receive money from corporations. The Labor Party is also the beneficiary of funds from the trade union movement. In the old days, the Labor Party was happy to describe itself as the political arm of the trade union movement. I think that is in effect still the case, although that description seems to have been dropped from some publications.

As the political arm of the trade union movement, the Labor Party receives many millions of dollars which are compulsorily extracted from union members, regardless of how they vote, and donated directly to the ALP. There is a bit of irony here because two members of my own immediate family are members of trade unions, and it would not surprise me if a portion of the contributions they make to those unions end up in Labor Party coffers. You would have to say that that is quite wrong in principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about shareholders of companies?

—Senator Sherry, they have to join the trade union—they will not get work unless they do. I am glad you made that contribution. I also welcome Senator Sherry's earlier response to the remark made by Senator Abetz, who asked whether it is possible that any funds the trade union movement has received from government may, through various processes, have ended up back in the coffers of the Labor Party. The fact is that $50 million to $60 million has been contributed in direct grants to the trade union movement by the Hawke and Keating governments. Whether that has freed up funds for other purposes, one cannot tell.
—But you make the assertion anyway.

—No, I raise it as a problem. If you receive significant contributions from an organisation and that organisation is in receipt of very substantial contributions from the government, it is a fair and appropriate question.
—He is very touchy.

—Senator Sherry is a bit touchy about these matters. Payments of election funding entitlements will be able to be made to the national secretariat of a registered political party with the agreement of the state body. The amendments will also enable a party agent to request that an amendment be made to a claim or return. Under the legislation as it currently stands, only the person who finished the claim or return can have that claim or return amended. The amendments also specify that organisations such as trust funds which are closely related to political parties will be required to furnish annual reports to the Australian Electoral Commission. They will also be required to detail the source of capital contributed even before the date of effect of this amendment where income derived has been used wholly or mainly for the benefit of a political party.

PARA.TAB: The coalition, as my colleagues have mentioned, believes the retrospective element in the provision relating to annual returns of associated entities, as they are called, will require details of the source of capital, even though that capital was contributed when there was no question of disclosure. Contributions of capital made years ago, when disclosure was not an issue, were made under completely different rules. It is grossly unfair to require details of these donors, some of whom may well be deceased, to be made public under a new and unnecessary law. The amendment we propose will address this issue. It removes the need for disclosure of capital contributed prior to the date of effect of this bill.

On 9 March 1995, the government moved a number of amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Bill, including some relating to the payment of political parties after an election. It would have been of assistance if proper notice had been given of this bill, to allow for more considered consideration. It was brought rapidly into the House of Representatives; and we are now dealing with it in the Senate.

In effect, the AEC will pay at least 95 per cent of the entitlement, calculated on the basis of votes counted as at the 20th day after polling day in the election—as soon as possible after the full amount of the entitlement is known. This amendment will prevent the present situation in which the payment of public funding arrives long after an election, because of the highly detailed claims which are required. While waiting for election funding to come through, parties often have to pay election expenses and rely on bank overdrafts, incurring the costs that involves.

Although, as a result of this bill, there is some lessening of the burden of detailed disclosure required of registered political parties, it should be noted that the bill does not reduce other impacts of the existing disclosure law; and the basic thrust of the original legislation remains. Registered political parties are still required to disclose their total income, expenditure and debts as at 30 June each year and must disclose particulars of donors and other persons from whom payments are received or to whom payments are made if the payments total $1,500 or more in a year.

That concludes my remarks on the second reading of this bill. As I mentioned, in the committee stage I will move an amendment. As my colleagues said earlier, we welcome a number of the amendments to this bill. With the exception of the retrospective element, which we seek to deal with in my amendment, we will be supporting the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will keep my remarks very brief, partly because of the backlog of legislation before this place and also because some of the points I wished to raise, particularly relating to the difficulties faced by individuals who do volunteer work for political parties, have already been dealt with by several of the previous speakers.

PARA.TAB: I wish to add to what Senator Kemp has said. The problems for the Australian Democrats are considerable because we are a totally voluntary party, with very few exceptions. Some of the very onerous requirements that have been placed on our branch officers, branch treasurers in particular, and transferred through to state level to members of the executive, have led to there being a lack of volunteers for some of the very critical work of raising money in the first place and then accounting for it in great detail.

That will still have to be done in that we will still have annual returns to furnish. But the minuscule detail of accounting for who is buying raffle tickets, who is buying goods at an auction sale or who has been attending functions, to the point of tracking through a dollar here and $3 there, has been very onerous. It has been difficult to add up all those amounts. So the Democrats will be supporting the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995. We have a strong and enduring policy commitment towards transparency in electoral funding. We demonstrated that commitment in our original support, amid some controversy, for financial disclosure and reporting by political parties.

As I have said, since these provisions have been in place we have certainly seen some real problems with the implementation of them. I believe that this bill represents a balance between the principles of transparency—in other words, we should know exactly where the money is coming from—and the very practical and real on-the-ground need to have a manageable system that is able to be implemented by all political parties.

We are also committed to the public funding of election campaigns. We do not shy away from that longstanding policy. We are pleased to see that this bill restores some equity between the funding of Senate and House of Representatives campaigns. We have been at a loss from the beginning to know why there was a difference in the first place. At last that is being remedied, and we welcome it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was surprised by the brevity of Senator Lees's comments and the very brief interruption from Senator Campbell. I have been surprised to note that, while there is no doubt that the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995 significantly changes disclosure and increases the transparency of funding and donations to political parties, the major component of it—which will certainly have a major impact on the public and, presumably, on the public purse—is that all the parties represented in this chamber will experience a tremendous financial windfall from this legislation. It occurs to me that this should have been given far wider community scrutiny. There should have been an opportunity for the community to comment.

PARA.TAB: The Greens have made some statements which have received some media coverage and some response. But, to a large extent, the community at large is unaware of the changes that will be brought about by this bill. We have not been able to gain the kind of widespread debate which we believe such a change in policy deserves.

Let us look first at the bill. The bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 9 November 1994. It was brought on for debate in the other place on 9 March 1995. On the morning of the debate being brought on in the House of Representatives—something like 35 minutes before the second reading speech of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker)—the government circulated amendments which do several things. It changed the name of the bill from the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995.

More importantly, it changed the way that payments were to be made to registered political parties. These changes increased the costs of the public funding of elections, which are imposed on the Australian taxpayer, by over $15 million per year to nearly $30 million each election. These figures are based on the votes in the last federal election. It was really interesting that, following these fairly dramatic changes in policy, three weeks later the government put on the bill—I believe that there was some concord in the Senate—a motion to allow us to debate and pass it. Fortunately, because of the other matters on the program and our failure to reach that point, we have had some additional time to provide more public scrutiny and to have an opportunity for debate.

The matter has been taken back to the Greens (WA). But because it has been a fairly small time since those amendments were raised in March and the groups work at a local group level, it has been fairly difficult to reach a consensus. However, there are some matters on which we are very concerned. We want to put on the record our disagreement with the way in which this matter has been handled.

It would be very misleading for any members of this chamber to believe that all the measures in the bill were recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I am a member of that committee. Several of my colleagues who have already spoken are also members of that committee.

Certain matters were put to the government in a report from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. They were responded to by the government following our report Financial Reporting by Political Parties. Most recommendations of that report were agreed to by the government. One recommendation of relevance was that the same amount of public funding be payable for a Senate vote as for a House of Representatives vote. In the past the funding payable for each vote was unequal, being 50c per Senate vote and $1 for a House of Representatives vote.

The committee felt there was no need for this discrepancy. The Greens supported this change because Senate campaigns, which often have to reach across a large area of the country, involve an equal or greater difficulty in reaching the community as a House of Representatives campaign. An equivalent vote rebate between the House of Representatives and the Senate is not a problem. That was a recommendation of the committee. However, no particular amount was set. Whether it was to be equalised to 50c per vote or $1 per vote was not an issue. We believe there is no reason in principle why the Senate vote should be half the amount of the House of Representatives. Thus, the Greens (WA) supported that particular recommendation.

Seeing minor parties stand a greater chance of success in the Senate and are thus more likely to stand Senate candidates, there is good reason to support it in the interests of both diversity and democracy. We did not at the time realise that two other changes would occur. First, in order to make the House of Representatives feel that it was not being ignored as a result of the Senate having its vote rebate doubled, the amount was increased to $1.50 for both chambers. That not only addressed the recommendation of equality in the report but also increased the amount.

I think this matter should be questioned. It needs a bit of research. There should be research into the amount that major parties spend on general elections. It seems reasonable to support an increase in the dollar per vote in accordance with the principles of relating it to CPI increases and expenditure keeping up with inflation. Our understanding is that this increase takes that into account as well. We should be checking whether the increase in the amount can be justified in terms of its impact on the public purse.

The main concern I am expressing here is that although the normal process for changing the way in which public funding and the funding disclosure provisions is for recommendations to come via the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, this was not the case with the changes in this bill. The amendments to the bill referring to public funding which the government moved in March were not recommended by the joint committee. My understanding is that they were part of a private deal which appeared to be engineered by the Federal Secretary of the ALP and agreed to in letters to the Minister for Administrative Services from the Liberals, the Nationals and the Democrats. That is what I was informed, but they may wish to verify this.

I know that was the mechanism of the arrangement because I was asked to sign that letter and was informed that all the other parties had signed it. I refused when approached to do so. I believe there is a concern that needs to be addressed; that is, the public is not aware that all the political parties—and the Greens are no exception—will become enormous beneficiaries of this legislation. I am searching through my notes to find a very interesting table which indicates the kind of windfall that we should all be expressing extreme gratitude for if we base our public funding expectations on the votes that we gained in our last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get a commission on all the preferences that were given?
—No. I would not like to see any of this matter that is under debate related to preference distributions either. I would be very loathe to see anything like that occur.

PARA.TAB: We have to look at the principle of public funding to encourage democracy and to encourage political parties not to be subject to pressure from big financial donations. However, this bill actually increases public funding and increases the accountability and transparency of funding disclosures. It certainly brings about changes that are very different from the past policy.

Under the Electoral Act the rule has been that political parties would gain a rebate for all their campaign expenses, or on the number of votes they received according to the 50c and $1 per vote public funding calculation, whichever is less. The dramatic change at this point in the legislation is that the political parties will get it up front anyway regardless of their campaign expenditure.

I will read the amounts that we would hope to get if we maintain our present level of support. In the federal election on 13 March, the ALP would have been able to receive $7,098,642 on the basis of their vote; the Liberal-National Party coalition $6,971,722; the Australian Democrats $459,815; the Greens (WA) $65,886; and Independents $63,855.

Everybody is going to have at least a doubling of their funding. I will now start from the smaller amounts and use round figures. The Independents' vote, which would have led to the $63,000, can expect to be doubled with this bill to $123,000. The Greens (WA), instead of their $65,000, can expect $164,000. The Australian Democrats, as opposed to their $460,000 or more, can expect $1,446,000; and the Liberal-National Party coalition can expect to get nearly $14 million rather than $7 million as can the ALP.

It is extraordinary that we can just push through this chamber legislation which allows an extra cost of $15 million minimum to the taxpayer without explaining that we are now funding political parties on the basis of their popularity rather than on the basis of the expenditure incurred during campaigns by those political parties. This is a matter of concern—it has been raised with me that the Greens in other parts of Australia, not just the Greens (WA), are concerned about this.

The Greens (WA) did consider asking me to put up an amendment that if it is going to put an emphasis on public funding, then we should be fair to everybody and drop the threshold from four per cent to two per cent of the vote for parties that would receive this kind of public funding support because that would be in the democratic interests of the community. Of course, that would add to the expenditure we would be asking from the community at large and from the public purse—something that has to be taken into consideration very seriously.

The New South Wales Greens communicated with me expressing their grave concern that this kind of increase in funding which is being pushed through the Senate could actually communicate to the public an extreme cynicism. For example, the land fund took many hours of debate and in the end provided only $24 million a year extra funding for land acquisition and management to redress the injustice of 200 years of white settlement in Australia. Yet we can push through an increase of over $15 million for each election with the minimum of fuss.

I also am making a minimum of fuss. I realise that the Greens' vote will not change this situation, that we will be the happy beneficiaries of something we will be voting against, but there is a principle involved—that where a change in policy directly affects the public purse it should have the kind of exposure that will allow the public to decide whether it is a good or a bad thing.

By making this token protest, the Greens are saying that our proposal to return funding to its original base of campaign expenses rather than the popularity of a political party raises the issue and gives the chamber the opportunity to discuss it. We are also expressing the views of those people within and outside the Greens who feel that it should not be so easy for political parties to get together and give themselves the kind of windfall that we see in the legislation today.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I wish to make some comments in relation to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995. The changes that have been proposed are the result of debate surrounding the financial disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act and the hearings that were held last year by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

PARA.TAB: The problems experienced by the parties and their grassroots members because of the existing disclosure provisions needed to be addressed. Clearly, if the concept of disclosure is to be a major part of our electoral legislation, we must make sure that disclosure is workable and reasonable. The public needs to know about the substantial donations, not the day-to-day expenses of the parties or a particular branch of a party.

The pressure to comply should be directed far more at the state and federal party administrators rather than the sub-branch treasurer. Volunteer party workers do not deserve to be placed under the degree of stress that they have been. The simplification of the process was supported by the committee and I am glad that it will be incorporated into the law.

Public funding is also dealt with in this bill and is an important element of it. The fact that we are encouraging democracy to be less reliant on donations from outside sources should be seen as strengthening our democracy rather than draining the public purse. Connecting funding to the results of a party and ensuring payment is swift are fair principles for us to support.

The actual amount of funding represents a need to recognise the increasing costs of electoral activity and, of importance to the Senate, the fact that a Senate vote is of the same value as a House of Representatives vote. I see this as an important recognition of the fact that costs incurred by minor parties are also significant. Like the ALP, minor parties cannot hope for massive donations from corporations. Indeed, $100,000 donations from overseas do not come along too often.
The simplification of the disclosure provisions do not weaken the thrust of the original commitment to disclosure. In fact, the changes to get rid of loopholes will make the legislation much tougher.

Money kept in trust funds, such as the Liberal Party's Free Enterprise Foundation and the National Party's John McEwen House Pty Ltd, must now be disclosed. Just as tax evasion undermines the fairness of our society, disclosure evasion undermines our democracy. This government is committed to a system where any donation that has any connection with a political party or an electoral outcome must be there for the public to see.

In South Australia we see a Liberal government giving projects to companies which have made donations. We also see overseas donations from donors of no fixed address. At least with financial disclosure we can see these connections and bring them to the attention of the public. Who knows what other secrets will be discovered when this legislation comes into effect. It is time for the spirit of disclosure provisions to be restored. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to government business.
Debate resumed from 1 February, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the government goes on towards the end of this program about the coalition not being responsive and responsible in respect of the legislative program, I will remind the government that we made an agreement to discuss non-controversial bills during lunchtime, although we do not necessarily have to do that. Today during lunchtime we are discussing a non-controversial bill, the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, and it is a sign of the coalition's goodwill that we do so.

PARA.TAB: I will remind the government that its legislative program is in a mess, firstly, because it is not able to control the amount of legislation that it puts through this place; and, secondly, because the legislation that comes in is so often in a form which requires amendment afterwards. When Senator Ray was running government business we did not seem to have such a mess. My cry would be, `Bring back Senator Ray to organise government business,' because the state of the program for this session is in an appalling mess. When you look at the number of bills that are supposed to go through here between now and when we rise, it is a joke.

It is also a joke that this bill has taken so long to come before the house. I prepared this speech so long ago that I actually thought I had given it, and I had to go back through the records to check. I think I have come into the chamber a couple of times armed with this speech, ready to give it. I have looked at it so many times in getting ready for it that I was convinced I had given the speech. That might say something about what is happening to my brain while I am in this place; it might also say a lot about the government's management of business and legislation in this house.

Today—with the goodwill of the coalition and the Democrats, who will be speaking later—we are debating the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. This bill amends the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 and the consequential amendments to the Social Security Act 1991. It implements legislative requirements of the reforms the Child Support Agency announced in April 1994 by the Assistant Treasurer, so it is implementing an announcement made in April 1994. That shows how swift of foot this government is!

The amendments contained in this bill will expand presumptions of parentage and require social security clients wishing to enter into private maintenance agreements to have those agreements assessed for adequacy under the reasonable action for maintenance provisions of the Social Security Act 1991. It will enable the child support registrar not to enforce court ordered support in some circumstances and extend the circumstances in which social security clients can opt to make arrangements for private collection of support payments. The amendments contained in this bill will provide some relief to some clients of the Child Support Agency. For this reason, the coalition is not opposing the legislation.

I would like to speak for a few minutes about the deficiencies in the operation of the child support scheme. Before I do that, I want to emphasise that the coalition supports the child support scheme and the principles underlying it. By way of background, the child support scheme was established in response to concerns that so many non-custodial parents were not paying to support their children. The burden for supporting these children was then falling on the social security system and, ultimately, the taxpayer. There was also concern about the adequacy of court ordered child maintenance and the difficulties which existed in the enforcement and collection of maintenance in Australia. The child support scheme has had a number of successes and, when we think back to the situation before the child support scheme, there is little doubt that what we now have is an improvement.

The total amount of child support which has been paid through the Child Support Agency demonstrates the significance of the scheme. Since 1 July 1988 to May 1994, a total of $825.7 million had been collected by the agency. This means that the scheme has saved the Department of Social Security and, hence, the taxpayer a very large amount of money—$161 million in 1993-94 alone—although, because of the burgeoning administration costs, the net savings have not been as high as were initially predicted.

Perhaps the greatest success of the child support scheme is not the amount of money collected but the shift in community attitude. Before the introduction of the child support legislation in 1988-89, debate centred around the extent to which parents should support their own children compared with the responsibility of the community to do so through social welfare and whether it was possible to introduce a formula for the calculation of child support liabilities.

There is now an acknowledgment by the vast majority of the community that it is the primary responsibility of parents to support their own children and that the support of children in our community involves very high costs. To a large extent this shift has resulted from enforcing the collection of child support through the child support scheme.

Having said that, we should not get carried away with the successes of the scheme. These achievements should not overshadow the very significant problems and deficiencies that have become apparent in the scheme. Whilst the concept underlying the scheme is admirable, in practice the system has resulted in a deluge of complaints from custodial and non-custodial parents and from the subsequent spouses of non-custodial parents.

If the staff in our offices had the opportunity to speak in the chamber, they would attest to the number of telephone calls that come into our offices with complaints about the Child Support Agency. Complaints range from the fact that they cannot get through to complaints about money being lodged and then not being passed on to them. There is a never ending procession. You can list on your hand the sorts of issues that come into your office and you can bet your bottom dollar that there is a high likelihood when somebody rings up that it is going to be about the Child Support Agency.

It is not an exaggeration to state that dissatisfaction with the operation of the scheme and its implementation through the Child Support Agency is unprecedented both in its intensity and in its quantity. This had to be borne out by the 6,000 or so submissions to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues which conducted an inquiry into the operation and effectiveness of the child support scheme. People often intend to write a submission but they do not get around to it. To have 6,000 submissions attests to the fact that there are problems and people have concerns.

The report of the joint select committee was tabled in November 1994. It is a scathing indictment of the government's failure to recognise and remedy the obvious problems of the child support scheme. It is an extraordinary arraignment of the chronic administrative problems of the Child Support Agency. The explanatory memorandum to the Child Support Assessment Bill 1989, dated 6 September 1989, stated that the bill was intended to establish a system which ensures that `access to child support is simple, timely and flexible and respects personal privacy'. It is now acknowledged that, by these criteria or any others, there are serious inadequacies in the administration, as well as structural anomalies and deficiencies in the child support scheme.

Basically, two criticisms have emerged. There are those directed at the Child Support Agency itself and those which criticised the operation of the scheme; in particular, the formula applied to assess a non-custodial parent's liability for child support. To begin with, a high proportion of custodians do not receive any, or very little, child support yet there is no reliable detailed information as to why this is the case.

As I said, all members of parliament have had dealings over a number of years with constituents who have had difficulties with some of the provisions of the scheme and in their dealings with the Child Support Agency. As the joint select committee report points out, this indicates that the government should have been more aware of the urgent need for change and action within the Child Support Agency.

One has only to skim through the joint select committee report to appreciate the magnitude of the deficiencies in the operation of the child support scheme. I will note a few of the problems mentioned: the legislation itself is convoluted, complex and difficult to interpret; the Child Support Agency has chronic administrative problems and the main reason for this is the consistent failure of the CSA's management to identify and rectify its own poor administrative and management practices. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The consistency of the types of complaints documented in the Ombudsman's Annual Reports from 1989-90 through to 1993-94 demonstrate that the CSA's management did not recognise and failed to accept responsibility for delivering an efficient and effective service to its clients.

PARA.TAB: Another complaint was that there was a lack of national direction in the management of the Child Support Agency. There were complaints about deficiencies in national policies and guidelines, a failure to enforce consistent national practice, poor administrative practices at local branch level, communication problems, inconsistent advice, administrative errors, refusal to verify data, delay in action, appalling client service delivery, and a failure to give full effect to people's rights and entitlements under the legislation. Other complaints included claims that the existing branch office organisation provides poor accessibility to clients outside capital cities and a failure to meet the information needs of clients. There is a complaint that the Child Support Agency is insensitive and unresponsive to complaints raised by clients. The Commonwealth ombudsman, the child support evaluation advisory group and the Australian National Audit Office have all commented on difficulties in communicating with the Child Support Agency.

There have been suggestions that Child Support Agency staff do not adequately understand the requirements of the Privacy Act and have disclosed personal information without authorisation. That is totally unacceptable, especially given the sensitivity of the relationships that are involved in cases dealt with by the Child Support Agency.

Child Support Agency staff have interpreted court orders incorrectly and have incorrectly registered applications to courts. That is totally unacceptable. There has been a lack of support from the Australian Taxation Office, the host department of the Child Support Agency—support which should have been there from the beginning. There has been a lack of dedicated and identifiable contact officers responsible for the administration for a particular case or client. There have been long delays between registration and receipt of the first payment. There has been delay or failure to recover arrears. No action to collect arrears has been taken until the debt reaches a certain level.

Setting aside whether the agency should be making judgment about what is wrong to warrant an effort to collect arrears, the real point is that the longer the arrears are allowed to accumulate the less likely full recovery becomes. The list goes on. This is an indictment of this government and its ability to organise anything. If this were a report by a company to its shareholders about the management of an organisation a lot of heads would roll. These are people—mostly women, but in a lot of cases they are husbands, male spouses or partners—who are being subjected to this sort of treatment, and it has gone on and on.
The government has done nothing about it. This bill has been listed over and over again in this place. That shows that the government does not have a great desire to do much about it.

We tend to forget that there are real people at the end of the process. We have to remember the woman who is trying to work in a factory and who goes to the telephone over and over again to ring the Child Support Agency and cannot get through. That is what is happening. These are people who have to ask permission to use the telephone. Many of them cannot do that easily. Then they cannot get through to the Child Support Agency. If they get through, they are often told to ring back, or they cannot get on to the person that they were last dealing with. That is the nitty-gritty of this report.

We should not forget that there are people at the end. We must also remember the person who has put money into the Child Support Agency but who cannot find out why it has not been paid. The committee's report should not have been used. The Child Support Agency has been under fire for many years. Criticisms have come from the Commonwealth ombudsman, the Auditor-General, the parliament and the many support groups that exist to help clients who have been poorly treated by the agency.

it is totally unacceptable that this government and the Child Support Agency have not been able to rectify these inadequacies. It is even more appalling that these problems are only beginning to be addressed now because of the JSC inquiry and report. Even so, government ministers are arguing amongst themselves about the report's recommendations.

The minister will say that the government has acted on a number of occasions to improve the child support scheme. It is true that there have been attempts to tinker at the edge of the scheme but, from the report and from constituent responses, we know that this has not been adequate.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 that we are debating today is yet another attempt to fix the mess, but, once again, it does not attempt to deal with the major problems with the scheme and with the Child Support Agency.Hopefully, when the government gets around to responding to the report of the joint select committee, there will be a comprehensive overhaul of the legislation. I note that an interim government response is being tabled this afternoon. I will be interested to see that response, but, as I said, it is only an interim response.

As I stated earlier, the coalition will not be opposing this bill. However, we have a number of concerns which need to be mentioned.
