This legislation proposes changes that will give the Child Support Agency staff greater discretionary powers. In theory, this is a step in the right direction, but, given the appalling record of the Child Support Agency, the high number of complaints to the ombudsman and the findings of the Auditor-General and the joint select committee, it is questionable that agency staff have the skills to make the sensitive and responsible decisions that their work entails. I hope that situation is addressed.

The government must make sure that officers of the Child Support Agency are up to the job if this legislation is to be delivered and if the desired results are to be obtained. Staff of the Child Support Agency will need comprehensive training to effectively manage the issues and the additional responsibilities that this legislation raises. The problem is that the legislation does not provide for such training; it merely adds to the burden of those struggling with the impossible task of making the legislation work. Giving more work to those who are already not coping is not a solution. As I already said, the coalition will not be opposing this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have supported the child support scheme since its inception. We have always considered it to be a scheme which offers the best method of ensuring that children are properly and adequately supported following the divorce or the separation of their parents.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, in 1986, well before the child support scheme began, Janine Haines, who was then the leader of the Democrats, gave a speech in this chamber in which she said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is worthwhile for us to remember that our primary concern about the breakdown of a marriage from which there have been children is that those children are adequately supported.

PARA.TAB: From time to time, we get rather excited about other issues resulting from the breakdown of a marriage, including relationships between the parents, problems with access, the damage that one parent can do by bad-mouthing the other, and so on.
In doing that, we sometimes lose sight of the fact that the most relevant factor is the welfare and wellbeing of the children of the union.

SPEECH.PARA: This is what Janine Haines, in 1986, wanted to see from a child support scheme: a scheme which had, as its first and foremost concern, the welfare and wellbeing of the children of marriages which had broken down. That is exactly what the child support scheme has delivered.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that anyone can deny the value of or, indeed, the success of this scheme. I do not think that anyone can deny that the child support scheme is, at heart, an effective and sound scheme which has delivered good results. In other words, it is one scheme which has really made a difference. Many Australian children undoubtedly have a better quality of life and a higher standard of living thanks to the child support scheme.

Just as significantly, the scheme has challenged the attitude that maintenance payments are voluntary and that non-custodial parents are not obliged to support their children. That attitude has changed, and it is understood that non-custodial parents do, indeed, have a real obligation. It is also understood that their obligation is not to be an afterthought after other expenses have been met, but that it is to be the primary obligation of the non-custodial parent.

Generally speaking, it is no longer considered acceptable for non-custodial parents to simply wash their hands of their duty to support their children. Australians now expect the responsibility of child maintenance to be shared by both parents.

Of course, this does not mean by any stretch of the imagination that the child support scheme is now perfect. As the recent report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues shows very clearly, there is still a large number of problems with the child support scheme. There is still an enormous number of custodial parents who either receive no child support from their former partners or who struggle to obtain child support regularly. There is still an enormous number of parents who remain outside the scheme, and the level of arrears remains unacceptably very high. There is still a great deal of dissatisfaction—a lot of it justified—with the operation of the scheme and with the conduct of the Child Support Agency.

These problems are not surprising. The child support scheme is fraught with difficulty. The nature of divorce and family breakdown means that the scheme operates in an emotionally charged climate in which people do not always behave sensibly, calmly or with patience and maturity. Right from the start the scheme was always going to be out there in the front line. It was always going to cop more than its fair share of criticism. While some of that criticism is justified, quite clearly some of it is driven by very real personal anger and frustration, rather than by any truly valid criticism of the scheme itself.

The bill implements the reforms of the Child Support Agency announced in April last year by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). It aims to provide more flexibility in the child support scheme. I want to cover four main areas very briefly.

The first major change in the bill is the aligning of the child support legislation with the provisions of the Family Law Act in relation to the establishment of parentage in the first place. The object of this alignment is to broaden the range of circumstances under which clients of the Child Support Agency can lodge an initial application. Hopefully, this will speed up the processing of their applications, which is a desirable outcome given the joint committee's finding that significant delays are still occurring between the date of application and the receipt of the first payment for child support. The delay period has been an ongoing problem since the scheme began and anything the government can do to facilitate the processing of this application is welcome.

The second change is to ensure that DSS clients who enter into an agreement will now have to have that agreement examined for its adequacy under the reasonable action for maintenance provisions of the Social Security Act. This change has come about because of growing evidence that child support agreements are being drawn up for amounts which are substantially less than would be payable under a formula assessment.

The third change is aimed at building some flexibility into the situation where parents want to alter their child support agreement because the non-custodial parent's income has fallen below a critical level. The bill enables the agency to exercise some discretion in enforcing child support liability ordered by the Family Court and registered under the child support scheme.

The fourth change proposed by the legislation is an amendment which will allow Social Security clients the option of receiving payments through either the Child Support Agency or by way of private agreement and arrangements. At present, some parents who are receiving income tested payments from DSS can elect to collect child support privately when they register with the agency. A significant number of custodial parents make that election and the agency only becomes involved when the private payment arrangement fails. However, once they are registered for collection with the agency, a custodial parent cannot revert back to a private arrangement at a later date. The change in the bill will enable all custodial parents in receipt of an income tested payment from DSS to choose private collection at any time after registration, provided the payer has a satisfactory payment record. If the private arrangement fails, once again the custodial parent will be able to elect to have the liability enforced under the act.

In conclusion, the Democrats support the legislation. That support is consistent with our ongoing backing of the child support scheme. As I said earlier, that does not mean we do not have some concerns about the scheme. Senator Spindler was a member of the joint select committee and the Democrats, like most members and senators, are well aware of the shortcomings of the scheme and the administrative problems of the Child Support Agency.

While I do not agree with everything the joint committee said, I believe the committee has produced a comprehensive and important report against which the government actions on child support can be measured. I also think that it is fair to expect the government to at least indicate during the current parliamentary session what legislative action it intends to take in response to that committee's report. In short, the Democrats look forward to a comprehensive government response to the committee's report. In our view, anything less than that is unacceptable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contribution. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government.
—About unemployment?

—About your unemployment. I remind the minister that during the last election campaign your government made unfunded new spending commitments of $5.2 billion, and that is according to figures published in a document produced by your government entitled Building on strength, which does not even include the One Nation commitments. In the light of your budget's apparently firm commitment to maintain a budget surplus of $3.4 billion in 1996-97 and $4.5 billion in 1997-98, will you rule out any further spending promises during the next election campaign? Or isn't it really the case that by polling day your surplus claims will be proved worthless unless you intend to further jack up taxes?

—There is one thing to be said about the government as compared with the opposition: at least we do articulate what our policy is—spell it out in a way that is something that is spectacularly absent from any contribution the opposition has made to this debate. There have been, of course, nonetheless, some opposition budget promises that have been made by the opposition since March 1993. Our estimate is that, depending on how one chooses to quantify them, they range between $6.6 billion—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. This is an appalling abuse of question time. The point of order relates to relevance. My question was all about to what extent we can believe the government's commitments and whether, during the last election campaign, it made unfunded promises of $5.2 billion. How could the minister possibly then start to talk about some shonky document that someone has given him about the opposition's promises?
—I can hardly judge relevance 30 seconds into an answer.

—Unless Senator Alston produces chapter and verse as to what it is that is supposed to have constituted those unfunded promises, I would no sooner accept a figure from Senator Alston than I would grow wings and fly around this particular chamber. There is no question of accepting anything that you say because you are, I have to say, with all due respect for the conventions of this place, a shonk. You are just a total shonk in the way in which you advance these propositions because you are incapable of any consistency in your own view of the world. You have been spreading yourself around the landscape making extravagant promises of your own—
—Answer the question!

—I am, Senator Macdonald—making outlay promises of your own in the range $6.6 to $17 billion; you have had outlay reduction measures hinted at of the order of somewhere between $5 billion in sole parent benefits, child-care funding, jobstart, housing subsidies, Medicare—

—Mr President, I take a point of order on the issue of relevance. I have looked very carefully through the question, listened very carefully to it, and there is no discussion in that question of opposition policies. What we asked about precisely was what the government was going to do and in particular, Senator Evans, will the minister rule out any further spending promises during the next election campaign. Could you instruct the minister to return to the question.
—I think it is time you started answering the question rather than digressing, Senator.

—It is a time-honoured principle in the courts that one is entitled to question the character of the witness. The character of the witness is extremely important in this particular matter because the witness we are talking about here is someone who speaks for a party that has been incapable of lying straight in bed or anywhere else in terms of its own budget commitments, both on the revenue and the outlay side. We do not know what you stand for. What we stand for has been amply documented in these budget papers, and there is no question—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You should not simply sit there and allow that sort of abuse to be streaming out of Senator Evans's mouth. I think he is capable of restraining himself if he tries. More importantly, I put a specific document to him—Building on strength. So it is quite clear that he has been asked a specific question about whether that document contained $5.2 billion worth of unfunded promises. So how you can let him talk about anything else, let alone our promises, is beyond me.

—Mr President, on the point of order. What is clear here is the orchestration of a politically-inspired question time. The senator over here asks the question; the other senator down here reads the same question. I make this point to underline the point of order. The point of order is that it is entirely appropriate for the government to deal with the opposition's promises at election time. It was the opposition that raised the fistful of dollars election campaign. It was the opposition that misled the Australian people on a whole range of promises when it was in government. It is quite appropriate, in the context of the political nature of this question, for us to reflect on the opposition's record.

—Mr President, I rise on the point of order. You ought to look very closely at allowing people like Senator Cook to answer in that way. Appropriateness has nothing to do with the standing orders. All Senator Cook is arguing is that he would like to be able to refute what we are putting, and he clearly cannot. You should not allow him to get up and grandstand in that fashion. It was not a point of order or anything that looked like it. In those circumstances, you ought to rule in favour of telling the minister to answer the question.

—Mr President, on my point of order, of course the standing orders speak for themselves, but you have to see the standing orders in the context of this place. In the context of this place, it is idle to pretend that this is not a politically-inspired question.
—Order! I have already asked Senator Evans to get to the point and I ask him to curb his legal right to challenge the credibility of the opposition.

—The point is every promise that we are implementing that has a dollar sign attachable to it is meticulously documented in the budget papers and quantified with the method of financing associated with it fully and comprehensively spelt out. That is the case for 1995-96. You also have most of the out-year projections of the way in which those particular programs are going to operate. That is all I can say in general terms.

PARA.TAB: The distinction is very clear between the approach we have adopted to our commitments, our promises, the quantification of them, the documentation of them, the description as to how they are going to be paid for—it is all there on the record—and yours. If you want to ask me any more precise question about any particular program component of that, I would be perfectly happy to reply, but in general terms, that is all I can say.

I can draw the contrast, accordingly, between our approach, which is to meticulously spell this out in the public domain, and that which you opposite have offered, which is totally empty. On the one hand you say no revenue increases and on the other hand you say a few benefits on the revenue side. On the one hand you say something like $11 million worth of outlay carrots that you are going to throw around and on the other hand you will not describe what the outlay reductions are that you are going to use in order to achieve that result.

You leave the Australian public totally bereft of any kind of knowledge whatsoever of where you stand on any of these basic questions of macro-economic management or responsible public accounting. On that basis, Mr President, for Senator Alston to get up here and accuse the government of anything other than absolute responsibility is something that utterly defies credibility and he is entitled to be sat down accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We had four minutes in which Senator Evans chose not to get to the second half of my question, which was quite clearly: during the election campaign, are we going to be subjected to a further set of unfunded promises? If we are, does that mean that we can simply ignore the surplus figures that are contained in these budget documents or are you going to in fact put any limit on the amount that you are prepared to spend during the election campaign?

—One of the key components of this particular budget is outlay reductions which fully cover the cost of all promises made and implemented since the last budget and which are contained in this particular budget. All new policy proposals that are program content have been fully funded since the last budget and will be in this particular budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology representing the Treasurer. Two days ago the Commonwealth budget brought forward a major new initiative in terms of Australia's comprehensive national savings plan. Can the minister inform the Senate what the role of national savings in the Australian economy is? What is the impact of the government's initiatives in terms of national savings? How will workers directly benefit from those initiatives?

—I congratulate the honourable senator on his question. The measures in this budget represent a two-part plan by the government to directly increase the amount of national savings. By increasing national savings, this plan will reduce the pressure on the current account deficit—something that everyone has been calling for—will reverse the accumulation of government debt and, significantly, will take pressure off interest rates. That is very good news for Australian business and particularly good news for Australian home buyers.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit is the result of the fact that as a nation we have been buying more than we have been selling and we have had too low a level of national savings. By saving more, we address this problem as well as securing a quality of life for Australians in their retirement. The nation's savings are made up of savings by the public sector and the private sector. This budget works on both those fronts. The budget increases public savings by bringing the Commonwealth budget into surplus, a surplus of $718 million, and a surplus achieved three years earlier than was previously expected. No-one has tried to deny that the asset sales make a significant contribution to the surplus outcome. That is on page 1 of the Treasurer's budget speech.

There are a few other points that I would like to note. Firstly, as the senior analyst for Moody's Investors Service said on radio this morning, `Going into surplus is a good idea no matter how it is achieved.' Proceeds from asset sales directly reduce the overall level of government borrowing. Secondly, the budget will be in surplus, even excluding asset sales of special debt and capital repayments in 1996-97 and increasing after that. The budget balance will be restored with revenue much lower in relation to GDP than in the past. When we last moved into surplus in 1987-88 revenue represented 27.2 per cent of GDP, compared with an estimated 25.3 per cent this year, 1995-96.

With regard to private sector savings, this budget implements Australia's first long-term private sector savings program through employee superannuation. The government will support the inclusion in all awards of provisions for employee superannuation contributions beginning at one per cent of earnings in July 1987 and rising to three per cent of earnings in July 1999.

In addition, employee contributions will be augmented through the payment of the second tranche of tax cuts directly into people's superannuation accounts. The government will match employee contributions dollar for dollar—a government contribution of $4 billion when fully phased in. This will do more for national savings than a straight tax cut would have done and it will be done in a way that increases equity in this country by the government's contribution to those earning less than $46,000. Moreover, it is estimated that the cost of the superannuation package will grow faster than the cost of the tax cuts it replaces, eventually exceeding the cost of the tax cuts. Middle and low income earners in Australia will be better off having their tax cuts paid in this way.

The measures build on and reinforce the significant achievements of the government since 1983 in transforming the role of superannuation in Australia. I have said it before, but in the Liberal era less than 40 per cent of Australian workers had superannuation cover; today the proportion is nearly 90 per cent thanks to the changes we have made. In 1983 superannuation funds assets were $40 billion; they are now $180 billion and they are growing. That is a huge pool for national investment purposes. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and relates to the land fund. On 9 November last the Leader of the Government in the Senate said:

QUESTION.PARA: The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act . . .

On 16 November, Minister, you said, `I am prepared to bet large sums of money that $21 million of ATSIC funds would not be used, exclusively or largely over the next three years, to purchase land in the Northern Territory.' On 30 March ATSIC agreed to allocate $20 million out of a budget of $24 million for land purchases in the Northern Territory in the next two years. Will the minister now advise the Senate whether the government discussed or agreed with this ATSIC policy prior to November last year? Will the government take action to remedy these clear breaches of assurances given to both the Senate and the Northern Territory government? Finally, will the government urgently consider amalgamating the administration of the two land acquisition funds under the ILC to ensure equity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians across Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anyone would actually like to make the bet now, I am happy to take any number of wagers. First of all, the mathematics in Senator Campbell's question have to be corrected. The total amount of money available to ATSIC for land acquisition over the next two years is not, as Senator Campbell said, $21 million; it is $42 million. It is, in fact, double—afraid so, Senator Campbell.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell, $21 million is available to ATSIC this year for land acquisition, and $21 million is available to ATSIC next year for land acquisition. It is entirely discretionary. It is open to ATSIC to spend every cent of it on land acquisition and none of it on management. I am advised—and I am not privy to ATSIC board meetings; I will have a look at the previous board decisions—that this is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you mislead the Senate then?

—I did not, Senator Macdonald; that is exactly what I am explaining. It the largest amount of money that has ever been made available by ATSIC for management. I mention that because, as Senator Campbell knows full well, I am very strong on the notion that in the past there has been a failure of Aboriginal organisations to direct money to management after the acquisition. But it is open to ATSIC to use every cent of that money—the whole $42 million—for land acquisition.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly enough, Lois O'Donoghue, the chair of ATSIC, issued a press statement on this issue on 11 April which nobody knew about. I was not aware of it until this morning. To the best of my knowledge it never got a run anywhere in the media—which surprised me. It was on this very issue. I will table the press release. She said:

ANSWER.PARA: Much of the criticism is based on an incorrect assumption that all available land acquisition and management funds will be directed to the Northern Territory.
She then went on to explain the break-up:
Of the Commission's annual allocation of $21, the Board decided to spend $9 million on land management Australia-wide—
this is in each of the next two years—
$10 million on land acquisition in the Northern Territory and $2 million on priority acquisition in other States.

The fact is that ATSIC has allocated less than half of its available allocation for land acquisition to the Northern Territory. I add that the purpose of the chair's press statement needs to be noted, because of the representations that I have subsequently had. Allegedly—and I do not know this to be a fact—the decision to do this was taken on the casting vote of the chair herself, which simply indicates how controversial the proposal was inside ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: I know that concerns have been raised from Aboriginal organisations from Tasmania to Queensland about the decision. I think in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald a statement was made that the New South Wales Land Council is considering legal action to attempt to injunct ATSIC from proceeding with its decision. Of course, that is a matter for ATSIC to determine itself.

The reason I make those concerns known is that the decision concerns me, Senator Campbell. I was not aware of it. The fact that you had leaked documents given to you from ATSIC indicates that there is some concern within ATSIC; otherwise you would never have got the documents. I will investigate whether the assertion that the decision was taken on the casting vote of the chair is correct. The principal issue is that $42 million is available to ATSIC for land acquisition, Senator, not $21 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you mislead the Senate?

—Senator Macdonald, are you really cloth eared? I have just explained that there was no misleading of the Senate. The statement I made—Senator Chamarette, if you had made your bet, you would have lost it—was that all of the money available to ATSIC would be exclusively used in the Northern Territory. The fact is that less than half of the money available to ATSIC for land acquisition has been used for that purpose.

—Mr President, I will take the bet. Minister, I repeat, you said in the Senate that you were prepared to bet large sums of money that $21 million of ATSIC funds would not be used exclusively or largely over the next three years. The fact is that $20 million will be used over the next two years. The money that was spent in the Northern Territory in the last reported year was in the order of $2 million to $3 million. Senator Evans said that the agreement with the Northern Territory government is that, as a result of the land fund bill, there would not be an increase in the amount of purchases in the Northern Territory. The reality is that there has been a five-fold increase because of the decision by ATSIC. Minister, will you answer the question I put to you: firstly, was the government aware, in negotiations with ATSIC, that it would be ATSIC's policy to divert its funds, but not as a transitory measure; and, secondly, will the government now take action to ensure that the assurance it gave to the Senate and the Northern Territory government is stood by? (Time expired)

—I just made it clear that that is not the case. No, the government was not aware that the board of ATSIC—and we do not control the board of ATSIC—would take such a decision. I have just said to the Senate—
—Well, why did you mislead the Senate?
—There was no misleading, Senator. Have a look at what I said.
—It is in Hansard.

—I talked about the fund being exclusively devoted to the Northern Territory and the facts are that less than half of it has been. Having said that, I express my concern about the decision. I have had one discussion with the chair of ATSIC about it, and I dare say there will be another. I point out that it is already in the public domain that significant concerns at the decision are being expressed among Aboriginal organisations. It appears the decision was made on the casting vote of the chair.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I know the Minister is aware of the need for the Sydney 2000 Olympics to be a financial and sporting success. What measures has the government taken to ensure that the sporting competition at the 2000 Olympics is free from performance enhancing drugs? How will these actions enhance the credibility of the 2000 games and thereby ensure the financial viability of the games?

—I thank Senator Neal for her question. I did announce in the budget this week that the Australian Sports Drug Agency will receive increased funding of $3 million over the next six years. This funding will be used to implement additional testing, education and international anti-doping programs. This will further enhance the world leadership role that Australia enjoys in anti-doping.

PARA.TAB: At the time I announced the increased funding, I made it clear that I am determined to do everything possible to ensure that the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games is drug free. This will involve both continuing our excellent work here in Australia and advocating an international level playing field. The size of our olympic teams that will be competing at Atlanta and Sydney will be the largest ever. Additional drug tests will therefore be conducted to ensure that we maintain the strong deterrent effect we have already achieved here in Australia. This increased drug testing initiative will be supported through enhanced education programs which will particularly emphasise that drug use is cheating.

Research has shown that 50 per cent of Australia's elite athletes perceive that Sydney hosting the 2000 Olympic Games will increase the pressure on them to use performance enhancing drugs. These enhanced domestic programs will ensure that this perceived pressure does not result in any drug use. I am aware that many of our top athletes are concerned that, in relation to drugs in sport, they are not competing internationally on a level playing field.

The increased funding to the Australian Sports Drugs Agency in this year's budget will also assist the agency in arguing on behalf of our athletes for an international level playing field. This will involve the development of additional anti-doping agreements with other governments, as well as encouraging the implementation of drug testing programs administered independently by international sports federations on a year round basis.

I will be encouraging all sectors of the Australian sports community to support our international efforts. This will include the national sporting organisations, the Australian Olympic Committee and SOCOG. The Australian Sports Drug Agency is already working closely with the AOC and SOCOG in the pursuit of a drug-free Sydney 2000.

All athletes from home or abroad are now on notice that ASDA's enhanced program will promote a sporting environment in this country before, during and beyond the Sydney Olympics that is free from performance enhancing drugs. Doping is undermining the credibility of sport throughout the world. If it continues, both government and non-government organisations will be less inclined to provide the necessary financial support to sport. There have already been many examples of sponsors removing their commitment to athletes as a result of positive drug tests.

The private sector will be expected to make a major contribution to the financial success of Sydney 2000. Corporations will be more inclined to be associated with a games that is drug free than a games that is tainted in any way by drug misuse.

The pursuit of a drug-free Sydney 2000 Olympics can re-establish the credibility of international sport. But this will only be a milestone in anti-doping. More importantly, it can provide a launching pad to take the drug-free sporting ethos into the 21st century. That is something that future generations of sporting men and women deserve to enjoy. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. On ABC radio in Brisbane this morning, the Prime Minister had this to say about small business people who are feeling the pinch:

QUESTION.PARA: If they're feeling the pinch they're feeling it in the highest growth economy we've had . . . so if they're feeling the pinch they ought to say small business is not for me because it's never going to get any better . . . if they're feeling the pinch they better say `well I better go back to PAYE employment'.

Minister, is the Prime Minister right? Is it never going to get any better for small business? On the your calculations, how many of them should give up and go back to PAYE employment? Do you, as the small business minister, support the Prime Minister's comments?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen an extract of the remarks made by the Prime Minister. I do not think Senator Kernot has quoted them in their entirety. The Prime Minister said that growth is currently running at around five per cent and that we have inflation at 3 1/2 per cent. Those two figures together represent about the best we have ever had. Remember that growth is at five per cent and inflation is at 3 1/2 per cent. They are the two points that the Prime Minister was putting together. In that environment, small business and big business—all business—should be able to do well.

PARA.TAB: I point out to Senator Kernot—I am sure that she knows this—that there are over 880,000 businesses in Australia, of which well over 800,000 are small businesses. Over half of them are what we would call micro-businesses, which feature the self-employed and have a non-corporate structure. Many of them involve people who all the time move from employment into running a small business and back. Unfortunately, we do not have exact figures or a statistical base to know how many are moving backwards and forwards in what is, and always will be, a very dynamic part of the economy. So it is not unreasonable to suggest that there will always be people who choose to say, `Small business has not worked out for me. I will return to being a PAYE employee.'

Look at most of the advice given by sensible accountants and financial institutions to people who seek to go into small business. Many advise quite rightly that their small business proposal will not be viable and that they should not implement it. From time to time, professional accountants and advisers also sensibly advise such people that their small business is not viable and that they should leave it. That appropriate advice is being given all the time. Over the last 12 months or more, our economy has been growing, on average, at around five per cent and has had very low inflation. The Prime Minister commented that people who are still having difficulty may have to look at leaving small business. There is nothing startling about that, because people are leaving and joining small business year in and year out.

If we did not have those dynamic changes going on, in my view we would have a very constipated small business section of the economy. We want dynamic growth and we want change. We want it to grow. During the period of this government, small business numbers in this country have grown significantly. We are now approaching around 900,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you agree with the Prime Minister?

—I think the Prime Minister's remarks, if you see them in the context in which that question was put and his explanation in that long interview on radio in Queensland today—not the small quote that you were just holding up but the full transcript which I have had an opportunity to see—are not unreasonable.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is just that you and the Prime Minister left out one fact, Senator Schacht. When you talk about growth rates and inflation rates, you leave out the fact that the provisional tax uplift factor is still three times the inflation rate. Where is the good news for small business in this budget?

—I know that Senator Kernot is making a big play for the small business vote at the coming election. However, you have to get your facts right, Senator Kernot. The provisional uplift factor is not based on the inflation rate. It is made on assessment of the profitability of those who pay provisional tax. The inflation rate is not the only matter taken into account in deciding the provisional uplift factor. To say that it is only the inflation factor is just wrong. I also want to point out to Senator Kernot—
—Time, time!
—Unfortunately time has stopped this good last point.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. In the budget we saw the announcement of the government's response to the review of future prospects in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. What does this response entail? Will the response bring about a positive future for these industries?

—On that last point, of course it will. When we came to power in 1983, the textiles, clothing and footwear sector in Australia was on its knees. We set about reducing tariff protection and restructuring that sector. It now employs just over 100,000 Australians in 3,500 establishments. It now contributes to six per cent of the total private consumption expenditure in Australia each year, and it now exports $690 million worth of products from Australia. They are the latest figures—the 1993-94 figures.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a turnaround in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. It has got smarter, it has done better in the export market and it has become more internationally competitive. It is for those reasons that the government, in looking at the TCF plan, commissioned a report last year to look at further strategies to enhance the competitiveness of this sector. The TCF 2000 development package is one that we have responded to in this year's budget. The purpose of the package is to bring together government, industries, unions and firms and concentrate them on improving the management and leadership skills of this sector, building a better customer focus, entrenching quality performance and establishing information networks to help the industry expand.

In the budget we announced our response to the proposals under that package. They are briefly put in five quite clear and distinct parts: an outreach program, which will assist at least 100 firms to take up best practice manufacturing practices; a quality program, which will assist firms or clusters of firms to reach international quality accreditation, the ISO standards; an international information program that establishes joint intelligence networks for sectors to identify new international customers and develop suitable marketing strategies; an infrastructure program incorporating investment promotion and attraction, funding for training infrastructure and an outworker information program; and the retention of the import credit scheme and overseas assembly provisions until the year 2000. I might say, in parenthesis, the exports of wet blue hides will no longer be eligible for the import credit scheme.

They are the features of the program. It has received a positive response from the industry. It enables the government to work with an industry that has undertaken massive restructuring and that is now world competitive and to see that it succeeds to be APEC ready and global economy competitive by the year 2000.

Therefore, with the opening up of freer trade in the APEC region because of the move due to the Bogor declaration of leaders last year to free trade in the Asia-Pacific by the year 2020, under this plan, working with the industry I am sure the Australian government—and that is the industry's view—has helped it take advantage of that more open market. This has caused Australian clothing companies in particular to focus on the upper quality end of the market so that they are not competing head to head with low cost, low wage countries but are carving out a niche for themselves as quality suppliers. That is what the basis of this industry resurgence has been built on.

The five elements of this plan are to encourage them to build further on that. That is good news for the industry; good news for workers in the industry; good news for Australia in the sense that it is a vibrant and important part of our national industry base and is set to continue to expand; and good news for the current account as we pick up more export markets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology representing the Treasurer. Yesterday, in answer to a question regarding the budget's fiddled deficit, Senator Cook said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the people take the budget deficit or the budget surplus to be what call on financial markets the Commonwealth will make. That is the important criterion. The answer to that is that we are not making a call on the financial markets because we are in surplus this financial year.
If that is the case, I ask the minister to explain the statement on page 5-5 of budget paper No. 1 under the subheading, `Budget financing task' which states:
The Commonwealth's financing task in 1995-96 is estimated at $6.2 billion.

Is the explanation for his highly inaccurate answer that he deliberately misled the Senate yesterday? Or that he believed the budget deficit to be $6.2 billion? Or perhaps that, as minister representing the Treasurer, he like many of his colleagues is simply ignorant of how to calculate the deficit? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is playing a game aimed at perpetrating in Australia the illusion that somehow or other the figures that we have presented in the budget speech are not accurate. Can I just say they are accurate. In the budget we have indicated the surplus after taking account of revenue and outlays—and there is a clear surplus in the budget.

PARA.TAB: The question I dealt with yesterday was one from Senator Kernot who, I think, went to page 7.3, table 2 and raised a question which was not the same question. Her question referred to table 2 which deals with the adjusted ABS budget deficit. I said to her that the accounting in this budget has been laid out according to the IMF standard and the United Nations convention on accounting.

TALK.START.PARA: —This isn't the question.

—It is the question that Senator Kernot raised with me yesterday because I made the point—and I will make it now, irrespective of the interjection—that there is nothing rubbery about this budget, the figuring is accurate. As the Treasurer, Ralph Willis, said in a radio interview last night—and I heard him—this is a budget and figuring of absolute integrity.

PARA.TAB: I also explained that the coalition has inappropriately and in the wrong context used the technical terms and technical language in budgets, which can be confusing to the lay person, to try to create absolute confusion and suspicion in the mind of the ordinary person and thus create a misunderstanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: it is the issue of relevance. Yesterday Senator Cook said, `We are not making a call on the financial markets because we are in surplus.' But the budget papers say the Commonwealth financing task is estimated at $6.2 billion. That is the question. Minister, could you explain to the Senate why you got it so hopelessly wrong?
—There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I was making the point that my answer to Senator Kernot was to say in lay language—not in technical terms—what the real meaning of the budget surplus is. I repeat: that is a fair presentation of the points raised by Senator Kernot's question. I am now asked a technical question—
—This is outrageous, Mr President. This is a continuation of the effort by the opposition to confuse the Australian public and to shout down information.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth financial transactions set out in the budget show that the budget deficit 1994-95 was $12.2 billion, while in 1995-96 it was plus $0.7 billion. Debt repayment and other financing was $7.7 billion last year and $5.9 billion this year. Public trading, enterprise and superannuation payments were $1.1 billion last year and $1 billion this year. That makes a total for last year of $21 billion and for this year of $6.2 billion.

That is the accurate technical presentation on the Commonwealth financial transactions, but it is a different thing from what I was talking about yesterday with Senator Kernot. Don't confuse it, because your efforts to confuse it fundamentally come down to this: the coalition is prepared to lie and deceive in order to gain political economic advantage and undermine the efficacy of proper and accurate budget figuring.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask again: did Senator Cook say yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . people take the budget deficit or the budget surplus to be what call on financial markets the Commonwealth will make. That is the important criterion. The answer to that is that we are not making a call on the financial markets because we are in surplus this financial year.?
If Senator Cook said that yesterday will he now acknowledge that he was wrong and apologise to the Senate accordingly, or was it a deliberate intent to mislead?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not wrong—
—You were.

—I was not wrong. If you read my words, you will see that I was talking about the call the budget makes on the financial markets. That is what my words were. As I understand it, Senator Short is a former Treasury official. Therefore, he knows that what he is saying is inaccurate. This is an episode in misleading the Australian public and his professional qualifications come under a cloud as a consequence.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I believe that the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has misled the Senate and the public. My understanding is that there is not $42 million available to ATSIC for land acquisition over the next two years, but $24 million only, of which $20 million has been approved for the Northern Territory while $4 million has been kept aside for emergencies or for land acquisition in the other states. How much of the $18 million given for land management will also be going to the Northern Territory is a matter on which I seek clarification. I ask the Leader of the Government to clarify these matters and request the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to correct the record.

—My understanding of the figures is as described by Senator Collins. It is the $21 million—a figure which we talked about endlessly during the debate and which you, Senator Chamarette, will remember—that is available each year out of ATSIC funds under the present arrangements for land acquisition. What you were told by Senator Collins, which is consistent with Ms O'Donoghue's press release, and which I would be perfectly happy to confirm as a result of further investigation, is that of that $42 million, $18 million, which is $9 million plus $9 million over two years, was to be spent on land management, which is something we all wanted; $10 million plus $10 million, namely $20 million, was to be spent on acquisitions in the Northern Territory; and $2 million plus $2 million, namely $4 million, was to be spent on acquisitions elsewhere. That makes a total of $42 million. That is my understanding of the arithmetic.

PARA.TAB: It is perfectly true that, as the earlier questioner said, in the course of debate in this place I said that it was my understanding, and I think Senator Collins said the same thing in his own contribution later in the debate, that, as a matter of practice—we were not making undertakings but we were saying that it was our understanding—the existing pattern of acquisitions in the Northern Territory was likely to be maintained. We both made the point that this was wholly within the discretion of ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it was by way of agreement.
—I did not say anything about agreement. I do not know what anyone else said, but what I said is on pages 1828 and 1829 of Hansard.
—On 9 November 1994 at a quarter past 9 at night you said that agreement with the Northern Territory government would not increase the amount of land claimed.

—I do not know what you are referring to, but I am talking about the statement I made in the Senate when this matter was debated and which was the subject matter, as I understand it, of your earlier question. I was making the point that it was our expectation that the existing pattern of purchases would, in fact, be maintained. That was what I said at that time. I do not know what the reference to November 1994 is about. I will have to have a look at that. According to the paper you have handed me, you say that the government has agreed with the Northern Territory that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act. I can answer that perfectly well now.

PARA.TAB: New moneys to the land fund, in addition to the $21 million presently being spent under the ATSIC funding, are going in as a result of the land acquisition bill. Certainly there is an agreement in relation to them. That is absolutely true. Not a dollar of that was to be spent on conversion of pastoral to inalienable freehold—not one dollar. That is the agreement. That is in writing as between the Prime Minister and the Northern Territory—no ifs, no buts, no maybes. But we are not talking about that; we are not talking about new moneys under the land fund. So, Senator Campbell, if you are going to be as helpful as you are on this occasion, I think you had better crawl back under the desk where you belong because you are not being helpful at all to advancing this case.

What is in issue in this case and what troubles me a little—let me be perfectly frank about it—is what I did say back in March 1995 when I said that it was my anticipation, my expectation, that the discretion used by ATSIC would follow the pattern in the past, which in my recollection is that roughly one or two properties a year at an average price of, say, $2 million has been the acquisition pattern in the past. It does seem that ATSIC, in the exercise of its discretion, has decided to go beyond that. I think that does call for an explanation from ATSIC.

I do not know whether there are any other understandings or agreements lying behind this. I am happy, as Senator Collins indicated he would be, to explore further what the circumstances are because clearly this is a matter of concern to other councils around the country which are concerned that there be a relatively even pattern of distribution of the funding rather than it all being concentrated in the Northern Territory.

I think that is Senator Chamarette's concern. That is my concern. That is the concern that I articulated. I do not think it is a matter of agreement. I do not think it is a matter of formal undertaking. I cannot recall any such agreements or undertakings being entered into, but it was certainly a matter of expectation. I am disappointed, as I understand the situation to be at the moment, that that expectation has not been satisfied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister aware that, as well the chairman's casting vote, another person who contributed to that vote was former commissioner Alf Bamblett in one of his last actions before resigning? Does this not confirm the fears I expressed at the time of the passage of the land fund bill that the government and ATSIC had made a deal with Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory that they would get the lion's share of the money available through ATSIC in exchange for support for the land fund bill? Does the government stand by ATSIC's decision? How can Aboriginal people have any faith in the government or in ATSIC in the light of the deals that have been made in the lead-up to the land fund and this manifestly unfair decision?

—I have absolutely no idea what the background to this decision was. I am quite certain that I had no knowledge of it, and beyond that I do not know. I do not know what the internal dynamics of ATSIC were on this occasion. I am very surprised that the dynamics did not work out in order to provide for more equitable distribution. I think that is a ground for concern. Senator Collins said he was concerned about that news. I certainly say that I am concerned about it and I will certainly be seeking some further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Can the minister explain the rationale to tax every Australian's dream home and the future renovations on all residential properties, particularly when only last month Mr Howe said `access to affordable housing is essential to the wellbeing of ordinary Australians and hence inseparable from the larger question of social justice' and that the government will `deliver high levels of housing affordability for all Australians'? What research and consultation did the government undertake on the impact of this tax on the cost of building, renovating or buying a home as well as the effect on home rents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement attributed to the Deputy Prime Minister is one that the government is very solidly committed to. We are committed to it in a way that provides meaningful results for Australian home owners and home buyers. One way in which we are committed to it is not to fabricate the facts. The fact is that Senator Tambling has been trying to run a fabricated, hysterical campaign in the community, misleading and alarming people as to the impact of this measure in the budget.

PARA.TAB: He put out a press statement that said that the government was talking about a $2,500 home tax when the true facts are that the impact of the tax on homes will be absolutely nowhere near that cost. His $2,500 figure is one that has been given the lie to even by the Housing Industry Association which, in its press statement, acknowledged that the figure may be $1,000. So already, Senator Tambling, you are 2 1/2 times off. The truth is that, on the department's advice and reckoning, in respect of a $100,000 home, we are talking about some $400; not $2,500, not $1,000, but $400.

One of the main driving forces for this measure was to ensure consistency in the current system. At the moment we have a system which has disparities in the treatment of certain goods; for example, fittings such as sinks, toilets, bath and towel rails are currently taxed at 11 per cent but associated taps, nozzles and shower heads are exempt. In order to bring consistency, the government, as one motivating force, has introduced this measure. It should be acknowledged that we have done so in an environment in which the price of houses has decreased marginally, and in which this budget has put the lid on interest rates. They have been steadying for some time now; that is acknowledged by the housing industry. We have done so in an environment in which the inflation forecast is low, which is obviously of great importance to people buying homes, and in an environment in which the industry acknowledges that housing affordability is at good levels.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me quote from a statement of 7 May by Dr Ron Silberberg, the national executive director of the HIA. This partly reflects the government's commitment to the housing industry and to home owners and buyers. He said:

Housing affordability conditions made a welcome recovery in the first three months of 1995. With home mortgage rates steadying, home buying affordability remains well above the conditions applying when interest rates peaked in the last recession. The latest Commonwealth Bank-HIA housing report shows that the housing affordability index for Australia rose from 135.5 in the December quarter 1994 to 138 in the March quarter 1995. When interest rates last peaked in the September quarter 1989, the rate had slumped to 96.5.

We are committed to Australians owning their own homes. We are tackling that in a way that is consistent with the outcome of enhancing home ownership. We have one of the highest home ownership rates in the world. We are keen to maintain that. On top of that, in terms of housing, this budget allocated $2 1/2 billion in housing and rental assistance for those who do not own their own homes.

PARA.TAB: That is the level of commitment we have. When we compare it to other commitments in this parliament, we see that there is only one side of the parliament that is prepared and equipped to tackle the economy and the situation in the broader community—that is, this side of the parliament, not the other side. We do not tackle issues like this with fabrication, hysteria and false arguments, trying to scare people. We would rather do it systematically. We are doing it in a way which enhances the level of home ownership in this country and keeps it at one of the highest levels in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister's answer raises two questions. Firstly, he talks about the $2.5 billion that the government is giving. I ask the question: how much more or less is that than in previous budgets? That is terribly important. Secondly, the minister quoted from Mr Silberberg's press release. I ask the minister if he saw today's press release which says that the revenue take will be about $550 million in 1995-96 compared with the budget estimate of $215 million. In other words, the budget has underestimated by more than half the revenue grab. That is detailed as follows: the impact will be—repairs and maintenance $144 million, renovations and additions $160 million, new buildings $146 million and office buildings $100 million, a total of $550 million. That is over $300 million above what is in the budget papers. Why did you lie and why are you causing this effect on the Australian public?

—When those on the other side have nothing to stand on they come in here making false arguments and accusing us of lying. Senator Tambling has done it again. I will tell Senator Tambling something that is not a lie. I will tell Senator Tambling the impact of this particular measure as opposed to his contribution.
—Mr President, I rise to a point of order. Could he make that l-a-w law?
—That is facetious and not becoming of this place.

—This is the truth. It amounts to $400 on a $100,000 home under this measure compared with $4,000 on a $100,000 home on the last measure that the opposition proposed to the Australian public in Fightback. The opposition's GST measure would have cost $4,000 to the buyer of a $100,000 home. Even when we deduct all the taxes that apply to it, it is $4,000 as opposed to $400. That is where the opposition comes from. The opposition has absolutely no moral authority to come into this debate and accuse us of lying. Those opposite are the hypocrites. They have absolutely no policy to stand on. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. On 28-29 May a high level scientific conference jointly organised by the Commonwealth Department of Health and Melbourne University will be held on the subject of CJD. Dr Frank Peters, who has been working with the recipients of pituitary hormone made by CSL and who may be suing CSL and the department over this hormone treatment, enrolled for the conference but had his $200 enrolment fee returned with the explanation that the department considers it inappropriate for him, as an interested party in possible court proceedings, to attend this conference. Has the department now allowed Dr Peters to be enrolled for the conference but only after the minister received a copy of this question this morning? Does the minister agree that this is a scientific conference and should be totally unfettered, open and devoid of political interference? Is the government now trying not only to emasculate science in this country by turning it into the poor handmaiden of industry, but trying to turn it as well into the handmaiden of dirty politics?
—I have absolutely no information on that matter. I will take it on notice and see what I can find out for you.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the minister's department has set up a scientific research subcommittee of the National Pituitary Hormone Advisory Council and that Professor W.K. Whitten, an internationally recognised authority on reproductive physiology and pituitary hormones and a fellow of the Australian Academy of Science as a consequence of this expertise, was proposed as a member of this subcommittee but was rejected? Is it not a fact that Professor Whitten is also providing advice to the recipients of CSL-made pituitary hormones? Does the government seek to win a legal argument by restricting access, even to scientists, of important factual scientific information?
