—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley. I refer the minister to the recent outbreak of Japanese encephalitis on Badu Island in the Torres Strait where three people contracted the disease, two of them dying. In view of the federal government's stated increased commitment to Aboriginal and Islander health, can the minister tell the Senate what steps the Department of Health took when advised of the outbreak of encephalitis on Badu Island to stop the spread of the disease to other islands and to the mainland? How much money was allocated to assist the Islander community to eradicate and stop the spread of this disease?

—I am advised that primary responsibility for controlling the outbreak was undertaken by Queensland health and primary industry authorities in close liaison with the island council, the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health and the Commonwealth primary industry bodies. The major measure undertaken was to control the disease-carrying mosquitos. This has been successful in controlling the outbreak.

PARA.TAB: Further investigations are being carried out on Badu island and surrounding islands to establish whether there is a risk of the disease spreading in the future. Additional control measures will be determined by the results of those investigations. The situation is being closely monitored by the Communicable Disease Network of Australia and New Zealand, CDNANZ, which is the group of public health and communicable disease experts that is responsible for the coordination of communicable disease surveillance and control activities at both state and national levels.

Through the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, the CDNANZ has the capacity to provide additional assistance in outbreak situations. Queensland has not requested any additional assistance. I think Senator Boswell's question also included a request for information about the cost. I have not been provided with any information about that at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I take a point of order, Mr President. I was on my feet before Senator Evans stood.
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I was asked by Senator Baume earlier in the week about the presence of certain British parliamentarians at the Gallipoli ceremony and another question about hymn singing. May I respond as follows. The dawn service at Anzac Cove organised by the Australian Embassy in consultation with the New Zealand Embassy in Ankara was open to the public. The British Embassy in Ankara some days before the event sent a report to London which included the advice that the Australians and New Zealanders would be very pleased for anyone to come to the dawn service, mentioning, however, that there was unlikely to be space in the VIP enclosure as that had been organised.

PARA.TAB: I note from the Spectator article of 6 May that Senator Baume referred to that Lord Bethell quotes the UK Foreign Office in London as saying that the service was the `Aussies show'. No mention is made in this article of any advice given by Australian Foreign Affairs officials. If indeed any British parliamentarians were under the impression from any contacts they may have had with Australian Foreign Affairs officials that they had been asked not to attend the service, I can only say that there must have been some misunderstanding.

The cemetery area was expected to be crowded, but anyone wanting to attend would have been welcome to join those present, as Lord Bethell and one other British MP did. It is certainly not, I reconfirm, Australian government policy to exclude our friends from commemorative services such as those at Gallipoli. In the event that in the future with appropriate notice being given it was anticipated that some VIP presence would be there, I am sure we would find it possible to accommodate them in an appropriate way, perhaps in a more appropriate way than on this occasion.

On the second question, I can tell the Senate that I am advised that it has not been customary in recent years to have hymns at the Anzac Cove and Lone Pine ceremonies. It was decided for 1995 that in addition to various addresses and wreath laying the playing of national anthems would be a sufficient and dignified musical conclusion to these ceremonies. Accordingly, recordings of the Australian and New Zealand national anthems were played at Anzac Cove and the Australian national anthem at Lone Pine. A New Zealand Queen's bagpiper and an Australian piper played at Anzac Cove. The Australian piper also played at Lone Pine.

While I am on my feet, on the same subject, might I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard, if I may, the text of the report to me which I received earlier this week from the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on the events at Anzac Cove. I table that report and the accompanying documentation, which is voluminous.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it say, though?
—Are you seeking to table or incorporate parts of it or what?
—I table the whole document. I do not seek leave for that, as even Senator Kemp would know. I seek leave to incorporate, for the convenience of honourable senators, the text of the report itself.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: REPORT ON ALLEGED PROBLEMS ARISING AT THE EIGHTIETH COMMEMORATION OF ANZAC DAY, GALLIPOLI, 25 APRIL 1995

PARA.TAB: The Eightieth Commemoration of ANZAC Day at Gallipoli involved a series of events spread out over the Gallipoli Peninsula. They were attended by President Demirel of Turkey, official representatives of the Governments of Australia, Canada, Germany, New Zealand, Pakistan, the United Kingdom and Turkey and thousands of people who had made their own way to the events.

ANSWER.PARA: the Governor-General, Mrs Hayden and delegation of 10
the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan and delegation of 5
the Minister of Veterans' Affairs, Mr Sciacca and Ms Sciacca and delegation of 23 including 9 descendants of Australian Gallipoli veterans, plus at least 10 Australian media representatives
6 Australian Parliamentarians, 5 of whom were accompanied by their spouses.

3.The battle area of the Gallipoli Peninsula is isolated (about six hours from Istanbul by road) and lacks the facilities to cope with large numbers of official visitors and crowds such as attended the ceremonies. The roads between the various memorials are for the most part single lane and include dirt tracks. The nearest city, Cannakale, is a 5 kilometre ferry ride from the Peninsula via Eceabat. Communications between the memorials are limited as they are spread out and, I am advised, mobile telephones do not function effectively in the area. Moreover, ordinary walkie-talkie systems do not operate successfully in the Lone Pine area. To have had available a satisfactory mobile communications system, it appears we would have had to bring in an Australian military communications unit. We have only done this once, on the 75th anniversary ceremony in 1990, when the Australian presence and resources committed were very much greater than on this occasion. While the Embassy has suggested that perhaps it should have considered this further, in my view it would have been extremely unlikely that we would have agreed to such a large scale and expensive undertaking on this occasion which while larger than normal was much smaller than in 1990. Furthermore, our Embassy in Turkey, including Ambassador Evans and Senior Administrative Officer Perry, have over the last few years successfully conducted ANZAC Day ceremonies on the Peninsula without access to such communications systems.
4.Security on the Peninsula was extremely heavy due to the presence of President Demirel and other dignitaries and in the wake of a terrorist bombing in Istanbul on the weekend prior to ANZAC Day.

5.On 13 April, the Australian Embassy cabled relevant authorities in Canberra, including to Minister Sciacca's Department, on the conditions at Gallipoli which included a warning of likely traffic and crowd congestion and tight security. (See Attachment 1).

6.The Australian Embassy also issued notes for visitors drawing attention to the difficult security and transport conditions on the Peninsula. It was also noted, specifically, that the international ceremony was some 30 minutes drive from Lone Pine; that it may be difficult to get to Lone Pine in time for the start of the ceremony at that location; and that because of the day's tight schedule, it would not be possible to delay the commencement time of the ceremony. (See Attachment 2).
7.The Turkish Government controlled the movement of official guests to Gallipoli and between the various memorials. Its security forces were handicapped by the poor communications on the Peninsula.

8.The Australian Embassy is a small operation and had limited resources to support the extraordinarily high numbers of official visitors, to arrange official participation in the ceremonies and to organise the Dawn Service at ANZAC Cove and the Australian service at Lone Pine. It also had to manage an official visit by Senator McMullan and his party to Istanbul and Ankara on 26-28 April, including a Joint Economic Committee meeting in Ankara on 27 April involving some 16 Australian business persons. Its resources were supplemented by the services of a Departmental officer from Damascus from mid-March (excepting the week of Easter) and a relief communicator from London for the weeks before and during ANZAC Day plus two additional locally engaged staff. The Post's communications system was upgraded and additional funds of, initially, $40,000 were provided on the understanding that additional funds would be made available to meet extra legitimate costs. However two key locally engaged officers went on sick leave for the last one and a half months and three weeks respectively of preparations which placed unforeseen pressures on the Post. A paper on the Post's resources situation is at Attachment 3.
9.The following sets out my understanding of the three main problems that occurred at the ceremonies based on reports prepared by officers at the scene. These reports are at Attachments 4-10.
(i) The Late Commencement of the Dawn Service at ANZAC Cove

10.The Dawn Service at ANZAC Cove itself was organised by the Australian Embassy but the transport of official Australian and New Zealand guests to the ceremony was dependent on the Turkish authorities. It was scheduled to begin at 5.30 a.m. but the crowd began gathering from 3.00 a.m. Minister Sciacca, who gave the welcoming address, and his party were in place by 5.00 a.m.

11.The start of the ceremony was delayed until around 6.20 a.m., some 20 to 30 minutes after first light, by the delayed arrival of the official Australian and New Zealand parties including the Governor-General and New Zealand's Deputy Prime Minister. The Turkish authorities have stated that sunrise was not until 6.22 a.m. but first light was, in fact, well before 6.00 a.m.

12.I am satisfied that the cause of the delay to the Dawn Service was due entirely to events outside the control of the Australian authorities. The vessel "Akdeniz" which transported the official parties to the Peninsula was late departing and arriving, even though all foreign official guests were on board as scheduled. Apparently its departure was due to the late arrival of Turkish medical equipment. The vessel made up some lost time but the docking and ferrying of the official parties by the Turkish authorities was also delayed apparently due to logistical problems. The Australian Embassy had earlier explored with the Turkish authorities the possibility of other means of transport for the official parties to the Peninsula (e.g. by helicopter) but the Turkish authorities decided on transport and accommodation on the Akdeniz, as was their prerogative.

13.The media have raised the question as to whether the Dawn Service at ANZAC Cove should have started on time in the absence of the Governor-General and the other official guests who were delayed including New Zealand Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition. Those who were late included most of the main official participants and speakers. In my view the answer to this question is clearly "no". It may be a matter for consideration as to whether in future there should be a broadly acknowledged rule that dawn services are to start on time even in the absence of official dignitaries. No such rule has existed to this time, however, and in its absence a decision to start without the official party, including the Governor-General as Australia's Head of State, would have been quite wrong.
(ii) The Late Arrival of Minister Sciacca and Party at the Ceremony at Lone Pine

14.The Lone Pine ceremony was originally scheduled to start at 11.50 a.m. but was re-scheduled two weeks earlier to commence at 12.15 p.m. It commenced on time with the Australian military guard, whose arrival had been delayed, moving quickly into position and the MC then calling the Australian Ambassador to address the audience. (The purpose of the Ambassador's unscheduled comments was to apologise for the delay in the Dawn Service at ANZAC Cove). The MC has stated that he commenced the Service after the military guard had marched into position; "At no stage did anyone state that the Service was not to commence without him [Mr Sciacca]. It was apparent that the Officials' Party were in place and that we were well past the start time. No attempt was made to further delay the commencement when I moved to the rostrum". (See Attachment 7).

15.The MC then asked Minister Sciacca to deliver his address. When it became evident that the Minister was not present, Senator McMullan took the microphone, apologised for the absence of the Minister and delivered the Minister's speech. The Governor-General then spoke. Minister Sciacca and his party arrived some 7 minutes after the commencement of the ceremony, towards the end of the Governor-General's speech, and were able to join the official party for the rest of the ceremony, including laying of wreaths and being present for the Last Post.

16.Following the ceremony Minister Sciacca sought to establish who had commenced the ceremony prior to his arrival. The Ambassador apologised for this development and told the Minister that he took responsibility for this. Minister Sciacca expressed the view that "heads had to roll" and formed the view that the main person to blame was the Senior Administration Officer from the Australian Embassy. He advised the Australian media that he was "extremely disappointed and extremely angry, and whoever did this, I want their head." (See Attachment 13).

17.It appears that the late arrival of Minister Sciacca and his party at Lone Pine was due to his bus being blocked by other vehicles at the International Ceremony at the Monument of Martyrs. I have established that the Minister's party had been briefed by the Embassy on what needed to be done to get its bus into position to make a speedy exit from that Monument. There was no delay in boarding the bus. The Minister's bus had been issued with a pass as required by the Turkish authorities, but this pass was not respected by all security personnel involved. As noted above, such potential problems were foreseen by the Australian Embassy and it had earlier suggested to Minister Sciacca that he should travel by car rather than by bus. The Minister, understandably, chose to travel with his delegation.

18.It is clear that no official in authority was aware before the ceremony commenced that Minister Sciacca and his party were not present. (One more junior official at the Embassy became aware of his absence but not in time to be able to alert those in authority of this fact before the ceremony commenced.)

19.The question arises as to why officials in authority did not notice the absence of Mr Sciacca and his party. Mr Perry and some others were caught up attending to last minute administrative problems that had arisen because of some unexpected actions on the Turkish side, and some other essential problems which had arisen. The Ambassador was engaged with the Governor-General and was focussing on his own presentation. The Governor-General and Senator McMullan had been present for some 10 minutes. Both had important commitments involving President Demirel following the Lone Pine ceremony and there was already pressure on their availability to meet these commitments, since the start time had been moved from 11.50 a.m. to 12.15 p.m. precisely in order to allow more time for people to arrive from the international ceremony.

20.I would also make the point that even had Minister Sciacca's absence been noted prior to 12.15 p.m., officials would have had no way of knowing how long he would have been delayed. (I have dealt in paragraph 3 above with the reasons for not having a local communications network available). The difficulties in travelling by road to Lone Pine due particularly to extremely heavy security and the consequent uncertainty of possible arrival times has been reinforced by the Australian military commander, Lt Col O'Brien. Had, moreover, officials delayed the commencement of the ceremony, they would probably have been criticised by the Australian media for again delaying a ceremony due to the late arrival of official guests, as they did with respect to the Dawn Service. In these circumstances, officials would have been in a "no-win" situation even in the hypothetical situation of having known of the absence of Mr Sciacca and his party. I have to say that had in fact Mr Sciacca's absence been known, and had, in fact, it been known how far away he was, it would have been a matter for fine judgement to have delayed the ceremony given the delays of the morning and given the Governor-General and Senator McMullan's subsequent commitments to President Demirel.

21.The Ambassador has publicly and privately accepted responsibility for the incident. I would therefore suggest that the Ambassador's apology to Minister Sciacca following the ceremony, and his subsequent written apology to the Minister (Attachment 17) and to each of the pilgrims on the Minister's delegation is a sufficient response to the situation.
(iii) The Demonstration on the Road to Lone Pine

22.On his way from the New Zealand national ceremony to the "Akdeniz", Senator McMullan's car was stopped by a large crowd of Australians who had been prevented from attending the Australian ceremony at Lone Pine by Turkish security police. Senator McMullan immediately negotiated with the Turkish authorities to allow them to proceed to Lone Pine where he conducted an impromptu service for the demonstrators.
23.Senator McMullan's initiative averted a potentially dangerous situation. There is nothing to suggest that the cause of the situation could be laid at the feet of any Australian official.

24.It is my view that the Australian Embassy carried out an extremely demanding and complex task in a professional manner, involving much voluntary after hours work and great dedication. All ceremonies on the day were conducted with due dignity and sense of historic occasion. The New Zealand Ambassador has written to thank the Embassy for organising the "truly memorable and very moving" Dawn Service in "extremely difficult" circumstances (Attachment 14). The Governor-General considers the commemorations were very successful and has written in strong support of the Ambassador and his staff. The Australian military commander has written that Mr Perry on behalf of the Embassy prepared and handled the ANZAC day ceremonies extremely well and that the difficulties were principally a result of changes made by Turkish authorities at short notice or as a result of the extremely tight security. His report also noted that Mr Perry prepared the ceremonies with good attention to detail (Attachment 7). While it is a fact that the problems that arose on this occasion were a matter within the mandate of Turkish authorities, I do not think for a moment that any criticism should be levelled at them. The ANZAC Day ceremonies now involve a multitude of countries and ceremonies at a variety of locations and at a variety of times. Turkey's own national ceremonies also take place. Turkey devotes enormous resources to this effort in very trying circumstances and has over many years shown great generosity of spirit and magnificent practical assistance in our commemoration of this important day in our year.

25.Staff were personally as well as professionally deeply disappointed that, despite their efforts, events did not go entirely as planned, even though they had anticipated the potential for problems and had advised visitors accordingly. For our Embassy in Turkey the ANZAC Day tradition looms extremely large, particularly when officers like Ambassador Evans and Mr Perry have devoted great effort over several years to carrying out successfully the Anzac Day major ceremonies outside Australia. There can be few people more devoted than our officers in our Embassy in Turkey in making sure the Anzac Day ceremonies are a success. The three glitches in the ceremonies were all due to events that were beyond the control of Australian authorities. The fact that Minister Sciacca and his delegation missed the start of the Lone Pine ceremony was deeply regrettable but, on measured reflection, it is also understandable how this happened. It would in my view be unjustified to seek to attribute blame to either the Embassy or any other Australian authority for this incident. The Ambassador has, nevertheless, accepted responsibility and has formally apologised to the Minister and to the pilgrims and I believe no further action is warranted and that the Embassy is to be commended for its sterling efforts over the last few months.

26.We will be giving further careful consideration as to how arrangements for future ceremonies at Gallipoli might be improved so as to minimise the risk of the types of problems addressed above. Following are, however, some initial thoughts:

The Department provided most of the additional resources requested by the Post. It is clear that Embassy officers were still under severe strain, exacerbated by unexpected absences. However, the incidents that occurred on the day would not seem to have been directly related to the resourcing of the Mission.
We should look again at the extent to which other agencies participating in the ceremonies can contribute resources and be more directly involved in the planning processes.
We need to look again at whether there are viable, cost effective mobile communications systems that would function effectively at Gallipoli.

We need to discuss again with the Turkish authorities whether there can be a further improvement on such issues as the timing of the events, the effective use of security passes for official guests, their transport arrangements and the use of police escorts (but bearing in mind that we are guests in their country and that they expend considerable resources in organising the commemorations).

TALK.START.PARA: —That report—which includes full-scale reports from each of the players involved on the Australian embassy side and on the military side, including the MC and so on—makes clear that a series of unfortunate happenings occurred which cannot really be attributed to the responsibility of any individual. It was a complicated series of administrative difficulties. Certainly, so far as the Governor-General's late arrival at the dawn service is concerned, it is made absolutely clear that that was a problem with the transport coming from Istanbul and in no way attributable to any actions of the Governor-General himself or any other individual on the Australian side.

PARA.TAB: So far as the Lone Pine ceremony is concerned, it makes absolutely clear that there was no decision made by anyone to proceed with that service in the absence of Mr Sciacca and the pilgrims. The proceedings simply went ahead at the due time because it had not been noticed in the swirl of events, which is fully explained here, that Mr Sciacca and the pilgrims had not turned up. It was not as if there were empty seats on a dais or anything of this kind, it was just a large crowd milling around. The assumption had been made that of course they were there because they were seen to have left at the time that others had left.
Senator Chapman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter for some argument. I think Mr Simmons's contribution to the debate this morning was rather unfortunately robust in all the circumstances, in particular to the extent that he directs his fire at a very junior member of the Ankara embassy in circumstances which she denies in her own report which is appended here. I do not think it serves any purpose to rake over the coals on this. No doubt some of you will be minded to do so. Do so in estimates till your hearts are content and we can respond to you there. But I do not think it serves the dignity of the occasion to further pursue it in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Gareth Evans for providing the parliament with this report, which I understand was in one way or another presented to the caucus earlier this week. Having been at the ceremony along with Senator Chapman and Senator Teague, who is not here, I had an opportunity to see what actually happened. I regret to tell the minister—and I am not going to develop this at great length here—that the version he has just given us is not accurate. Someone in his department has unfortunately set out to mislead the minister.

PARA.TAB: While I do not support all the points made by two of the members of his own party in the House of Representatives this morning, I do want to say that the bulk of what Mr David Simmons had to say was in my view an accurate reflection of what happened. I saw him in an agitated state. I could not hear exactly what he was saying, but I saw him in discussion with a junior member of the staff of the Ankara embassy. Immediately after that, he expressed to me his outrage that she had refused to convey his demand that the proceedings should not proceed because Mr Sciacca was not there. Unfortunately, Mr Simmons was in mid-argument with this junior official when the proceedings started. So it was then out of his hands and he could not himself go over and instruct the captain, who was totally blameless in this matter and who was the Master of Ceremonies, not to proceed.

I cannot tell the minister how dreadfully embarrassing and upsetting it was at that ceremony—Senator McMullan was there and is aware of this—for the captain to call on the minister, Mr Sciacca, to welcome people to this ceremony for the 80th anniversary of Gallipoli, for the minister not to be there and for a subdued laugh, I suppose you could call it, to go around this solemn ceremony: a laugh at the incompetence of Australian officialdom. It was terribly depressing.

All of us who were there felt not only embarrassment but anger that the centrepiece of that ceremony, which was to have been the pilgrims presenting their wreaths and mementoes—a matter of enormous significance—did not proceed as it should have and that there was this rush at the end. I commend Senator McMullan for stepping forward and filling the breach when Mr Sciacca's name was called and he did not respond.

I say to the minister that when you are in charge of a function it is a basic rule of conducting any function at all that you establish before you begin, particularly such a solemn ceremony as this, that the participants are there. Maybe it was just a mistake but it was a mistake of horrendous proportions from anyone who was in charge of such a thing. It put Australia's good name at risk—in fact, it made us a muttered laughing stock—and it damaged a very solemn occasion.

However, it is most unfortunate that the Governor-General has been subjected to criticism on his role in this matter. I think that is grossly unfair. When you are a head of state at an event, as he was, it would have been improper for him to have intervened. I am certain that he was not aware that Mr Sciacca was not there. We were all separate; we were put to one side. The minister was to one side. It was a situation where, quite frankly, the organisation was inadequate.

On the other hand, I would like to stress that the Ambassador to Turkey, David Evans, always behaved in his dealings with me—and, I am certain, with my colleagues—with the utmost courtesy. He was very helpful to us. I would not want to suggest that damage or blame should be attributed to him in any of these matters. I suppose we can say that because a junior member of his staff may not have acted properly that he has to bear the ultimate responsibility. That seems a bit tough. The Governor-General was totally blameless and was caught in the involvement of the particular problems that the Turks had and was not in a position to defend himself. It is unfortunate that he should be criticised. I would certainly seek, in a bipartisan way, to defend him.

I thank the minister for his comment that for some years now at Gallipoli hymns have not been sung. I find that to be just dreadful. The dawn services that I attend every year in Australia have always relied on the participation of a religious, as well as a secular, form of service. A dawn service without, for example, Abide with me, does not represent the sort of dawn service most of us have known all our lives. I do not know who made this decision but I regret it. I regret the nature of the decision because I do not think anyone on this side of the chamber was aware that it had been made.

I do not think it right that one should make too much of this situation. I understand that members of the media were not properly accommodated, which got them off side. The whole thing was a real problem. There are some people who read deeper things into this, saying that it is part of some republican agenda and so on.

All that concerns me is that there was a mistake. It would be better for DFAT to acknowledge the mistake rather than to pretend that there was no mistake and that it was just a series of unfortunate coincidences. I must admit that I am simply depending—because I have not had the opportunity of reading this; I will read it later—on what I understand was said about this matter in the Labor caucus room. I think it a bit unfair for the minister to say that Mr Simmons was intemperate and that this situation arose simply because no-one had noticed that Mr Sciacca was not there.

Mr Sciacca is someone very difficult not to notice, even in a crowd of that size, and so would be a contingent of pilgrims specifically dressed in very distinctive blazers and uniforms who were to play such an important role in this ceremony. On top of that, I can confirm—as I am certain Senator Chapman can—that an official of that embassy was apprised of the fact that Mr Sciacca and the pilgrims were not there and that the ceremony should not proceed. She took the view that she could not, and should not, limit or delay the proceedings. I do not put all the blame on her, but any official running any function whatsoever should ensure that the participants are there before allowing it to start.

I thank the minister and stress to him that I am taking a totally bipartisan view. I do not want to take any political shots at anyone on this, because I think it is far too important a point. Members of the minister's own party have been far more critical of this matter than I have. I conclude by commending Senator McMullan for his role then and later, when he corrected an oversight. I understand that he participated in a much more moving ceremony at Lone Pine than the one that Senator Chapman, Senator Teague and I had attended.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! During question time Senator Tambling, in addressing a question to Senator Bolkus, said `Why did you lie?' I did not say anything at the time; I let it pass. But I should have said something as it is important not to let the standards in this place diminish. Senator Tambling, I would ask you in the interests of those standards to withdraw that, retrospectively.

—by leave—Mr President, I am cognisant of your comments, and I certainly will withdraw my remark. It was intended in the context of the government plurally. I ask that you look at the Hansard and make sure that any similar comments that were made on the other side are dealt with equally.
—I am happy to look at the Hansard.

—by leave—I want to reinforce the request put to you by Senator Tambling. I noticed that your face did not appear to flicker much when Senator Gareth Evans was happy to call us a bunch of shonks, when he said that Senator Alston was nothing other than a shonk and that none of us could lie straight in bed. If you can see a difference between the implication that we are a bunch of liars and the straight statement to this lot—who, in fact, are a bunch of liars—good luck to you! I look forward to an explanation of why you correct Senator Tambling, but you do not bother to mention this minister.

—I think you have just damaged your case. If you had been watching me, you would have noticed that I winced when Senator Evans said that. I did not say anything in the interests of getting through question time in an orderly way.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You say I may have damaged my case by referring to this lot directly to you as a bunch of liars. Frankly, you damage your own. You point out that you noticed what Senator Evans said, that you winced and you were unhappy with the comment, but you did not stop him at the time to let question time flow freely. I could understand if, after question time, as you picked up Senator Tambling, you had also picked up Senator Evans. But, of course, you did not. You have ruined your own case.
—The term `liar' is clearly against the standing orders and, through a series of precedents, has been for many years. The term `shonk' is a new one to me. I am not even totally sure what it means.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak at length on the motion. Senator Michael Baume has detailed quite effectively the bungles and difficulties associated with the commemoration of Anzac Day at Anzac Cove and Lone Pine. I want to reinforce the veracity of what he said, in all detail, and also what I understand the Hon. David Simmons said in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I simply give an example from my situation there. I think the Hon. David Simmons has referred to this in the House of Representatives. There was clearly a bungle on the part of representatives of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I had ordered two wreaths for presentation at the Lone Pine ceremony, one for me to lay and another for my young son to lay. He wished to represent his school, a number of old scholars of which had served and died at Gallipoli.

When we arrived for the Lone Pine ceremony, lo and behold, only one wreath could be produced, despite the fact that I had previously ordered two. After some time of rustling around, a second wreath miraculously appeared; so that problem was solved. However, a wreath could not subsequently be found for Mr Ted Lindsay to lay at the Lone Pine ceremony, despite his having ordered one. This simply reinforces the unsatisfactory way in which this matter was managed and administered by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I reinforce that the report, which I will read with interest but which apparently attempts to whitewash these incidents, is false in a number of respects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to reflect on the sincerity of Senator Baume's and Senator Chapman's concerns about this matter—I was aware of them at the time—but I think it unfortunate that we are having this debate before anyone has read the report. That seems to me not to be very clever. I think it might be more helpful if we did so subsequently because the report is more balanced than the comments up to now have suggested. People have made an interpretation without having had a chance to look at the report. It seems to be a very odd procedure; and I would prefer to wait.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to get involved in a debate about the merits. If there is a debate after the report has been read, I will join it. I thank Senator Baume for the comments he made about me. I have had a very brief opportunity to hear the comments made in the House of Representatives. My concern is that individual officers, some of whom were not in a position to rectify the problem, even if they were aware of it, are being criticised beyond any reasonable interpretation of the circumstances.

It is not a game we are playing. This is about the lives and careers of people who worked extremely hard to make events that are important to all Australians meaningful to the thousands of people who were there. We ought to be a bit more careful about the way we throw around our criticisms of participants and officers of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to place on record what happened.

—I accept the legitimacy of Senator Baume's interpretation, although I do not entirely agree with it. There is no point in my pretending otherwise. I have said in public in Australia for reporting purposes and elsewhere that there was a serious administrative error. That remains my view. It is what I said at the time, and it is my view now. It is reflected in the report. That is why I think we would be better having the debate after people have read it.

PARA.TAB: I have wanted to come to the defence of some of the officers of the department and to reinforce the view that, despite what did take place, notwithstanding all the administrative problems—some of them were of Australian making and some were not—both the dawn service and the Lone Pine service were significant, moving events. Hundreds of Australians in one instance and thousands in the other got great pleasure and comfort from those events. They should not be undermined by our seeking to focus on the inadequacies, although I accept that they were there and should not have been there.

We should place on the record that these were distinguished, solemn, serious events worthy of the circumstances. Notwithstanding the problems, it was an honour for me to participate in them. Madam Deputy President, this is the first time that I have had a chance to speak since you have occupied that post. Congratulations to you. If we are going to pursue this matter any further, I would prefer that we did it on the basis of people having had a chance to read the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I too join with my colleague in congratulating you. This has been my first opportunity to do so. This is an important debate. I have listened very carefully to the comments of all those who have participated. I do not wish to spend time unduly on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I want to reiterate one of the queries that Senator Baume brought to the attention of the Senate. It would come as a great surprise to most Australians that someone perhaps one, two or three years ago decided that it was not appropriate to sing a hymn at an Anzac service. I would like the minister to explain to the Senate when that decision was made—

TALK.START.PARA: —What decision?

—The decision to not have a hymn at an Anzac service. I would like to know when and why that decision was made. To be quite frank, I believe that most Australians would be shocked by it. Every survey that I have seen shows that the vast majority of Australians describe themselves as Christian.
—It is not quite a dawn service without a hymn.

—That is the case. Most Australians take their dawn services with great seriousness. Most Australians would still describe themselves as Christian. Most Australians, even those who do not describe themselves of that faith, find no problem in having a hymn at a dawn service. I put that point to Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: About 12 months ago, a similar problem occurred with the entombment of the unknown soldier. Certainly vast numbers of the Australian soldiers who went to Gallipoli would describe themselves as Christian. It is surprising that someone in a department has made a unilateral decision that it is not appropriate in 1993, 1994, or 1995 to have a hymn. I would certainly welcome an explanation from the minister as to why that decision was taken. I urge the minister to ensure that that decision is immediately reversed and that we revert to the tradition which this country has had for many years, which is that a hymn is sung at such a service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to seek further information and ponder its implications.
—I wish to ask a question.

—It is a little unfortunate when, by the mere device of putting an answer down after question time, you get into an open-ended, extended debate just by allowing one person the courtesy of a quick response. That is not the intention. This really ought to come out of the time period devoted to debating answers to questions.
—Well, answer them in question time, and they will.

—We give you the courtesy of allowing you the full question time, putting down an answer to something that was asked earlier in the week after question time, and then we waste a great block of time. I will give you leave to ask a question, but that is it.

—Madam Deputy President, I have a procedural question for you. I feel very strongly about this matter, even though I was not there. Should this debate be adjourned, or should we take note of the answer? I would like to come back to it when I have had the opportunity to read the report.
—Senator Crane, you are at liberty to move the adjournment of this debate if you wish.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Crane) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the 30-day rule contained in procedural order No. 16, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts for an explanation of why I have not been provided with answers to questions Nos 2048, 2049, 2050, 2051 and 2052 which I put on notice on 8 March 1995 and which concern certain public sector staff and equipment matters.

—Questions 2049 to 2052 are the questions put to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The minister or the department—it is not clear to me which one—wrote to Senator Ellison on 19 April 1995 indicating that the questions relate to a number of issues ranging across various areas of the department. Many of the questions comprise around 100 parts in total are both detailed and complex. They relate to individual cases and events that occurred over two years ago. Therefore, the effort in compiling this information is quite considerable.

PARA.TAB: The minister has been advised by his department that the draft responses are nearing completion and should be available shortly. I am not in a position to give an exact time, but I will make personal representations on behalf of Senator Ellison to make sure that they are available to him by the next sitting week. That is all the information I have.

I have some information on question No. 2048, which relates to Telstra's acquisition of office equipment. There was an initial draft of the answer. My advice is that the minister thought it did not adequately respond to Senator Ellison's concerns and he sought more information. I was hoping that I would have that by today. It is very close to being ready. I will similarly seek to make representations. On the basis of the advice so far, there should be no problems. Not being within my personal responsibility, I cannot guarantee that it will be available by the next sitting week. I wish that I could be more forthcoming, Senator Ellison. I think senators need to realise, as I think Senator Ellison does, that when questions are asked with so many subparts over such a long period of time there is sometimes a delay in providing the answer. I can only assure him that the two ministers concerned and I are endeavouring to get the answers for him as promptly as we responsibly can.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the minister's explanation, I move:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the table, on or before 19 May 1995, by the Minister representing the Ministers for Communications and the Arts and Administrative Services, answers to questions on notice Nos 2048 to 2052, relating to public sector staff and equipment matters.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Agreement has been reached with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) that straight after question time and before motions to take note of answers to questions I should seek leave to move a congratulatory motion to David Adams who has just won the around the world yacht race. I seek leave to do so.
