SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Campbell this day, relating to the land acquision fund.

SPEECH.PARA: During question time, I asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), a question about the decision on 30 March or thereabouts by ATSIC to provide $20 million out of a total allocation of $24 million over the next two financial years to acquire land in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: During the debate in this chamber over the indigenous land fund bill, before the finance and public administration committee hearing into that bill and indeed before the Senate select committee's hearings into that bill, we raised on a number of occasions, as did Senator Chamarette from the Greens (WA) and my colleague Senator Ellison, concerns that splitting the moneys available under the land fund allocation between ATSIC and the Indigenous Land Corporation would ensure that a commitment made to the Northern Territory government that there would be no massive increase in funds flowing into the Territory for acquisition of lands which could then be transferred to inalienable freehold title would not be met.

We received assurances from a number of ministers, including the minister in the chamber here today, Senator Collins, that the government's agreement with the Territory was indeed that that would not occur. On this matter on 16 November 1994, Senator Collins indeed went so far as to say this:
The only fear that would then be raised, and I am prepared to bet large sums of money that this is not going to happen, is that the $21 million of ATSIC funds would be used

SPEECH.PARA: —this is what Marshall Perron was referring to in terms of his reference to double dealing;
and it is a nonsense scenario—exclusively or largely—

TALK.START.PARA: —Per year.
—Not over a year, Senator Collins—

SPEECH.PARA: over the next three years to purchase land in the Northern Territory to the exclusion of everywhere else in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, I think it is less than half that.
—Senator Collins, we could have a long debate over the specifics.
—Not today.
—We will not today—over the specifics of your words and whether you meant $21 million a year or $21 million over three years.

PARA.TAB: But the reality of all this when you take away the semantics of whether it is new money, old money or whatever is that historically in the Northern Territory ATSIC has been putting into acquisition as opposed to management somewhere in the vicinity of $2 million to $4 million a year purchasing one or two stations—and Senator Evans confirmed that and Senator Collins knows that—under the LAMP, the land acquisition and management program.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an average of one.

—Senator Collins has corrected me. But the reality is that $10 million will go in, not $2 million or $3 million. That represents a fourfold or fivefold increase in the funds going into the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: We explained to the Senate that the reason ATSIC would keep receiving this $21 million a year until 1997 was to get around the promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Northern Territory, and his assurances to every Aboriginal in Australia, that this would not be a back door method of increasing the amount of pastoral land bought in the Northern Territory. On two or three occasions in the Senate—the Hansard is there for everybody to read—Senator Collins said that was not the reason things were being done in this way. He said it was agreed by all parties concerned that this was a sensible transitional arrangement. Certainly, it was a matter raised by a lot of senators in the debate at the time.

I point out the reference on page 3 of the ATSIC policy document to special treatment for the Northern Territory with respect to land acquisition from ATSIC's land acquisition and management program in line with discussions with the government and the restrictions of the bill. I ask the minister to come back to this place and tell us whether this back door method of a fourfold or fivefold increase in purchases of land in the Northern Territory is, as ATSIC has said unequivocally on page 3 of its policy document, special treatment for the Northern Territory that was indeed discussed with the government. I seek leave to table that policy document.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, as I explained earlier to Senator Campbell, I must leave the Senate chamber shortly to address the annual conference of the Australian Wool Council. No doubt this matter will be revisited but for the moment I simply reiterate what I said during question time today.

PARA.TAB: The Hansard record speaks for itself. I certainly do not place an interpretation on what was said there, although Senator Campbell obviously does. I have read it and Senator Gareth Evans has succinctly put his views about it. I also spoke to the chair of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, today to express my personal concern about the matter.

As Senator Campbell would accept, I am not the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs so I am not in a position to unilaterally say what the government's position will be on this matter. The statements I made to the Senate during the ATSIC debate were based on my knowledge that three and sometimes four—depending on Yami Lester's election—of the 19 ATSIC commissioners were from the Northern Territory. At the time I thought that achieving that against all the odds was testimony to the persuasive powers of Northern Territorians. It was on that basis that I made the statement that there would be some concern expressed by other ATSIC commissioners.

I am told that the decision was a controversial one—the fact that Senator Campbell has the advantage of leaked papers indicates the level of disaffection with the decision—that the ATSIC board was split and that it took a casting vote by the chair to determine the issue. That was of concern to me and, as a courtesy, I expressed that concern to Lois O'Donoghue before the matter was raised in the Senate. I will continue to pursue that concern.

As I said in question time today, now that this matter is in the public domain—I was not aware of it until 48 hours ago—views are now being expressed by Aboriginal organisations in Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland. Eventually, ATSIC itself will have to address the matter.

As Senator Evans said, the government will consider the decision taken by the ATSIC board. I am concerned about it—although I acknowledge the absolute right of the ATSIC board to make it—because it was a split decision determined by the casting vote of the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obliged to Senator Chamarette for allowing me to have priority to speak on this matter. I might say at the outset that the coalition shares the concern of Senator Bob Collins in relation to this latest event because during the debate on the land fund bill it was made abundantly clear that the money in excess of the $20 million allocated each year to ATSIC would not all go to expenditure on acquisition of land in the Northern Territory. That comprises roughly half of the total annual sum allowed for acquisition of land for Aboriginal people. It would be unfair if half of the total expenditure was spent in only one area of Australia; namely, a territory which does not have a majority of the Aboriginal population in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have the potential for creating great division in the Aboriginal community because ATSIC has embarked upon a decision which will allow up to 50 per cent of expenditure for land acquisition to be spent on just one area—Aboriginal people within the Northern Territory. Of course, Aboriginal people in Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania would feel left out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the ACT while we are here.

—And the ACT. That is why the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council is taking action and complaining bitterly about this, because this decision will leave it out in the cold. When we debated how the money would be dealt with, the coalition expressed great reservation about this funding being reserved to ATSIC. We were told, `Look, don't worry. It won't all be spent in the Northern Territory. We will continue to acquire land on the basis that we have been purchasing it to date.' That is roughly, I think, a station or two a year, but it is certainly nothing in the order of $20 million. If you average it out at $2 million a station, it would be 10 stations a year. That is just unfair.

PARA.TAB: I believe this decision needs looking into. It really does cast some doubt on the accountability of this Indigenous Land Corporation, which is set up under the land fund and has this autonomy in purchasing land. There should be some review of how it will operate. We heard Senator Collins saying that the government really does not have any control over ATSIC's purchasing ability or decisions. I can understand how people say, `Well, ATSIC should be autonomous,' but the problem is that, when it makes a decision of this sort, it has the potential to create great division within the Aboriginal community. That is harmful not only to the Aboriginal people of Australia but also to the wider community.

I believe the taxpayers of Australia have a right to see their money being spent in an even-handed manner; that is, you look across the country as a whole and you apportion the money in an even-handed way. This is not doing that. It is for that reason that this decision has to be criticised, and I am pleased to hear that Senator Collins is concerned about it. I do remember the debate in this chamber only too well when the government assured us that ATSIC would not be doing this very thing—that is, spending the vast majority of its land acquisition money in one area; namely, the Northern Territory.

Certainly, the people in the Northern Territory were of that view. The government must do more than just be concerned about this matter. It must take action to use its influence in relation to ATSIC to make sure that this does not go ahead. It casts doubt on how the Indigenous Land Corporation will operate. If it is going to make decisions in the future along the lines that we have just seen here, we will not get satisfaction for money. We will not get satisfaction for the Aboriginal people across Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to Senator Bob Collins's response as well as the related response to me from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). My question was not satisfactorily answered and I will certainly be awaiting a more adequate response when the Senate resumes if I have not received it beforehand.

PARA.TAB: I asked an important question: how much of the $18 million that has been set aside by ATSIC for land management over the next two years has been allocated to the Northern Territory? It is crucial information as to whether the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has misled this Senate and the public. In any case, I believe that the Senate and the public have been misled.

My distinct memory of Senator Collins's response—and I will have to check the Hansard record—is that he made a joke of the question that was put forward quite legitimately by Senator Campbell. Senator Collins said that it was nonsense, that it was not $20 million that had been put out of the $24 million but $20 million out of $42 million. He was deliberately overlooking the fact, when he stated that it was $42 million that had been set aside for land acquisition, that only $24 million has been set aside for land acquisition, of which the Northern Territory has certainly been granted $20 million by the ATSIC decision, and that $18 million has been set aside for land management.

No information is available to me as to how much of that will be taken up by the Northern Territory. If there is not a substantial proportion of it that is taken up, there should be. If that money is being given for land acquisition in the Northern Territory, there will certainly be land management needs. If that land management funding has not been given through this ATSIC funding, then there is another way in which it will impinge on the other half of the funding for the next two years which is actually part of the Indigenous Land Corporation land fund money of $21 million. That will mean that the amount that has been given to the Northern Territory for acquisition of land will then be required to be added to for management of those lands from funds available under the ILC component of the land fund.

These were the matters I raised in the debate on the land fund at the time. This underlies the orchestrated debate against the use of any kind of prioritising of needs in the allocation of the land fund money. I will quote something that I asked while the debate was going on because I think the deal and the double deal need to be on the public record. It should also be on the record that both Senator Collins, who answered my question in a very facetious way and basically denied the validity of my argument, and Senator Evans, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, have a responsibility here. The second tranche of the response to the High Court decision on Mabo is the responsibility of the government. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I would like to ask the minister to justify why this split is necessary, because I think it needs to be on the public record.

I was referring here to the split between the $21 million to ATSIC for the next two years to 1997, and the $21 million plus $3 million available to the ILC, because I think it needs to be on the public record. I continued:

What I have heard is that it was initially a deal with the Northern Territory government essentially against the interests of the Aboriginal people by preventing them from using any of the ILC funds under the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory. There was then a double deal—or a counter deal—with the Aboriginal people that said, `It's all right; half will still be going to ATSIC'
until 1997—
and then presumably to the Northern Territory people who would be disadvantaged by the first deal in order to gain access under the Land Rights Northern Territory Act.

PARA.TAB: So we have very strong evidence that the government was using its role within ATSIC to manipulate decisions within ATSIC which it needed for its own legislation and to support or substantiate the deals made between the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. I believe that the government has a question to answer. It needs to say whether it is supporting ATSIC's decisions—and why.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Collins has left the chamber because I do not like saying this in his absence. In entering into this debate I do not want to highlight the substantive matter which my colleagues Senator Campbell and Senator Ellison, and also Senator Chamarette, have correctly referred to. I want to point out that Senator Collins is a past master at doing what he has done in this particular instance. I was getting to my feet to warn Senator Chamarette, but it seems that I do not need to; I think she has seen through him.

PARA.TAB: It needs to be brought to the attention of the Senate and the public that Senator Collins is just so good at putting off the real issues by these flamboyant, glib promises and offerings. He did it at the time of the waterfront reform. He said, `I will resign if the waterfront is not fixed up' by a certain date. That is good enough in the political system, but I am concerned that people believe him because he sounds so genuine. It is a problem with the administration of this government. It is virtually attempted by all Labor ministers, but it is worse with Senator Collins because he says it with such gusto and people believe him.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a fan of Shakespeare.

—He is a fan of Shakespeare, as my colleague Senator Tambling says. Senator Collins does this and he gets away with it. The farmers of Australia are as impressed with him as were the wharf people and the shipping people. However, people must wake up that he is not what he appears to be.

PARA.TAB: In this particular instance Senator Collins said that he could not stay in the chamber to debate the matter: he had to get away and he could only stay 60 seconds. He told us that he had to get away for this particularly important speech, but he then spoke for four minutes. That is typical of this man. I do not criticise him personally; he is quite a nice sort of fellow. But as an administrator in the government he must be exposed.

Let me take the Senate back to the matter that Senator Collins and Senator Campbell were arguing about. There is no equivocation about what Senator Collins said; it is quite clear. Senator Collins blusters his way out of it, but it is clear from Hansard that he said this in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The only fear that would then be raised, and I am prepared to bet large sums of money that this is not going to happen, is that the $21 million of ATSIC funds would be used. . . exclusively or largely over the next three years to purchase land in the Northern Territory to the exclusion of everywhere else in Australia.
That is quite clear. Senator Collins is saying that he will bet a large sum of money. I wish Senator Chamarette had taken him up on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be a rich woman.

—You would be a rich woman, but he would not have paid you. He did not resign over the waterfront issue. Senator Collins said that he would bet that there will not be $21 million of ATSIC funds spent largely or exclusively on the purchase of land in the Northern Territory. My colleague Senator Campbell has clearly and correctly pointed to the minute of ATSIC decisions and policy options. It says in the minute that it was agreed by ATSIC to set aside $10 million for land purchases in the Northern Territory and $2 million for other priority national purchases in each of the next two years, with the balance of funds being allocated to land management. Senator Collins was prepared to bet large sums of money that that was not going to happen.

PARA.TAB: The point I make is that during debate he bluffs everyone with that bluster. He says, `Look, I will bet anything, I will give you any money you like if I am proved to be wrong.' So people, particularly gullible people, say, `We must believe him because he would not be going on like that.'

I think this minister has to be exposed. That is my purpose in entering into debate. I am sorry that Senator Collins is not here to listen. He chose to exempt himself and he can answer when he likes, sometime on. I am pleased to see that perhaps my warning was not necessary; it is quite obvious that his conduct has become clear at least to the Western Australian Greens. I suspect my colleagues down on the far left corner of the chamber still are fooled by Senator Collins and his colleagues with this bluff and bluster, but I am pleased to see that at least Senator Chamarette and her colleague are awake to this minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Carr this day, relating to the 1995-96 budget and national savings.

SPEECH.PARA: This was a response given to a non-technical question. It was an interesting question because it raised the issue of the nation's savings and what the government is doing about them. Not surprisingly, in the response, Senator Cook referred to the grand superannuation plan which was such a central feature of this year's budget. I wish to raise a number of questions from a number of people who did not get too many advantages out of the grand superannuation plan which was such an important part of this year's budget. Then I wish to raise a number of questions about the actuarial calculations which were behind those plans, on which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made such grand statements.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, why should people on $60,000 have to subsidise people on higher to middle incomes, on $40,000? That is the first question. Then I refer to self-funded retirees, those people who have saved this country hundreds of millions of dollars. They have saved for their independent retirement and they have got nothing. The government has cancelled the second tranche of the personal income tax cuts promised in the One Nation statement. In that cancellation, these very people have got no benefits from the tax cuts which, allegedly, hopefully, provided we can get enough money, are going to be transferred into superannuation accounts sometime after 1998.

The government made rather a shrewd move in its plans to transfer these so-called funds—if it has the money available, if it is believable—into the superannuation accounts later this decade. The government was shrewd because it chose not to use the legislative mechanism but to use awards and enterprise agreements. In so doing, it has created yet another massive layer of legislative complexity and runs the risk, I say to Senator Schacht, that not everybody will be covered. I think that is a great tragedy.

In the government's attempt to overcome this problem it has created another problem for itself. After all, it was the imperfections in the award system that led to the necessity for the superannuation guarantee charge.

There is also a problem because the government is using the tax mechanism to get the information. This is going to be a very imperfect situation. People will pay one year and get the benefit the next year on a one-to-one basis provided their income level is right. For those at the bottom, it will not help much because they will still be under the government safety net. The problem here is that there will be difficulties in working out the details of what I term qualifying contributions, particularly for those people who go from job to job during the year. How will they remember? The government is going to ask the employer, probably not through goodwill—and it will require a bit of goodwill—to put this information on their group certificates, listing the eligible contributions.

Since my time is running out, the important thing I wish to raise is the issue of this gross final benefit of $461,907. This was in the Saving for our future document—table 1, employee and government contributions effect on retirement incomes after 40 years. Very few people nowadays get anywhere near the 40 years, so they will not get anywhere near that sort of benefit. But having looked at some of the actuarial calculations, I believe the figure is based on the top side of opti mism.

The second issue is that there is no allowance in these calculations in a lot of funds that actually provide sickness or disability relief. That is quite common in a lot of funds. If we take that out—the costs incurred for additional cover—we will not get anywhere near that fin al benefit. Where are the administration costs? It may be true that this is a gross figure, because it does say a gross figure. If we deduct administration from this, we are going to get a significantly lower figure—maybe $40,000 less. If people have not done that, they have overly optimistic estimations on their future earnings which I do not think any actuary worth his salt really could sustain. This is an important issue and I will continue my remarks later tonight. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to Dr Frank Peters' attendance at a scientific conference.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) gave a non-answer to my question. The fact that she did not answer is a very significant thing, which I will explain in a moment. When I sent the question to her this morning, it was in relation to the fact that Dr Frank Peters had been refused admission to this high-level scientific conference. Dr Peters, in a letter I have from him, explained that he had rung about this matter, the matter had been put on hold and he was not to be notified until Friday as to whether he was to be admitted.

PARA.TAB: However, later this morning I heard that, as a consequence of my sending that question to the minister, Dr Peters was suddenly admitted to this conference. That indicates the reason why the minister was not able to answer my question. She was so embarrassed by the fact that, having been put on the spot, she had to change her position and that she was found out and was found to be wanting. I would like to go on about the dangers of CJD and the risks to which thousands of people in Australia, mainly women, have been exposed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make notice of motion No. 1525 a formal motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and pursuant to contingent notice of motions I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1525 standing in the name of Senator Abetz for this day, relating to academic freedom.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that in general principle my motion has the support of the vast majority within this chamber. I understand that the government is of the view that its business ought to take priority and therefore it will be opposing the suspension of standing orders. But there are some principles, some values and some fundamentals that need to take precedence within our body politic and within our nation.

PARA.TAB: I can understand the government's concern about wanting to push its program through, but there are some matters which are more important than the government's program. The principles of academic freedom and freedom of speech are such matters. Any attempt to undermine those principles needs to be exposed and criticised. That is what my motion is all about. This motion will express the Senate's disapproval of the high-handed action of the Greens in attacking in a personal way and reflecting on a person's professional and ethical attributes for one reason and one reason only—that is, the audacity of that person to challenge the Greens' self-claimed monopoly on wisdom, intellect and integrity.

In Tasmania in recent times Professor Forteath, a world renowned authority on lakes and aquaculture, opposed the view being promoted by the Greens concerning Lake Pedder. I do not want to get into the rights and wrongs in the substantive debate, but I want to get into the right of Professor Forteath to express his views without the threat of somebody making a complaint to the university ethics committee and saying that in some way he ought to be disciplined or dealt with for challenging the Greens' point of view.

There has been widespread condemnation of the Greens in Tasmania. My colleague Senator Bell condemns that action as well, although he and I may well have differing views about the issue of Lake Pedder. The issues of academic freedom and freedom of speech are absolutely fundamental and they ought take precedence over the government's program. As indicated to the government, I will limit my remarks substantially, as will Senator Bell, to ensure that this motion gets through the Senate as quickly and as expeditiously as possible, not to waste the time of the Senate but to put on record our absolute rejection of the way the Greens have behaved.

In the past the Greens have been the martyrs in the political debate. They were the ones who were always attacked. But in relation to Professor Forteath, with which this motion deals, the Greens have become the executioners. Professor Forteath is, in fact, the martyr.

I conclude as I commenced: there are some principles that ought to take precedence. Those principles are the right to academic freedom and the right to freedom of speech. I commend the motion for the suspension of standing orders to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, we oppose the suspension of standing orders—not because we disagree that the matter that Senator Abetz has raised about the issue of academic freedom is not a matter of substance, but because there is also the very practical matter of getting the government business through the Senate in the short time we have available in the coming weeks.

PARA.TAB: I want to place on record on behalf of the government that the issues raised in the way the motion was redrafted this morning will not be opposed by the government. We accept the absolute right of academic freedom and the right of people to express their view without any form of intimidation from any quarter. People should have that right to express it accordingly.

I am not getting into the argument of whether there are a certain number of platypuses available in Lake Pedder; that is a different argument. We make that clear. However, although Senator Abetz said that he would reach an agreement that only he and Senator Bell would speak on the substantive issue if suspension was granted, I have a belief, knowing the Senate, that that would be a very generous view about people not wanting to speak in this place. Once the debate started on this issue, there would be quite a few speakers and we would end up using a lot of government business time, which we cannot afford in our agenda.

I want to make it clear that we do not support the suspension of standing orders only because we are committed to the government program. I also want to make it clear that the government has no problem with the motion itself, as redrafted this morning. The issue at stake is an important one but we think it could be better addressed in private members' business or in the adjournment debate. That is the reason we oppose the suspension of standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz did circulate to my office his motion requesting formality, and I correct my misapprehension about its arrival. But he did not do either my colleague or me the courtesy of asking whether we would agree to its being declared formal. The opposition made it very clear to me, when it denied formality to my motion deploring the conduct of Mr Graeme Campbell, that in its view such a motion deserved the dignity of a full and unfettered debate. It would be extremely unreasonable for any of my colleagues in the Senate to expect that the Greens (WA) senators would allow a motion which condemns, without any substantiation, the leader of the Greens in Tasmania to be passed without free and unfettered debate in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: We oppose suspension of standing orders to enable debate on a motion which has already been denied formality, because I regard it as a purely political point scoring exercise. The motion to suspend exposes the motivation of anyone who supports it and does no credit whatsoever to the opposition for allowing Senator Abetz to propose it, or the Democrats if they support it. It is a time-wasting exercise, but no-one who supports it can expect the Greens not to express their view and allow some natural justice to the leader of the Greens in Tasmania, who is not here to speak for herself and to clarify the local explanation of what has occurred.

It is well within my information base now, though I had no knowledge of it when the motion was proposed this morning, that false information has been used relating to a particular disagreement between Dr Bob Brown and Dr Forteath over the Lake Pedder project. There has been no constraint of freedom of expression in the instance that is being referred to. However, that is getting into the substantial debate, and I will clarify those issues as they are made known to me when we go to debate it. I do think it is a time wasting exercise, and I regret that this matter is being raised in this party political, point scoring way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree about this being a time-wasting exercise. I think it is unfortunate that the circumstances ever arose. I know Nigel Forteath quite well, and he raised this issue as part of an overall debate. I agree with the one correct statement that Senator Abetz made, which is that there should be a right to raise any issue in debate. I think that, simply because that matter has been raised and is not accepted by others, it is quite wrong for those others to take some of the action that has been taken.

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz, I do not think it is necessarily serving any purpose, in so far as Nigel Forteath is concerned, to conduct a political exercise. I do not know that he would appreciate it too much anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your colleagues in Tasmania proposed a similar motion and the Liberal Party supported the Labor Party.

—Let me tell you, Senator, I know him a lot better than you do. I doubt whether you have been to Lake Pedder to carry any debate anyway, so I would not go on about it too much. The fact is that you are trying to run it as a political exercise, and I do not think that is right. At the end of the day, Nigel Forteath is a very credible person, and he is entitled to his view. I support that. Like Senator Schacht, I will be opposing the suspension of standing orders.

—Originally I was hoping that this debate would be very brief. The hope may be futile; but I will proceed on the assumptions that were originally made that this matter was very close to having the full acceptance of the chamber as a formal motion and, therefore, there would be the necessity for only cursory discussion. Because this matter is fundamental to free speech and the nature of our democracy, I see good reason for supporting the suspension of standing orders. I hope the ensuing debate will be as brief as was originally intended.
—by leave—I wish to correct something or claim to have been misrepresented, whichever is appropriate.
—You can speak on the basis that you have been misrepresented.
—Senator Chamarette indicated that the motion, not the request to have the motion made formal, had been sent to her.
—You should have had the courtesy of speaking to me.
—I am sorry. I faxed it to you with the words, `I refer whips to the attached notice given in the Senate today and I now seek your support for the motion to be made formal.' I wrote to you, Senator.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Abetz, on behalf of Senator Hill) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No. 1525 standing in the name of Senator Abetz for this day, relating to academic freedom, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)reconfirms its commitment to academic freedom and the right of academic staff at Australia's tertiary institutions to engage in public debate without fear of intimidation; and

(b)expresses its disapproval of the actions of the leader of the Greens in Tasmania in seeking to silence Professor Nigel Forteath by referring him to the Tasmania University ethics committee because of a view he expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter got the bipartisan support of the Tasmanian parliament as Senator Shayne Murphy, Labor from Tasmania, would well know. In the Tasmanian parliament, Michael Field, the Leader of the Opposition, moved a motion in stronger terms than this one, condemning Christine Milne, the leader of the Tasmanian Greens, for her activities in relation to Professor Forteath. In a bipartisan gesture—not political, Senator Chamarette—the Liberal Party agreed without amendment, as I understand it, to support the Labor proposed motion on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Today, it just happens that a Liberal senator has moved the motion. I think it is appropriate that the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party have indicated support in relation to the substantive elements of the motion. Let us get one thing clear at the outset. This debate will not canvass the rights or wrongs of the draining of Lake Pedder. This debate purely and wholly is about the right to academic freedom and the right to freedom of speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his credibility?

—Senator Burns interjects, undoubtedly not on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. He says, `What about his credibility?' That is the question for public debate. For example, I happen to think that Professor David Bellamy is as nutty as a fruitcake, but I would never seek, just because I disagree with his views, to have him disciplined on academic grounds. I will take him on in the public forums, issue media releases, make statements and try to win the debate within the public domain, fairly and squarely. I would not go sneaking to the university Senate to try to have him disciplined by its ethics committee. That is what this debate is all about.

PARA.TAB: I do not mind the Greens attacking me or other people on the basis of credibility. If they can knock down my arguments on the basis of fact, I deserve to lose. If they can knock down Professor Forteath on the basis of facts, Professor Forteath deserves to lose. Methinks he will win; but that is beside the point.
This debate is about the right to academic freedom and the right to express a view, even if that view just happens to run counter to the green version of how the world ought to be run.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or even if it's wrong.

—The Democrats are quite right. The simple fact is that the Greens are the classic people to draw out academics to support their cause and say, `Here we have a world renowned expert supporting our cause.' But when a world renowned expert comes out against their cause as they perceive it, all of a sudden they sneak to the back door of a university and try to have him dealt with by an ethics committee or the university senate on academic standards to try to put him on the back foot. It is gutless, weak and indicative of the fact that they realise they cannot win the public debate fairly and squarely by the clash of ideas and allow the public of Australia to determine who ought to be believed. What do they do? They sneak in the back door and try to make life very difficult for the individual concerned.

PARA.TAB: Professor Forteath was reported on page 14 of today's Examiner as saying this about the Greens:

SPEECH.PARA: It's sad. We need the Greens. They were a breath of fresh air at the last election.

This person was clearly very sympathetic to the green cause, but he felt he had to speak out on the basis of his world renowned expertise on lakes and aquaculture. What did the Greens do? Like ferals, they turned on their own, and that is to be condemned.

PARA.TAB: In the past, the Greens have gone to the electorate saying, `We are the minority view. Here is our heart on our sleeve. We are the martyrs in the political debate. Give us the sympathy vote, because we are always being attacked. We have the guts to speak out on issues that are of importance and that we are concerned about.' When somebody does exactly the same thing but it happens to run counter to what the Greens believe in, they very foolishly seek to turn that person into a martyr. The Greens have now become the executioners in this debate and tried to turn Professor Forteath into a martyr. But the person subject to execution has been taken away from the gallows by the people of Tasmania. Professor Forteath's credibility has been enhanced all the more as a result of this vicious and inappropriate attack upon his professional and ethical credibility.

I will keep to my promise. I said that I would speak for five minutes. I think I have about five or 10 seconds to go. I will complete my comments at this stage, understanding that, if need be, I have a right of reply at the end of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate my colleague Senator Abetz on initiating this very important motion, which is all about freedom of speech and freedom from intimidation, particularly at the academic level. We have unfortunately witnessed a series of reprehensible actions in Tasmania by two Greens in particular, Mrs Milne and Dr Brown, of which I do not think we can be particularly proud. It is appalling to see two senior Greens adopting the lowest form of criticism by attacking Professor Nigel Forteath at a personal and professional level.

PARA.TAB: Freedom of speech is a right to express a personal view, even if it may be an unpopular one. It would appear that the Greens have taken the attitude that it is the prime or exclusive right of parliamentarians to exercise freedom of speech. When one attacks a person by approaching the senate of a university and effectively querying his credentials and right to practise, I believe that we should speak up in every parliament of this country and express our condemnation. It is just not good enough. It is not good enough for a man who aspires to come into this place to take such an attitude and to try to demean another so far as his peers are concerned and take away his livelihood.

It was the message in the process involved in Mrs Milne's action that was so reprehensible. We have to ask: can we, in the future, expect such people to have their livelihoods put at risk and their reputations damaged by such people who take a view different from that which an academic might take? I think universities have been the bastions of free speech in this country. Here I think for the first time we have seen a very dangerous precedent, a precedent that I would not like to see repeated in this generation. Unfortunately, it has been an attempt to muzzle Professor Forteath through defending his right to take a different point of view from that which has been accepted by the Greens. Because of the restrictions on time, I want to make those few brief comments to associate myself with the importance of the right to free speech and to protect a friend in academia, Professor Nigel Forteath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly. I do not think we needed to have this debate. The loss of government time is of some consequence to the government and the business of the Senate. However, now that the debate has gone to the substance of the motion, we do support the motion. We believe that the way the motion is now worded and amended this morning states the principle of academic freedom and the right of free speech. Irrespective of the arguments over Lake Pedder or any other aspect of it, that is not the point of the motion. The point of the motion is now about academic freedom, the right of free speech for any person to be involved in a public controversy and to express their views without having threats made to them in any form. In this case, supposedly it is about the academic ethics which could affect a person's employment in the university.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to get into the detail of who said what down in Tasmania by some members of the Tasmanian parliament from various parties, but we are willing to indicate our support to this motion. As far as the particular case is concerned, I have been given a letter that Mr Forteath sent to the Secretary to the House of Representatives Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts briefly explaining his position on the matter in dispute. I table this for the Senate. Whether you agree or disagree with it, his point is a reasonable point to be made as part of the public debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you incorporate it?
—I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: University of Tasmania
Department of Aquaculture
Professor Nigel Forteath
PO Box 1214
Launceston
Tasmania 7250
Australia
10 April 1995
Mr I Dundas
Secretary
House of Representatives Committee
on Environment, Recreation, and the Arts
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Dundas
Subject: Evidence to Lake Pedder Standing Committee Enquiry

On page 97 of the evidence which I gave it has been drawn to my attention that a major error has been set down. While given in good faith during interview it is imperative that I correct the statement set out. This statement is as follows:

If you want a conservative estimate of the sort of numbers that you can obtain of this animal, in one place in NSW there are 453 animals over an 11km stretch. Unfortunately, there are few places left in Australia where this actually happens. So my estimate of 2000+ platypuses is probably very conservative indeed.
I request that this is changed to read:

At one study area in NSW an expert in platypus ecology has stated that he has tagged more than 450 in an 11km stretch of river since 1973. This researcher does not claim that 450 animals are living in this stretch of river at any one time. His study has taken place over 15 years and thus it is difficult to make an estimate of actual population numbers without a major research effort and an in depth tagging programme over many years. I believe they are abundant in Lake Pedder and 2000 animals is not a far fetched estimate.
I apologise for any inconvenience that I have caused by this admission but I do not go out of my way to misrepresent other people's work or distort the facts.
Yours sincerely
Nigel Forteath

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this matter is of quite genuine relevance to the public debate. Whether people agree or disagree with Mr Forteath is not the point. He has the right to say it. He has the right to be recognised because of his academic position accordingly. I think he is a professor in the Department of Aquaculture at the University of Tasmania. All in all, I hope that we can bring this debate to a very rapid conclusion and get on with the real business of the Senate.

—I remind the Senate that the Democrats hold very dear the protection of the rights of citizens in a democracy to hold and express views and ideas which are alternative and even contrary to the prevailing established ideas of government. Perhaps we even see the need to challenge the established views of the opposition. That is why we established an alternative party. That is why for a decade and a half the Democrats have strongly supported whistleblowers legislation. That is why we support freedom of information legislation. That is why we initiated full public access to information about chemicals. Some people call that the community right to know. That is why we support the right of the Tarkine Tigers in Tasmania to exist and to make their protest. That is why the Democrats encourage students to protest about this government's education policy and to campaign for no fees for degrees.

PARA.TAB: We support open discussion of ideas and concepts. We are wary when definitions get changed and used in ways that reflect political purposes. When definitions undergo subtle changes that pave the way for political changes we need to be very wary indeed.

We should be aware of the examples that occurred only recently in our political history. For example, the deliberate confusion and obfuscation about what is sustainable development or ecologically sustainable development or economically sustainable development. The confusion that has been brought about in the adoption and misuse of that term indicates the need to ensure that people can express alternative views and seek a true definition which can be substantiated.

Another example is the way the government continually redefines an independent student in the capacity to receive Austudy. Those alterations of what we are actually talking about and where the debate is going require full and untrammelled public debate.

The Australian Democrats take care not to suppress alternative ideas. Nor do we support the notion that any one group has a monopoly of ideas or has the right to establish an unchallengeable orthodoxy. Therefore, we encourage freedom of expression in the questioning of ideas be they the establishment positions, our own perspectives, or the perspective of those who aim to challenge the dominate paradigm.

Whatever they are, we support the right of those challenges to be made and those challenges to be given a public airing. The question is not whether they are right or not. What is important is the opportunity for those challenges to be made.

Really, no more needs to be said. I have explained where the Democrats see it is important to maintain those opportunities. In supporting the substantive motion that Senator Abetz has put forward we are sticking true to that for which we have fought for some 18 years now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a nonsense to suggest that there is any disagreement whatsoever about freedom of expression or free speech, particularly in relation to the academic or educational area. I am very pleased that everyone agrees on that.

PARA.TAB: I am a bit saddened that we are all so willing to agree on the importance of it without actually ascertaining the facts that have caused this whole incident to be raised both by the ALP in the Tasmanian state parliament and by Senator Abetz and the Liberal Party in the Senate.

My understanding of what has occurred in Tasmania is that a highly charged political debate, ostensibly in defence of Professor Nigel Forteath, has coincidentally had the outcome of a united attack on the present and former leaders of the Tasmanian Greens.

In relation to the original incident, my understanding—which I gained from Senator Devereux who is not able to be present to speak to this debate and conveyed the information to me from his personal knowledge—is that Professor Forteath made a submission to the House of Representatives Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts.

The information that he presented was challenged and further information was requested and received by that committee from Mr T.R. Grant, the honorary visiting fellow of biological sciences of the University of New South Wales, who could not confirm the information that Professor Forteath had presented to the committee.

His letter was requested because Professor Forteath had requested a change in his testimony as he wanted to correct it, and he apologised for any inconvenience that he caused by the fact that he had not fully reflected on the information that he had presented to the committee.

I understand that Senator Schacht has incorporated Professor Forteath's letter in his speech. If that is so, I will not be seeking to table it but I will seek leave to table the correspondence to which it relates to show that there has been a genuine difference of academic opinion over the Lake Pedder project and the number of platypus affected by it. I will also table evidence that Professor Forteath agreed that his view was not totally accurate and asked for it to be amended.
I will now read an article written by Michael Lester for the Mercury of Thursday, 11 May which gives an account of how this incident arose. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: STATE Parliament has taken the unusual step of censuring a former member for allegedly threatening to discredit an academic for speaking out against draining Lake Pedder.

PARA.TAB: The Government and Opposition voted together to censure national Greens leader Bob Brown and his state colleague Christine Milne for allegedly threatening University of Tasmania professor Nigel Forteath.
Both Dr Bob Brown and Mrs Milne strenuously deny the allegations and last night Professor Forteath said he could not recall either personally threatening him.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we need to take that into consideration when people are mounting such a spirited defence. In the very worthwhile cause of defending somebody's freedom of speech, they are actually violating other people's freedom of speech and their right to present a view.

PARA.TAB: While I cannot defend the leader of the Greens in Tasmania, Christine Milne, from my own experience, I will accord her a measure of natural justice by reading from her statement on this matter. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Greens hold as fundamental, the right of all citizens to freedom of speech.
Every citizen must have the right to speak out publicly and freely, and every other citizen must have the right to publicly question the accuracy of what they say.
The Greens have always been and will continue to be advocates for accountability, openness and freedom of expression.
It is a cynical misuse of the powers of the Senate to single out any individual without the right to reply and to proceed to denigrate that individual with no foundation what so ever.

In the Tasmanian Parliament yesterday there was the disgraceful defamation of National Greens Leader Dr Bob Brown by the Labor Party on completely spurious grounds—which over the last 24 hours have been demonstrated to be complete fabrications.

Professor Nigel Forteath who the ALP claimed had been threatened and intimidated has said today that neither Dr Brown or myself had ever threatened him. He said that Dr Brown had been polite at the only meeting they had.
I have never met or spoken with Dr Forteath.
There are two issues here: one is the right of academics to speak out, the second is professional accountability for what they have to say.

Professor Nigel Forteath made a statement in his capacity as professor of Aquaculture at the University of Tasmania. He said that thousands of Platypus would starve to death if Lake Pedder was restored and that the number of platypus in Lake Pedder was 4000.

Professor Forteath was unable to substantiate any of his claims with hard research at a recent academic symposium held at the University of Tasmania. Academic experts, Dr Rose Senior Lecturer in Zoology and Tom Grant Visiting Fellow at University of NSW, have openly disagreed with him and in the case of Dr Grant has revealed to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment that his research was misrepresented by Professor Forteath.

This issue was referred to the academic senate as the appropriate body to ask for the basis of Professor Forteath's research and to justify his claims in line with the University of Tasmania's code of conduct for academics.
This in no way questions his right to free speech.
I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of that statement and to table the three documents to which I referred.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The remainder of the statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens are concerned about the climate of hate, intimidation and the culture of fear developing in Tasmania.
I am saddened to see that the Liberal Party and particularly the Australian Democrats are combining to expand this culture of fear and misrepresentation into a national arena.
In Tasmania in the last week we have had protesters called `filthy' and `animals' by the Health Minister Roger Groom.

Car bumper stickers have been released saying `Register Poofters not guns before they kill us all' and leaflets have been circulated saying `Stop aids now execute Homos'. Tasmania's gay community have just warned that it is only a matter of time before a hate-based killing is committed in Tasmania.
We have just seen draconian changes to the Police Offences Act which make trespass a significant crime on crown land, so that areas of public land can be declared off limits.
Today we had confirmation that the Tasmanian Liberal Government is tinkering with the doctrine of the separation of powers to hand over power of contempt of parliament to the courts and police.

In this climate we have a marked increase in these obscene bumper stickers and posters advocating everything from death to homosexuals to businessmen calling on rural communities not to serve known protesters opposed to the Tarkine Road—which the Federal Government continues to refuse to stop despite all the scientific evidence.
We have cruise operators who, according to two tourists one from Germany and one from South Australia, refused to take people on board who look like greenies.

It is in this context that the Labor and Liberal Parties in Tasmania have joined together to vilify the Greens for asking that an academic who entered a political debate on Lake Pedder be accountable for his statements.
Now the Democrats and Liberal party nationally have decided to stoop to this level.

This attack on the Greens by the Liberal party and Democrats, is all about the likelihood that The Greens will hold the Balance of Power in Tasmania after the election in February 1996 and that Dr Bob Brown will win a Senate seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before, this whole issue is unfortunate. I have some sympathy for what Senator Chamarette has said. I think the only thing Christine Milne did wrong was to approach the university senate, and she may have sought—I am not sure of the exact detail of what Christine Milne sought from the university senate—to have Professor Nigel Forteath disciplined.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to deal with is that when we in the community deal with debates that are of a controversial nature, particularly things like the Lake Pedder debate and even forestry debates, the various parties use sources of expertise, claimed experts on this and that, to support their various arguments. I think one thing the conservation movement has done time and again is use people who are so-called experts, whether they be professors or otherwise, to support some of the claims that they have made. There have been many occasions when those claims have been proven to be wrong. So it is not really an issue of whether or not Nigel Forteath is right or wrong.

With regard to platypus at Lake Pedder, I can vouch for the fact—being someone who has been to Lake Pedder every year for the last 21 years, having spent some six months in overall time on the lake, having walked about two-thirds of the lake's shores and having been on every area of water within the lake—that there is a substantial platypus population on the lake. Whether they would starve or otherwise, I am simply not expert enough to make any argument for that.

What I found disappointing in Mrs Milne's action was that, if Nigel Forteath had been one of those people supporting her argument or that particular line of debate, she would have chosen to champion the cause of Nigel Forteath. I think it is very unfortunate, and it appears to be a common practice, that when people disagree with certain lines of argument put forward, they seem to be very strongly criticised. Of course, the same can be said from the other side of the fence. I just find that this is a very unfortunate set of circumstances which has arisen.

I think Nigel Forteath is a very eminent person, particularly in the field of aquaculture, and is doing a lot of marvellous work at the University of Tasmania. I know Nigel Forteath personally. I have spoken to him on a number of occasions about this particular issue and I know that at no stage of the Lake Pedder debate did he ever seek, in making comments that he made, to take a political position. Therefore, he should not be pursued politically.

I find the continuation of any debate about the position, by Christine Milne, by the state government or even by this chamber, somewhat unfortunate. I support the motion in so far as it relates to the right to free speech and the right to express a view. Whether it is right, wrong or indifferent, we should have that right. I support that very strongly and I find it very unfortunate that the whole thing has occurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate; however, having heard some of what Senator Chamarette had to say, I am a little disturbed that we may be doing a further injustice in the second paragraph of this motion. I think everybody agrees in relation to the first paragraph of the motion; there is no question about that. The second paragraph clearly reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . condemns the leader of the Greens in Tasmania for seeking to silence Professor Nigel Forteath by referring him to the Tasmania University ethics committee . . .

That implies that there was an attempt to silence him. What I have heard Senator Chamarette say—I have no other evidence of this at all and I do not want to get into the details—is that the Tasmanian university has a process by which the professional competence of people can be looked at in terms of the statements which are made and the truth of those statements.

PARA.TAB: If there is a reference to such a committee, that carries a somewhat different overtone to it than a reference to an ethics committee which, in my mind, clearly suggests an attempt to suppress information and to deny academic freedom. I wonder whether Senator Abetz would accept an amendment to paragraph (b) which would read `condemns the alleged action of the leader' because there is some doubt as to what the actual action was; we can condemn the alleged action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I accept that.
—I take it that Senator Abetz is prepared to accept that. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (b), omit "actions", substitute "alleged actions".

SPEECH.PARA: If that happened, then the motion stands; if it did not happen, then we are not unfairly blaming somebody.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly tonight because I think it is important to look at today's debate in the light of what might be normal procedure within academia. I want to think carefully about what the situation might be. We know there must be ethics committees in universities. We know how much parliaments and the media rely on the information that is provided to them by universities. They rely on the fact that if they go to a supposed expert in a field, then that information, firstly, should be reasoned information and, secondly and most specifically, that information should be able to be backed up by data or reasoned debate.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of reasons why this is the case. Most importantly, the reason this mechanism is in place is to protect the reputations of the universities and of those people who are in the position of occasionally being spokespeople in their field of excellence. If we do not have this ability to require professional accountability, then that puts at risk this whole system of being able to go to experts in a field.

If there is a line which says that Christine Milne did wrong to approach the university senate, then I would like to know on what basis there is some principle upon which any member of the community or academia is refused permission to use this normal procedure. The procedure was not to silence what anybody in academia says. There is no evidence whatsoever that there was any move by Christine Milne to seek to have Professor Forteath disciplined. The procedure was to ask an academic who has made a public statement which has obviously had a big public impact to back up the statement with scientific evidence, a rational debate, a paper or some background which other academics—as they normally do with cross-referencing—can use to establish the basis of the argument.

On many, many occasions in this chamber I have heard senators questioned about the basis for statements. That is the right and proper thing to do. If you are an academic and you happen to make a public statement—especially if you know it is a public statement which is likely to have a certain impact—you are responsible for that statement. If you are not in a position to back up that statement with scientific data or the basis of your research you may be called to account for your statement. This is extremely important for our system. It is extremely important not only for our university system and our research but for the media and our political system. We must have the ability to cross reference. We are in trouble if that does not happen.

I find it ludicrous to suggest that Christine Milne did wrong to undertake the right process and ask if there was backup information that could be sought. Therefore, I join with my colleague Senator Chamarette in opposing this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

PARA.TAB: By this motion I am seeking to criticise the Leader of the Greens for attempting to have him refer to the university. As we are in the business of quoting newspapers, let me quote from page 5 of the Examiner of 10 May 1995 where Mrs Milne's comments are in inverted commas:

—I am not going to read out the whole page about who said what and how.

—I am willing to table this whole page which is headed `Attack "like Nazi persecution"'—the words of Judy Jackson, an Australian Labor Party frontbencher in the Tasmanian parliament. If Senator Murphy—a Labor senator from Tasmania—wants that tabled as well, I am more than happy to do so.

If the Greens think that that is a fair way of conducting a public debate, if they want to support the Greens who have been engaging in this sort of activity, let them be on the record. TALK.START.PARA: —I tabled it.
—She only quoted a section, which was:

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Forteath said he could not recall either personally threatening him.

Nevertheless he said he had been "very, very intimidated by the whole thing", particularly by Green accusations that he had misused his position and discredited the university and denigrations of his observations of platypuses in Lake Pedder.

The Green attack clearly was that he had misused his position in the University of Tasmania and thereby had somehow brought the university into disrepute. TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.
—Senator Chamarette says, `Nonsense.' Let her be with the Greens on the public record.

—Senator Margetts. Let the Greens be on the public record, because they will be decimated when the people of Australia come to realise the sort of authoritarian attitude that they have in relation to matters of public debate.

PARA.TAB: To sum up very briefly, this motion has not touched on Dr Bob Brown in any shape or form, yet the Greens have sought to bring him into the debate.
