DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on disaster management. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE
REPORT ON DISASTER MANAGEMENT

In June 1994 the then Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure issued the report of the inquiry into disaster management which it was tasked to carry out by the Senate. The report covered many aspects of this enormous subject and the government compliments the committee on its
endeavours to cover as much of the subject as was possible in the time available.

As senators will be aware, the New South Wales bush fires of December 1993 and January 1994 fell within the period of the inquiry and the committee was able to make a limited examination of the response to those fires during its hearings.

The government response to the 45 recommendations of the committee report required coordination of a total of 22 commonwealth departments and agencies. Discussions with state and territory governments were also required as a number of the recommendations had implications for those governments. The response was coordinated by emergency management Australia on behalf of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, the Hon Arch Bevis MP.

The government has already moved to implement a number of those recommendations of the report which are the responsibility of the commonwealth government. Those recommendations which relate to matters specifically the responsibility of state governments have been drawn to the attention of those governments through the National Emergency Management Committee.

While the government's response has been in preparation there have been continuing improvements in emergency management capability at both commonwealth and state level. A number of these result from actions undertaken as a result of the committee's recommendations; others are part of the continuous development and improvement policies espoused by all involved in this field. Of particular note is the government's endorsement of a commonwealth policy statement on emergency management which was communicated to responsible state and territory ministers by the Minister for Defence at a meeting of emergency management ministers in Sydney in December 1994. In this statement the government, for the first time has clearly stated the commonwealth acceptance of certain responsibilities in emergency management in support of the states and territories. The statement will form the basis for future development of the commonwealth and national capabilities in the field.
I commend to senators the government's response to the senate standing committee report on disaster management.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE
REPORT ON DISASTER MANAGEMENT
April 1995
INTRODUCTION

Disaster management is a large and complex subject which is difficult to examine in detail over a short period. The Government is grateful to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for the report of its inquiry into the subject.
The Terms of Reference for the Committee were:

The capacity of the public sector authorities to plan for, forecast and respond to major disasters and large-scale emergencies, fully respecting and utilising the skills and capabilities of volunteer organisations.

The Committee has taken a comprehensive approach in its report and looked broadly at the concepts applicable to emergency management, covering the full cycle of prevention, preparedness, response and recovery. It has also produced useful comments and recommendations on matters related to Commonwealth responsibilities and arrangements. The report provides a valuable synopsis of disaster management arrangements at Commonwealth, State and Territory levels and has identified areas where improvements are warranted. In the light of emergencies and disasters that occurred during the period of the inquiry, the Committee has also raised some valuable points in relation to such specific issues as the participation of volunteers, and matters arising from the NSW bushfires of January 1994.

The majority of the recommendations of the report are endorsed by the Government although many will require the cooperation of the States and Territories. Where appropriate, follow-up action will be pursued with the States and Territories on a bilateral and collective basis through existing arrangements coordinated by Emergency Management Australia (EMA).
The Government's response to the report is in two parts: an overview followed by detailed responses to the specific recommendations.
OVERVIEW
This overview provides comments on the main themes emerging from each of the chapters of the report.
Chapter 1—Disaster Management in Australia

This chapter defines, in general terms, the disaster management roles of various Commonwealth Government departments and agencies. In so doing, it highlights the extensive support that the Commonwealth provides for disaster management in Australia and its commitment to working with State, Territory and Local Governments for the development and maintenance of an effective disaster management structure.

The Government fully endorses the Committee's commendation of the Australian Defence Force for the very positive way in which it responds to requests for disaster assistance, and for the efforts made by Telecom during the 1994 NSW bushfires.

In international terms, Australia can be proud of actions taken to date under the umbrella of the International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction (IDNDR). These have been recognised internationally as examples of judicious expenditure of relatively small funds to enhance a wide range of emergency activities. Of particular relevance to Australia among the mid-term strategies recently endorsed by the United Nations is the `involvement and active participation of the people in disaster reduction, prevention, preparedness, leading to improved risk management'.

It is time, however, at this mid-point of the IDNDR to take stock of the Australian approach. Increased State and Territory involvement in the activities of the IDNDR Coordination Committee and in implementing the themes of the Decade will be pursued. The presence of these representatives, together with those from Commonwealth agencies, non-government organisations and academic and professional bodies, makes the Committee a valuable forum for wide-ranging discussion of emergency management issues and gives a variety of opportunities for raising the profile of the IDNDR as is recommended by the report.
Chapter 2—Pre-Disaster Phase—Preparedness

The importance of disaster mitigation and preparedness measures have been well recognised by the Committee and it is noted that 13 of the 45 recommendations in the report are found in this chapter. These will require action from a number of Commonwealth agencies as detailed in the responses to the specific recommendations. Of particular interest are those recommendations which discuss the use of geographical information systems (GIS) and remote sensing. Recent developments in these technologies make their use in disaster management much easier and the Government intends to examine their use in a number of ways.

The Government is mindful of the concerns raised in Recommendation 2 in relation to the preservation of records and the maintenance of functions of all Commonwealth agencies. Agencies do not always give sufficient attention to these issues and there can be a tendency for agency emergency planning and counter-measures to be neglected even after periods in which major centres have been preserved from the effects of a substantial disaster. This issue will be considered by the Commonwealth Counter Disaster Task Force (CCDTF) and steps will be taken to bring the subject to the attention of departments and agencies.
A national uniform building code is highly desirable and progress on this is well advanced though the efforts of the Australian Building Codes Board.

While the occurrence of a major mouse plague obviously raised the profile of such an event with the Committee, the majority of such plagues are very localised in their occurrence and in their impact on the economy. The Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management is supporting the development of a systematic and integrated approach to the management of such events. Meanwhile the Commonwealth, through the Grains Research and Development Corporation and CSIRO, is contributing funds to the search for long-term solutions to the problem.

Of greater concern to the Government is the potential impact of major exotic animal disease outbreaks. These could cause untold hardship to rural communities and suffering to animals as well as severe damage to the economy. The work of the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council (EXANDIS) over recent years has considerably enhanced the national capability to respond to such events. Methods of continuing this work will be included in a current review of Australia's long-term animal health requirements.
Chapter 3—Disaster Phase—Response

The Government agrees with the Committee's view that the Commonwealth's response to requests for emergency assistance from the States and Territories is highly organised and that the current arrangements for seeking such support are suitable. It also endorses the statements in Paragraphs 3.13 and 3.14 concerning the role of the Australian Defence Force in disaster response. While clearly willing to make the resources of the Australian Defence Force, as well as other Commonwealth resources, available to assist the States and Territories after disasters, the Government emphasises that these resources are maintained for other purposes. The significant additional outlays in equipment and training to meet the potential needs that might be generated by the range of hazards which threaten Australia are not justified at the Commonwealth level given that, in general, primary responsibility lies with State and Territory Governments.

The development of Government Business Enterprises with specific roles and different funding arrangements has also raised new issues in relation to the funding of the Commonwealth response. These issues require further examination.
Chapter 4—Recovery

Recovery is a key element of the disaster cycle and the return of individuals and communities to normal life after disasters is critical. Although most action is taken by States and Territories and non-government organisations, the Commonwealth provides a range of financial support to assist in this process.

The Committee has recommended that the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements be expanded to include a wider range of disasters and that a pamphlet be produced relating to Disaster Relief Provisions of the Social Security Act 1991. Both of these matters are currently being examined in a wider review of Commonwealth financial support arrangements for recovery from disasters.
Chapter 5—Zones of Commonwealth Responsibility

While State and Territory governments have prime responsibility for safety of life and property of their citizens, there are a number of areas for which the Commonwealth also has a significant responsibility. Among these are marine pollution, hydrographic surveying and aviation and some aspects of maritime search and rescue. The Commonwealth also has certain specific responsibilities in relation to nuclear safety. All these subjects are discussed in this chapter of the report.

The Committee has raised a number of issues in relation to accidents at sea and marine pollution. The Commonwealth has demonstrated its commitment to maritime safety and marine environmental protection over many years. The responses given to Recommendations 17-22 demonstrate that this commitment continues.

The emergency preparedness at airports located near water was the subject of a recommendation. This is a sub-set of the larger issue of air safety which is continuously addressed by the Civil Aviation Authority, the Federal Airports Corporation and other Commonwealth agencies in conjunction with State and Territory authorities.

The recent Research Reactor Review commissioned by the Commonwealth Government agreed with the judgement of relevant organisations that it is unlikely that an accident involving the research reactor at the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories would have any effects outside the boundaries of the establishment. Nevertheless, cooperation between Commonwealth and State authorities takes place in planning for a response for such an event.

The Government agrees that it should be demonstrating a standard of best practice in the field of emergency management on Commonwealth property and facilities. EMA will assist relevant Commonwealth agencies to maintain this standard.
Chapter 6—Volunteers

Although the Committee has not made any specific recommendations in relation to volunteers who play a key role in Australia's emergency management arrangements, it has identified a number of issues for consideration by States and Territories. These have been referred to the States and Territories.

At Paragraph 6.16, the desirability of sending key training personnel from voluntary organisations to the Australian Emergency Management Institute at Mount Macedon is identified. Nominations for places on courses at the Institute are made by State and Territory authorities. These authorities do nominate representatives of voluntary agencies to attend courses from time to time and the desirability of continuing this practice has also been drawn to the attention of nominating authorities.

The Government recognises and commends the vital and unselfish role which voluntary organisations play in all areas of disaster management. The involvement of community-based organisations is an important characteristic of the Australian approach to emergency management.
Chapter 7—Bushfire Management

Inclusion by the Committee of a chapter on Bushfire Management is particularly appropriate in view of the experiences in NSW and WA earlier this year. The Committee has highlighted problems with a lack of national standards in relation to communications and equipment. These matters are currently being actively examined by relevant committees including the National Emergency Management Committee and the National Communications Advisory Group.

The recommendation that CL-215 water bombing aircraft be obtained for trials in Australia has high-cost implications. The Committee has stated that the 1985 study of the use of fire bombing aircraft by CSIRO (Project Aquarius) has been strongly criticised and its results argued to be wrong. The Government is unaware of any scientifically-based analysis of the Project which would support such a position. A preliminary examination of the anticipated costs of further limited trials of a number of aircraft types was undertaken by the Government. It was considered that such trials should also re-examine the use of smaller aircraft and helicopters, since the case for their use appears to parallel that for the CL-215, if rather less stridently promoted. The results of this examination were discussed with State and Territory Ministers responsible for emergency management matters in December 1994. The majority view was that the cost of further trials was not warranted. The Government undertook to continue to monitor developments in this field..
Chapter 8—Commonwealth Emergency Management—Conclusions

In the final chapter of the report, the Committee has emphasised the need for the Commonwealth, through EMA, to play a greater role in preparedness planning, prevention/mitigation, training and recovery as well as disaster response. Although EMA already covers all these aspects, particularly through its training arm at Mount Macedon, it is agreed that there is scope to increase the priority given to these components of emergency management. These matters will be considered in conjunction with the National Emergency Management Committee.

The Committee has made a key recommendation that EMA be placed with the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and that it be set up as an independent body with its own legislation and funding through a separate budget program. The Government does not support this approach. The management arrangements for EMA within the Department of Defence are working satisfactorily and no substantive argument has been provided to change these. The effect of Defence budgetary pressures on EMA is overstated. Regardless of the location of EMA, it will not be removed from the need to justify its financial requirements.

The Committee has also recommended that EMA be established under separate legislation. The Government is satisfied that the current administrative arrangements are satisfactory and does not see a need for specific legislation, notwithstanding that this approach has been adopted in some other countries.

Civil defence is identified as a responsibility which should be given to EMA. The responsibility for civil defence operations has remained with EMA since its creation as the Natural Disasters Organisation in 1974. Responsibility for the development of civil defence policy was devolved to EMA in 1992 and a national policy was endorsed in principle by Government in December 1994.

Finally, the Committee recommends that the CCDTF take on the wider role of coordinating forward planning of Commonwealth Government disaster relief systems, both short and long term. The Government agrees that the Task Force should play a more active role in developing the policies which will produce a comprehensive and integrated approach to all aspects of emergency management at the national level.
Conclusion

The Government commends the Committee on its valuable report which will significantly assist in strengthening Australia's emergency management arrangements. Effective emergency management in Australia depends on cooperation between Commonwealth, State, Territory and Local Governments working in partnership with the community. There are many recommendations made by the Committee which the Commonwealth can implement. Nevertheless, constitutional responsibility for the protection of life and property rests with the States and Territories and complementary action is required. This is already being discussed by the National Emergency Management Committee. Cooperation was developed further at a meeting of emergency management ministers which the Minister for Defence convened in December 1994.
RECOMMENDATIONS
Recommendation 1

The Committee recommends that EMA (Emergency Management Australia) give higher priority to activities under IDNDR and in particular work towards gaining increased State/Territory commitment to their own IDNDR projects. (Paragraph 1.37)
Comment

Agreed. In support of the `Yokohama Strategy' and `Plan of Action for a Safer World', which were endorsed by countries attending the United Nations World Conference on Natural Disaster Reduction held in Japan in May 1994, EMA is examining the Australian IDNDR program for the latter half of the decade. Membership of the IDNDR Coordination Committee will be reviewed with a view to obtaining representation from a wider range of disciplines. The States and Territories, previously represented by a single delegate, now have individual representation on the Committee. The committee will also be invited to raise the profile of the IDNDR, to support projects which have a practical impact on disaster mitigation and to seek ways to increase State/Territory commitment.
Recommendation 2

The Committee believes that all Commonwealth agencies should have a counter-disaster plan to cover emergencies which may affect normal agency functions and damage or destroy agency-held records. To achieve this the Committee recommends that an inter agency Committee be established to determine a basic standard for Commonwealth agencies and to draft a blue print plan as a basis for all agencies. The Committee further recommends that the existence, scope and currency of agency plans be subject to formal mention in annual reports, and be subject to both internal and external auditing. (Paragraph 2.15)
Comment

Potential interruptions to the functions of Commonwealth agencies or potential damage to agency-held records could result from a variety of causes. These may range from small incidents such as common localised accidents, for example fire or water damage, up to major widespread natural disasters such as floods or earthquakes.

Accordingly, contingency planning of the kind suggested by this recommendation should be part of the normal arrangements considered by program managers and agency heads. In general, it is their responsibility to make risk assessments regarding such events and decide on the level of contingency planning required.

Given that assessing the need for and capacity of agencies to maintain operations under extreme circumstances should be a normal part of program planning and administration, contingency planning would be within the current agency annual reporting and audit practices. Again, the level of priority given to reporting on such planning is a matter for the judgement of program managers and agency heads and is likely to reflect the level of threat and the importance of rapid business resumption assessed on an agency-by-agency basis.

However, experience shows that agencies do not always pay the required level of attention to these issues particularly after long periods without major disasters. Attention of agency heads will be drawn to this by the Commonwealth Counter Disaster Task Force (CCDTF).

Rather than an inter agency Committee, the CCDTF, in consultation with relevant bodies, will, in the near future, assess the need for broad guidelines for agencies to consider in planning for such contingencies.
Recommendation 3
The Committee . . . recommends that, as a project under the auspices of the IDNDR, States and Territories adopt nationally uniform building codes for improved disaster preparedness. (Paragraph 2.20)
Comment

The Building Code of Australia, which is maintained as a joint initiative between the Commonwealth, State and Territory and Local Governments through the Australian Building Codes Board, is currently being further developed. It is appropriate that development be continued by the Board rather than establish a separate project under IDNDR. The code provides the technical basis for State and Territory building regulations and has been adopted by all States and Territories. The Code covers all types of building. It focuses on fire protection and building fire safety and also prescribes a comprehensive approach to protection from such events as high wind, earthquakes and progressive collapse. The Code incorporates the latest developments in building standards (such as Australian Standard AS 1170.4: Earthquake Loading Provisions).

Australian Standard AS 3959/1991: Construction of Buildings In Bushfire Prone Areas, is included in the Code. This requires residential buildings in designated bushfire areas to be provided with protection to reduce the risk of ignition by embers during a bushfire. Although this Standard is not called up in New South Wales, a recent report of a New South Wales Parliamentary Select Committee on Bushfires has recommended its adoption in the State's Building Code.Nevertheless, many shires in the State require buildings in areas subject to bushfire hazard to be protected to the standard given in AS3959. South Australia has not accepted the Standard because it has a special requirement defined in a Ministerial specification. AS3959 is being reviewed urgently and the new edition is expected to be called up in the Building Code of Australia on completion.
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends that EMA explore the possibility of simulator training for other emergency scenarios, with a view to having at AEMI an array of simulators for use by State emergency services in training their officers. Funding for simulator technology would be on a Commonwealth/State cost sharing basis. (Paragraph 2.34)
Comment

EMA has begun an evaluation of simulation systems available overseas to assess their suitability for use in Australia. The cost of obtaining and introducing simple systems may be covered by offsets within the emergency management financial support provided to States and Territories under a State Support Package. Major simulation packages are expensive and the rationale for their use would need to be discussed in detail with State and Territory authorities.
Recommendation 5
The Committee recommends that ADMIN be used as a model to establish an Australia wide network for information exchange specifically related to disaster management. (Paragraph 2.46)
Comment

Agreed. Funding has been provided in financial year 1994-95 to provide further development of the Australian Disaster Management Information Network (ADMIN). EMA is committed to supporting ADMIN as the Australia-wide network for disaster management information exchange and will also encourage links with other similar systems.
Recommendation 6

The Committee . . . recommends that EMA convene and coordinate a technical committee to evaluate geographic information systems with particular regard to disaster management and make recommendations as to the suitability of various types of systems. (Paragraph 2.53)
Comment

Geographic Information Systems (GIS) offer a framework for assimilation of spatial data of value to disaster managers. While standing data can be entered in slow-time, that relating to a current disaster will often only be available through remote sensing. Consequently recommendations 6 and 7 are closely related.

The importance of GIS has been recognised by the conduct of a national workshop in April 1994 at the Australian Emergency Management Institute (AEMI) in conjunction with Australasian Urban and Regional Information Systems Association (AURISA). As a result of this workshop, EMA and the Australian Geological Survey Organisation (AGSO) are collaborating to develop the use of GIS in emergency management.

EMA is involved in a Natural Hazards GIS Working Group and has become the convenor of an AURISA standing public safety group. Both groups provide avenues for technical consultation and information exchange on ways of incorporating GIS capabilities into emergency management. The groups include representatives of Commonwealth and State agencies able to facilitate full evaluation of systems. Development of a pilot project on the comprehensive use of GIS for disaster management purposes in the city of Cairns has been approved for funding as an IDNDR project. The project will be conducted in conjunction with Queensland Government agencies. Commonwealth agencies, such as the Bureau of Meteorology and the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group (AUSLIG), will be consulted in development of the project.
Recommendation 7

The Committee recommends that EMA, as part of the IDNDR, convene a specialist working group to evaluate remote sensing technologies and the relative merits of their application in Australian disaster management agencies. The Committee also recommends that support be given to CSIRO in its development and promotion of multi-spectral technology instruments. (Paragraph 2.59)
Comment

A number of aspects of remote sensing, including data acquisition and management, broad spectrum remote sensing and multi-spectral instrument capabilities can have a significant impact on Australia's ability to predict and manage disasters. EMA intends to conduct a national workshop on remote sensing technologies to evaluate their application to emergency management in the Australian environment. The need for a specialist working group will be examined during the workshop, which will include participants from CSIRO, AUSLIG, AGSO, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Bureau of Resource Sciences (BRS). France and New Zealand have also expressed interest in cooperating with Australia on the use of remote sensing technology in assisting the response to and recovery from disasters and emergencies in regional nations. EMA will examine the feasibility of including representatives from these nations in the national workshop and extending its scope to cover this wider approach to the subject.

Government provides funding to CSIRO on a global and triennial basis but does not specify the priority of activities against which funds are to be allocated. This is a matter for the CSIRO Board. Recognising that there are a number of other priorities for CSIRO's research and development efforts, it is expected that the Organisation will continue to develop capabilities in the remote sensing and GIS fields at a rate determined by the availability of overall resources, collaborating where appropriate with such other agencies as EMA and the Bureau of Meteorology.
Recommendation 8

The Committee recommends that [the issue of national acceptance of professional qualifications for forensic pathologists and forensic odontologists] be taken up by EMA directly with State and Territory authorities and if necessary the State Emergency Management Committee. (Paragraph 2.63)
Comment

EMA conducted a national workshop on disaster victim identification at AEMI in January 1995. The subject of national acceptance of professional forensic qualifications was examined during the workshop and the recommendations arising will be taken into account in seeking wider acceptance of professional qualifications.
Recommendation 9
The Committee recommends that EMA conduct a workshop on ways of increasing standardisation . . . among State emergency service agencies. (Paragraph 2.67)
Comment

Agreed. A national workshop will be conducted at AEMI to review significant problems in achieving standardisation in emergency management and to identify more effective methods of implementing standardisation.
Recommendation 10

The Committee believes that the States should cooperate with AGSO and recommends that, to improve liaison and planning, each State identify a Department or institution to be responsible for earthquake issues. (Paragraph 2.74)
Comment

Agreed. Arrangements for cooperation between AGSO and agencies representing South Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria are now in place. Discussions are under way between AGSO and Tasmania, Western Australia and the Northern Territory.
Recommendation 11

The Committee . . . recommends that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training identify at least one tertiary institution to be made a centre of excellence for seismology teaching and research. (Paragraph 2.75)
Comment

There is currently no Commonwealth-funded Key Centre for Teaching and Research in the field of earthquake seismology although a number of tertiary institutions are undertaking research in the broad field of seismology. The Australian Research Council, which advises the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on research policy, agreed in February 1994 that there should be a new selection round of Key Centres for Teaching and Research with funding to commence in 1995/96. $2.4 million per annum will be made available to support approximately eight new Key Centres. The new selection round was advertised in the national press in September and universities were invited to submit up to three proposals. The peer review process, which will be managed by the Institutional Grants Committee of the Australian Research Council, is rigorous and competition is expected to be very strong. Applications will be assessed on merit, in terms of the excellence of the proposed research and the relevance of the proposed educational programs in the development of expertise in fields important to Australia's economic and social development. Advice will go to the Minister on that basis.
Recommendation 12
The Committee . . . recommends that a Rodent Plague Commission be established as soon as possible. (Paragraph 2.88)
Comment

This recommendation is not supported. Commonwealth and State authorities agree that there is little that a Rodent Plague Commission could achieve over and above the work already being done by such bodies as the Grains Research and Development Corporation's Rodent Task Force.
Recommendation 13

The Committee recommends that NDRA guidelines be reviewed with consideration given to include mouse plagues. There also is a need for a clear policy at federal level on the availability and use of strychnine. In the absence of a Commission, the Committee recommends that State governments maintain a stockpile of strychnine along with a plan for its distribution in the event of a severe mouse plague such as occurred in 1993 in South Australia and Victoria. (Paragraph 2.89)
Comment

NDRA guidelines are being reviewed as part of a widespread examination of emergency response policy. The subject of mouse and other plagues will be included in the scope of the review. The review team will liaise with the Vertebrate Pests Committee, the peak committee under the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management which has responsibility for mouse plague issues. It should be pointed out that mouse plagues rarely fall into the `severe and unpredictable' category of events currently covered by NDRA. Most such irruptions are localised and do not cause significant widespread economic loss.

Given the highly toxic nature of strychnine, the concerns of health and environmental authorities over its use, the fact that its use is only permitted in two States, and that a task force of the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management is currently examining a more systematic approach to the problem, the recommendation concerning State government stockpiling of strychnine cannot be supported.
Recommendation 14

The Committee recommends that the preparation and adoption of uniform national [exotic disease control] legislation by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories should be completed as a matter of urgency. The Committee further recommends that funding be maintained sufficient to allow bodies such as EXANDIS, which the States and Territories believe essential to planning processes, to be retained. (Paragraph 2.95)
Comment

The recommendation concerning uniform legislation is supported and it is noted that the achievement of such legislation is almost complete as a result of national endorsement of an Agriculture and Resource Management Council proposal of 1988. By August 1994, uniform legislation had been implemented in New South Wales, Western Australia, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. The legislation is included in the current programs of Victoria, Tasmania and the Northern Territory, while the legislative drafting process in Queensland is still under consideration.

The provisions of the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989, which established the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, cease to operate on 20 June 1995. The major elements of the EXANDIS charter have been included in a broader review of Australia's long term animal health requirements; exotic animal disease control is a core function of these requirements. A proposal to establish a new tripartite national body comprising Commonwealth, State/Territory and industry interests is under active consideration. Such a body would provide future focus on animal health policies, including those relating to exotic animal diseases. Funding proposals are also being examined and it is expected that any Commonwealth funds provided will be subject to Government scrutiny in the same way as other budget funded programs.
Recommendation 15

The Committee recommends that, in keeping with contemporary needs in emergency management, a review be conducted of NDRA arrangements to consider the inclusion of technological disasters. (Paragraph 4.27)
Comment

NDRA will be examined as part of preparing a consolidated Commonwealth policy statement on emergency response with the scope of the review broadened to include consideration of technological disasters as an eligible disaster.
Recommendation 16

The Committee recommends that the Department of Social Security publish a pamphlet outlining the circumstances in which people receive disaster relief payments to counter perceived inequity in the allocations. (Paragraph 4.31)
Comment

A review of the Department of Social Security emergency payments arrangements is to be conducted for the CCDTF. Once this review is completed and any changes are authorised, information will be made available to the public in an easily understood form.
Recommendation 17

Just as the Committee has recommended in other parts of this report, that EMA must work closely with the States and Territories to develop comprehensive and integrated emergency planning, the Committee recommends that AMSA and EMA should make maritime emergency planning a model of best practice. (Paragraph 5.13)
Comment

EMA and AMSA are both committed to the principle of `best practice' and continually review their plans and procedures in the light of developing knowledge. The two agencies have a close working relationship and cooperate in marine pollution planning and the arrangement of maritime support for other disasters
Recommendation 18

The Committee recommends that AMSA in conjunction with EMA and relevant State and Northern Territory agencies develop a comprehensive emergency management plan for chemical transportation by June 1995. (Paragraph 5.20)
Comment

EMA is participating with AMSA in planning for the response to maritime chemical transportation accidents, a process which involves a number of other Commonwealth and State agencies. Because of the complexity of this planning process, the time scale recommended by the committee may not be achievable.
Recommendation 19

The Committee recommends . . . that funding be upgraded for the Australian Hydrographic Service sufficient to allow for identification of such routes and the production of a series of accurate National Charts and sailing directions suitable for modern navigation along them. Funding increases should be such as to allow a production rate of at least 25 charts per annum. (Paragraph 5.33)
Comment

Agreed. The Royal Australian Navy (RAN) has already provided a new hydrographic facility in Wollongong and plans a 20 percent increase in civil staff over the next five years to permit production to increase to at least 25 charts per annum. CSIRO's Division of Oceanography has provided data relevant to chart production to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre for many years and holds additional information of potential value for new chart production.

In addition to the conventional charting program and in seeking to provide effective measures aimed at prevention of maritime disasters, the RAN Hydrographic Service, has begun a new program to support integrated electronic navigation systems through provision of a digital chart data base. Such systems (generally known as ECIDS) have the potential to reduce significantly the number of groundings caused by human error. Groundings are the type of casualty causing the highest number of oil spills world-wide. ECIDS is being promoted by the International Maritime Organisation as a technology offering significant improvements in navigation safety. There is widespread support for it in the international community and in Australia. The Navy is currently evaluating the merits of a project to provide a national ECIDS data base for providing progressive national coverage over the next five years.
Recommendation 20

The Committee recommends that AMSA, the CSIRO and the Australian Hydrographic Service review imaging spectrometer technology and determine whether it could be cost effectively utilised to improve navigation in Australia's waterways. (Paragraph 5.34)
Comment

Agreed. The RAN Hydrographic Service already uses remote sensing techniques such as the Laser Airborne Depth Sounder in the collection of material for charts. The Hydrographic Service and CSIRO are already discussing the potential of imaging spectrometer technology and other remote sensing techniques which may have a positive contribution to make to safe navigation.

AMSA is currently conducting trials of a Differential Global Positioning System which broadcasts a correction to Global Positioning Systems enabling navigation accuracy to within 10 metres to be achieved.

A new DGPS broadcasting station on Horn Island in the Torres Strait will be operational by October 1995. With the establishment of this station AMSA will insist on the compulsory use by pilots of transportable global positioning equipment.
Recommendation 21

The Committee recommends . . . that the Commonwealth Government work internationally towards acceptance of compulsory pilotage in sensitive areas while establishing a register of such areas around Australia's coast with a view to their promotion for this purpose. (Paragraph 5.37)
Comment

The Government has been to the fore of international developments particularly in relation to safety of life at sea and marine environment protection. It works through the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) to achieve international agreement on such measures which may include compulsory pilotage.

The Great Barrier Reef has been declared a Particularly Sensitive Area by the International Maritime Organisation and pilotage through the reef is compulsory. AMSA have agreed to pursue the question of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait. It will now become AMSA's highest international priority in negotiations through the IMO.
Recommendation 22

The Committee calls upon AMSA, and other relevant Commonwealth Government agencies, to ensure that this Report's recommendations regarding preventative measures for shipping are reflected in international conventions. (Paragraph 5.41)
Comment

The basis of AMSA's activities in relation to safety of life at sea and marine environment protection are predicated by a `prevention first' approach. This is reflected in the comprehensive range of international conventions that Australia has helped to develop and to have internationally endorsed, and subsequently implemented domestically through Commonwealth/State and Territory legislation. The `prevention first' approach will continue to be followed whenever there is an opportunity for Australia to influence the content of such conventions.
Recommendation 23
The Committee recommends that the CAA be required to provide its own suitably equipped launches at all major airports located near water for use in emergencies. (Paragraph 5.48)
Comment

Search and rescue outside the boundaries of airports are the responsibility of State and Territory emergency management authorities although CAA accepts responsibility for rescue of persons and property from an aircraft that has crashed on, or in the vicinity of, an airport. The vicinity is identified as the area within 1,000 metres of the airport boundary. CAA intends to provide a first-stage response to aircraft crashes on water within this area by providing in-shore rescue boats crewed by trained aviation firefighters to provide an immediate rescue capability for aircraft occupants until the second stage, and more substantial, State or Territory rescue response arrives on the scene. The first boat was commissioned in Hobart on 1 July 1994. Further boats are expected to become operational in Sydney, Brisbane, Cairns, Coolangatta and Mackay during the next few months.
Recommendation 24

The Committee recommends that the Minister responsible require ANSTO to draw up a plan in consultation with the [Sutherland] Shire Council on matters relating to preparedness and planning at Lucas Heights, and in particular evacuation procedures for the Shire. (Paragraph 5.56)
Comment

There is no requirement to draw up additional emergency response plans relating to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories (LHRL). There have been detailed arrangements in place since the early 1960s which set down the actions to be taken by the relevant Commonwealth and State authorities in the remote event of an incident at the LHRL which has off-site consequences. These arrangements have been developed jointly between ANSTO and the relevant authorities including EMA. The enactment of the NSW State Emergency Management and Rescue Act 1989 required that the previous emergency management arrangements be reviewed. The new arrangements are in place and are being continuously refined as necessary by ANSTO and the State authorities.

The emergency arrangements for the LHRL are regularly exercised by ANSTO in conjunction with State and local government authorities. The new arrangements were the subject of a comprehensive exercise held by the State authorities and ANSTO in December 1993. Sutherland Shire Council officers participated in this exercise. Following the exercise, the Nuclear Safety Bureau, the Commonwealth body responsible for monitoring the safety of ANSTO's research reactors, concluded that the relevant emergency arrangements provide effective protection for site personnel and members of the public.
Recommendation 25

. . . the Committee recommends that Emergency Management Australia work with Commonwealth bodies which have direct emergency management responsibilities to set and maintain appropriate plans in areas of Commonwealth jurisdiction. (Paragraph 5.57)
Comment

Agreed. EMA maintains links with relevant Commonwealth bodies through designated Disaster Service Liaison Officers and through the CCDTF. These links will be used to remind Commonwealth bodies of the need to prepare and maintain, in conjunction with relevant State and Territory emergency management authorities, emergency plans for areas and resources under their jurisdiction. A review of Commonwealth policy on emergency management is currently being carried out by EMA before presenting that policy for consideration by Cabinet through the CCDTF. The discussion paper on this proposed policy has been widely circulated within the Commonwealth Government structure.
Recommendation 26

The Committee recommends that the Department of Social Security review guidelines for payments to volunteers with the objective of ensuring that volunteer activity is not unduly inhibited by financial situations. (Paragraph 6.24)
Comment

The Department of Social Security regards the payments made to volunteers after the NSW bushfires as a `one-off' event which should not be taken as a precedent for future payments. At a meeting of the National Emergency Management Committee, State and Territory representatives unanimously recommended that volunteers not be paid by the Commonwealth for their emergency service involvement. The issue will be examined in the review of emergency payment arrangements being carried out for the Commonwealth Counter Disaster Task Force.
Recommendation 27

The Committee . . . recommends that funding for the National Bushfire Research Unit be increased and that the possibility of raising money from the States for bushfire research again be explored on the basis that bushfire management is a State responsibility. (Paragraph 7.29)
Comment

CSIRO's Bushfire Research Unit is funded as a project within the Division of Forestry and its degree of financial support within the organisation is determined in relation to other priorities of the Division. The Unit's basic research is of national significance and is relevant to all States and Territories. As bushfire management is a State responsibility, the Government considers that any additional funding for further research should be provided by the States and Territories. Collaborative work with State agencies is conducted on a project-by-project basis with States contributing operating funds and in-kind support. CSIRO would welcome initiatives from the States for further joint ventures to address the priorities identified in the Report. The management of agreed research projects would be undertaken cooperatively.

The Division of Forestry needs improved laboratory facilities to carry out bushfire research and is currently costing a proposal to construct a fire research (combustion) laboratory to undertake basic research not possible in the field.

CSIRO has carried out significant programs in Victoria, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory using contemporary remote sensing technologies to help assess fuel loading during fire seasons or to detect fires using airborne scanners. These fields would have potential for further activity, possibly involving the Bushfire Research Unit, the Office of Space Science and Applications, other CSIRO units and operational agencies (including the Bureau of Meteorology).
Recommendation 28
The Committee recommends that the Spectrum Management Agency review the situation in Western Australia with a view to allocating emergency services to a dedicated frequency block. (Paragraph 7.44)
Comment

The Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) allocates radio frequencies to organisations and individuals throughout Australia in response to requests. Some requests are for allocation of specific frequencies while others are for allocation within a specific band of frequencies. As far as possible the Agency endeavours to meet these requests consistent with the need to ensure no interference is caused to existing users. The radio frequency spectrum is a finite natural resource and frequency availability is limited especially in major metropolitan areas.

The SMA and the former Department of Transport and Communications have for many years, through involvement with individual services and at a local government level, actively encouraged emergency services to coordinate their radio communications infrastructures. Several State Governments are presently taking the opportunity to rationalise some of their radio communications use as part of a restructuring of the VHF frequency bands.

The specific difficulties associated with sharing of certain frequency bands by the Western Australian Bushfires Board and local shire councils have been resolved at local government level. The SMA will review the allocation of a dedicated frequency block for WA emergency services in association with the EMA National Communications Advisory Group on which it has been invited to participate.
Recommendation 29

The Committee recommends that National Emergency Management Committee request the National Communications Advisory Group to review emergency communications throughout Australia with a view to finding ways of achieving standardisation and compatibility among and between State emergency services. The Committee further recommends that a representative of WICEN be included in the Group. (Paragraph 7.46)
Comment

At its meeting in August, the National Emergency Management Committee supported involvement of the National Communications Advisory Group in the review proposed by the Senate Committee. Membership of the group is to be reviewed and widened to encompass a broader range of interests. The Wireless Institute Civil Emergency Network (WICEN) has been invited to join the group.
Recommendation 30

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government in conjunction with State governments trial at least 4 CL-215 water bombing aircraft on a shared cost basis, and that other uses for these aircraft be fully explored. (Paragraph 7.54)
Comment

The Government carried out a preliminary assessment of the cost of further trials of the capabilities of various aircraft and systems for aerial suppression of fire. The trials would need to examine the capabilities of various fixed and rotary winged aircraft using the latest suppression techniques and taking into account the capabilities of a number of recently introduced aircraft. It was established that the cost of the trials would be very high and that they would need to be carried out in collaboration with the States and Territories. The subject was discussed at a meeting of State and Territory Ministers responsible for emergency management matters which was convened by the Minister for Defence in December 1994. With the exception of South Australia, all agreed that there was no evidence that larger aircraft would be of any economic benefit in bush fire fighting. The consensus was that the present method of aerial fire suppression using an appropriate mix of agricultural air craft and helicopters was more suitable for Australian conditions.
Recommendation 31

The Committee . . . recommends that the Government should reconvene the Emergency Broadcasting Committee to consider generally the subject of emergency broadcasting issues and specifically the need for agreed rules on access to the media in times of emergencies. (Paragraph 7.63)
Comment
Agreed. A meeting of the Emergency Broadcasting Committee will be convened to examine issues raised by the Committee. Membership will be reviewed to ensure appropriate examination of the issues.
Recommendation 32

The Committee . . . recommends that, as part of the International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction, EMA formalise arrangements for coordinating international offers of assistance, or requests for help, during times of disaster. (Paragraph 7.70)
Comment

The Government requested the CCDTF to give the issue consideration in the context of developing the Commonwealth policy on natural disaster response which was endorsed by Cabinet in December 1994. In this policy the Government stated that coordination of offers of and requests for international assistance would be the joint responsibility of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Emergency Management Australia. The policy was noted by State and Territory Ministers at the Ministerial Meeting later that month.
Recommendation 33

The Committee . . . recommends that the Department of Social Security produce an information document which makes very clear the conditions under which volunteers may receive payments through the Special Benefits and DRP schemes, and why some firefighters received Act of Grace payments, and circulate this document to all Brigades in Australia, through relevant State government departments. (Paragraph 7.81)
Comment

This issue is to be considered in the Department of Social Security review of emergency payments arrangements being carried out for the CCDTF. Suitable public information material will be made available once the results of the review have been approved and put into place.
Recommendation 34

The Committee believes that the issue of fire protection on land used by the armed services is important and recommends that the Government require the Department of Defence to improve communications between Defence personnel and surrounding Shire fire control officers, and improve fire prevention and suppression activities at each of its bases. (Paragraph 7.94)
Comment

Defence fire protection policy is contained in the Defence Manual of Fire Protection Engineering, identified as a Defence Policy by a Defence Instruction General (Administration) 20-26. Specific policies are in place to cover the requirement for liaison with local fire authorities when preparing fire management plans which address the issues of hazard reduction, fire protection and suppression requirements identified by the Report. These policies are further amplified by Single Service Fire Manuals. The issues raised in evidence to the Committee, although of concern, are localised instances and not a general reflection of Defence land and fire management practices. The specific issues raised on Holsworthy and RAAF Base Pearce are being examined by the responsible area Commands.
Recommendation 35

The Committee . . . recommends that EMA conduct a review of all State and federal reports on major conflagrations over the last 50 years to identify key elements of prevention and suppression, and develop a national bushfire preparedness strategy, with emphasis on improving national coordination and cooperation (Paragraph 7.100)
Comment

The Australian Fire Authorities Council agreed to undertake this review for EMA and provided a preliminary report in January 1995 in relation to the review of conflagrations. Further work in now continuing on the development of a national bushfire preparedness strategy.
Recommendation 36

The Committee reminds State governments that they have a clear constitutional responsibility to prepare for and respond to bushfire threats and, while the Commonwealth government can and does assist, States must give bushfire management higher priority in their allocation of resources. (Paragraph 7.103)
Comment
Noted. EMA has drawn this recommendation to the attention of State and Territory members of the National Emergency Management Committee.
Recommendation 37

The Committee draws the attention of the Government of Western Australia to the difficulties being experienced by rural communities which have wide responsibilities for fire management but few resources with which to properly equip and train themselves. (Paragraph 7.116)
Comment.
Noted. EMA has drawn this recommendation to the attention of Western Australian members of the National Emergency Management Committee.
Recommendation 38

While the Committee supports EMA's proposed change in focus it is important that EMA more clearly address in its corporate plan those other areas for which the Commonwealth can play a direct role: preparedness planning, prevention/mitigation, training and recovery as well as actual disaster response. While the Committee acknowledges that these elements are contained within the core functions which EMA sets itself, the Committee recommends that they be specifically addressed in the mission statement. (Paragraph 8.16)
Comment
Agreed. In the next revision of the EMA corporate plan the mission statement will be changed from:

PARA.TAB: `To promote and support effective emergency management in Australia and its region of interest'

SPEECH.PARA: to

PARA.TAB: `To promote and support comprehensive, integrated and effective emergency management in Australia and its region of interest'

SPEECH.PARA: This change of emphasis has been included in the latest edition of the Australian Counter Disaster Handbook. This ensures that the approach recommended by the Committee is widely promulgated.

EMA has reviewed its Corporate Plan (1994-95) and is continuing to seek ways of developing flexibility and sensitivity in its program to enhance comprehensive emergency management. In future, EMA will examine further ways of developing the total national emergency management capability through increased emphasis on preparedness/planning, prevention/mitigation, training and recovery activities as well as disaster response.
Recommendation 39

Because of the importance of natural disaster reduction programs the Committee repeats its recommendation set out a paragraph 1.37 that EMA give higher priority to activities under IDNDR and, in particular, work towards gaining increased State and Territory commitment to their own IDNDR projects. (Paragraph 8.17)
Comment
Agreed. The response to this recommendation is given in answer to Recommendation 1.
Recommendation 40

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth and the States and Territories jointly commit more funds to the following critical areas of emergency preparedness: training, research, information collection and dissemination and public awareness. (Paragraph 8.18)
Comment

EMA has been undertaking a review of its support for the activities mentioned. Greater flexibility in the use of State Support Package funds will facilitate reallocation of funds to these critical areas. EMA has opened discussions with other Commonwealth agencies on methods used to develop alternative funding sources.
Recommendation 41

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government make a clear commitment to the retention of the AEMI at Mount Macedon. The Committee regards the location of the Institute outside Canberra as an advantage and cautions against calls for its relocation on the basis of cost cutting. (Paragraph 8.19)
Comment
No final decision has been made on the facility at Mount Macedon. However, the Government has a predilection to retaining the Australian Emergency Management Institute at that location.
Recommendation 42

The Committee recommends that EMA be removed from the Defence portfolio and that it be placed administratively within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Committee further recommends that EMA be set up as an independent body with its own legislation and funding through a separate budget program. (Paragraph 8.22)
Comment

The Government considers that the current location of EMA has enabled it to carry out its planning and response tasks effectively, and has not adversely affected its performance or its resource base. As a sub-program with the Defence Portfolio, EMA is well able to relate to the relevant program areas within Defence that provide the bulk of Commonwealth physical and technical services which are supplied in times of emergency. Indeed, EMA's location in Defence is probably the most cost-effective way of addressing both its long-term planning and short-term response roles.

Moving EMA into the Prime Minister's portfolio would not, of itself, necessarily improve EMA's effectiveness in carrying out its mission. To the degree that major natural disasters require the capacity to coordinate physical and technical responses effectively, EMA has demonstrated that it is currently well-placed. In addition, as a key member of the CCDTF, chaired by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C), EMA liaises closely with PM&C on strategic planning and, through this forum, also has a conduit to the Prime Minister in times of national emergency.

It is Government policy that legislation should only be proposed when it is necessary, as a matter of law, to give effect to the desired policy. As stated in the Legislation Handbook: `Legislation should not be proposed simply to give a matter `visibility' if it can be implemented without legislation'. Moreover, EMA has operated successfully for over 20 years under administrative arrangements. Hence, Commonwealth emergency management legislation is not considered necessary in the present circumstances.
Recommendation 43
Because the Commonwealth is required to put in place effective civil defence planning the Committee recommends that this responsibility be given to EMA. (Paragraph 8.28)
Comment

Agreed. EMA already has this responsibility and is involved in policy, planning and other development activities. Two staff members are dedicated to the civil defence function. Courses and a range of awareness raising activities are also conducted at the Australian Emergency Management Institute and elsewhere.
Recommendation 44

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Counter Disaster Task Force and the National Emergency Management Council (sic) take responsibility along with EMA for the development of an integrated approach to civil defence and emergency planning. (Paragraph 8.29)
Comment

The Government agrees that planning for civil defence and for emergency management should be integrated to the degree that there are common features and in the light of the Geneva Conventions Amendment Act 1991. EMA and the CCDTF gave consideration to this issue in the development of a Commonwealth policy on natural disaster response which was endorsed by the Government in December 1994. A national civil defence policy developed under the aegis of the National Emergency Management Committee was endorsed in principle by the Government at the same time.
Recommendation 45

The Committee recommends that the [Commonwealth Counter Disaster] Task Force take on the wider role for which it was set up. That is, coordinating forward planning of Australian Government disaster relief systems, both short and long term. (Paragraph 8.30)
Comment

The Government endorses the broad role of EMA in forward planning for the Commonwealth physical and technical response to natural disasters. The other major components of Commonwealth response to natural disasters, financial support to the States through the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements and to individuals through the Disaster Relief Payments and Special Benefits provisions of the Social Security Act, are currently being reviewed in parallel with the development of a Commonwealth policy statement on natural disaster response.
Consistent with the Committee's recommendation the CCDTF coordinated the development of this policy statement, which was endorsed by the Government in December 1994

While the CCDTF's current coordinating role is likely to be reinforced through this process, Government does not envisage that the CCDTF will take a significantly more detailed role in planning for natural disaster relief. It is likely that planning responsibility at the Commonwealth level will remain primarily with the key Commonwealth programs which provide the direct response to natural disasters.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, a point has just been raised with me, and I would like to ask for your guidance on it. In the last vote, Senator Margetts asked that her negative vote and that of her colleague, who was not in the chamber at the time, be recorded. I would have thought that it would set an extraordinary precedent if we started recording the votes of people not in this chamber. This is a matter that Senator Bell has raised with me; I do not wish to claim authorship for the idea. But I would like to be clear—and I suspect all senators would like to be clear—that as the process is that only senators present are allowed to be recorded as voting, that should be the case.

—by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was in the chamber at the time. I took it that Senator Margetts was seeking to make a brief statement by leave. She was not seeking to utilise the provisions contained in the standing orders for a vote to be recorded. As you would be aware, the provisions dealing with divisions also state that where a senator is voting for or against a matter and the chair rules against that senator, that senator can have his or her name formally recorded as voting against it. However, I was in the chamber at the time and I was of the understanding that Senator Margetts was merely making a statement by leave rather than seeking to utilise that mechanism.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—It was sought by leave of the Senate and leave was granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the understanding is that Senator Margetts was merely making a statement by leave indicating her attitude to the ballot, that is fine. I understood when I heard her speak that she was asking that her negative vote be recorded.
—And Senator Chamarette's, too.
—Yes, and Senator Chamarette's negative vote too. I am just concerned that you cannot ask for a negative vote to be recorded if you are not in the chamber.

—You are quite right; she sought leave to have Senator Chamarette's vote recorded in the negative and leave was granted. Unless you wish to formally reverse that—and I do not know whether that is possible—as leave was granted, I would have to—

—I am advised that it has happened plenty of times before. This may be something that we might ask for further information about. Perhaps Mr President might be the person who could assist us with this matter.

—I wish to make a brief statement, as it might assist Senator Crowley. If the matter is of concern, Senator Crowley might consider it appropriate to raise the matter the next time the President is in the chair. It will expedite the proceedings at this point and it would not seem to go against the good work of the Acting Deputy President.

—I understand that; I will have to seek leave and we will have to move motions. We can certainly raise that. It is in Hansard and I am sure Mr President is listening to it. We will make sure that it is brought to Mr President's attention for advice.
—I will undertake to do that and refer it to the President.

—I think it is a very valid point that Senator Crowley raises. I would like it recorded that my opinion is that it should be brought to the attention of the President and a ruling sought because it is contrary to the spirit of the chamber.

—by leave—Just briefly, I would like to point out that it has been done on numerous occasions in the past. If it was not valid for today, it was not valid for all those occasions in the past. Why are you trying to break precedence as well, because it has been done before and it is perfectly acceptable to ask that it be done the same way again?

—Perhaps it is something that we could refer to the President. The President may then refer it to the procedure committee and we could get a definitive ruling on it. As the Senate granted leave, I am bound by that and I know of no mechanism to reverse it. It will now go forward to the President, and hopefully then to the procedure committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the failure of the Government to understand the critical position of the new car industry in South Australia and Victoria;
(b)condemns Labor's attack on economic recovery in South Australia and Victoria by its decision to increase taxes on the new car industry; and
(c)urges all Australians to help throw this Government out before it does even more harm to the interests of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not give me much pleasure to move this motion, because this government stands condemned for its incredibly short-sighted decision to increase the sales tax on non-luxury cars, which will have such a devastating effect on my home state of South Australia and on the state of Victoria. I am pleased that Senator Crowley is here, and I know that Senator Foreman was in here previously, because it is our state which has, after 10 years under state Labor governments, reached the stage of virtual economic ruin. Now, under Premier Brown's Liberal government, we are determined to do what we can to get the state's economy back on track. This unconscionable decision of the government will make the task just that much harder.

PARA.TAB: Jobs are going to be lost in South Australia because of this tax grab by the government which, despite its rhetoric, is obviously not interested in keeping jobs and companies in South Australia. I highlight that by saying that, prior to this budget being brought down last Tuesday night, the premier wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and said some very important things which particularly concerned South Australia. One of the important things he said was that we must be aware of the added burden that an increase in new taxes would bring to specific regions within Australia.

South Australia is particularly heavily dependent on the car industry for providing employment and prosperity in South Australia. Some 50 per cent of this nation's new cars are produced in South Australia; 9,000 South Australians are employed at General Motors Holden at Elizabeth and by Mitsubishi at Clovelly Park; and 25,000 people are currently employed in South Australia's growing component manufacturing sector, car dealerships sector and other associated industries. These jobs are going to be at risk if production slows or jobs are lost at either GMH or Mitsubishi. Mitsubishi has already said that, despite planning for a small increase in employment this year, there will now be no extra recruiting.

Even the unions in South Australia are disgusted with this budget measure. I am quite sure that if Senator Foreman was in the chamber, he would feel quite uncomfortable—he has a background in the vehicle industry. The secretary of the vehicle division of the Automotive, Foods, Metals and Engineering Union, Paul Noack, said this is `economic madness'. One of Labor's supporters, the secretary of the union is suggesting it is economic madness. He said the sales tax increase is `a disincentive, just when the industry needs support'.

The sales tax on non-luxury cars will increase by five per cent, from 16 to 21 per cent, and this is going to add $330 million to government revenue in the next financial year. The price of popular non-luxury cars will increase by $500 to $1,600 and the average family car will now cost between $800 and $1,000 more. The cost of a standard Holden Commodore will rise from $23,554 to $24,570, a jump of $1,016. The price increase in cars alone will add 0.3 of a per cent to the consumer price index. Try to convince anybody who is involved in that industry or anybody who is about to purchase a car just how much this budget is going to help them!

The government says in Budget Paper No. 1 that the sales tax on non-luxury cars was reduced to 16 per cent as `an anti-cyclical measure in One Nation'. It goes on to say, `Strong growth in the economy has removed any need for a concessional rate.' I wonder what cuckoo land this government is in if it believes that strong growth has removed the need for the concessional rate. The increase in sales tax could not have come at a worse time. The Australian car industry has already been hit hard by the government's high interest rate policy and the increase in fringe benefits tax on company vehicles.

The falling value of the Australian dollar has also put an upward pressure on car prices. The demand for vehicles dropped by 27.9 per cent in April and new car registrations were already forecast to fall in the second half of 1995. One can only say, in the light of this budget, that they are now likely to plummet. There are predictions that there will be a severe downturn with the loss of some 25,000 car sales this year alone. The Managing Director of Mitsubishi Motors in my home state of South Australia, Mr Mike Quinn, has predicted that Mitsubishi sales this year will drop by about five per cent from 625,000 to 600,000. GMH predicts its sales production figures will drop from 650,000 to 630,000.

Modelling by Access Economics shows that even after one year, the increased sales tax on non-luxury cars will result in sales being down by 2.32 per cent. The modelling shows that even four years later, the reduction in sales will settle at 0.92 per cent below the level that would have been applied if there had not been a sales tax increase. Even if sales do increase back to the pre-sales tax increase level, this will still be considerably below the 1985 level.

Even before the announcement of the sales tax slug, Australian car makers were facing crucial investment decisions about their long-term commitment to production in Australia. This sales tax rise could be the final nail in the coffin for some of those companies; and for the decisions they may take in the future. Jobs and businesses are now at risk, particularly in South Australia and Victoria.

The car industry still has not recovered completely from the recession we had to have and Labor is now hitting it again with another tax rise. The Australian Automobile Association has dubbed the sales tax rise as a lose-lose decision. The environment and road safety will lose out because older cars mean more pollution and possibly more accidents; the motor industry will lose out because of reduced sales; and the government loses out because the increases in sales tax will be offset by reduced sales. It seems that the government just does not learn from its past mistakes.

In 1990, when the luxury car sales tax was introduced, sales collapsed from about 18,000 to 6,500 per year, and the government lost $1 billion in revenue over three years. This measure means that motorists will be forced to keep their cars for even longer. This will have negative effects on both the environment and road safety.

The Australian Automobile Association says that Australian cars are already amongst the oldest in the Western world. They are on a par with Brazil and are not far behind Mexico and Greece. The slow rate at which we have been replacing our cars has seen the average age of our cars rise from 8.5 years in 1985 to over 10 years in 1995. In fact, half of the cars on Australian roads are now over 10 years old. This most ridiculous situation will now be exacerbated by the budget decision to increase sales tax. If this government really cared about the environment, it would make sure that the average age of our cars is consistently reduced, not increased.

This government, by its actions in the budget, is shooting Australia in the foot. It is also dealing a massive blow to South Australia, which has been virtually brought to its knees by the decisions of 10 years of state Labor government and economic mismanagement. It desperately needs to get debt and unemployment under control. Putting 34,000 South Australian jobs at risk is not the answer. To once again quote union official Paul Noack, it is `economic madness'.

The government has miscalculated if it thinks it can persuade swinging voters to vote Labor at the coming election by putting up the price of family cars by $1,000. In many parts of my state of South Australia, a family car is not a luxury; it is an absolute necessity. A car is absolutely essential for the vast distances that have to be travelled, particularly by people in more remote areas. It is absolutely essential for families to have cars. They need to be able to travel to do all the things that are essential in their daily lives.

In the future this government will rue deciding to put up the price of a car—which is absolutely essential for the wellbeing of people in these areas—at a time when such people are feeling the effects of other factors, such as a drought on top of an economic recession. This budget measure will backfire on the Labor government, as it rightly should. It stands condemned for this attack on South Australia, the job prospects of many South Australians and the future prosperity of my state.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the debate on the government's increase in sales tax on new cars. I was very pleased to hear Senator Ferguson amend the motion to include Victoria. For a moment, I thought the Liberal Party had forgotten that Victoria had a car industry. I am very pleased that he did it. If he had not done it, I certainly would have. In Victoria, in particular—it can be said in Australia—the car industry is the backbone of the manufacturing industry generally.

PARA.TAB: It is a strategic industry that directly employs approximately 340,000 workers. But that is not the end of it. About 11 other industries are clustered around it. Glass, plastics, rubber tyres and textiles are perhaps the main ones. When all of them are added in, it becomes evident that more than half a million Australians depend on the car industry for their livelihood.

It is quite unbelievable that the government could have taken this step at a time when the sales of new vehicles are beginning to drop. We must be aware that volumes in the car industry affect the viability of the industry.
