If the government thinks it can push to this extent the manufacturers, which are hanging on by the skin of their teeth, it is running the risk that companies such as Ford and others—which are carefully monitoring the future of the industry and their participation in Australia—will eliminate up to half a million jobs. The backbone of the manufacturing industry has been hard hit in the last few years by the government's policy of reducing tariffs.

While our tariffs are down to some 27 per cent at the moment, due to go down to 25 per cent, our trading partners in the region have tariffs ranging from 45 per cent to 100 or even 200 per cent. In this situation, it is utter folly to put pressure on an industry and to expect that the industry can simply recover from this new slug.

It might be useful to look briefly at the background of the sales tax on the car industry. The tax on passenger motor vehicles was 20 per cent until the One Nation statement in February 1992. In that year, it was reduced from 20 to 15 per cent, obviously to undercut Fightback. This was because the 20 per cent WST made cars more expensive than the 15 per cent GST. The WST rate for commercial vehicles, four-wheel drives and motor cycles was left at 20 per cent. Car sales rose from 406,000 in 1992 to 460,000 in 1994. But orders have been falling markedly since September with interest rate rises. The forecast for 1995 was recently pared down from 470,000 to 435,000—a very dangerous figure.

Let me look at some of the alternatives that the government could have employed if it wanted to get revenue out of the car industry. Tariff rates for passenger vehicles have been falling by 2.5 per cent a year since 1988, falling from 45 per cent in 1988 to a 15 per cent forecast for the year 2000. From 1 January 1996, the tariff will fall to 25 per cent. For an imported car, both tariffs and customs duty are payable. When we look at tariffs, our bound rate—that is, the rate we are obliged to maintain under the WTO treaty, the successor to GATT—is approximately 45 per cent. That means that we could easily raise tariffs to 40 per cent without infringing our obligations under the WTO treaty.

The proportion of imported cars sold here rose from 40 per cent in the March quarter 1994 to 47.5 per cent in the March quarter 1995. The April monthly figures show the trend is worsening. The rising value of the yen might offset this, although much of the growth of imports is from Korea and Malaysia, rather than Japan. The other area that we need to look at is the fact that the fringe benefits tax on company motor vehicles is proposed to be increased by about $120 million to pay for the concessions in the compliance review. This will mostly hit domestically produced cars, as fleet cars tend to be Commodores and Falcons. Once again, we must look at the government's policy, loading these two slugs on a car industry that is fighting for viability. Indeed, it is not too far fetched to say that it is fighting for its life.

The proposal that the government should consider is to raise the car tariff to 30 per cent and hold it there for two years before starting to reduce it. If the government is out for revenue, this measure would raise $105 million in 1995-96, $175 million in 1996-97 and $210 million in 1997-98. The tariff phase-out would finish in 2003 at 15 per cent. We also suggest that the tariff on passenger four-wheel drive vehicles not used to carry goods—this would exclude utilities—be phased in up to the same rate as passenger cars over two years; that is, in 1994-95, 10 per cent, in 1995-96, 20 per cent and, in 1996-97, 30 per cent.

So there are options that the government could have employed if it was concerned to obtain revenue from the car industry but at the same time wanted to ensure that the car industry remained a viable centrepiece of our manufacturing industries.

Another area the government could have looked at was gearing the sales tax to the fuel consumption rates of vehicles. For instance, one could develop a scale by looking at the ratio of litres per 100 kilometres so that: under 6.5 litres per 100 kilometres there should be no sales tax; between 6.6 and 7.8 litres, 20 per cent; between 7.9 and nine litres, 30 per cent; between nine and 10 litres, 35 per cent; and above 10 litres, 40 per cent.

That approach would ensure that the sales tax regime took into account long-term sustainability of car transport in our community. It is a principle that I believe sooner or later we will be forced to adopt. It should be sooner rather than later.

I once again put the Democrats' severe disappointment on the record that the government has seen fit to increase the sales tax on the sales of cars. At a time when the industry is already in a downturn, the estimated loss of some 25,000 car sales will clearly put many sectors of that industry in jeopardy and the industry will continue to lose jobs which have already been on the downward trend in that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few brief remarks in support of this motion, which quite properly condemns the Labor attack on the economic recovery in South Australia by its decision to increase taxes on the new car industry.
—What about your zero tariff plan for the car industry?

—It is unbelievably ironic that the two Labor senators who are in the chamber are both South Australians who ought to be utterly humiliated and ashamed that they have been utterly incapable of preventing this outrageous attack on the South Australian car industry and the South Australian economy. A fat lot of use you are to South Australians, sitting there without any influence on this government whatsoever. You have allowed this government to attack the car industry in South Australia and attack every South Australian by this outrageous increase in taxation.

PARA.TAB: This government ignores the fact that South Australia is in serious economic trouble after having Labor governments running the place for so very long. Now they have increased the tax by 37 1/2 per cent on the car industry, which is vital to South Australia. This is not a five per cent increase. This is a 37 1/2 per cent increase to Mr Keating in the taxation payable on cars. That is what we are talking about here—and it impacts on South Australia most severely.

The South Australian economy, after so many years of Labor government at state and federal level, is the lowest growth economy in Australia, has some of the lowest wages in Australia and is the most fragile economy in Australia after Tasmania. The car industry is vital to that economy.

As Senator Ferguson said, over half the new cars produced in Australia are produced in South Australia. Thirty-seven thousand South Australians are employed in the industry and two of the four manufacturers are based in South Australia. It is an industry that is absolutely vital to the state—and here we have the Labor government, the friend of the workers, attacking that industry.

The real problem is that this government ignores the regional problems in Australia. We have two economies in Australia: Queensland and Western Australia are growing at a massive rate, and the three southern states are in real trouble after so many years of Labor government and Labor ignorance of their problems.

I bet you this government has made absolutely no assessment of the regional impact of this decision. It just says, `We have to get more money from somewhere. We conned the voters back in 1992 on this thing. We dropped the tax to match Fightback. Now the 1993 election is over, let's whack the tax back up, because we think the voters are fools anyway, and ignore completely the consequences of this tax on South Australia and the regional impact of this tax.' They have ignored it completely.

Senator Ferguson has quite rightly pointed to the consequences of this. It completely ignores the government's rhetoric about the environment. It means that Australians will continue to drive older cars. Our car fleet is already virtually the oldest in the Western world. Australians will be condemned to driving old cars which pollute and which are dangerous.

This is a regressive tax because it will hurt the people that Labor professes to represent, particularly young people who cannot afford new cars. They will be condemned to driving dangerous, polluting old cars by this Labor government. It really treats its own voters with contempt.

Ironically, the electoral consequences will actually benefit us and hurt the Labor Party. We can be very confident of retaining the eight seats that we have of the 12 in South Australia because voters in South Australia will understand what this means. It means that Labor is treating them with contempt. It will be disastrous for Labor.

If Mr Bilney was worried before, he will be really worried now. There are 4,800 people at the Mitsubishi plant at Lonsdale and Tonsley Park in Mr Bilney's electorate of Kingston. He is sitting on a margin of 1.5 per cent. I think we can approach the electorate of Kingston with great confidence. Mr Bilney would be the one most upset by this decision. It will be disastrous for Labor on the ground in South Australia. As I said, South Australians have the lowest wages in Australia. That fact, combined with the effects of this measure on the car industry in that state, means that South Australians will be hit harder than almost anybody else when trying to buy a new car.

Under this government we have some of the highest interest rates in the Western world. Most people borrow money from the bank to buy a car. Not only will they be paying record high interest rates, they will also have to pay another $1,000 in sales tax. As far as the industry is concerned, today's headlines say it all: `Locally made car revenue may be driven backwards', `Car makers warn of sales melt down', `Car sales tipped to dive in wake of tax rise', `Manufacturers predict loss of 20,000 car sales'.

This is a disastrous decision, cynically made on the back of the 1992 decision to drop the tax in order to win a few more votes. The government should stand condemned for it and the two South Australian Labor senators in the chamber tonight should be ashamed of their failure to prevent this attack on South Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is coincidental that I am on chamber duty while this ranting mob on the other side are putting up this motion. I was particularly interested to hear them talk of their pious concern for the car industry. It is only just over two years ago that the coalition supported a zero tariff option for the car industry in Australia, aided and abetted by a South Australian Liberal member, then shadow minister for industry, Mr Ian McLachlan. He proclaimed that the car industry did not deserve tariff protection of government assistance. He said that if it went to the wall after the year 2000 that was just bad luck and the market would fix it.

PARA.TAB: The appalling attitude he expressed about the car industry had a big impact on Australian manufacturing industry in general. As one senior executive in the car industry said, `It's not just that his policy is wrong or that he doesn't understand; when you talk to him it's clear that he just doesn't care.' Ian McLachlan, the then shadow minister for industry, went to the back bench for a period, was shadow minister for the environment for a period, and has now disappeared back to the back bench.

The opposition talks about its concern for this industry but it is the Labor government which, over the last 13 years, has developed the car industry plan and has turned our car industry from being on its deathbed.

I want to remind Senator Ferguson and Senator Minchin that back in 1982-83, when their party was in government, the car industry in Australia exported cars or components worth under $100 million a year, and it was in decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were selling a lot more than they are today.

—The figures show that it was about $50 million. In South Australia it was about $20 or $30 million. That was in your last year of government. What do the figures show in 1993-94? I think it is around $1.4 billion worth of cars and car component exports. Why has that occurred? It was a Labor government which introduced the Button car plan—and it ought to be called the Button car plan because it was John Button's drive, initiative, wit and intelligence that got the industry together with the government and the unions to create the great culture change that that industry needed—and now it is a world competitive industry.

PARA.TAB: You might not know this, Senator, but if you look at the last full financial year figures for exports from South Australia, you will see that the car industry is the single biggest exporting industry in South Australia. Mr Acting Deputy President, these fools opposite do not understand that when you export a car, you pay no sales tax on it. We are talking about growth in the export industry. They do not pay sales tax at all; therefore, they are not affected by it and the export industry continues to grow.

As a backbencher and as minister for small business, I have had the opportunity to visit a number of firms, not only big firms such as General Motors and Mitsubishi but also quite a few of the small manufacturing component industries and associated engineering and metal fabrication plants in South Australia. Back in the early 1980s, when your policies were in operation, all the economic gurus said, `The car component industry in Australia is certainly dead and finished. It's got no future. It is inefficient. It only relies on quotas and high tariffs. It's got no future. It cannot be competitive.'

If you went to visit those factories in South Australia now, you would see that they are absolutely competitive and they are exporting. Some of them are exporting well over 50 per cent of their product to the top car manufacturers of the world. Some of them are well known, and I hope that even some people opposite have heard of examples such as Castrol oil, ROH wheels and several others. The wheels of every Harley Davidson bike sold in the world today are made in Adelaide.

If you had said 10 years ago in South Australia that it was possible for a South Australian firm to provide the product for a well-known motorcycle brand around the world, you would have been taken away and locked up. No-one would have conceived that that was possible. It is possible because of this government's car plan introduced by John Button. Yes, it reduced tariffs sensibly, reduced the protection, but also provided the export facilitation plan to encourage exports, to get the car industry out of your mind-set, which is only the domestic market. I have to pay tribute here not only to the management of the car industry but also to the trade unions in the car industry in Australia, who accepted the challenge and the need for change in an enormous way. They and their workers have every right to be extremely proud of those changes and the sea change in culture to make our car industry well competitive.

There was a frenzy on the other side about the budget increase in sales tax. They failed to mention that in 1992, when the sales tax was dropped from 20 per cent down to 15 per cent, it was made quite clear in the One Nation statement that the sales tax was being dropped as a countercyclical economic measure—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—Look, you dimwits opposite, go and read the One Nation statement and you will see it clearly written that it was being reduced to provide an impetus for sales in the car industry during the recession. That was clearly stated. Of course, at that stage, the Liberal Party opposed One Nation. The opposition said One Nation was terrible when we dropped the sales tax by five per cent.
—We did not oppose that.
—You did oppose One Nation. You said it was terrible.
—We loved the tax cuts.

—You are picking the eyes out now. A bit of history is being rewritten here by those on the other side. We stated quite clearly in One Nation that it was a counter-cyclical measure. Now that the car industry is running at a much better level than it was in 1991-92, the level of sales tax has gone back to the long-term level that the former Liberal government had for 23 years, which is 20 per cent. That was the figure it kept it at year in, year out; whenever there was a recession, the former Liberal government did not budge from it.

PARA.TAB: I remember that in 1961 the former Liberal government jumped it to about 30 per cent and nearly crippled the car industry for all time. Even with another recession in 1982-83, did Fraser drop it to 15 per cent? No, he left it there. There was no stimulation for the car industry when there was a recession in the broader economy. It was kept at 20 per cent and those opposite supported this level that they are now claiming is so terrible. We are getting history rewritten. The Liberal Party has amnesia about its own industry policies.

I find it hypocritical that the Liberal Party is now crying crocodile tears when, during its whole history—23 years of Menzies, Holt, Gorton and McMahon, and including seven years of Fraser—sales tax was always at 20 per cent. Sometimes it was put up even higher. I refer, for example, to the famous 1961 credit squeeze.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you remember that?

—One thing you must understand about me is that I have been in politics for a long time. I learnt from the age of 10 that having a good memory in politics is a very useful asset. The only reason, I suspect, that I have survived this long in the Labor Party is that I remember, very well, what people have said. I know that I perform pretty well here, remembering what those opposite were up to in years gone by. That is what you lot did in the 1960-61 credit squeeze which nearly cost you government. You jumped the sales tax up to a level that nearly put General Motors, Chrysler and Ford out of business. It might be noted that it was the only time that the car industry came out and overtly supported Labor and gave sizeable donations to the Labor Party.
—Never again.
—We still get a fair bit of support. They certainly gave us moral support at the last election when your madman, Mr McLachlan, was running around talking about zero tariffs.
—That is not the way to describe a member of the other place, if you would care to withdraw that.

—I withdraw that comment and instead refer to Mr McLachlan's mad policies for the car industry. I want to conclude by referring to a couple of other issues that Senator Minchin raised. He said that the federal Labor government has no understanding of regional economics. Again, a very good case of amnesia has overcome Senator Minchin. I will just mention a few things to remind him of what the federal Labor government has done in South Australia in the last decade.

PARA.TAB: I will not dispute with Senator Minchin—it would be crazy for me to try, and I would not try—the impact of the collapse of the State Bank in South Australia. My party, at the state level, has copped it absolutely hard. It has suffered the biggest electoral defeat since the party was formed because of the public's view about responsibility for the State Bank collapse.

I certainly cannot ignore that the public made its judgment, nor the fact that the collapse of the State Bank has had a major economic impact on South Australia. But I suspect its psychological impact on the community's confidence is even greater than the size of the economic losses from the collapse. I acknowledge that, and the Labor Party, both state and federal, has paid an extremely high price in South Australia. At the last election, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced $600 million in compensation for the sale of the State Bank. Despite the change of government in South Australia, 80 per cent of that $600 million has now been paid, even though the bank has not been sold.

I think over $450 million of that money has been paid into the state budget. I will bet Stephen Baker is very grateful that it has been paid. That was negotiated by the previous state Labor government with the federal government and the Prime Minister before the last election. That is $600 million for South Australia for a mistake for which the federal Labor government was in no way responsible.

Senator Minchin asked what else we have done. I remember that in the mid-1980s we made sure that the federal Labor government took a decision to ensure that the submarine contract went to South Australia. An excellent proposition was put forward with the full support of the South Australian community, including the trade unions, the Chamber of Commerce and the opposition. It was bipartisan. The community of South Australia performed very well in bringing maximum resources to bear to win that contract with an excellent bid.

However, I have to say that that occurred in the face of extremely stiff competition from areas where people would normally have expected this contract to be let—Sydney, Melbourne or Newcastle, the more traditional shipbuilding areas of Australia. The federal Labor government took a decision and said, `We will build a greenfield submarine facility in South Australia from scratch.' That was a $4 billion contract. It has created thousands of jobs and given critical mass to high-quality engineering jobs in South Australia. That was a decision that a strong federal Labor government was able to make against strong opposition and weight coming from Sydney, Melbourne and Newcastle demanding that this is where we would normally expect the project to go. Do not tell me that the submarine project was not of major benefit to South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's that got to do with sales tax?
—Senator Minchin said that we do nothing for the regional economy of South Australia.
—That's not the regional economy.
—That is the regional economy. It employs thousands of people.
—What about outside Adelaide?

—Let us go to an event that occurred last week; I refer to the completion of the standardisation of the Adelaide-Melbourne railway line. It has not been officially opened yet. That was a One Nation project costing several hundred million dollars. That money was spent in South Australia, making sure that Adelaide is now connected directly by standard gauge to all the other capital cities. That was a major initiative in One Nation which the opposition criticised by saying that too much money was being spent. This money was spent in South Australia to ensure that the railway transport system was effective.

PARA.TAB: The opposition may not have noticed this—those opposite may have been asleep—but recently Senator Robert Ray announced the allocation of $50 million for the rebuilding of DSTOs research laboratory at Salisbury. That is a major program of expenditure. We have the recent SARDI and CSIRO joint venture at Waite, and that was a contribution from the federal government. These are all areas of regional support into South Australia. They are specific federal government policies. For Senator Minchin to say that South Australia has been ignored is absolutely preposterous. The opposition should not complain about the level of sales tax on cars. For 30 years post-war whilst the opposition was in government it always supported sales tax rates at the same level. Now the opposition complains that it has risen to that level. For those opposite to cry that that is something evil is extraordinary hypocrisy in political terms.

As I explained, the government had to make some tough decisions in this budget to ensure that we got the deficit down and into surplus so that the pressure on interest rates was reduced. But it is more important to have the pressure off interest rates so that consumers know that they can buy cars, houses and products without interest rates going up. We need to have greater stability in interest rates. That is what this government's budget strategy was about from the very beginning.

From this opposition we have only criticism about expenditure cuts and revenue measures. Those opposite keep saying that we should have been tougher on expenditure, but they will not tell us in which programs they would have made further cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has this got anything to do with the motion?

—It has, absolutely. We had to make some tough decisions to make sure that in equity terms the pain—and it is painful—of new revenue measures was spread evenly across the community. Cars went back to the long-term level of sales tax which is around 20 per cent. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to commence this Senate debate on the government budget, a budget brought down at a critical time in Australia's history when continued economic recovery is so vital after the devastating recession Mr Keating and his government inflicted on Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of tests that this budget must pass. It seems to me that the first is whether it is consistent with the government's election promises. Obviously, the answer is no. This government, and Mr Keating in particular, promised no new taxes and no increases in taxes. He breached that promise in his first budget, the 1993-94 one, and this compounds that breach of promises. Taxes go up at an extraordinary rate. Estimated total tax revenue in this budget goes up by 13.2 per cent. Estimated income tax—company and personal—revenue and individual income tax revenue go up by 13.5 per cent. These are huge increases. Overall estimated revenue in this budget goes up by 12.8 per cent. If this increase is realised, it will be the third highest rate of increase in the postwar period, a rate exceeded only by Mr Whitlam's first budget and Mr Keating's second budget in 1984-85. It reinforces not only that people cannot believe Labor but that Labor is the high tax alternative in this country.

The second test is whether this budget addresses the chronic current account problem this country faces. Again, the answer is no. This year's current account deficit is expected to come in at about $27 billion. What is the budget forecast for the budget year? Another $27 billion, or approximately six per cent of GDP. I remind honourable senators that is the percentage that Mr Keating used to refer to as a banana republic figure.

Thirdly, the question is whether the budget addresses our frightening load of foreign debt and the threat that that debt poses to our national economic sovereignty. Again, the answer is no. Foreign debt remains at a net figure of $160 billion—up or down a bit depending on the value of the dollar—a staggering figure, really beyond comprehension.

The next question is: will the budget provide economic growth necessary to adequately address our appalling level of unemployment? Again, the answer is no. The government's own green paper on unemployment said that to bring down unemployment—that is, to the government's goal of five per cent by the year 2000, which was already an incredibly high figure—we would need continual annual growth of 4.5 per cent. Yet this budget projects growth falling to 3.75 per cent. Mr Keating is on record as saying that any economy that cannot travel at four per cent without spilling over to imports should give the game away. He said that we ought to be able to run this economy at four per cent at least. Yet this budget projects a drop below that four per cent. Mr Keating fails his own test. But, more importantly, the hope dims for hundreds of thousands of Australians who are still out of work.

Will this budget take pressure off interest rates so that business might be encouraged to grow and prosper? Again, unfortunately, the answer is no. Total government real expenditure is not substantially reduced. The figure is only about three per cent—a bit less than three per cent, in fact.

As for the deficit reduction, of course, fudged by the hoped for capital repayment, the real figure—the underlying deficit figure—remains at something over $8 billion. If you add to that the current account failure that I mentioned a moment ago, realising, of course, that that will continue to put pressure on the dollar and that interest rates will have to stay up to protect the dollar, then there is little hope for a fall in interest rates as a result of this budget.

The second last point is: will it in fact contribute to savings? Again, at least in the short-term, the answer obviously is no. In the longer term, maybe; but that is a debate in itself—something that will not be known for some years. If you argue that one of the major economic issues facing Australia is how to address our savings shortfall, there is no answer in terms of the next few projected years in this budget. So on seven obvious, critical tests the budget fares poorly.

Budgets, however, are not just intellectual exercises. They contain decisions and choices of government which have massive impact on people's lives. It is worth reflecting that this is the government which gave us the worst recession in 60 years; which gave us the highest level of unemployment since the 1930s; which provided the economic stewardship which led to the highest interest rates since the Great Depression; and which produced record bankruptcies and record liquidations.

It is a government with an appalling economic record and with so much of its failure being directly the result of the errors of judgment of one man: Paul Keating. So much of the economic failure and personal misery which has resulted therefrom lies at the feet of Paul Keating. For 12 years he has pulled the levers. No longer can he blame the previous government. No longer can he blame the drought, or the world economy or someone else. It is time he accepted the failure of his policies, the failure of his performance.

Mr President, look at unemployment. Nothing so saps the confidence of individuals and undermines their personal dignity as unemployment. This government claims success in the battle against unemployment; yet, on today's figures, 765,000 Australians are still looking for work. The unemployment rate in Australia still remains 8.3 per cent. For adolescents it is more than three times that—26.5 per cent. That is why students were so angered by his recent `get a job' jibe. Mr Keating does not understand that they cannot get a job.

If we look at the tragedy of long-term unemployment, we will see that the figures have not improved markedly. In 1993, 37 per cent of unemployed were long term—out of work for more than a year. In 1994 the figure had dropped to just 36 per cent—the slightest of drops. Let us look at the even longer term unemployed. In 1992, 43 per cent of long-term unemployed were unemployed for two years or more. In 1993 it had gone up to 52 per cent. In 1994 it had gone up to 56 per cent. Some success record!

In international terms, we do not fare well at all. Compare our performance, Mr President, with other OECD economies. In December last year the USA, the UK, Germany and Japan all had lower levels of unemployment than Australia. Japan's level was three per cent. Some people think that is exaggerated. How often does this government look at the Asian experience when it is trying to equate Australia's economic performance and unemployment performance? It is a highly unsatisfactory result.

Despite the fact that there were some pleasing figures today, the consistent signs are that employment growth is again weakening—tragic signs, in fact. DEET's leading indicator of employment has declined for six consecutive months since peaking in September. In its commentary on the March figures, DEET said that continued decline in the indicator suggests that growth and employment would peak and begin to fall in the second half of this year.

If we are going to have an election in the second half of this year, it is because the government believes that unemployment is going to start rising again, and of course interest rates are going to rise with it. DEET's skilled vacancy survey index also has been declining for several months. The ANZ's job advertisement series fell for the third consecutive month in April. As I said, even with the growth projected in this budget, the situation cannot be improved. So it cannot be improved on the government's own figures. What does it do? In addition to that, in this budget it decides that it is time to slash funding for training. It is an obscure logic that calls for a slash in training funding at a time when unemployment not only is so high but also is likely to rise again.

It is typical Paul Keating. We have had the jobs white paper. The problem is solved and now he is on to the next issue. It simply demonstrates not only how out of touch he has become but also how insensitive he is to the real issues in the community.

Let us look at poverty. Of course, unemployment and poverty are related. The government boasts of its social welfare and welfare spending. However, the increase in welfare spending might as easily be viewed as an index of Labor's failure to achieve and maintain a sustainable rate of economic growth and full employment. Unemployment and poverty have become permanent social scars after 12 years of Labor government. A recent study by two ANU economists showed that since the mid-1970s a significant gap had emerged between low income, low employment neighbourhoods and high income, high employment neighbourhoods. Low incomes have been falling under Labor and high incomes have been rising. Children suffer as a result.

Another recently published survey of data found—these figures are really appalling—that 400,000 children are living in poverty, 200,000 children are homeless, there are 50,000 cases of reported child abuse each year, we have the highest rate of teenage suicide in the world and we have high levels of mental health disorders, tobacco, alcohol and drug abuse. Is this the Australia that we want?

When noted social commentator Hugh Mackay talked about the development of an underclass, Mr Keating and Labor simply scoffed. How often we say to Mr Keating, `Listen to the messengers; don't always knock the messengers.' But Mr Keating knows better—in his lifestyle and in his circle there is little poverty.

What about ordinary middle Australians—not the wealthy, not those living in poverty? In this budget they find the cost of their car rising by about $1,000 and the cost of a house rising by about $2,000. These were the people who voted for Labor at the last election because Mr Keating promised them no new or increased taxes. The same people who had to pay higher fuel prices as a result of the indexation can again expect another rise in wholesale sales taxes in July, already legislated but which sometimes the community forgets. These are the same people that Labor says should save more, without understanding that under Labor with its taxes, its interest rates and its costs these people simply do not have the discretionary income to save more. It is again Labor and, particularly, Mr Keating, who are out of touch.

The increase in company tax falls into the same category. Mr Keating says that some large businesses can afford it. Maybe so. But a lot of small businesses are incorporated. Another three per cent tax hike in company tax with added bank charges and probably added phone bills and postal charges flowing through from this budget will cause them to suffer greatly. In other words, not only are these tax increases a specific breach of promise, a part of Mr Keating's campaign of deceit at the last election, but also they will also harm the recovery and hurt middle Australia.

Australians do not like being deceived and they are angry about a Prime Minister who is so out of touch. I mentioned interest rates. The effect of this budget on interest rates is so important. Nothing stops small business in its tracks like rises in the cost of its finance. It is a lesson Labor should have learnt in the late 1980s and early 1990s when Mr Keating forced up interest rates to dampen demand in an effort to answer the current account decline and gave us the worst recession in 60 years.

This was the budget in which we were told to expect the substantial expenditure cuts as an alternative to pushing up interest rates and they simply did not occur. With inflation on the rise, with no improvement in the current account and a government which has baulked at major cuts in its own cloth, it is not surprising that most Australians fear a government reverting to type—that is, a government prepared to push up interest rates.

Australians remember that this government gave Australia the highest housing mortgage rates in 50 years. In fact, its irresponsible budgeting has meant that housing mortgage interest rates have been in double figures for all but 19 months of the last 12 years, and now they are in double figures again. Australians remember that from 1980 to 1990 housing interest rates went up to 17 per cent before the property market crashed and before the onset of the `recession we had to have'. Interest rates are now rising again. There have been three official interest rate increases since last August. If we look at the 90-day bill futures, we see that the finance market expects them to rise further.

Mr President, I remind you of what the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, said only a few months ago. He said that interest rates were still on the agenda even with a big cut in the deficit. Of course, a big cut in the underlying deficit simply did not come. Regrettably, all the signs are that the government has not learnt the lessons of the past. We are constantly reminded that Mr Keating is a big-picture man. If he is not prepared to look at the lot of individual Australians and the hardships they suffer under his management, perhaps he should reflect on the big picture. In March, the current account deficit was $2.3 billion, the second highest on record; for seven of the last eight months, the current account deficit has been above $2 billion. It has been nine years since Mr Keating gave his warning on a banana republic and nothing has changed. The pattern continues.

Australia's net foreign debt has doubled in a decade under Labor from around $80 billion to over $160 billion. A debt of that size, accumulated within a decade and spent on consumption, is an enormous burden on the next generation. The size of the debt and the debt service liability makes us especially vulnerable to fluctuations in international economic conditions and puts our economic sovereignty at risk. This Labor government has plunged Australia into recession and debt. Household debt is still at an extraordinarily high level. Now we are slipping in the income stakes. Honourable senators would have noticed that in the last year both Hong Kong and Singapore passed Australia on an income per capita basis. Who would ever have believed that 10 years ago? It would have been beyond comprehension.

Senior economists from the Asia-Pacific Economics Group at the ANU recently said that Australia's economic performance is poor. They said that the strong recovery from the recession was the wrong recovery, driven by domestic demand, including fiscal expansion in an economy with high foreign debt and a weak current account—Mr Keating should take note. Australians sense that something is seriously wrong, but, of course, it will not be addressed by Mr Keating because that would be to admit error and, to some extent, failure. The message, unfortunately, will not be heard.

The budget is a failure. On Paul Keating's own criteria it is a failure. It fails to reduce the fundamental deficit in the government's accounts. It fails to address the chronic problem of excessive spending, the chronic current account deficit, the accumulated foreign debt and the threat posed to our national economic sovereignty. It fails to produce a framework for sustainable economic growth and employment.

It is also a fraudulent document. Not only does it withdraw the promised tax cuts—the l-a-w legislated tax cuts—it replaces them with some of the largest revenue increases imposed in postwar budgets. Only Mr Keating would so insult the Australian people. After 12 long years, it is time for a fresh start. It is time for a different approach to the management of the economy, for a government which is prepared to take the hard decisions. It is time for a total change to the approach of government. It is time to introduce a new honesty into government—a prime minister who will tell the truth at election time. It is time for a prime minister who accepts parliamentary responsibility and is prepared to answer the parliament on each sitting day. It is time to be rid of Labor.

I conclude by referring to the report of the two eminent economists from the ANU who posed this question: as the current account widens and the economy slows in an election year, Australians may wonder about their economy's relatively poor performance. Is it the jockey or is it the horse? After this budget and 12 long years of Labor, we can all say with confidence that it is the jockey.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a good speech, Senator Hill. This is a clever budget. It is not a particularly responsible budget and it is not a particularly honest budget; but it is a clever budget. It is clever because its net effect and its real impact on the Australian community cannot be determined until after the next election. It is clever because its fundamental, fiscal integrity cannot be determined either until after the next election. It is a budget which reflects the government's No.1 priority; and that priority is not about reducing the current account deficit, getting unemployment down or moving towards a more equitable society. The priority is about getting its government re-elected.

PARA.TAB: When we put the budget in that context, its cleverness becomes apparent. With an eye on the markets and an eye to the next election, the government has brought down a budget which has plenty of up front gloss and, despite what we just heard, there are some positive things in this budget. But beneath its glossy surface, I think, lie some serious shortcomings.

On the very first page of the budget papers we are told of a $718 million surplus. Buried well down the list, 400 pages later, we are told that the real budget outcome is a deficit of $8.2 billion. That is the figure which the Commonwealth uses when it talks to the states. That is the figure used by the Reserve Bank and by Treasury. But a deficit of $8.2 billion does not have quite the same pre-election ring to it as the magic word surplus.

It is a pity the government has tried to dazzle us with that magic word. It is a pity it has opted for what is essentially a dishonest ploy of claiming a surplus. I am not alone in thinking it is quite incredible that the coalition has let the government off the hook on its claims, by the opposition's decision not to support a Senate inquiry.

Despite resorting to trickery, the government has delivered a fairly tough piece of fiscal tightening. The deficit has been reduced by $3 billion and, in anyone's book, that is quite a tough clawback. I wish to state on the record that the Australian Democrats accept the government's true fiscal outcome of an $8.2 billion deficit but we have always reserved the right to show the government how we believe its objectives could be achieved in a way which is fairer and more economically, socially and environmentally responsible.

With this budget we also have the responsibility to question the basis upon which the government has achieved its alleged surplus. We have a responsibility to point out that the outcome of this budget changes according to whomever the government is talking to. When the states put out their hands for money, we are still in deficit but when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is out and about selling the budget to the Australian people, we are magically in surplus. The simple fact acknowledged by every economic commentator in Australia after the budget is that we are not in surplus. This surplus depends upon achieving $5.35 billion worth of asset sales. That is a task which, on past performance, the government will go nowhere near achieving.

The Democrats have always determined our decision on privatisations on a case by case basis and we have been strongly critical for many years of the government's indiscriminate approach to the sale of public assets. We put on the record our commitment to retaining certain key public assets. Our belief is that the benefits of privatisation are often greatly overstated and frequently result in additional costs being borne by taxpayers.

There are reasons for supporting the sale of assets but we cannot see too many good reasons for supporting the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. We will continue to oppose that because the recent history of banking in this country has proven it to be non-competitive. In such an environment, we believe the government needs to have a role in setting some standards. If we take the example of superannuation and the recent history of it in this country, the only way the government could get the superannuation funds to deliver a fairer deal on fees was for the government to threaten to use the Taxation Office as a competitor. That is one reason, we believe, why the government should not give up one of the few means of influence it has over banking in this country.

In this instance, the argument against privatisation appears to be further strengthened by the threat of the government's disregarding the rights of existing shareholders. I saw Mr Costello on tonight's news threatening to block the bank's sale. Anyone who believes the government can and will raise $5.35 billion from asset sales and then deliver a surplus probably also believes that the world is flat and that Elvis is still alive and well. In fact, it is almost easier to believe that Elvis is alive than it is to swallow some of the lines in this budget.

For a start, it is pretty difficult to believe that the government can take an extra $1 billion in dividends and debt redemption out of government business enterprises without having any impact on their services. There will be reduced programs and increased customer charges, such as the cost of local telephone calls. It is also pretty difficult to believe that the government can take $1.2 billion out of labour market programs over four years without that having a detrimental effect on unemployed Australians.

It is pretty difficult to believe that the government can redefine the meaning of `indexing of inflation', use it to take $2 billion over four years out of Commonwealth grants and then claim that that will not have any effect on public and community sector programs. That last cut is a particularly insidious one which deserves very close scrutiny. The Commonwealth has a huge range of financial agreements which could be affected by these changes.

At the end of the funding line are those community based services which target the least well-off in our community: the sick, the aged, the disabled, veterans, the users of public hospitals and child-care centres, and indigenous Australians. If these indexation arrangements ultimately impact upon these sorts of services—there is absolutely no reason to suppose that they will not—it will actually make a mockery of the government's family friendly budget.

As I said, there are positives in this budget. The environment portfolio has done reasonably well with long awaited funding for a coasts inquiry and for restructuring of the forestry industry. The Democrats have been lobbying for both of these initiatives for a long time. We welcome them. We are still disappointed that they are underfunded. But the response on greenhouse gases is an incredibly token one which is certain to be ineffective. We are disappointed about the government's continuing lack of interest in using the taxation system to encourage better environmental outcomes. In fact, in this budget, the contrary has occurred, with higher taxes on recycled paper and higher taxes on low polluting new cars.

Another positive is the long overdue recognition of the need to assist workers with family responsibilities. In this case, it takes the form of what I think is a horrible term—the baby bonus. However, we are still ranked third last in the OECD in terms of the maternity assistance that we provide. But this is at least a start. Overall, as a package for families, the budget is pretty thin. Take Australia's poorest families—sole parent families. They get a $2 per week increase in the guardians allowance in 1996. Boy, that is generous; it starts then. There is then the increase in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme threshold for general patients. That will have a very severe impact on families with chronically ill members or disabled family members.

The Medicare levy increase is generally supported by the Democrats. However, we have concerns about where that additional revenue is being directed. We have asked the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to indicate how much of that revenue will find its way into new or additional health programs.

This budget contains an ambitious and far-reaching plan to increase national savings through superannuation. As we would know from the debate a couple of years ago, the Democrats have never objected to compulsory savings. But arising out of this move there are five key questions which the government needs to answer on the superannuation proposal. Firstly, what consideration is being given to the likelihood that the superannuation contribution will reduce the disposable income of low income families when they most need the money, which is during their younger years? Secondly, recognising this, what consideration will be given to allowing access to superannuation for life cycle needs, such as housing, retraining or additions to the family?

Thirdly, how will the $4 billion of superannuation contributions be funded? Fourthly, what happens if enterprise bargaining fails to extend superannuation across 80 per cent of the work force as predicted? In any event, what happens to the other 20 per cent of the workers? Fifthly, will the government now proceed to improve the interface between superannuation, taxation and the pension to reduce the effective 60-plus per cent tax rates faced by retirees on less than average weekly earnings?

Now that the government has given the superannuation industry another giant free kick—ownership of this nation's pool of capital—the Democrats believe it has an obligation to respond to these critical questions. As I indicated earlier in my speech, this budget represents a physical tightening of about $3 billion and the vast bulk of that tightening, some $2.4 billion, comes in the form of taxes. So let us talk about the three letter word tax.

Unlike the opposition, the Democrats have always recognised that deficit reduction, if it is not to adversely affect unemployment and the social safety net, needs to be a combination of expenditure cuts and revenue raising measures. We have also called on the government to use this opportunity to make the tax system fairer. The Democrats remain concerned about the impact of the company tax rise on small business, and we will certainly be putting forward proposals to address this problem. We would have preferred to have seen the government crack down on those companies not paying their fair share at the moment, those which are paying less than 20c in the dollar.

When it comes to provisional tax, the government wants to keep the uplift factor at three times the inflation rate. We opposed that last year; we are not convinced that it is needed this year. We will be very interested to see whether this time around, unlike last year, the coalition will actually join us in doing something for small business on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what the consequences were?

—I heard your three furphies last year, Senator Watson, and they were dismissed at the Senate inquiry. This budget contains $700 million worth of increases to sales tax, focused on cars, building materials and computer software. In 1995-96 the federal government will collect 50 per cent more sales tax than it did just three years ago, which I think is an interesting concept to sell to an electorate that voted against the GST just 2 1/2 years ago.
—You'll vote against it then.

—The Democrats will look very closely at these indirect tax measures, Senator Watson. As I said, it is a clever budget. I scored it nine on politics and five on economic responsibility, and I think that pretty well sums it up.
—Out of what?

—Out of 10. What do you think—out of 100? Finally, despite today's lecture from the Prime Minister on executive privilege, it remains the Democrats' firm conviction that the Senate can and should now do its job of scrutinising and reviewing the budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight brings the 13th budget that this Labor government has brought down. Hopefully, for the sake of Australia, it will be its last one. The budget is lacking in any vision of hope for a direction to take this nation into the next century. It is a budget which offers nothing for rural and regional Australia, nothing for the all important small business sector and nothing for most Australian families. It is a budget fashioned with one eye on the peas in the financial markets and the other on obtaining some short-term electoral approval from a few key groups. It is a budget that will ultimately be the swan song of the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: The dissatisfaction of the financial market was demonstrated by the immediate dive of the dollar by almost a whole cent. The vast majority of Australians will not be deceived by this budget, based as it is on broken promises, misleading financial statements and asset stripping. The prevailing economic indicators are grim and highlight the government's complete inability to manage the economy. The government's own forecast of a $27 billion current account deficit by the end of the financial year at six per cent of the GDP is dangerously close to a banana republic, and it is a massive $9 billion blow-out on last year's forecast. Inflation is rising to four per cent. Interest rates rose three times last year. While the official cash rate is now 7.5 per cent, small business and farm enterprises are paying interest rates in the region of 13 per cent and up to 17.5 per cent for highly geared businesses.
Unemployment is over 8 per cent, including 270,000 long-term under-employed and 300,000 under 25-year-olds. The net foreign debt is over $160 billion and the gross foreign debt is over $200 billion.
These sobering economic indicators cannot be muted by a budget manipulated into a small surplus by one-off asset sales and some creative accounting.
Largely through one-off asset sales totalling $5.3 billion and some creative accounting measures the government has turned last year's budget deficit of $12.2 billion into a $718 million surplus.

However, when the asset sales of the remaining 50.4 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank, worth around $4 billion, the Australian National Line, Aerospace Technologies, the sale and lease-back of Dasfleet and Qantas for the fourth time are removed from the slate the difference between government spending and the revenue is an underlying structural deficit of around $8.2 billion. When we come into office the asset cupboard will be bare just like Mother Hubbard's.
As well, the government has engaged in some fancy accounting for which it is renowned, such as factoring in repayment by Telstra of all outstanding loans, capital repay

SPEECH.PARA: ments by Australia Post and accelerated debt repayments from the states.

PARA.TAB: This budget surplus hinges largely on the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. What if there is a shareholder or an ALP Left revolt, and there does not seem to be any sign of that. A lot of people have asked where the Left are, and the Left have just disappeared. They have vacated their ground and they have lost their soul—there will be a gaping $4 billion hole in the government's balance sheet and the budget will revert to its damaging deficit of the past seven years. You do not have to be a bond salesman or a futures trader to understand that—the Australian people will realise that and judge this budget accordingly.

This budget sees the imposition of a tax burden totalling $2.4 billion for this financial year and going up to $16.7 billion in the future. This unprecedented raft of tax hikes takes the form of: the increase in company tax from 33 per cent to 36 per cent, collecting $230 million for this year, rising to $1.5 billion in 1996-97; an increase in sales tax on passenger motor vehicles by 5 per cent initially from 16 per cent to 20 per cent and then to 21 per cent on 1 July 1995 when all sales tax rates rise one per cent automatically; the imposition of 12 per cent sales tax on the family home; an increase in the Medicare levy; an increase in the fringe benefits tax in line with the Medicare levy rise and then a further increase from 1 April 1996; and a 10 per cent rise in the tobacco excise.

In this budget the government finally abandons its longstanding promise to deliver the second tranche of the One Nation l-a-w tax cuts worth around $4 billion. Instead the government will implement a scheme of matching the superannuation contributions of low and average earning workers by 1997.
This is a deal worked out with the ACTU and will be implemented through the award system, not by legislation and will therefore exclude around 30 per cent of workers not covered by an award.
With every budget this government finds more areas in which to extend its taxation tentacles, despite going to the people at election time with promises of tax cuts.

The 1995-96 budget contains expenditure cuts to areas including $1.2 billion from the labour market programs of last year's $3 billion Working Nation program. There are also across-the-board departmental running costs savings of $162 million this year and $662 million over the next four years, cuts to pathology services of $46 million this year and $224 million over four years and a tightening of the safety net threshold for the pharmaceutical benefits schemes.

This 1995-96 budget contains little in the way of hope for rural and regional Australia. Australia is still experiencing the worst drought this century despite some helpful rainfall at the end of last year. It appears that the drought is set to stretch through until 1995. I welcome the drought assistance measures that will total $519 million by 1997-98 and the primary industry minister's commitment that drought relief payments, which have to date assisted around 10,000 producers, will continue through this drought.

The effect of the projected drought has caused farm production to plummet, particularly in the grain production areas. This decrease in primary production and consequent decrease in exports have shaved 0.75 per cent from GDP last year and was the significant contributor to blowing out the current account deficit. This indicates the important role rural Australia and the diverse rural industries continue to play in underpinning the wealth and living standards of this nation. Yet in this budget, despite the level of drought assistance, the agricultural sector with forestry and fishing account for only 1.5 per cent of total outlays. Producers contribute around $703 million to this budget through a variety of taxes and charges.

I note the government baulked at making any changes to arrangements of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The government obviously formed the view that it would have had a fight on its hands if it tried to abolish or reduce in value the successful diesel relief payment.

Last year the government reduced road funding by almost 20 per cent—around $200 million. This year the government has maintained funding at that low level. This is despite the fact the government's total fuel excise grab for 1994-95 will be in the region of $10 billion—yet its contribution to road funding continues to decline. There is no commitment by this government to rural and regional Australia when it neglects to such a degree such fundamental infrastructure as the national road system. This is symptomatic of the government's attitude to rural and regional Australia: when it cannot be taxed, it should be ignored.

The budget does nothing to address the growing divide between urban, rural and regional Australia. Rural and regional Australia accounts for 70 per cent of Australia's export wealth and contains 28 per cent of the population, yet the gulf in essential services, employment prospects and lifestyle between city and the bush has never been wider. A war of attrition is being waged on rural Australia, and this budget provides no ammunition for the rural heartland to combat this decline.

As population decreases from closure of services, local shire councils find it increasingly difficult to maintain a rate base essential to provide basic services such as roads and water supply. Yet this budget makes no acknowledgment of this decreasing revenue base and instead provides local government with funding representing only 0.67 per cent of total outlays. This is less in real terms than when the government came to office 13 years ago. I ask: do we want a country that has lost its rural heart with a population that sprawls for miles out of the capital cities, particularly Sydney? If this is the vision that this government has for Australia, for once it is on the right track.

However, if we want to encourage regional economic development, policies which promote the retention of essential services for rural dwellers must be fashioned instead of policies that are positively detrimental to the inhabitants of regional Australia. One such example is the government's levying of the fringe benefits tax on the mining industry's provision of housing to its employees. This has led to the development of fly-in fly-out schemes. Transporting employees to the mines is not subject to fringe benefits tax, while housing, electricity, water and vehicle allowances are.

The imposition of fringe benefits tax in this manner has led mining companies to increasingly reject the notion of setting up permanent mining towns, which has led to a decline in services and population and regional development of our inland centre. The reduced access country Australians have to health services and education opportunities must be urgently addressed.

A recent Australian medical journal stated that the turnover of rural doctors is around 200 per year and each year a similar number is required to fill vacant positions. The 1992 budget established rural incentive programs which were designed to improve rural Australians' access to basic medical services. Funding for this program has been reduced in this budget from an initial $25 million to a paltry $15 million.

Students from country areas continue to suffer educational disadvantage compared with metropolitan students. Financial difficulties have long presented the main barrier to farm students wishing to undertake higher education. Access to higher education was made even more difficult with the imposition of the Austudy assets test in 1989, which excluded many low income families from receiving assistance. While the drought relief payment makes Austudy available for the children of families declared exceptionally drought stricken, rural families suffering from low commodity prices or reduced income from other causes remain unassisted.

The Senate Rural and Regional Affairs Committee conducted an inquiry into the impact of the assets test on farm families. The committee found that 5,400 students who could qualify for Austudy on the basis of the income test were precluded from accessing it on the basis of the assets test. In other words, 5,400 students who otherwise would have continued their education have had it made very difficult for them to do so. In fact, they are ruled out.

The government has taken no steps to correct this manifestly unfair situation in this year's Austudy budget. It has belatedly acted to close loopholes that were enabling the children of wealthy people on business migration programs and the children of people who were minimising their incomes through complicated company structures to receive Austudy. These tighter targeting measures are expected to save from $13.5 million to around $29 million per year. The government could have channelled these savings into extending Austudy to those 5,400 country children. Its refusal to do so exhibits its complete lack of concern for the future of rural children.

The 1995-96 budget singles out the small business sector to take the brunt of much of its taxation measures. The one sector that has the ability to fire the economy, the one sector that registers employment growth while big business continues to downsize, is the last sector that should be hit.

The boosting of company tax rates from 33c to 36c will impact heavily on the 300,000 small businesses—around 40 per cent of the small business sector—that are incorporated. Uncompetitive company tax rates, together with high interest rates and an inflexible industrial relations regime, tend to cause business to flow offshore to countries such as Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia, which offer not only overall lower tax regimes but also other benefits, such as tax holidays and investment allowance. The company tax hike will ensure that this damaging trend will continue and that Australian manufacturing industries will continue to move offshore.

The strong small business sector that pays provisional tax will again be hurt by the government's decision to levy the provisional tax uplift factor at eight per cent, imposing an unfair burden on these businesses. In question time yesterday I asked Senator Cook, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, why the government was imposing the uplift factor at the very high rate of eight per cent, particularly in view of the fact that this rate is double the growth rate and double the headline inflation rate. Senator Cook evaded my question, saying that the government was trying to provide a strong macro-economic outcome, an outcome of sustainable growth.

That is not enough. Small business needs taxation relief, labour market deregulation and a competitive interest rate regime. Many small businesses that have survived this government's monetary policies over the past five years are highly geared and this unrealistic uplift factor of eight per cent imposes a considerable strain on cash flow and adds to their debt. The Reserve Bank figures show that the level of small business indebtedness to banks stood at $44 billion as of March last year.

The high risk involved in running a small business is reflected in the bankruptcy figures. There were over 14,000 last year and over 70,000 over the past four years. That is absolutely devastating for small business. An uplift factor in line with inflation and growth of around four per cent would have been a far more reasonable impost for small businesses to meet their provisional tax obligations.

The fringe benefits tax is an area of great contention to the small business community. The government has hugely expanded the scope of this tax since its introduction in 1986, which is reflected in its revenue raising capacity, from an initial $585 million to $3.2 billion last year.

The notion of Australia as an egalitarian society with a large middle class is increasingly under challenge. The release last month of the Economic Planning and Advisory Commission report on income distribution reveals that the gap between rich and poor has widened significantly over the last few years. The key to economic equality is a job. It is the only way for people to improve their standard of living and that of their family. A job should be every unemployed person's fundamental right, not a privilege.

This budget penalises business and the productive sector rather than offering them incentive and encouragement. The government's overriding obligation to the Australian people is to implement policies that engender economic growth, national productivity, investment and savings. With this budget, the government has abrogated that fundamental obligation on all four counts.

This budget also shows that, through its taxes on the car and the home and through the selling of historic assets like the Commonwealth Bank, this Labor Party has lost touch with its grassroots and its base support. I believe the Australian people have seen through this budget and will register their disgust with this government at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth remembering that a budget is a plan by cabinet, more specifically by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, for this year and for the next four years. The main purpose of the budget is to ensure that the functions of government can be performed effectively and responsibly.

PARA.TAB: In overview, the government has decided to appear to be more fiscally responsible in this budget. It has recognised that its revenue reductions in 1993 were ill advised, and that there was no way the functions required of government could be paid for with the tax base that was left. It raised some new revenue through a number of taxes. It announced that it would finally put the second tranche of cuts out of the way forever.

The changes are hardly visible. The second tranche cuts were deferred to `some time in the future' to be brought in by regulation rather than legislation. The super scheme is to be introduced at a four-year budget horizon. It is only in the final year's projection in 1998-99 that the $1 billion tip of the super iceberg becomes visible. We cannot see its real effect on the furthest projections of this document.

The notion of giving the tax cuts as super payments is problematic. A tax cut increases disposable income. It allows taxpayers to decide how they wish to invest or spend their money. Super contributions, especially those tied to compulsory employee contributions, will decrease disposable income. It will put investment decisions into the hands of super fund managers. People may get a return but only at some distant future date, assuming the world and national economies and Australia's social and political system manage to carry on without major perturbations until then.

Tax is about revenue; superannuation is about retirement income and industrial relations. It is also about savings, investment, speculation and the creation of a huge private industry funded through compulsory payments and taxpayers' dollars. We are being asked to create an alternative private sector pension scheme, a `Medicare Private' model of the age pension through taxes paid to the private sector by employees and employers, and through taxes paid to that sector by government. These taxes will be paid to create a system of taxpayer funded inequality with the better off getting a bigger contribution from government than the lowest paid workers.

No estimation has been made of the impact on people of the change to their pre-retirement income. No assessment has been made of whether super funds, which will see huge and rapid taxpayer funded growth, will cope, improve fund performance and address the prudential problems. No assessment is made as to what kind of investment we will see and what the impact of creating such huge demand for institutional investment will be. Yet the Treasurer boasts that he will increase super investment tenfold.

There are general superannuation issues about which I will go into more detail in a separate speech. I notice that all the super schemes will only start to show up at the budget horizon. So even the government's idea that the super scheme will lift our savings statistics and therefore somehow fix our current account balance will not be put to the test for several years.

What about the economy now? What about our current account balance in the near future? The government is doing nothing. There is no plan here to address the need to become more self-reliant, to move to higher value-added industries to ensure that our domestic economy becomes more diverse, to be more able to meet the needs of ordinary citizens without the need for imports. We see a huge dependence on growth and the assumption that we will keep getting these benefits without any calculation of possible costs.

What we see is a great increase in expected revenue. While there are additional revenue measures the increase is mainly through growth, primarily tax on increases in personal income. This, in turn, is predicated on, firstly, the economy growing more rapidly than it has this year; secondly, employment growing as strongly as it has this year; thirdly, average wages rising one per cent faster than they have this year; and, fourthly, the agricultural sector growing, despite uncertain predictions about the end to the drought.

Government revenue is very sensitive to small changes in these parameters. If, for example, the only change in government projections is that wages only rise at the same rate as this year, the government will lose $780 million from the predictions. This would wipe out the projected budget surplus and already put the budget into a very small deficit. The basic problem is that revenue from personal income tax is projected to grow at 13.6 per cent when it grew at only 8.8 per cent last year.

Another factor is outlays. Outlays as a section have increased only slightly. This is mainly because of the offsetting influence of huge asset sales and clawbacks of past loans to the states. These, which are included under outlays in the budget, total over $7 billion, making it possible to increase outlays slightly for normal growth in programs and to make a few new promises without badly impacting on the bottom line figure.

The issue here is whether the government can actually get over $5 billion for the assets it is trying to sell. The assets are not individually valued in the budget but media reports suggest that the bulk of the money will be made with the sell-off of the Commonwealth Bank. But government has not been very good at estimating the value of assets or the timing of sale. A case in point, Qantas, is in there again, still waiting to be sold. We were to have seen big sell-offs last year of $2.7 billion but the reality was sales of $55 million. Obviously, reality may wreck any deficit reduction plan for the coming financial year, leaving government with an empty boast of surplus to bring to the next budget. Perhaps sell the same things again!

An issue of deeper concern is that this year the surplus is to occur through growth and some sleight-of-hand in offsetting within outlays. But the surplus is forecast to rise rapidly in future while asset sales and loan repayments fall off rapidly. The only way that this can occur is through real cuts to program outlays of about 10 per cent of the current budget. With transfers to the states at 12 per cent and defence at eight per cent both locked in and expected to increase, and promises not to reduce pensions or welfare payments, options for cutting such a huge amount from outlays are limited.

When we couple this projection for cuts in programs with the claims by Senator Gareth Evans yesterday over the proposed sale of the Commonwealth Bank, we must agree with Senator Evans that there are now no significant differences between the policy of the government and that of the opposition.

Where will these cuts occur? Forward estimates are a measure of intention rather than a reflection of what actually might happen. Many areas which are shown as marked for future decline year after year actually see reasonably stable, sometimes even growing, funding from budget to budget. This calls into question the value of forward estimates and also the ability of government to make cuts wherever it wishes without facing strong community backlash.

In our budget pack we asked a few questions. Most relate to equity. Here are some relating to outlays. We asked: are proposed revenue measures progressive in nature? Has expenditure on the welfare sector remained intact or increased? Has funding for health programs been maintained or increased? Has funding for education programs been maintained or increased? Have the higher education contribution scheme, HECS, and fees for additional education services remained at no more than current levels?

We also asked: is spending on overseas aid programs greater than the stated goal of 0.36 per cent of Australia's GDP? Is there new and adequate funding for biodiversity programs, marine and coastal initiatives, and restructuring of the forest industry? Have such new programs been funded without compromising existing programs?

I will start with the environment. We see on page 3.137 that the environment protection budget is going up by 82 per cent. They say, `Well, that should make the greenies happy.' Maybe not. It seems that 82 per cent is based on a figure of spending of $75 million last year, a bit more than the cost of a single FA18 team. But that figure is a 33 per cent underspend on the amount appropriated. According to Greenpeace, a big part of that underspend was the rehabilitation of Maralinga and a big chunk of the increase this year is simply rolling over that unspent money.

If we go to last year's budget, we see that the increase is actually only 21 per cent or $20 million. It is still a good chunk, but with $18 million of that money for the national forest policy there is not much there for the greenhouse package that was put forward as a major initiative. It should be noted that the greenhouse voluntary agreements with industry will cost $11 million this year. Other specific critiques from the environment movement are that the money supposed to go to the national pollutant inventory has been rolled over twice now in some measure. There is still no sign of any action as a consequence of the program.

A problem we have is that not only is environmental protection and other environmentally important areas very frequently underspent but also the forward projections in these areas almost always show marked decreases in funding. Is this a sign that government will cut out environmental protection after the budget? Is it a sign that government has some strange notion that the environmental problems of Australia are almost solved and we will do the bulk of that work this year?

We have problems with toxic algae in many rivers. There is a second instance of major coastal fish deaths this year. Greenhouse will not go away. Rangelands are deteriorating. Political pressure on environmental issues is also not going to disappear—believe me—although it is clear that the Prime Minister would like to ignore it.

Regional development also has seen the same pattern of underspending and declining forward estimates. The only grey spot in the black vision is the extension of the better cities program, although the concerns about its performance continue. Hopefully, the strong linking with greenhouse issues will result in a more focused performance that flows into other portfolios at all levels of government, but we are not holding our breath.
