Social security has kept fairly constant, although the new deeming laws will hit pensioners with more income reduction based on assumed asset value increases treated under income rather than assets tests. Several areas are declining in real terms, especially in the forward estimates. But social security spending must grow with demand. There is some recognition that the Working Nation parenting allowances will shift demand from assistance to the unemployed to assistance to families, but again in forward estimates it appears that assistance to families, an area about three times the size of unemployment, will not keep up with the demand in real terms. Since there is also the maternity allowance and the shift to social security payments as a way of eliminating tax deductions for children, it is hard to see that this area is funded appropriately.

I refer to the area of health. Through inadequate funding hospital waiting lists will increase; pharmaceutical bills will be more expensive; there will be a decline in the quality of nursing homes; and the crisis in medical health will expand. The issue of dementia and specialised dementia units is ignored. Integrated community out-of-care support services will be inadequate to meet demands of shorter institutional care and so on.

Health care has perceptibly declined over the last several years, with increasing pressure on fewer understaffed hospitals. This year the overall budget gets small real increases in dollar funding because of Aboriginal health and a few other programs. But the general health component is not being maintained. The medical benefits budget increases in dollar terms by 3.3 per cent, while inflation is four per cent. This means that there is a decline in real funding for this area which covers much of Medicare. When you factor in an underlying growth of five per cent in demand for services and an average annual increase in fees of four per cent, then the effective reduction in Medicare benefits is in the order of eight to 10 per cent per person.

The government seeks to direct this decline by reducing the number of pathology tests a Medicare recipient is eligible for, a saving of $46 million; by building in downward pressure on total health wages, a saving of $23.3 million; by unspecified running cost savings, a saving of $4.2 million—that means the hospitals will get blamed for it, not the government—and by shifting some of the cost for cervical cancer screening to other areas, a saving of $2.4 million.

Public hospitals are in trouble, with annual budget increases not even keeping up with inflation. When demand and climbing above-inflation costs are included, the level of service will decline markedly. These two areas constitute 62 per cent of the total health budget. Changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are another blow with several drugs being struck off the list and the amount of drugs that an ordinary family buys before moving to the lower rate increasing from $407.60 to $600—an increase of 150 per cent. This will effectively add $200 to the health bill of families—all of this when the Medicare levy is going up.

For the aged: although there is a welcome recognition of the needs of home carers through increases in funding in the home and community care program, there is no measure at all to address the problems of dementia—a measure that was expected as a result of the Gregory report. The nursing home subsidy has gone up by 0.4 per cent in real terms this year and will probably decline in real dollars on a per person basis. The government will not even keep up with inflation next year and in subsequent years.

At the same time, we see a real blow to preventive medical treatment. Preventive medicine gets about five per cent of the health budget. There is a modest increase of 14.5 per cent in this area—health promotion and disease prevention—although the $36 million, or 24 per cent, underspending last year makes it look much bigger. This was expected, as there are several new programs—cervical and breast cancer screening and the Burdekin mental health initiatives—which are to be funded from this program. Women's health, mental health, the national health advancement program and family planning are all located in this area where proper funding can result in a decline in the demand for more expensive acute and chronic treatment. It is therefore of major concern that this area is set to decline in funding by 42 per cent over the next four years.

In higher education we see a planned decline in real funding of between 1.5 per cent and 1.9 per cent in each forward estimate year. This is at a time when more people are being pushed into further education as an alternative to the dole and tertiary education is seen as necessary to get a reasonable job. The worst aspect of what we see in education, though, is the `hip pocket nationalism' of a government that will sneak in increased fees and cut 50,000 students from Austudy by targeting residents—people who may have been born here, may have worked years here and paid taxes. This is not about foreign students who already pay 100 per cent of fees up front. It is about people who have been accepted as residents and are treated in all ways, other than voting, as Australians.

On foreign aid we have seen a complete abandonment of any pretence of concern. We were supposed to get increased funding last year yet the target, set as a percentage of GDP, was not met. The target has been lowered this year and appears to be lower in the foreseeable future. What we see in this budget is a cleverly packaged election year budget where cuts to services are minimal and disguised. But they are there. An appearance of responsibility is created through high estimates of revenue from growth and through huge assets and clawbacks from state housing and other programs. Beneath the election year budget we see a program to cut public services far more radically. As the icing on the cake, we see the superannuation scheme—a measure to entrench social inequality in retirement, and to do so at taxpayer expense. We are moving here to establish the foundations of measures which will see the divisions between rich and poor expand until we become two nations within the same borders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some 21 speakers to go tonight. I believe I am the last speaker on the budget. There is a heap of speakers on the valedictory to Senator Loosley and a number on the adjournment. It is my intention, therefore, to make a short statement on the budget, if I may, for a matter of only three minutes and then seek leave to continue my remarks to deal with the other matters at some future time.

PARA.TAB: The issue I want to deal with tonight is how the budget puts pressure on certain families. Having studied the budget and the associated budget papers, I have come to the conclusion that this budget will force more families to have both parents in the paid work force because they will be not be able to make ends meet.

If we look at the fine print in the budget we find that it implies that average weekly earnings are expected to fall after inflation and tax. As a result, household incomes will only be sustained if the income earner works longer hours or another member of the family enters the paid work force. This is a consequence of bracket creep tax increases and indirect taxes, not to mention losses in some years of wages diverted to compulsory superannuation levies.

Because more families will have both parents in the paid work force, this will increase pressure on the labour market. The unemployed—particularly those without skills or experience; they are usually the young—will face greater difficulties in gaining jobs. In this budget the government has slashed its One Nation commitment to the unemployed by something like $400 million.

Of course, I welcome the reintroduction of the maternity allowance although it amounts to less in terms of average weekly wages than when the maternity allowance was first introduced in 1912 by the Fisher Labor government. Most families will not get the maternity allowance in any year, but all families will have to pay increased direct or indirect taxes or lose wages to the compulsory superannuation levies.

This government needs to consider how families have faired from the time it took office to the present time. The bottom line is that a family with a husband, wife and two children on average weekly earnings is at least $26.77 per week worse off than they were in December 1982 and they will be $32.72 worse off by December 1995. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a document that gives a tax comparison for a taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the last sitting day in this place for Senator Stephen Loosley, who retires on 19 May after five years in this place. It has been a very distinguished career, not the only highlight of which was being made Mr October in the Men of the Senate calendar for 1993. I think it is important that we mark the occasion by paying appropriate tribute to him.

PARA.TAB: Let me begin with the basics. He was born in Sydney in 1954, which makes him still, of course, a mere slip of a lad. He attended Sydney Technical High School, went on to the University of New South Wales and received first-class honours in political science, with a thesis, inevitably, on Jack Lang—that figure of endless fascination for the New South Wales Right—and the Labor governments in New South Wales in the 1920s and 1930s. In 1976 he planned to start a PhD but was persuaded by Graham Richardson to join the newly elected Senator Kerry Sibraa as his research officer—not, of course, that Kerry ever needed a research officer, but that is the job that Stephen was given. It is reported that he initially said no to Graham Richardson, but he should have known then—as he undoubtedly does now—that no-one is ever allowed to say that.

In 1977 he was elected to the New South Wales State Labor Council. In 1977-78, he was the national secretary of Young Labor, in 1979 assistant secretary of the New South Wales state branch, replacing Leo McLeay when Mr McLeay came into the House of Representatives on Frank Stewart's death. In 1983 he became general secretary of the New South Wales state branch when Graham Richardson was elected to the Senate. In that capacity, might I say for the record, he was a great organiser and a great campaigner and also showed very considerable, albeit less widely recognised, talent for property management.

Following that, he was senior national vice-president of the ALP. In 1990, he was elected, of course, to the Senate. In the whole period from 1983 to 1991 he was a member of the ALP national executive, for a good proportion of which time he occupied the chair of the foreign affairs, defence and trade policy committee and the international committee of the ALP. His very distinguished career of service within the party structure culminated in his being president of the ALP in 1991-92.

In this place, in the Senate, Stephen Loosley, unquestionably, has left his mark, and did so in a very short space of time. That mark most notably—I think most people would again agree; I certainly see it this way—was in the area of his greatest love, which was foreign affairs. He was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade from when he arrived here in 1990 to 1993, then moved across to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, where he immediately became chairman, and has remained so since May 1993.

Of course, in this place he has been a supplier of endless series of dorothy dixers of the most helpful kind during my tenure as foreign minister! I do not quite know from where Stephen derived his very obvious flair for current affairs. I have always had one little theory about it. It has been based on one of those `separated at birth' photographs one sees from time to time with prominent look-alikes. It has always seemed to me that if you look very carefully and discount just a little for a certain Caucasian cast you will see that Senator Loosley is a dead ringer for Chinese Premier Li Peng. That is a personal perception I have had which he regards as very quirky. Hitherto, that has not been in the public domain, but there it is.

As chairman of the joint committee, Stephen was personally associated with the production of a number of quite excellent reports of that committee. He was also a first-class host to many prominent and high level visitors to this country. It is not always, might I say with the utmost respect to my parliamentary colleagues, that one can with total confidence send a high level visitor off to the chairman of a parliamentary committee with the knowledge that that visitor will be in for a stimulating and informative encounter, but that was invariably the case with Stephen. That is a great asset to have around the place.

I think beyond all of that it was Stephen Loosley's very capable and sensitive leadership of several very important parliamentary delegations that was the role in which he made probably his most significant and positive contribution of all, in relation to some very intractable problems on the foreign policy agenda. I have in mind particularly his leadership last year of the delegation to Papua New Guinea and Bougainville. It was an initiative that unquestionably led very directly to the peace talks which then occurred between the Papua New Guinea government and the Bougainville separatists, and has created the environment for the uncertain but nonetheless quietly progressive movement towards the restoration of peace in that unhappy province.

Then again, most recently there was his leadership just a month or so ago of the path breaking—and it was path breaking—delegation to Vietnam. Whether or not Senator Short concedes that status, I think the trip by that delegation and the report which was tabled in this place just yesterday have helped Australia and the government of Vietnam come to grips more comprehensively with each other and helped, in particular, the Vietnamese to come a little more squarely to terms with human rights issues in a constructive and forward looking way. I warmly congratulate him and the other members of that delegation, but particularly Stephen, for his leadership of that very sensitive, very delicate, very difficult task.

Alexander Downer, about whom I was discussing a variety of matters in the last day or so, was very quick to tell me how much he appreciated Stephen's leadership, which introduced a note of immediate caution on my part as to just what he had actually been up to. But there it is. You do get that bipartisanship endorsement which good leaders in the foreign policy area particularly and indeed other public policy areas in this place can invariably attract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like yourself.

—Thank you, Senator Panizza. That is very gracious of you. Senator Loosley has also participated in many other important delegations, including twice to the former Soviet Union at a time when it was transforming into the post-Cold War state that we are now becoming more familiar with. He has been a regular visitor to the United States over the years in an emerging tradition, not entirely confined to the New South Wales Right, of close association with a knowledge of the United States political system and he has been one of the great communicators about the American political system on the Australian scene.

PARA.TAB: Generally his travel in the five years of his time in the Senate has been almost as extensive, I think, as my own. Indeed, I have often sensed his breath at the back of my neck as I have modestly gone about my business around the world. But one further thing should be said about Stephen Loosley's foreign affairs role. It was always the case that he never saw his role as being only to deal with what purportedly counts as the more glamorous side of the foreign affairs business, to the extent that there is one. Quietly, sympathetically and effectively he has helped many Australians affected by the good and the bad side of international events. I know, to take just one example, how much he has personally tried to assist the family of the young Australian David Linder, who disappeared in what are unhappily seen to be tragic circumstances while travelling in Iran some 18 months ago. Stephen's remarkable diversity of talents, I think, is shown by the fact that he was simultaneously patron of the Australian Defence Association and chair of the parliamentary Human Rights Subcommittee, proving once and for all, irrevocably, in a way that made the point beyond argument, that these two activities need not be contradictory.

Finally, Stephen and I have been good friends personally over the years, especially since his entry into this parliament. We combined most memorably for several years on the tennis court in Senate versus House of Representatives matches until it got to the point where I got puffed walking onto the court and had to retire gracefully. It was the only time I can ever remember barracking for the Senate against the House of Representatives in my 17 years here. But it was a fine partnership, Stephen, while it lasted and we did actually win a match or two.

I fully expect that Stephen Loosley will continue to make a very fine contribution to this country and to the evolution of good public policy in this country in whatever role he chooses to play. For the moment he has chosen now to follow a quite different career path in law, for which he has been very successfully preparing himself through part-time study in the last few years. He has explained the reasons why he is leaving at this time in what he said to the Senate in announcing his departure a few weeks ago. I can certainly sympathise with him in his desire, which he will now be able to fully realise, to spend more time with Lynne, and with Nicholas and James, his two young children, and to have a generally more rational and sane and balanced lifestyle than is possible for any of us in this place. Certainly I know I speak for everyone in the Labor Party and in the wider labour movement and I believe I speak for everyone in this chamber when I wish Stephen Loosley all the very best for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: I rise for myself and for those of my colleagues who will not be speaking to acknowledge Stephen Loosley's contribution to this parliament and to this Senate and to wish him well for the future. Not all of my colleagues will speak because there is no hypocrisy on this side of the chamber, Stephen, but there is a lot of goodwill towards you and we would not want you to be leaving without being aware of that fact.

PARA.TAB: I guess part of that goodwill relates to the fact that you are so party political. Some of us believe not only in being political but also in being party political. The strength of our democracy very much reflects the strength and good heart of the major parties in this country. I am reminded of your party background and your commitment to the ALP; that is something we recognise also. Such a commitment is not often well understood within the community and the part that that plays in our public life is not always well understood or fully appreciated in all its consequences. But we understand what it means and recognise it.

Obviously I also wanted to speak because I appreciate the contribution that you have made to Australian foreign policy—I think I could probably say—certainly to the practice of it and to the support you have given Senator Gareth Evans in the role that you have played in Senate committees and then as chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, a committee on which I served for many years. I know that you have been held in high regard on that committee.

I know of the work that you have performed on many of the delegations to which Senator Evans referred. Some of them I regard as vitally important. I am as interested in the future of Bougainville as anyone in this place, having been there also in difficult times—perhaps not with the same support mechanisms that you might have received, but in opposition you have to battle along notwithstanding. I recognise and appreciate that work. I appreciate the commitment you have made to enhancing Australia's bilateral relationships and, in particular, your belief in human rights—not simply believing them but getting out and working to maintain and to enhance them. I wanted to put that appreciation on the record as well.

Lastly, as I have said to you personally, Stephen, I am disappointed you are leaving at least parliamentary life at this time. I hope you are not leaving public life, as such. I suspect you will not. But it is a little disappointing when somebody such as yourself comes in so well qualified and stays for such a relatively short time. We were confident, now that you have completed your apprenticeship, that you would be on the front bench of the next opposition and would have made a very useful contribution in that regard.

We listened to you when you explained why you were leaving. It does cause us some concern that pressures on family life that seem to be part and parcel of this business can take such a consequence—and, in some ways, an unfortunate consequence. Perhaps it suggests that we all should look for ways in which we can try to make this life perhaps a little more civilised and a little easier on families.

Stephen, you have chosen, however, a different path and I think you will find it interesting. Some of us who came from that path before we came here found the law fascinating in the same way that politics is fascinating. I know that you will enjoy it and find it challenging. I wish you well in that regard. As I hinted a moment ago, I am confident that you will remain in public life in various ways and I certainly encourage you to do so. On behalf of those of my colleagues who will not be speaking, I thank you for your contribution to this parliament and to the Senate and wish you all the best for the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stephen Loosley, on behalf of the National Party senators here, I too would like to join with Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Hill in wishing you the best in your new chosen role with a law firm. It will be quite new and different for you, after having spent most of your adult life working for—and very successfully working for—the Labor Party at both the state and federal level.

PARA.TAB: I also recognise the contributions you have made to the foreign affairs aspect of the Senate and the committees which you have chaired and the contributions you have made in the parliament in that area—an area with which you are very familiar. I have known you since 1990. I am not an expert in any way on foreign affairs; in fact, it is completely—

TALK.START.PARA: —Foreign.
—Foreign to me, yes.
—Honesty becomes you!

—But I have always found Senator Stephen Loosley to be a very nice person, a fellow you enjoy sitting with at a public lunch or a Senate dinner. We have always been able to sit around and have a friendly chat. That is the sort of thing that I will remember of you, Steve, when you go. You are just a damn nice guy, and I will miss you; and I know that all my colleagues feel the same way about you. Senator Loosley has never been aggressive. He has just been a person to whom you can go and talk.
—You don't know him!

—He certainly may be different over there. But that is the way I see Steve Loosley. Steve, all I can say to you is that you have made the change, and I wish you all the best. I hope that you do get those extra bits of joy and companionship from your family and your kids.

PARA.TAB: I know that it must be very hard for people like Senator Campbell who have young children whom they must leave to come over here. I remember the joy that I used to get with my young children and how, upon my return home after travelling around the country, I used to be welcomed by them. I know that it must be very hard for people in the Senate who do have young children. Stephen, you have made your choice. On behalf of the National Party, I wish you all the best.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill mentioned that Senator Loosley is a party political person. It is not for me to go over that area, but I do agree with what Senator Hill said. To be a party political person in the true sense of the word is very important for democracy in Australia. That might seem strange coming from me as an independent. But I do feel that, with the combination of the Westminster system and the United States system that we have here, that is very important.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, it has been very interesting to sit back and have a look at the terms of various MPIs that have been produced from time to time, particularly by the opposition. It is very interesting to see that the more pejorative the terms of those MPIs, the more likely you are to have Stephen Loosley fronting up to defend the government. It is very interesting indeed to see who the government wheels in when it is under a bit of attack and who the government wheels in when there are problems about.

There is somebody sitting rather close to you, Senator Loosley, who is also wheeled in on difficult occasions—that is, of course, Senator Barney Cooney. It is quite noticeable when the government is in trouble as to who is wheeled in. Senator Loosley is going; I do not know what Senator Cooney has in mind or who they will wheel in next. But I must say that, whenever Senator Loosley was so wheeled in, he made a jolly good fist of it and defended what was indefensible on many occasions—and did so very vigorously indeed.

I was interested to hear what Senator Gareth Evans said. I did not think I would ever hear him say that he would be barracking for the Senate against the House of Representatives. But he might remember—and certainly Stephen might remember—that the last occasion we as a Senate tennis team defeated the House of Representatives was the day after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had called the Senate `an unrepresentative swill'. I must congratulate the two of them for their valiant defence of the Senate on that occasion, that day after. It may indeed have improved their performance.

Seriously, my main parliamentary association with Stephen was on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and particularly on the subcommittee on human rights. I have worked under a lot of chairpersons in my day and I do not think I have come across one who has been as patient in the face of provocation as Stephen Loosley. There have been occasions—we both know the occasions—when one or two members have asked banal, offensive and even startling questions of witnesses. Senator Loosley has passed them off beautifully and made everybody feel quite relaxed about it. I suppose he has been able to—what is it?—let a thousand or a hundred thousand flowers bloom at times.

TALK.START.PARA: —A hundred.

—You should know, after what Senator Evans has said. He has been able to let a hundred thousand flowers bloom and then draw it all together. In the end, he would get down the agenda and draw the line and that would be the end of it and on to the next subject. That is the sort of chairman that people like.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I would like to say that I agree with what Senator Boswell and Senator Evans said. It is such an important and valued thing that Senator Loosley is going to do. He is going to make a career change but will do so with something very clear and in the forefront of his mind—that is, to spend more time with his family. In that respect, a lot of us envy him but wish him very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with others in wishing Senator Stephen Loosley well in his new career. I would like to pass a few remarks about what I have come to know of Senator Loosley in the time that I have known him. He and I were inducted into the place at the same time. That was a strange experience because the then President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, was responsible for the induction process. We were sitting there, open-mouthed and wide-eyed, while the process was taking place. I think Senator Kemp and Senator Campbell were inducted at the same time.

PARA.TAB: I recall that near the end of the process, in wanders this fellow who sat there for five minutes and seemed to know what it was all about. Then he stood up and started to thank the President for the program. I said, `Who's this bloke?' I had not actually seen any part of the process but he soon revealed that he knew what the arrangements were, who to go to, where the toilets were and generally what the place was all about. Being the deep soul that Stephen is, his previous relationship with the President was not revealed at first, nor was it revealed how he actually became so familiar with this place.

Over time, from that deep soul, he has revealed to me some of his idiosyncrasies. I think I have reciprocated, and perhaps that is a dangerous thing to do. But I have held a little insurance for some time—I will speak a bit more about that later—and I have been quite confident about reciprocating this revelation of idiosyncrasies. Stephen has visited my home and he has, on occasions, acted as my artistic consultant in the capacity of interior decorator. On occasions, he has even offered advice on how I should arrange my office. I must say he is not alone in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't take it, did you?

—No, I didn't take the advice. I found Stephen to be a widely read fellow and well-filmed—I do not know what you would call a person who has seen every film there is to see, can quote them all verbatim and does it often. I call it well-filmed—it is like well-read—and that is what he is. He is an urbane fellow.

PARA.TAB: I recall how well he slipped into place in the various social situations that I have found myself in with him. I recall—and I know that Senator Crowley will recall this as well—how we found ourselves on a parliamentary delegation in Argentina. That was not mentioned by Senator Gareth Evans as a highlight, and I think I know why. I have an image in my mind of the suitably clad Senator Loosley in suitably crumpled semi-tropical garb shuffling across the polo field in earnest conversation with the son of the owner of the estancia. I think the cravat was in the right place and, if I try hard enough, I can see that the white shoes were in place as well. He really looked the part.

TALK.START.PARA: —I own neither.

—I have shared many philosophical moments with Stephen Loosley, perhaps not as many as I would like. We have had various moments on the tennis court—and you do own some white shoes—various moments in the dining room and various moments that I will advert to later. During those moments of philosophical reflection he has shown genuine concern for the principles of democracy. We have all seen evidence of those. He has shown concern for the future of this nation and for international justice and equity.

PARA.TAB: We shared a particularly stunning moment when we declined the advice of our protocol officer and we went the wrong way along Atlantic Boulevard in Rio de Janeiro. Normally, it would not have mattered but at the time we went—and it was after midnight—it soon became obviously risky. This was not amusing to either of us. We soon became non-plussed, nervous and, in fact, a little frightened when we were confronted by beggars and people who lived in the street—they were people who, by their own situation, sobered us both very quickly. Stephen is the sort of person who you can share that moment with, reflect upon it at a later time and consider what good you might be able to do about it. We shared that stunning moment.

We later took the advice of our protocol officer. I must say that this fellow, Evandra Magellinas—Ted Magellan—was perhaps even more suave and sophisticated than our New South Wales senator. He knew just what to advise us to do. Until I had reflected upon those moments, I had forgotten that I recently rediscovered this piece of insurance that I mentioned earlier. I have had it in fairly safe keeping, because it was a piece of insurance that I thought I might need when mixing with a character such as Stephen Loosley.

I am prepared to relinquish this damming evidence tonight. I have no further use for it, so I suppose I should reveal it to the Senate. I can describe it as a candid photo. You know the sort of thing—a lonely beach resort; I think this was the Manaos Paradise Hotel's private beach on the Amazon. There were a couple of bikini clad people there—somebody else's wife and somebody else's secretary. The previously mentioned crumpled semi-tropical suit was there, this time inhabited by our New South Wales senator. I think this time he had the beach sandals on.

The incriminating aspect of this candid photo was the desperate palm to the forehead. You know that expression that acknowledges the moment of being sprung and desperately asking, `Which editors will pay how much to get their hands on this?' I have no further use for such trivia, Stephen. I will pass it on, with sincere good wishes. I thank you for the particular insights you have given me so I can better understand politics in New South Wales, the Labor Party and humanity in general. That just about sums you up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank Steve Loosley. I do not want to go into the history of his life—or anything else; there is not much I could throw a lot of light on. In the time I have known Steve Loosley, which is about 10 years, I have always been very grateful for the help he has provided me, particularly when I first started in the Labor Party a bit over 10 years ago. During the formation of the Right faction in Tasmania—or re-formation in part, I suppose—people said, `If you really want to learn something about faction building, particularly as it relates to the Right, you should go to New South Wales;' so I did.

PARA.TAB: I met a range of interesting people, one of whom was Steve. I have to say that I learnt many interesting and some unique methods of recruiting, from a factional point of view, and I learnt about fundraising from Johnno Johnson. Over the time I have known Steve, whether or not I have been in constant contact with him, I have always been able to ring him and ask his advice and assistance; and it has been provided. Since my coming to the Senate, I have found Steve to be a great source of knowledge. He has been a contributor in many ways, as other people have said.

I did have the opportunity to serve on the committee inquiring into print media. It handed down a report on percentage players. I know Robert Hill said there were no hypocrites on that side of the chamber but I think I could name a few.

Steve, thanks very much for the time I have known you and for the assistance you have given me here. I gave you a little token tonight in the form of some Tasmanian smoked salmon, the best smoked salmon in the world. I hope we never have to call on you in a legal sense to devise some mechanism to protect it in the long term. I hope the government will maintain its position and do that. I wish you and your family well, in your new life and in your new career. I know you will be very successful. I hope that from time to time we are able to make contact and spend a bit of time with you so you can impart some of the great knowledge you have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have come to know Stephen Loosley since he first came to this chamber about half a decade ago. I have learned, as previous speakers have already said, that he is a man of grace, intelligence, industry and integrity. I have come to admire Stephen as a person deeply committed to those values which make for a true parliamentarian. He holds to the rule of law, to the primacy of civil rights, to the equality of all, to the fair distribution of opportunity, to the proper sharing of resources and to the apt application of community care.

PARA.TAB: The going of Stephen Loosley from this place is much too early. Had he stayed, Australia would have gained enormously. Fortunately, Stephen's contribution to this country will continue, amongst other ways, through his work in the law—a noble profession which, Stephen, you will practise nobly. Together with the rest of the Senate, I thank you for the work you have done here and wish you well in your new career.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join the remarks on the retirement of Senator Loosley. It is a measure of the man how many people wish to speak on this occasion. Indeed, I found it rather hard to get my name on the speakers list. Stephen, that list shows the high regard in which you are held, both on that side of the chamber and on this side.

PARA.TAB: Five years as a senator is a very short time. I looked at the statistics to see how many people have left the Senate since Stephen and I entered it in 1990. Senator Loosley, you will be interested to know that since that time some 10 senators have resigned in mid-term and a further 10 or so senators have also left at the end of their careers or as a result of the ballot box. You, Senator Loosley, are different from them all, actually, because you are in fact comparatively young. I think people would have assumed that by most standards you had a bright and comparatively shining career ahead of you in politics.

Of course, it is not for us to question the judgment you have made. I think it is a big loss to the Labor Party. I hope your colleagues appreciated that. Looking from over here, the Labor back benches are not exactly loaded with talent—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the opposition front benches?

—Senator Carr, I really hoped you wouldn't cause me to make a comment. I have a big list of John Cain quotes here for you, so please do not provoke me this evening. I think we would have assumed that had one of the frontbenchers tripped over divvying up some grants on a whiteboard, Senator Loosley would have been the next cab off the rank. I think that shows what the Labor Party has lost as a result of the decision Senator Loosley has made.

PARA.TAB: Stephen, you are professional. I think the comment Senator Hill made was appropriate. You have a great love and affection for the Labor Party. You are Labor and you will always be Labor, despite the fact that you might grow fat and rich as a lawyer. In fact that, given the modern Labor Party, may be more typical.

Senator Loosley, you have, as many of my colleagues have said, made a contribution in this chamber. I will not go through the list that others have given, but certainly in the area of foreign affairs I think your contribution is very widely recognised indeed. I certainly appreciated in the last major report you brought down that, almost alone of your colleagues, you showed some interest in the area which is now occupying quite a bit of the time of Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Lavarch; that is, the role of international treaties and our legal and constitutional system. While I was hopeful that the report would go further than it ultimately did, I think the recognition you gave in the report that this was an important issue and that it was time the parliament addressed its mind to it certainly helped push that debate a little further.

You are a child of the New South Wales Labor Right, but I have always thought you were slightly different from the other members of the New South Wales Right that I had met over the years. I have always felt that they had a 100 per cent, winner-take-all approach to politics. You seem to have a 95 per cent approach. That at least, I suspect, has encouraged you to establish perhaps wider links than many of your colleagues have done in their time in this chamber.

Senator Bell quoted a story about Senator Loosley walking down the beaches in Rio. To show the range of contacts you have, I was astonished to find on going to the wedding of two well-known Liberals recently that I had to share the platform with you, Stephen. That came as a surprise to a few people, I have to say, but I think it showed, among other things, the very wide range of contacts that you have been able to establish.

I was surprised to hear how often Stephen has been on these overseas trips. Taken with his part-time study, I have wondered how much time he was able to devote to chamber work. The record shows that he has been a very active participant in this chamber. I have always found his speeches worth listening to. I have often come into the chamber to try to cause him some problems and harass him, often with very limited success. The points that Senator Harradine made were very well taken.

This is an early end to a political career. It probably makes us all reflect a little on our own circumstances. But most will want to plough on and achieve the glittering prizes that we all seek. Stephen has a wide range of interests. I know that he is a great movie buff. I know that he has a great love of history. Above all, I know in my many conversations with him that he has a great love for his family. This is why he has decided to leave this chamber. So I join with my other colleagues and wish Stephen and his wife Lynne and sons Nicholas and James all the very best for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I re-entered this place in 1990 along with Stephen as the third Labor senator from New South Wales. I have now known Stephen for 20 years. I knew him when he was a member of the Left. He is probably going to throttle me for saying that, but he saw the light very quickly and joined the strength, as Senator Evans has outlined. He hates to be reminded of it, but it is very important for history. Only one person here tonight has known Stephen longer than me, and that is Senator Forshaw; they grew up in the same area.

PARA.TAB: This is quite a sad night. I have spent 20 years in party politics with Stephen. I have spent 17 or 18 long weekends in June in Stephen's company with 800 or 900 others at annual conferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a confession?

—These are recollections. When I think of Stephen, I think of long weekends in June at Sydney Town Hall. For those in the Labor Party in New South Wales, they are very important occasions. I think very clearly of Stephen's contribution to those conferences. He has contributed as an organiser, an assistant secretary and then as secretary in a number of the debates. For as long as I can recall in the 20 years that I have known him, Stephen has been a participator and a player in the foreign affairs debate. So his foreign affairs interest is not something that was acquired on arrival here; it is something that he brought with him to this place. He has discharged it with eminent ability and brought a great deal of credit to this country in his overseas journeys.

PARA.TAB: Many of us travel overseas, but most of us end up with lots of visa stamps from the more desirable and salubrious places, such as Europe and the Americans. But Stephen's passport must look very interesting, because there has to be some visas and entry stamps from some very out-of-the-way, small and interesting places that do not rate very highly on the tourist brochures but which rate very highly in terms of human rights and development issues. Stephen has to a fair degree led this chamber and perhaps the parliament of this country in addressing those issues. Many people in those countries will in years to come be able to say, `This report and visit by this committee and these people has had a significant effect upon our country.' Stephen will be able to take some pride in that. In his future career, he will be able to observe what happens in those places.

For those who have ever needed some quick American history information on presidents or American civil wars—if they have been not quite sure of dates or events and they have wanted to use them in debate—Stephen was always a source of information if Kim Beazley or Brian Courtice could not be found. If those three men did not know about it, it probably was not in the history books and it probably did not happen.

It has been an interesting 20 years of knowing Stephen. I have just asked him whether he will be going to the next annual conference because for me it will not seem like an annual conference of the Labor Party in New South Wales if Stephen is not there. But that is history, I suppose, and that is what happens when we move on.

His family are Lynne, Nicholas and James. Lynne is probably not going to know what to do having you home all the time. Nicholas and James will actually have a full-time father again, so that will be enjoyable for you. The parents who are in this place with young children are part-time parents. James was born after you came to this place, Stephen, wasn't he? So he knows nothing else except his father being here as a member of parliament. It will be the same for your children, Senator Campbell—they will know nothing of their father except him being a senator and living this crazy lifestyle, not quite working out why everybody else comes home at night.

You will be able to see the boys grow up, spend more time together and do those normal things that some of us crave to do from time to time—actually eat evening meals at home, have what you want to eat and do what you want to do. To the four of you, it is not a retirement; it is a progression. It is the next step in your life. Good luck to the four of you and keep contact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Deputy President, and congratulations. Senator Loosley and I were elected at the same election in 1990 and for the next four years we had offices on the same floor next door to each other in the Commonwealth parliamentary offices in Sydney. I probably should have mentioned this to you before, Stephen, but your answering machine is set on very loud and you can actually hear through the wall. If I happened to be in my office and you were not it was very interesting listening to the very well-known voices on that answering machine telling you to ring back or die in some cases.
—Do they all say `mate' at the end of it?

—Yes, they did all say `mate' at the end of it. I have known Senator Loosley over the last five years, mostly in his role with foreign affairs and human rights and particularly as the chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and on the human rights subcommittee.

PARA.TAB: I would have to agree with Senator Harradine's remarks about those committees, that sometimes terribly interesting questions are asked and even when we, as senators and members, ask questions and are squirming in our seats and really want to jump up and run away Senator Loosley would go calmly on with the meeting. Witnesses were always treated with great respect.

Everyone got a fair go—everyone. Sometimes I did not think that was a reasonable thing but everyone got a fair go to ask questions, and the session—and this is the real key—always finished exactly on time, if not a bit before. I have never known a chairman who can do that and whatever that secret is, Stephen, I would really like to know. It is something that we ought to spread around here. It is a great skill.

I think the first delegation that Stephen led that I was on was to Bougainville. It was a difficult delegation. At times we thought we were being shot at. It was very hot, very humid. It was a war zone, so it was very difficult. At all times he was a polished and skilful leader. When we were questioning members of the PNG defence force in Arawa, when we were talking with Bougainvillean church and women's groups in Buka or when we were in very formal meetings with the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Stephen was always exactly what Australians would want as a leader of such a delegation. I congratulate him for that. I was proud to be on that delegation with him.

At one point, right at the very beginning, we were on Buka and we had had a very long and difficult meeting that had taken five or six hours in very difficult conditions and we had just gone to visit the hospital, which I do not recommend to anybody. It is in a disgraceful condition. Anyway, we were coming back from there and the ABC cameraman came up alongside me and said, `The Bougainvillean women are talking about you, you know.' I, like any normal person, assumed that they were talking about the hideous state my hair was in because I had pulled it back to get it off my face it was so hot. But, no, that was not what they were talking about at all.

He said they were talking about the way the delegation actually seemed to want to make a difference, the way we had stuck it out for five hours in that really dreadful meeting and then gone straight from there, even though it was dusk and we were told we really should not go, over to see the hospital before we went back and had our evening meal. They were very impressed. He said that they had been very impressed with the way Senator Loosley had led that first discussion. I thought that was really quite special. It was his first big discussion on a very difficult human rights delegation. To get that sort of feedback from the people we were talking to was very impressive.

There was an example of Stephen's generosity in that trip too. Overnight, the temperature in Buka went down to about 35 degrees celsius, and the humidity went down to about 99 per cent. For the first night, Stephen had an airconditioned room and the rest of us had not. Margaret Swieringa and I shared a room next door to Stephen, and at breakfast the next morning he said, `You really do not look very well.' We said, `That's because we did not sleep at all. We did not sleep for one minute last night.' He insisted that we take the airconditioned room the next night. I do not believe for a minute that he slept at all during the next night, but I will be forever grateful because I did. I slept for a good eight hours, and it was wonderful.

The trip to Vietnam was more difficult than Bougainville. We never at any point thought anyone was shooting at us, but our hosts were not really keen to see us come and they were not really keen to see us go through it. We had expected, especially before we left, that it would be a very difficult mission. It was made far easier because Stephen was such a good chair. He led that very well, and we came out of it with a very good report—one that I am proud of and one that I have heard a lot of good reports of. I think that was another real high point in Stephen's career until now. I wish him and Lynne well for the future, particularly in a new and spectacular career. I expect it to be spectacular, and I look forward to watching it. I also wish them well in the vastly improved family life which they and their two boys, Nicholas and James, who are both friends of mine, can now enjoy.

I will miss you. I will certainly miss you on the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee and especially on the human rights subcommittee. I am really sorry that you are going at this point, but good luck for the future. I know that you will do well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your appointment this week. I first met Stephen Loosley in the early 1970s. I cannot recall precisely which year it was. I have been endeavouring to remember that far back. I do recall that I received a phone call from Graham Richardson. One thing you do not forget is receiving phone calls from Graham Richardson or from any other general secretary of the New South Wales ALP. They are usually about important matters.

PARA.TAB: At that time, I was a delegate from the Sutherland shire area in Sydney to what was called the regional assembly. It was an assembly of members of the party which covered the St George and Sutherland shire areas. Graham was a bit concerned at the time that the Left were pretty active in the area under the leadership of a former senator and that they might get control of the regional assembly that was to be held in a few weekends time. He said to me, `I want you to go to one of the planning meetings for this regional assembly. There will be a young bloke there called Stephen Loosley. You should say hello to him, because this guy is going to go places.' Graham gave Steve a very big wrap. He particularly pointed out to me that he is an ex-Leftie but said, `We have him now and he will certainly be one of our stars of the future.' Graham's predictions came true, as invariably in those days and for a long time thereafter they did.

Steve demonstrated at that meeting I went to when I first met him what a first-class political tactician he was. He developed a strategy that if we could actually convince enough people not to turn up to the regional assembly there would not be a quorum and the Left would not get control. Eventually, down the track we did actually abolish the damn thing. That all happened.

On numerous occasions thereafter, in his various capacities in the party administration, Steve demonstrated not only what a first-class political tactician he was, what a first-class campaign director he was, but also what a first-class policy analyst he was—something not often found in those who are involved purely in political administration. Steve went on to become an official of the New South Wales branch of the ALP. He rose through the ranks to become general secretary in 1983 and served in that position until 1990 when he entered the Senate.

I have already said that Steve showed what an astute political mind he had when he joined the New South Wales Right after having a brief flirtation with the Left. It is customary in this place, in the press—just about everywhere—and even in the Labor Party at times, for people to denigrate the New South Wales Right. Many times we have been abused and pilloried. Our leaders have been defamed and demonised and, of course, Steve Loosley has had to cop his fair share of that. But all of that criticism—a totally unfounded attack as it was—is motivated by jealousy of the phenomenal political success of the New South Wales Right and therefore, as a consequence, the political success of the New South Wales ALP. Certainly, under the stewardship of Stephen's predecessor as general secretary, Graham Richardson, and under his own stewardship in those years between 1983 and 1990—when he left to go into parliament and handed over to John Della Bosca—that political success has continued.

Throughout the last 20 years, the New South Wales branch of the ALP has been at the forefront of the electoral success of the Whitlam, Hawke and Keating governments in the federal sphere and the Wran and Carr governments at the state level in New South Wales. Administering a political party is not an easy task. It is particularly difficult in the Australian Labor Party. It is even more difficult in the New South Wales branch because of the broad range of interests, both political and industrial, of Left, Right, Centre and occasionally Other—never the Centre Left. But we have managed to ensure that it has only ever made a small intrusion.

As I said, it is a difficult, thankless task to be the chief administrator of the branch in New South Wales. When you win everyone wants to claim the victory. When you lose—fortunately, only infrequently has that occurred in New South Wales over the period—you find yourself bearing the blame almost alone. Steve Loosley in his period with the New South Wales party can rightly take great credit for the electoral success of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales and, indeed, the nation during those many years.

As I said, people unjustly attack the New South Wales Right because in Steve's own personal qualities he puts the lie to all of those attacks made upon the New South Wales Right and its leadership. Over the many years that I have known Steve and counted him as a good friend, I have always found him to be—as other people here tonight have said—considerate, polite, articulate, fair and patient; indeed, a good, decent, respectable mate. Steve has carried on that commitment and those characteristics during his time in this parliament. Others have already spoken about his work in the parliament and in the government, particularly in the areas of foreign affairs and his commitment to human rights.

It is with some degree of irony that I actually rise tonight to speak on what is Stephen Loosley's last day in this parliament, because it was exactly 12 months ago today that I was sworn in as a senator for New South Wales and I was escorted to the table by Senator Loosley and Senator Gareth Evans to take the oath. During that 12 months, Steve has always been ready to offer me as a new senator advice, encouragement and assistance whenever I have sought that from him.

Steve has indicated that he leaves the parliament and the government to take up a career in the law. Someone, I think, earlier noted that this is a rather strange twist because people usually leave the law to take up politics. As we all know, Steve has a deep interest in—indeed, a passion for—politics, particularly political biography, political history and an unparalleled knowledge of American political history.

I am sure everyone has seen him at some time or other with a book under his arm and no doubt we have all shared the anecdotes that he can relate about the great and not so great figures of American and Australian political history. I am sure that Steve has already heard this little story, but I think it is appropriate to recall tonight what a great American figure of political history, Adlai Stevenson, once said. It was shortly after the election of John F. Kennedy to the Presidency of the United States when John Kennedy commenced putting his administration together and he recruited many legal practitioners from Adlai Stevenson's law firm to serve in his administration. Eventually, Adlai Stevenson became so frustrated at losing all of his legal talent that he remarked:

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that I have but one law firm to give to my country.

Today the country returns the favour somewhat with Steve leaving the political arena and entering into the law. But, Steve, I do issue a warning. As you no doubt are aware, lawyers, like politicians, are not very popular. Indeed, we rate fairly low in the popularity polls. And I know that—like many in this building—I happen to be both!

PARA.TAB: I cannot claim anywhere near your expertise in political history. But I have had a longstanding interest in literature, particularly the great American writer and satirist Mark Twain. Mark Twain did not much like lawyers. He and his fictional characters demonstrated the public's general distrust of those who exercise power and authority. But he did it with humour—a quality that I know you possess in great measure.

On one occasion after delivering a very humorous address to a New England society banquet, Mark Twain sat down and the host, a leading attorney of the area, stood up with his hands in his pockets and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Does it not seem unusual to this gathering that a professional humorist should really appear funny?
To which Mark Twain then rose to his feet and replied:
Does it not also appear strange to this assembly that a lawyer should have his hands in his own pockets?

One further thing that I was reminded of occurred when listening to Senator Bell talking about dress sense. One of my early recollections of Stephen Loosley at state conferences occurred on one of those long weekends in June. There were two people who wore double-breasted suits—only two of them, I think. One of them was the late Rex Connor and the other one was the young Stephen Loosley. As was stated on one occasion, when Stephen Loosley strode to the microphone he looked like a spinnaker under full sail. He certainly made an impression whenever he strode to the microphone in both what he wore and what he said.

PARA.TAB: Stephen Loosley will take up his new career in the law with the same dedication and professionalism and touched with that sense of humour he has displayed throughout his distinguished political career. With his considerable advocacy and journalistic skills, just maybe he will be able to convince the public that politicians and lawyers are not so bad after all. Stephen, I wish you all the best in your new career and best wishes to Lynne and the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few words tonight to the valedictory debate for Senator Steve Loosley. As a number of people have mentioned tonight by way of aside, Steve and I share some common factors in our political career. We both came into this place in 1990 and we both had children after we came here. I think James and my son Edward were born only a few months apart. We were both very aware of the unusual nature of the career we had entered into.

PARA.TAB: When we were juggling our private pairing arrangements for finance and public administration meetings, which seemed to be held on virtually every Friday of the first few years of our careers, Steve always had a special understanding of my situation even though he had young Nicholas and James at home. They were up in Sydney, but young Edward was about six hours travelling time away in Perth. So Steve and I used to do deals, I guess between the New South Wales Right and the Western Australian Right, to pair each other when it suited us, particularly leading up to my first preselection in 1992. I have appreciated that.

I have served with you, Steve, on a number of committees, although not since the last election. I always found that Steve had a very positive contribution to make. Steve would often find himself trying to resolve trenchant differences between particularly the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration Committee, who was Senator John Coates, Rod Kemp, who has just come into the chamber and who spoke earlier, and me. We often had very contradictory views. Steve would always come up with a sensible compromise—whether it was either delaying or adjourning the meeting or trying to come up with a set of words or a couple of different reports. More out of a sense of wanting to write another article for a newspaper or something—or a sense of `let's get this bloody meeting finished with'—he always solved the problems.

Senator Harradine made an important remark in relation to the talent that Steve obviously possesses as a debater, as someone with a good grasp of policy and as someone who could defend the indefensible for the Labor government. In virtually all of the urgency motions and the MPIs that I have seen take place in this building during the past five years, Senator Loosley has bowled up as one of the government's speakers—a very effective speaker at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Barney.

—We will talk about Senator Cooney when it is his valedictory—which I hope is not for a long time, Senator Cooney. As I was saying, that is a mark of the man. I was very surprised that Steve was not made a minister after the surprise win in the 1993 election. As other speakers on this side have said—from memory, they were Senator Hill and Senator Kemp—there is no doubt from our side in looking across at the government benches that Senator Loosley, no matter what happened after the next election, would have been on the front bench. Clearly, Steve has thought about that in making this decision which will affect the rest of his life. As Senator Hill said, he probably thought that six or nine years on the opposition front bench would not be that much fun so he has gone to the law instead.

PARA.TAB: Either way, Stephen Loosley has been a great success in national politics. In a period of five years he has achieved an enormous amount not only as a government member—albeit not on the front bench—as a very successful chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, as someone who has come into this place with the reputation of being a hard and successful party political operative but also as someone who has shown his policy credentials, his debating credentials and communication credentials, which are all facets of a well-rounded and successful politician. Steve has shown he is better than most in all of these areas.

Steve and I also share an interest in US politics, although I would never pretend to know as much about it as he does. It is something in which I have had a close interest since the Watergate years, when I used to sit around and read Time magazines. It was interesting to watch the ABC series about it. Watching that series, Watergate seemed like a hell of a long time ago now, but it seems like only yesterday that we were reading about it in Time magazine.

I will tell one anecdote about Senator Loosley to show how he can get things done around this place. For a number of months leading up to the November congressional elections I was contemplating how we could receive the CNN broadcast in this building. Most people thought it would be a good service to have although, as it happened, some of us were not that keen on the election result. I was contemplating writing a letter to the President or the Speaker to get that organised. It got to within about a day of the November election and I thought that the quickest way to do it would be to speak to Steve.

We bumped into each other in the corridor and I said, `Steve, can we get CNN organised?' The next day it was all fixed. The trouble is that they have forgotten to turn it off. I think that Steve and I between us ensured that everyone in this building was able to witness one of the greatest events in modern history—an absolute landslide election in the US Congress.

Steve is going to a career in the law. As other people have said, he will be a loss to this place. We know it takes sacrifice and a special sort of person to pursue a career in politics. It is very sad to see someone who, as Senator Hill said, has served an apprenticeship leave so prematurely. There are enormous pressures here, and other people have referred to that, but there are special pressures on those of us who enter politics at a younger age. It is a great loss to Australian political life that someone with Steve's undoubted capacity should decide that the private sector offers more. Steve had so much to offer.

People have spoken about Steve moving to the law and having a successful career. I was looking across at his leader, Senator Gareth Evans, when he said that if Senator Loosley fulfils in law the potential he has shown in politics, it may not be too many years before he appears before Justice Evans in the High Court. I look forward to seeing that.

I conclude by saying one or two things about the importance of political organisation. The work done by the so-called numbers men, the behind-the-scenes operators, is rarely spoken about. It is about manoeuvring political parties. It is about factional organisation. It is about organising volunteers to build a political party through recruitment of members and organisation of election campaigns. It is about keeping the party organisation together between campaigns and ensuring that the party attracts the sort of people who can go on to serve in parliament. It is sometimes referred to in valedictory speeches. It is sometimes analysed by journalists who do not understand what is involved. It is a very important part of the political life of any nation and, as Senator Forshaw said, it is hard work.

I was impressed by a speech made by the now Speaker of the House of Representatives in the United States, Newt Gingrich, when he was talking about this to his political organisation, which is called GOPAC, in the United States. He was encouraging volunteers by saying that you do not need to ask the questions, `Is it hard to run a nation? Is it hard to change a democracy like America'—and I think you can apply this to Australia—`Is it hard to create a political organisation? Is it hard to gather the ideas, the volunteers, the money and the skills required to communicate those ideas to the people?' because it is all very hard. It is important work. It is not recognised broadly in the community. It is very hard to build that organisation.

Whether people over here like it or not, there is no doubt that the New South Wales Labor Party—and many of the people who sit opposite us, Senator Loosley in particular—has been very successful at that very hard work of political organisation. It is something that people very rarely get any sort of recognition for, except for having a few glasses of champagne or a few cold tinnies on election night and for that thrill, that feeling, that very few of us over here have enjoyed for many years except in recent state elections.

Steve, you have been an enormous success. It is an enormously premature decision for you to leave. It is a victory for the coalition that you are leaving because the Labor Party in the Senate is losing one of its most effective people, and one of the people who was marked for great things in the future no matter what happens at the next election.

I envy you to the extent that you will be able to spend a lot more time with Lynne, Nicholas and James. They will be the winners as well. The Labor Party will be the loser. I wish you genuinely very well for your future career. I do hope that you maintain your public life, albeit outside this parliament, because you do not necessarily have to be in a parliament to be a good citizen of this nation. You have a lot to offer this country. On behalf of my family to your family, you have my genuine wishes for your future life.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not able to be here for the opening remarks of the leaders of the various parties on the occasion of Stephen Loosley leaving the Senate. I want to say a few words and be brief, but this in no way reflects my view about Stephen's contribution to both the Labor Party and the Australian parliament.

PARA.TAB: I, like Stephen and a range of people who sit on this side, came into the Senate from being a full-time party official of the Labor Party at some stage or other. There are a number of us here who belong to the ex-secretary's or ex-assistant secretary's club. At times I think we are the biggest faction in the Labor Party in the Senate. I have known Stephen since the mid-1970s when he was the assistant secretary of the Labor Party of New South Wales.

I want to pay particular tribute to an aspect of Stephen's work in the Labor Party before he came to the Senate. Stephen was one of those people who, as assistant secretary but particularly as state secretary or general secretary in New South Wales and then a senior official of the national executive, had a view about the need to modernise the organisation of the Australian Labor Party to make it contemporary with the needs and wishes of Australia in the latter part of the 20th century.

Stephen always put his hand up for change, to reform the organisation of the Labor Party so it would have a national outlook, a national perspective. I believe the Labor Party has won five elections in a row—unparalleled success in our history of over 100 years at the federal level—because during the 1980s a number of people of the national executive at a national conference voted to make fundamental changes to the way the Labor Party operated so it could become a truly national organisation. In every one of those debates—whether they were at the national executive, the national conference or back at the state party level—Stephen was always supportive of those moves.

Stephen, whatever else you may achieve in the rest of your life, as a person who is interested in history you have the great record and proud achievement of turning the Labor Party into a proper national party which has borne great benefits not just for the Labor Party but for the people of Australia.

I have always been intrigued by the fact, to which others have paid tribute, that Stephen is an enormous historian in his own right.I think he played a major part during the 1980s in convincing the Labor Party to be proud of its history, to research it, to promote it, to have Labor historian conferences and so on. It has been a great achievement for the party that we realise that, whatever our failures and our successes in the past, it is all part of the great historical tapestry of the Labor Party which has meant that the culture of the Labor Party of which we are members has an enduring history. The people who have gone before us are to be respected and remembered, as are those who will go on in the future. Stephen was one of the leaders in that regard in the Labor Party. That is another major achievement.

I will not comment about Stephen's success as a factional leader of the New South Wales Right. I am in another faction and from another state. But it was often put that when we both served on the national executive, on a number of occasions he would move a motion and I would second it, or vice versa, to intervene, under the new national approach of the Australian Labor Party, in recalcitrant state branches which seemed not to be able to resolve their own problems.

I think Stephen and I have moved more motions to intervene in the 1980s in the ACT branch than we have had good or bad dinners. Although it made us unpopular in the ACT branch, in the long run it was to the advantage of the ACT branch. I think all other branches, including my own, who had resolutions of intervention ultimately moved against them will know it has made the Labor Party a better organisation. So Stephen Loosley's contribution to the success of the Labor Party is very, very significant and I pay tribute to him. As he comes from the largest state it would always have been easy to ignore the interests of the smaller states but Stephen did not. He always argued for a national approach. What was of interest in other states was of interest to Stephen Loosley.

Since being elected to the Senate his interest in foreign affairs in particular has always been noted. He was chairman of the party's foreign affairs committee before he came here. His commitment to the campaign to abolish apartheid in South Africa was second to none. He was always the one moving those motions at the party conference, or at the national executive. He also put his hand up for his own state branch to put money into the cause of getting rid of apartheid in South Africa—money that people sometimes said should have been spent at home on winning a local election campaign. Stephen always had the broader view that there are issues in the world that one cannot walk away from. I know that the ANC in particular recognises Stephen's contribution to their campaign and the ultimate success which we now all rejoice in.

As a former chairman and member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I acknowledge Stephen's contribution over the last 2 1/2 years since he became chairman. I am very pleased in particular that the work he has done on human rights in that committee continued to establish a benchmark for the parliament and for Australia on the issue of human rights.

Of course, being an agnostic in the sense of being without fear or favour, he has criticised those regimes around the world on the Left and the Right which have abused human rights. Stephen has always been there to put his hand up to make the criticism. His work on the recent report on human rights came through, as Senator Vicki Bourne outlined, in the visit to Bougainville and the recent visit to Vietnam. Although it has only been a short time since he became chairman of the committee, Stephen has left his mark there.

Some people may think it is very strange that, after only five years in the Senate, Stephen has chosen to take up a position in the law. I think it is very strange, and most people know my views about the legal profession. But what people forget is that Stephen has not been in politics for just five years; he has been at it for over 20 years in a full-time capacity in one way or another. To be in full-time politics for 20 years—whether it be in parliament or in the party organisation—is a long time. We on all sides of politics should always remember, as Senator Campbell said, that the work in the organisation in respect of the political structure and the functioning of a democracy is as important as that in the parliament itself. As a former state secretary I would have to say that it is much easier being a senator than the secretary of a state branch of the Australian Labor Party.

After Stephen had been in the Senate for about three weeks—I had already had one term here—he came up to me in the corridor just outside the chamber and said, `Gee, this is an easy job compared with being a state secretary.' I said, `Stephen, you're dead right.' Fred Daly may well have said this: the Senate proves that there is life after death. The party may have pensioned off many of us party secretaries or assistant secretaries to this place, but it is a useful apprenticeship to have been through the party machine—whether it be that of the Labor, Liberal or National parties or the Democrats.

Stephen has done his apprenticeship. He served in public life for over 20 years in one form or another. Stephen, I wish you and your family well. You have made a great contribution to both the Labor Party and the parliament of Australia. You deserve our thanks for that contribution, and I wish you well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to Stephen Loosley. I do so in the full knowledge—I hope others understand this—that we come from very different traditions within the Labor Party. As a consequence, I will not be applauding him for his successes against the people whom I have come to know and love. I will also not be in a position to agree with many of the statements made about my colleagues from New South Wales, particularly those from Sydney.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to Stephen who is a very tough opponent and a very committed fighter for the principles that he believes in, some of which I share, including commitment to the labour movement and the creation of a society based on a redistribution of wealth and power. We have different views about what that means. That is the nature of the struggle within the labour movement. Senator Loosley shares with many on the left a commitment to human rights and international social justice. I think the breadth of that commitment is surprising. Perhaps it indicates that some of the good things he learnt while he was a member of the Left have not been lost entirely.

When you come into the Senate, you come with certain perceptions; certain prejudices, I suppose; and certain reputations. But you have to change many of those things. When you are thrown into battle against the real enemy, you soon notice just how important those skills and the commitment learnt discussing matters internally within the Labor Party are.

Many people have told me how surprised they were at how well Senator Loosley and I got on during those battles and how effectively we were able to work together.
