One of the great strengths of the Labor Party is that people with different traditions and different views of the way we should go forward are able to come together in respect of the struggle that is so important to this country. It has been said that we ought to understand how important it is for the political organiser in this country. I think Senator Loosley is one of those whose contribution to our society has gone unmarked.

Other senators have mentioned this point, but we must acknowledge how important it is to a country with a political system of our type for people to have an opportunity to participate in the political struggle and to learn the political skills through a commitment to a political organisation. That is what Senator Loosley was able to bring here. Before he was able to open his mouth in this chamber he had effectively served 20 years in an apprenticeship. It needs to be understood that, when we come into this place, we quite often come in here as seasoned veterans in the struggle, and Senator Loosley's contribution to his country goes way beyond the five years that he has spent in this chamber.

Tribute ought to be paid to his toughness and his commitment to the battle. It also needs to be understood that he has shown remarkable courage. The application of that courage and that commitment is a great asset to the Labor Party. I have been put on the odd committee under adverse circumstances and I could look to Senator Loosley and know that he was someone in whom I could have some confidence. He was not going to walk away from a fight. He is a very good person to have with you in your particular corner.

It is quite a surprise to me that Senator Loosley is leaving. I share with Senator Gareth Evans the hope that Senator Loosley will continue to make a contribution to society as a whole. I wish him very well in his new career.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being the youngest member of the tribe that Senator Loosley hails from, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to have the last word on this occasion. I also want to ensure that maybe the real enemy, and also the siblings that we differ with in the Labor Party, are not able to follow me and say something that we could not answer.

PARA.TAB: I very much hold the view that even though it is important where you end up, and it is important where you go to, it is really more important where you came from in a determination of what sort of person you really are. I might hark back a little to Stephen's earlier history. Steve grew up in the St George area as the son of working class parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —He came from the Left.

—I have to confess that he had a brief period when he liaised with members of the other faction but he soon came to his senses and returned to the working class roots that his family came from. He went to St George tech high school along with other notorious members of our tribe—the Easson twins, Graham Richardson and Gary Punch. Having performed very well at that institution, he went on to work part time and put himself through university where he graduated with an honours degree in arts. Shortly after that he went on to work for Kerry Sibraa after the double dissolution in 1975. He obviously excelled there. He went on to become an organiser. When Leo McLeay and Graham Richardson left he became general-secretary. That is where I met Steve.

PARA.TAB: In recent years in the public arena there has been emphasis on our tribe perhaps giving people a bit of a push and the exercise of power. There is an aspect of our tribe that is not emphasised a lot but which is probably more fundamental to what we are about. I am referring to the proposition that you look after your own. In extension, that becomes a part of what the Labor Party, and in particular the New South Wales Right, sees as what we do for Australia. We look after our own: that is, we look after Australians. Steve has done very well in the Labor Party and in the Senate in looking after his own. He has looked after Australians at large. In my short time here I have noted—and it is universally acknowledged—his expertise in international affairs and human rights.

I also note that his great contribution to policy debate in the Senate and his contributions generally and in committees have been acknowledged tonight. If you need help you can ask Steve and he will assist. Sometimes he helps in more practical ways. He always helps out when you need assistance.

I am very pleased to see that Steve is doing two things that we all hope to do—he is going at the time of his choosing and he is going to pursue something that he will obviously enjoy and is very glad to be doing. I wish him a great deal of luck in his chosen path and I also wish Lynne and the boys the best of luck. Thank you for what you have done for everyone here and in Australia generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate as the person on this side of the chamber who probably did more to ensure that Senator Loosley came into this chamber than anyone else. Senator Loosley was not originally on the 1990 election ticket. In fact, Senator Morris was to lead that ticket. Senator Morris was renowned for being, in an inverse sense, one of the most loquacious and steady attenders on record in this chamber. He was known to us all as the silent senator.

PARA.TAB: I was strongly criticised for pointing out his workload because it resulted in the Labor Party replacing mediocrity with real talent. My colleagues criticised me for that, saying that it was not really a very good outcome for us politically. They were right. Their judgment was correct because Senator Loosley has made a very significant contribution to this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the only thing that you have got wrong.

—I regret that I got it wrong, but I am also pleased that Senator Loosley has been here to make his contribution. I must say that I cannot claim any credit for his departure despite my comments in passing on one of his less successful decisions.

PARA.TAB: The problem I see is that Senator Loosley has not been properly able to fulfil his talents or potential in this place. He is far more able than so many of his more highly placed colleagues. As he goes into the legal business I must say that I hope there is a continuation of the evident trend from Labor's Left to Right that will move Senator Loosley more towards the position that he would find more comfortable—that is, on this side of the chamber.

Senator Loosley is not a one dimensional politician. There are far too many in this parliament who are one dimensional. Senator Loosley, you are a person of a great deal of depth and capacity and you have quite a width of interests and knowledge. I hope that the law does not take up your complete interest because it would seem to me to be stultifying and deadening if you were to limit yourself to that area.

Unlike Senator Bourne, I can say that I did everything to avoid occupying a neighbouring office in the Sydney Commonwealth parliamentary offices. Having heard about your answer phone, I am very glad that I avoided that and ended up on another floor. I think it is the parliament's loss that you have decided to leave. I wish you and Lynne all the very best. I hope that when we next meet, as I trust we will, it will be as friends and associates rather than as the formal enemies that we are presented as being here.

I would like to stress to those few enthusiastic people sufficiently masochistic to be listening to the chamber at this hour that there is a false impression, helped by the media, that we spend our time here warring, that we are in constant conflict. The reality, of course, is that, particularly in the Senate committee system—which you, Senator Loosley, have graced—the amount of consensus, the amount of searching for accommodations and the effort to try to achieve a reasonable solution that will be in the best interests of the people of Australia does exercise the great bulk of our time. The great bulk of legislation passes through this place without objection, or at least with only a moderate volume of amendments sought—amendments often moved by the government as a result of the committee activity in which you have been so heavily involved, Senator Loosley.

I hope that this debate will be some indication to people of what the reality of parliamentary life is. Your departure from it, Senator Loosley, to live a proper family life is probably another indication to the people of Australia that there is an enormous amount of sacrifice made by people who come into this place. As has been pointed out, you have sacrificed your life to politics for the last 20 years. Let us hope that you have a very enjoyable time in the life you have now chosen to lead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Deputy President, and congratulations. Stephen, I will not take too much time, but I just wish to endorse the remarks made by people in the chamber. I think it is worth saying that a mark of the man is the number of people who have spoken in relation to his leaving this place.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, could I say to you that I hope you have a great life when you leave here. I feel sure that, with the talents and the ability that you have, you will be very successful. I think that the heights that you reached in the Senate will only be a very small stepping stone to the heights that you will reach in private practice as a lawyer or whatever the case might be.

Senators tonight have described how great Stephen was as a committee chairman. As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I have had an opportunity to sit at meetings that Stephen chaired. Stephen, I would have to endorse everything that has been said, particularly by Senator Harradine, in relation to you as chairman. I refer not only to the way you chaired meetings. I was fortunate enough to have been on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority with you. I say to honourable senators that as an ordinary member of that committee Stephen showed the same talent as he did as the chair of the Joint Foreign Affairs Committee.

One of the great impressions that one gets of Stephen is of when he chairs a meeting and has a very important overseas visitor there. I think Senator Harradine referred to this. The person I particularly remember was the Clerk from South Africa. The way Stephen handled the meeting, the way he put forward Australia's point of view to the visitor and the way he encouraged the visitor to answer the questions was supreme; and this was the only time I have been at a committee meeting when I have seen the chair handle the matters before it as well as Stephen handled them on that occasion and on many other occasions.

Stephen, your leaving here will be a loss not only to the Senate but to the Australian political scene. I think some senators on the other side, and on this side, have already said that we expected that, with the sort of talent you showed, one day you would be on the frontbench—and that it would not be too long before you would be a member of the cabinet.

Stephen, when you made your statement to the Senate about your decision to leave the place you said that you wanted to spend more time with your family. Our loss will be their gain. Could I say to you and to your family that I hope your leaving here is the decision that you want to make. I hope that decision brings joy to you and to your family in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening with interest to the comments Senate colleagues have been making about my friend Stephen Loosley and I do not wish to duplicate them. Enough has been said, very important and serious things. I do not know when I first met Steve Loosley—it seems like I have known him forever—but we have worked very closely together as officials in the party, senators and friends. I want to comment on three aspects of his activity which are not directly related to any of those activities but which I think are important parts of what has made Steve such a good contributor to the political process.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Jones has said, he is more than just an efficient political operator, which he certainly was, sometimes on my side and sometimes not and unfortunately equally efficient on both sides. I only 50 per cent appreciated the bit when it was on my side. But there are other things that made him a more interesting and substantial contributor. The first of the three things I want to emphasise is his profound interest in history—Australian history, world history, and particularly his expertise in some areas of American history. It gave him a depth on which he could draw in his analysis of contemporary circumstances. Obviously much of it was about political history. That was what one heard drawn upon most often in political discussions, but he had a breadth of interest in history, which is something we should all pursue.

Secondly, there was his role as an internationalist. That had a very important influence in the Labor Party in the development of some of the links in this region and in the wider international community that has made the party, and subsequently the government on which it is based, a broader and more effective institution.

Thirdly, there is his love and knowledge of the film industry. I was always overwhelmed by the fact that, compared to most other people around the Senate and around the Labor Party I knew a lot about the film industry and had an interest, but compared to Steve I always found I knew nothing. It is not just an interest and a passion but a very deep intellectual commitment to it and study of it. I am sure the movie theatres are going to get quite a bashing now he has more time to attend to them. I hope that he takes advantage of the opportunity and that it adds another perspective to public life, as I am sure it will to private life. I find that a commitment to any area of the arts gives one a capacity to make more interesting and effective and original contributions throughout other areas of public life.

There are a lot of things I could say about Steve in the Labor Party but they have been said by Senator Schacht and others and I will not duplicate them. I merely endorse them. I have enjoyed the opportunity to work with him in many forums but those three aspects were, I thought, unique contributions that he made over and above those effective organisational contributions for which the more orthodox recollections will always record his significant contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a few comments I would like to make to farewell Stephen Loosley. I had the pleasure, too, of being with Senator Bell on a trip to Argentina. The thing that I learnt about Senator Loosley then—which I do not think has been referred to here tonight—is that he is one of the few people I know who can recite word for word every chapter and verse of The Adventures of Barry Mackenzie. I know he is a scholar. He knows his history. He is erudite and wonderful. In any doubtful moment, another passage of what Barry was up to flowed from the lips of Senator Loosley and indeed, I have to say, from the lips of Mr Paul Filing from the other place. Senator Loosley was a most entertaining addition to the delegation.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is quite right. I thought an odd note of reality and a different sense of humour might be intruded here. Another thing about Stephen Loosley is that he has a splendid sense of humour. It is a very informed and intelligent sense of humour, but it is a splendid sense of humour. It is one of the factors that have helped rescue a number of difficult situations and indeed probably adds to the qualities others have mentioned of Stephen's capacity to be such a good chair or manager of any kind of organisation. His capacity to do that is splendid. He has also been very willing and very able to offer any support or advice to me and to others who sought it.

PARA.TAB: As a member of committees, I will never forget listening to an exchange between Senator Loosley and Mr Pooley from the Treasury when Mr Pooley was even more than usually disinclined to pass on any information at all to honourable senators. Stephen bowled every ball that is in Shane Warne's armoury. He tried a few curve balls, a few medium pacers and a couple of fast balls. Absolutely nothing stirred Mr Pooley from his considered and reasonable approach: `That is what I want to say and I am not saying any more.' I was enormously entertained then, Stephen. I am not sure I should say that entertainment is the only way I will remember you, but it is certainly one way. I will remember you with great fondness and I wish you every success in wherever your future takes you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I begin my final contribution in the Australian Senate by congratulating you publicly, as I have done privately, on your election. It is thoroughly well deserved and you will make a great contribution to the Australian Senate.

PARA.TAB: To paraphrase Robert Penn Warren: there is an end but you will not see it; there is a beginning but you cannot see it. Perhaps tonight the great author was wrong in the sense that this is the finish of my involvement in the Senate and shortly there will be a beginning in another career—in law. It is something that causes me a degree of sadness, but it is something that also brings to me a sense of optimism about the future.

It has been a privilege to have served in this chamber over the last five years. It is a very great privilege afforded to very few Australians. I want to acknowledge that now at the beginning of my speech. I thank my personal staff over the years, the staff of the parliament and my colleagues and friends. I am absolutely overwhelmed by the generosity of spirit demonstrated by people around the chamber—from within my own party, the coalition, the Democrats and Senator Harradine. It has been extraordinarily generous of all those who have spoken.

When Bob referred to my interest in films, I wrote down the opening of John Huston's film The Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, which ran, `This is not the way it was, it's the way it should have been.' To everyone who has spoken, and spoken with such very real decency and generosity, thank you. I begin by thanking my friend Senator Gareth Evans. There is no doubt that in Gareth Evans we have quite an extraordinary Australian.

I have served three Labor prime ministers—Whitlam, Hawke and Keating—all of whom have been outstanding in different ways. I have served three Labor premiers in New South Wales—Wran, Unsworth and Carr—all of whom are very dedicated in different ways. There is no doubt in my mind that, for the future, I can see a number of figures in the parliamentary Labor Party who are capable of assuming the prime ministership—I am thinking of Kim Beazley and Michael Lee in the House of Representatives and Gareth Evans in this chamber. I thank Minister Lee in particular for coming across tonight. It is a very decent thing to do for an old friend.

There is no doubt that chairing the joint committee on foreign affairs, which was a recommendation of my friend Chris Schacht—to work towards chairing the joint committee and the human rights subcommittee and make that a political objective—has been a great experience, a privilege, a joy. Very often we dealt with extremely complex issues in the range of interests demonstrated on the committee and the range of objectives which the parliament set us, and very often there were difficulties.

I can recall, Senator Harradine, the most difficult question ever put to a guest being a question about, `Would a nuclear war between two countries be in the Australian national interest?' I will not mention the distinguished congressman who asked that question, but that did tax my powers of patience and response.

The joint committee, though, endeavours all the time around the table to make a contribution to policy, to influence policy for the better, to reflect—in Sam Rayburn's classic expression—the fact that `disputes over external relations, be they matters of foreign affairs, defence or trade, really should stop at the water's edge'. That has been the case with the delegations in which I have been involved. I reflect on just three or four of them.

Michael MacKellar and I were in Russia at the end of 1993, for example, as international monitors for the democratic election, beginning in Khabarovsk at a quarter to eight in the morning where the temperature was minus 27 degrees. The cold was so extreme, it was in our respiratory systems. But it was a task that we were asked to fulfil, and we were proud to be involved on behalf of the Australian parliament in ensuring that the democratic process was free and fair—which it was.

Michael Lee and I had been in Nepal some two years earlier for the same purpose—to witness the first democratic expression of the people of Nepal in nearly four decades. I recall being on the Chinese border on the Friendship Ridge, as I recall, Senator Bourne, between Tibet and Nepal, and looking very carefully into that country and thinking to myself: I hope to come back when there is a democratic Tibet to neighbour a democratic Nepal.

Senator Bourne, Senator Calvert, Mr Sinclair, Mr Knott and I went to Bougainville—a great experience for us. We endeavoured to find solutions to a war that had claimed at least 3,000 lives and displaced at least 50,000 and probably close to 100,000 people. It was a tragedy on a scale in our region that really caused us to recognise a particular Australian responsibility. The report we wrote was unanimous and shifted opinion in Papua New Guinea and changed opinion in Australia. Ian Sinclair said to me just the other day that he regarded that report in all his long time in parliament as being the most influential in which he had ever been involved. So to Rwanda and other parts of Africa earlier this year, and then to Vietnam just recently, but working on the basis that the parliament can influence foreign policy, should influence foreign policy—and a close working relationship with the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the Minister for Trade or the Minister for Defence really assists in that process. It is a process of working with people; not endeavouring to score points.

I realise that we have to sharpen the differences from time to time; that is part of the democratic system. I acknowledge that we have to confront each other as political players on issues, and that is healthy. There will be some issues on which there will be really quite distinct differences of emphasis, priority and philosophy—in matters of economy and industrial relations perhaps. But very often the parliament can achieve a great deal more where we focus over time, produce policy options, argue them through and then arrive at a consensus. The work on APEC, for example, in which Senator McMullan has been so intimately involved over the last few years, is a good example of that.

In my view, parliament should always endeavour to reflect—to use Gough Whitlam's great expression—the intelligent anticipation of change when it comes to the country's external affairs. They are just so important.

Travelling abroad has caused me on any number of occasions to be so proud of what our people do. I am referring to the Australian Defence Force, our police, our electoral officials, our humanitarian agencies, our non-government organisations and our people who go into extremely difficult and dangerous places and always perform with credit and great courage. Whether it be in a refugee camp in Kibeho in Rwanda, whether it be in the black townships outside Johannesburg, whether it be in a Salvation Army hospital for AIDS in Zambia or whether it be in forestry in remote areas of Nepal, in any number of instances I have been able to witness this dedication first hand.

By the presence of our delegations—I trust to reinforce this—not only is the Australian parliament interested in what our people are doing abroad to better the capacity of mankind to achieve, but we are committed to those projects. We are involved and committed. I hope for the future in an honorary capacity that I will be able to keep up those interests. I have had approaches from several human rights groups to do some voluntary work and I am more than pleased to be involved in that.

I am sorry, Senator Baume, but in response to your very generous remarks, the last movement on the political spectrum for me has been from democratic socialist to social democrat. I will be Labor until I cast my last vote but that does not mean that there are not any number of occasions when it is possible to work and find common purpose and common ground with people opposite and people in the other parties.

I shall miss the camaraderie and I shall miss the friendships—friendships that I had when I arrived, as with Bob and Gerry and Schachty and a whole lot of other people; new friendships that I have made, as with Kim; and friendships that go back a long way, as with my colleagues from New South Wales, Sue, Belinda and Michael in particular.

One thing I have learned—and I say this without fear of contradiction—is that in politics no-one has a monopoly on wisdom, no matter what your political commitment and no matter what your particular philosophical position. No matter how experienced you believe you happen to be or your party happens to be, there is always opportunity to hear another person's point of view and to try to work useful and valuable ideas into the process. That has been a strength of our party over a very long period. We have had over a century of experience to learn not only by our successes but, more importantly, by our mistakes.

For the Senate to always look forward—I am thinking of Senator Peter Baume's retirement speech when I say this—really involves this chamber being part of a process which I hope will be bipartisan. I have always regarded my party as the agent of change; I still do and I always shall. That is not to say that other people and other parties do not make contributions very often and very significantly.

I mention three issues in particular in which I trust the Senate will be involved. The creation of an Australian republic with an Australian head of state is one. This is not something about which we should be arguing. There are no political points in this. There were no political points once Henry Parkes decided to bring New South Wales into the federation in 1895. Once Parkes scotched the idea of renaming New South Wales `Australia' and going it alone, it was going to be an Australian federation. And it is going to be an Australian republic.

I trust as part of that process of constitutional modernisation and reform that we shall have a Bill of Rights which is endorsed by the Australian people which guarantees and protects human rights in this country and gives our judiciary a series of guidelines within which they operate. If the parliament does not create a Bill of Rights, the Australian judiciary will create it for us. Where there is a vacuum, it will always be filled.

For the parliament itself, I ask that the recommendation of the human rights subcommittee—which was endorsed unanimously by the subcommittee and which came into the parliament and appears to have been embraced—for the creation of a joint standing committee of the Australian parliament on Australian human rights, become a reality in the next parliament.

The human rights subcommittee does sterling work. Every shade of opinion is represented on that body. It does outstanding work. Some of the issues with which we deal are the stuff of nightmares. The committee has been very effective. We have looked not only at circumstances abroad but at circumstances in our own country—for example, circumstances of our own Aboriginal people in remote communities—in so far as the international human rights instruments are concerned. The new joint standing committee on human rights will be able to achieve far more for our own people in relation to Australia's role in the region and Australia's role in world.

We have been very active in the United Nations since its inception, particularly in respect of peacekeeping. Virtually every major peacekeeping mission has involved Australian personnel at one level or another. I believe the creation of a joint standing committee on human rights can only reinforce those very positive, purposeful and constructive tendencies in our parliament and in our political culture.

David Malouf wrote brilliantly of the `Great World' not so long ago. I am about to depart one career and enter a second career. I am looking forward to that. I am also looking forward to spending a great deal more time with Lynne, Nicholas and James. I thank the three of them most sincerely for their support over a very long period of time. For example, James has grown up without me being around, and that is something that has caused me to think about the future. They have been extraordinary in terms of the amount of support which they have given me.

I will end my remarks there. I thank everyone again for honouring me with their far too generous observations and comments and for being present. I wish everyone here in the chamber and beyond in the parliament good fortune, good health and much by way of future contribution to the national interest and to Australia's capacity to contribute in the world.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue the remarks that I began last evening on CSL—on its work before it was privatised and since it has been privatised and on the work of the Commonwealth department of health in relation to the supervision of CSL in the products that it made and the products that it makes now.

PARA.TAB: When I left these remarks last night, I was speaking about the manufacture of human pituitary hormones. I pointed out that CSL had never been under a process of good management practice, and that was recognised. It had not developed proper processes of assay for its pituitary hormones. Indeed, many of the pituitary glands that had been collected from overseas had been collected under unsterile conditions. Pyrogenic batches were produced and these were distributed to Australian patients. In connection with that, CSL had not been employing a microbiologist on its staff—or in the team manufacturing hormones—in order to protect the Australian public against the hepatitis B virus.

I would like to continue by pointing out that today I have sought, through the FOI, a number of documents relating to the procedures used to assess the health status of foreign donors of either blood, blood fractions or tissue, the safety associated with the methods of collection, storage and transfer of these materials and the processes used for the inactivation of any disease carrying entity that may have been in any of these products.

I know there is a great deal of written documentary material on these matters. I know that some of this material is marked `never to be destroyed'. I fear there is a very strong temptation to destroy much of this material that would prove very damaging to CSL if it were released. I urge the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to give a firm undertaking that none of that material will find its way to the shredder, the waste bin or the incinerator.

I will continue specifically with the history of CSL, its secrecy and its lack of openness in relation to pituitary hormones. Long before the Therapeutic Goods Administration's recent efforts to deny any possible link between CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, and blood or blood products, the health department had sent medical details and names of hormone recipients to a range of medical institutions around Australia, including blood banks, advising that the hormone recipients were a risk as donors of human tissue, including blood. Recipients were not told that this data was sent. Therefore, there is a serious inconsistency in the behaviour of the Therapeutic Goods Administration in this regard.

The government's answers to a long and important series of questions put by my colleague Senator Meg Lees and by opposition senator Kay Patterson, through the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee last November, were released three months later. These provide many examples of secrecy, evasion, ducking and redefining the question. They demonstrate that these matters cannot be determined adequately by such exchanges and require, as I indicated last night, the forum of a committee inquiry to nail down the truth.

I note that neither the health department nor CSL, which made the pituitary hormones and blood products, revealed, until the company was up for sale in May last year, that CSL had engaged in the intrinsically unsafe practice of making blood products from human placentae. Strong evidence is emerging that senior CSL Ltd personnel responsible for blood product manufacture believed their virus inactivation and manufacturing techniques can eliminate disease agents. This is a deadly and serious state of affairs. It could lead the company to again mix human with inferior foreign or other material, as it has in the past. It has grave implications for the health of CSL workers and transport personnel and could cause the company to not issue safety and risk warnings about its products. I query whether a corporation which holds this belief is fit to fractionate our blood plasma.

In 1992 the corporation knowingly and intentionally appropriated Red Cross blood clotting factors which had been bailed to them in trust that they would be returned to Red Cross. Instead, CSL Ltd secretly sent products to an overseas government, or the government's blood banking agents, evading Customs clearance. CSL, it appears, failed to report this incident under trade practices law, when it learnt the products were contaminated with hepatitis C. Other allegations of CSL routinely sending Red Cross material to foreign countries without Red Cross knowledge or consent have been ignored by the minister and her department.

CSL has long brought in foreign plasma to process and return for a commercial fee. The Hong Kong incident shows it was willing to bring in plasma with high levels of infectious disease for processing in the same machinery as processed Australian plasma. CSL misleads the public by claiming that foreign plasma is required to meet WHO standards, as if this were a good thing. Let an open inquiry hear what Australian Red Cross thinks of the WHO standards for blood donors. Let us compare those standards with the standards required by the Therapeutic Goods Administration.

Between 1957 and at least 1990, CSL secretly mixed Red Cross donor plasma with plasma from overseas countries having lower health and testing standards than our own. This made a mockery of Red Cross efforts over decades to provide only the best available plasma for Australian blood products. The company has lied about the practice on a number of occasions since last October while insisting that there is no evidence of harm from the practice. So why should they lie about it?

According to the company's statement tabled in Hansard on 9 February this year, segregation of all plasmas for the manufacture of products exclusively for each country of plasma origin was commenced in 1992. Alarmingly, CSL in 1995 reveals that `as the volume of plasma supplied by various countries increased it became possible to segregate plasma'. Yet it was economies of scale—that is, not enough bucks in observing health standards—which prompted the company to mix plasmas in the first place. How can we believe the head of the bioplasma division, who told assembled journalists last October, `I must be honest with you. My greatest concern is for the health care community of Australia,' when the company itself reveals this kind of motivation after it has been supposedly reformed as we were told?

Is there a conflict of interest in having our plasma processed under community service obligations by an internationalised corporation which is avowedly profitmaking and persists in judging its role as our national blood fractionator by the inferior benchmark of international standards? Is there a conflict of interest in CSL providing plasma based clotting factors while holding a licence to sell the more lucrative overseas recombinant product?

This is another matter the government and CSL prefer to treat with complete silence. We have evidence that CSL's virus inactivation techniques in the 1980s were inadequate by the standards and limits at that time. Let me be clear about this because anyone keen to avoid blood product liability loves to argue that they could not have known at the time that what they were doing was harmful or risky—`20-20 hindsight' and `state-of-the-art' are the chorus lines they like to throw up when anyone tries to sing about the subject.

Why are the minister and her department showing no interest in this matter? CSL escaped negligence claims for HIV contaminated blood when haemophiliacs contracted AIDS. In the same year it claimed to have stopped mixing, but it never told about the mixing in court, and the health department, which paid up indirectly for CSL's share of liability, never told about the mixing. No-one told the judges in the court and no-one told the public in the prospectus. That is a second very important point for the 100 per cent public sale of CSL last May. I see that I am not going to finish this speech tonight so I will finish at that point and conclude when next we meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I also join in congratulating you on your elevation to the chair. Yesterday in the House of Representatives Mr Colin Hollis continued a pattern of personal attack on me which I mentioned in this chamber earlier in the week and which involved, I must say, a continuing diminution of the standards of the House of Representatives. I believe this is a cause of some concern, not only to that House but also to this chamber when it involves denigration of members of this chamber.

PARA.TAB: However, I must say that yesterday Mr Hollis correctly pointed out my error in my assertion that I had never issued a defamation proceeding against Mr Hollis. I said this in response to his claim that I had issued a couple of defamation actions against him. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been on the receiving end of a couple of these, and he is well known throughout the Illawarra for serving defamation orders on people.

I said that that was utter bunkum and I now have to recognise that 12 years ago I did back up a demand that he apologise for telling the most disgraceful untruths about me by threatening him with legal action. As a result of his not doing the decent thing and apologising for what he knew to be something totally false, I did ask my solicitors to issue a District Court writ which, I might say, did not proceed for a variety of reasons, the main one being that it costs money.

PARA.TAB: I was seeking to force Mr Hollis to recognise that the decent thing is to admit errors and the telling of disgraceful, damaging, defamatory untruths. Unfortunately, Mr Hollis is a person who would not be amenable to that kind of suggestion. I will read the legal advice that I have:

SPEECH.PARA: Counsel is clearly of the opinion that the material is defamatory.
It continues:
. . . I am of the view that a cause of action would flow against Mr Hollis—

I will read into the Hansard what he said, because it reveals what sort of a person he is. It relates to the HMAS Albatross naval air station in my electorate. He said this in the 1983 election campaign:

PARA.TAB: Albatross would be expanded under Labor, there would be no reduction in the economic input to Nowra. Albatross would become the headquarters of a Maritime Command. The Fleet Air Arm would be returned; some of the Orion could be transferred to the Fleet Air Arm; the Skyhawks now in mothballs should be used as a Maritime Land Base strike weapon. Extra training would be provided such as Helicopter Training being transferred to Nowra.
The Trackers would be put back in the air for Coastal Surveillance.

SPEECH.PARA: All those promises were totally and absolutely false. Only a man of Mr Hollis's character, standing and poor integrity would be prepared to make such statements knowing them to be false.

PARA.TAB: He said this in that letter to service personnel:

SPEECH.PARA: Service personnel have been lied to and misled by Mr Baume.

I am not in the habit of lying to service personnel or anyone else. I never had to lie to service personnel to win my seat when I was in the House of Representatives, unlike the present member for Throsby, who at that stage won the seat of Macarthur with the same kind of disgraceful campaigning that the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) used to win the last election.

PARA.TAB: I challenge Mr Hollis to produce any evidence that he has received a couple of defamation writs from me. That is simply false. I challenge him to present anyone in the Illawarra region to substantiate his claim that I am `well known throughout the Illawarra for serving defamation orders on people'.
I will also deal with another matter that he raised in attacking me. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume also misrepresented me in that he claimed I had given myself funds from my former employer, the Workers Education Association, which were retrospectively agreed to. This is simply not so—
He continues:
The only funds I received from the WEA were my severance pay and contributions I made to my superannuation. I have documentary evidence of that.

I have some documentary evidence in relation to that matter about which Mr Hollis may be interested. It deals with a complaint by the state president of the Workers Education Association in a press release dated March 1983. The state president of the Workers Education Association of New South Wales at the time—he has unfortunately since died—David Ryan, Mr Hollis's employer, said this:

I was contacted by a reporter on Tuesday 1st March 1983 and that reporter indicated that he intended to have published an article relating to Mr. Hollis and his dealings with the WEA and sought my confirmation of certain elements of the rumour which he informed me were circulating in the Macarthur electorate.

Immediately it became apparent to me that this matter had become part of the public arena, I travelled to Wollongong to attempt to find out information which would permit me to make a statement denying the truth of the rumour circulating.
I was unable to do so.
He then went on:
The directors of the company have been endeavouring for over six months to obtain information from the Wollongong branch about payments made to Mr. Hollis—these efforts have proved unsuccessful.
He then goes on at some length about the extraordinary behaviour of Mr Hollis to him as president when he was trying to find out what had happened to this money. He went on:

In the light of this, the publicity already surrounding this matter, and my inability to obtain the information I sought on Tuesday last, I have now requested the firm of Coopers and Lybrand, auditors of the WEA, to conduct a full investigation of the books of the WEA in Wollongong, and will raise this matter at the next meeting of the board of directors on 12th March 1983.

I regret that the actions taken by Mr. Hollis on Tuesday 1st March 1983 precluded me from making any statement of a substantive nature relating to the rumours circulating regarding the propriety of financial dealings between Mr. Hollis and the Wollongong branch of the WEA as I believe that, had I been in a position to make those substantive statements, it would have been in the public interest, in the best interests of the WEA, and in the best interests of Mr. Hollis, that those statements be made as quickly as possible.

I deplore the need to issue this news release and I deplore the fact that the WEA, a non-political body dedicated to the provision of adult education, through no fault of its own, finds its organisation embroiled in a political campaign.

If Mr Hollis wants to, I suggest he table the Coopers and Lybrand inquiry. Perhaps, in order to avoid a scandal, he might also like to produce the minutes which retrospectively approve the payments that he made to himself and which were the cause of such concern by the former state president of the WEA.

PARA.TAB: I might suggest to Mr Hollis that if he is now in the mood to start revealing court matters he might like to deal with the way in which he sought to sue Mr Cobb. Eventually he withdrew that action because ultimately he did not think it appropriate for one member to take out defamation proceedings against another. He might also like to deal at some length with the prosecution that was successful against him in the Melbourne magistrates court. Frankly, I am sick and tired of Mr Hollis attacking me on a personal basis. I find it contemptible that he should say yesterday, when talking about my speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to remind him that he should be very careful regarding hints in the last paragraph of his speech, as recent magazine articles make interesting reading.

I have no idea to what he is referring but if he is referring to any member of my family then I suggest to him that that is beneath contempt and it is only what I would expect of Mr Hollis. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter which has been of concern to me for quite a period of time now—the Commonwealth Bank and the promises that were made by Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner to the employees of that bank. I think it is becoming increasingly obvious that the Labor Party believes in nothing in terms of its philosophical position, but one hoped that it would believe in at least keeping election promises. I remind colleagues that the Commonwealth Bank was one of those Labor Party icons. How long ago was it when a Labor Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national assets like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas? But as the people of Australia come to realise the extent of the economic and social vandalism proposed by our opponents—
What we were talking about was privatising Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. It was Mr Hawke who made those comments. Then he continued:
. . . it will be necessary for us—Ben Chifley's great heirs and successors—to keep fresh and green the memory, the example and the experience of this great Australian.

The Commonwealth Bank is now going entirely from public ownership without a whimper or a protest from any member within the Labor Party. Such is the commitment of the Labor Party to any consistent philosophy or approach. No wonder so many Australians think this Keating Labor Party has nothing in common with the Labor Party of old—no matter what the current wordsmiths might try to say.

PARA.TAB: The issue which has emerged in recent days very powerfully in the House of Representatives is the promises made by Mr Keating and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to keep the majority shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank in public ownership. This is not a promise which is cost free. Madam Deputy President, you may remember that the Commonwealth Bank was merged with the State Bank of Victoria following the disastrous mismanagement of the Cain and Kirner governments in my home state. A press release was issued at that time in which Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner announced the process by which the State Bank of Victoria would be merged with the Commonwealth Bank. A joint press statement issued by the then federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, and Mrs Joan Kirner states:

SPEECH.PARA: She said the Government had received two very good offers for the bank by the deadline of late Saturday. She said the CBA offer of $1600 million for assets and goodwill was $55 million lower than that of the other main bidder.

Mrs Kirner said that in agreeing to the Commonwealth Bank offer, the Government took into account the relative closeness of the bids along with other considerations. Those included the security to depositors provided by Federal Government control and the community's desire to keep SBV's operations publicly controlled.

"Taking those other factors into account, the Government decided that, given the relative closeness of the offers, the CBA offer was the one which best served the interests of SBV depositors and all Victorians," she said.
It ensures the bank remains publicly-controlled and significantly strengthens the public banking sector.

That particular promise made by Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner cost Victorians $55 million. The Victorian government accepted $55 million less because they wanted to favour a publicly owned bank which Mr Keating, despite his election promises, has decided to fully privatise—following the coalition policy which has been our policy for a very long period.

PARA.TAB: As a result of this merger, some other promises were made by Mrs Kirner and Mr Keating. They said that there would be no compulsory retrenchments as a result of the merger. Whether they should have made that promise or not is not a matter for debate here tonight. The fact is that another Labor promise was made. Since the merger, on the latest figures available, some 8,300 Victorians have been retrenched from the merged bank. That is almost the same number that were employed in the State Bank of Victoria when it was a stand-alone entity. Many of those would have been compulsorily retrenched, and others would have taken voluntary retirement. However, many who took voluntary retirement have gone public and have said that it was more akin to a forced retrenchment. As a Victorian senator, I have been very keen to track what the State Bank of Victoria has been doing. The management took the decision to strip all headquarter activities of the State Bank out of Victoria and transfer them to Sydney, causing further unemployment in our state.

I have put a further three questions on notice in the last month or so. In the first I referred to an article in the Business Review Weekly of 27 February 1995, which indicated that there had been 260 management and executive appointments made from outside the bank since February 1993, and asked whether that figure was correct. The bank had a lot of management in Victoria, but apparently a lot of managers had to be recruited from outside. I was told that these are matters for the management of the bank and, furthermore, that the provision of answers would release information which is of a commercially sensitive nature. In other words, when I asked how many managers have been appointed from outside in the past, the answer is apparently of a commercially sensitive nature, thereby resulting in a competitive disadvantage to the bank. That was one question.

Then I asked how many of the 8,300 full-time positions removed from the bank were compulsory redundancies. Again, I was told that these were of a commercially sensitive nature, and no answers were given. Thirdly, I asked how many branches the Commonwealth Bank planned to close in Victoria in the years 1995, 1996 and 1997 and how many staff will be lost as a result of that. These again were regarded as being of a commercially sensitive nature. One could argue that the last question is commercially sensitive, although I would dispute that, but the first two questions are not commercially sensitive. They are politically sensitive, because they expose the lies of Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner. I give notice in this chamber that I am singularly unsatisfied with those answers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, perhaps you would care to withdraw that and phrase it differently.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President, I withdraw. I give notice that I plan to pursue these matters in the Senate estimates hearings which will be convening at the end of this month. It is simply not good enough for the bank's management not to provide answers to these questions because they happen to be politically sensitive to the government of the day. As a senator, I have a perfect right to ask these questions and I have a perfect right to receive answers. They are embarrassing to the Labor Party.
—Most of us want to go home. Hansard wants to go home. I want to go home. Let's go home.

—Senator Schacht, you used to go around saying what a great thing it was to keep the Commonwealth Bank in public ownership; you did not breathe a word, not a whimper, now it is being sold. Those promises were made by Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner. They were made to the employees of that bank. It is time that we got some answers. I intend to pursue this matter. Questions will be asked in the Senate estimates committee. We will get some answers to these important questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the crisis facing small business in the Hunter which is now sending out a mayday alarm for help. Tonight I am pleased to see that the duty minister is the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht). The closure of small business units in the Hunter is now happening at the rate of one a day, which is a truly alarming figure.

PARA.TAB: Already the President of the Hunter Regional Small Business Persons Association, John Farragher, says that some 3,000 small business units have shut in the Hunter in the last four years. Hurt and despair is now surfacing and proud and independent shopkeepers are demanding to be heard. Small businesses in the Hunter are facing reduced demand. They are cutting employment and capital funds are being lost. The irony is that consumers, who are avoiding these small businesses for some of the chain stores to save a few dollars on a basket of groceries, should not be surprised if their children have no work because of small business closures at the rate that is occurring in the Hunter.

Hunter small business includes fruit shops, chemists, delicatessens, butchers, bakeries and takeaway food stores. Many of these are becoming unviable and closing. Unconscionable conduct in trading practices by quite a number of the large chain stores is responsible for a lot of this. Misuse of market power and predatory pricing by some of the chains is one of the major problems facing these small businesses.

Some shopping centre managers are restricting hours and even restricting the trading policies of some small businesses, with examples like bread shops not being able to sell bread rolls because of the competition this puts them in with some of the larger businesses in the centre.

Small business owners have told me the nub of their problems. For the minister's edification, here are some of the problems that they are facing. Ten years ago in this state we had over 2,000 independent bakeries. These have now shrunk to eight and the chains, open for 24 hours a day in many cases, are baking their own bread. Chemists are being decimated. The pharmaceutical companies are offering a very large range of lines now through the chains. Delicatessen turnover has dropped by half and the chains are selling similar lines at half price.

The supply and distribution network in the Hunter for small business is now starting to break down as small stores close. Coke recently closed its Newcastle distribution point. This has flow-on effects to other jobs—packers, forklift drivers and carriers.

There is now a response from the business community to this developing crisis in the Hunter. Newcastle small business representatives wrote to Minister Schacht and the letter outlined the problem in the way in which I have informed the Senate tonight. On 8 February back came a very unsympathetic reply from the minister. His letter was read to a 500-strong crowd of small business people in Newcastle. You should have been there, Minister, to hear their reaction to your words. I will not quote the whole letter because of lack of time but let me give you some of the flavour of it. I quote from the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: it would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth to establish mechanisms to reduce competition in the marketplace . . . . unfortunately it is the larger supermarkets who are best placed to meet these new demands.
This is from the minister for small business. Maybe he should rename his ministry the ministry for big business if his interjections a few minutes ago are any indication.

PARA.TAB: The reaction to the letter ranged from anger to misbelief—that the Australian minister for small business could just say, `Small business in this country can just sink or swim.' This federal Labor government's sink or swim attitude to the plight of small business comes not only from the minister; it comes from the very top.

Today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) finetuned some of his invective to tell struggling small business owners to consider their future employment options. Paul Keating was at his most insulting to small business on ABC radio in Queensland earlier today—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: If they're feeling the pinch it is in the highest growth economy we have ever had; we've been growing at 5 to six per cent with 2 per cent so if they are feeling the pinch they should say "small business is not for me because it's never going to get any better."

This lecture comes from a Prime Minister responsible for record interest rates, an arthritic industrial relations system and a range of other policies that have severely hurt small businesses in this country.

PARA.TAB: Over the last 12 years this range of policies including taxes, industrial relations and red tape have greatly reduced the capacity and the potential for a very wide range of small businesses. But fortunately for Australia, despite the government's policies, we find small businesses are a very committed breed. They commit the life savings of their business and mortgages of their home to provide what they hope is a sound and secure future for their families.

We cannot let the small businesses in this country that are in crisis just wither and die, which is increasingly the outcome of this Labor government's policy. Small business growth in Australia in the early 1990s brought us out of the recession with the creation of 550,000 new jobs—and this has been the pattern overseas as well. We really depend for growth on small businesses—but it needs supporting policies for it to happen. In the United States, for example, in the 1980s not one new net job was added by big business or government to the employment pool. It all came from small business.

What this government must do is create a climate that will allow our small businesses to flourish. It must create a regulatory system which will allow small businesses to flourish. But that is not happening, as we now have the predatory chain stores being able to destroy the viability of the little guy. It is not good enough for the Prime Minister to say small businesses go broke every day. With appropriate policies many could prosper and create jobs.

Obviously, people are going into business and out of business all the time, but under this government's policies more and more are going out of business. If the government is really interested in creating lasting employment in this country, it should be supporting them and not standing back and watching them be destroyed.

The small business mayday call forum in Newcastle is a backlash to this ALP government's negative approach to small business. On Friday, 19 May the Sandgate regional fruit and vegetable markets in Newcastle are expecting a turnout of over 1,500 people. They want the state and federal government ministers responsible to listen to the real problems and act with real policy changes.

Minister Schacht has been invited to Newcastle. We sincerely hope that he comes. This might get his feet back on the ground. He might have a chance to listen to the real problems that have been outlined tonight from the people who are really hurting from his government's policies. It is not good enough for a minister who has had no experience in small business to listen to bureaucrats who probably have not had any experience in business themselves. If they would get out and listen to what is happening to the real people in this country, perhaps they might come up with some measures to support them.

At that function the rest of Australia will see this plight even though the minister seems to refuse to see it. Business Sunday from the Nine Network will be there. ABC's Four Corners is onto this crisis. They will be reporting the Mayday forum. Out of all this we hope that Minister Schacht will face up to his responsibilities for small business. He has, within the Trade Practices Act, the power to—

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do? You have not provided one solution.

—Minister, you are not proposing any solutions at all. Within the Trade Practices Act there is more power than the minister is admitting to. He is really squibbing action by saying that he will have a working party look at the problem. Minister, businesses are going broke every day. People want action today. They do not want action next year. They want action today or next week.
—You are a fraud. You are an absolute fraud.

—They do not want you, Minister, to just send stuff off to working parties. You have to stop procrastinating and get on to this real problem. If you were really interested in jobs being created in this country, you would be out there doing something instead of writing a very dismissive letter to these people and showing the obvious attitude you have in supporting the Prime Minister in his very dismissive approach to small business in this country.
—Senator Schacht, I ask you to withdraw the word `fraud'.
—I withdraw the word `fraud'.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) site Ravenhall situated at Robinson Road, Sunshine in Victoria:
(1) What was the ADI site Ravenhall used for.
(2) What are the details of current plans for the use of the Ravenhall site.
(3) What companies other than ADI are involved in developing the site.

(4) Has any environmental assessment been undertaken of the: (a) level of contamination; (b) need for decontamination before developing the site; and (c) impact of future site development on the environment; if so, can copies of the assessment be provided; if not, why not, and when will an environmental assessment be done.
(5) (a) Has any assessment of decontamination processes been made at the Ravenhall site; and (b) what decontamination process will be used at the site.

(6) (a) What are the estimated clean-up costs of the site; (b) when is it expected that the clean up will begin and when will it be completed; and (c) what development will the site be appropriate for after clean-up.

(7) (a) What is the estimated land value of the site; (b) are there any factors such as zoning or contamination that would devalue the current value of the site; and (c) what is the expected land value of the site with appropriate zoning and decontamination.

(8) (a) What percentage of the Ravenhall site is heavily contaminated and what percentage is lightly contaminated; (b) what are the names of the areas which were heavily contaminated and what is their use; and (c) what are the names of the areas which were lightly contaminated and what is their use.

(9) (a) What is the nature of the contamination; (b) are any of the following materials present at the site: foundry slag, ash, copper, zinc, mercury, arsenic, chromium, cadmium nickel, tin, mercury compounds, inert wastes, building rubble and various heavy metals, if so: (i) what are the levels present, (ii) which exist in high levels, and (iii) which have the potential to leach.

(10) (a) Where were the samples of each material sampled from at the site and what was that part of the site used for; (b) what was the sample method chosen; (c) are the levels of sampled material representative of maximum levels or minimum levels of materials/contaminants found; (d) what were the maximum levels of each substance found and where were these levels found on the site; (e) how were the sample sites chosen in the environmental assessment; (f) were areas believed to have higher levels of particular substances included on purpose or deliberately left out.
(11) Are there any areas of botanical, wetland or national heritage significance situated at Ravenhall; if so, what is the nature of these areas.
(l2) (a) How big is the Ravenhall site; and (b) what is the soil contamination in cubic metres and as a percentage of the site.
(13) (a) What are the land use concepts for the Ravenhall site; and (b) is there any risk of flooding at the site; if so, how does this affect the choices for land use.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) to (13) When the Ravenhall site was in Commonwealth ownership and controlled by the Office of Defence Production, it was used on an infrequent basis for the testing of small rocket motors. The site was transferred from the Department of Defence to Australian Defence Industries Ltd (ADI) in 1989. ADI did not use the Ravenhall property since assuming ownership of it and the Company sold the site to the Victorian Government, under normal commercial arrangements, in December 1994. Any further questions relating to the Ravenhall property should be referred to the Victorian Government.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Defence Offset arrangements in relation to the F/A-18 program are described in the Deed between McDonnell Douglas Corporation (MDC) and the Commonwealth of Australia for "Australian Industry Participation in the New Tactical Fighter Program" dated 1 December 1981 and as amended. This Deed benefits in excess of 50 Australian owned or Australian based firms, such as Hawker de Havilland, British Aerospace Australia, AWA and Comsteel, through offsets to a current total value of approximately $US334M (1981 prices).

(2) The ADF in this and following questions is taken to mean the Defence Organisation. MDC had responsibility for selection of any Australian firms to be used in conjunction with the F/A-18 program. MDC used in excess of 220 Australian based firms during the F/A-18 program. The Commonwealth of Australia stipulated the use of the Government Aircraft Factory and Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation to ensure certain strategic skills and capabilities continued to be available in Australian industry post production of the aircraft.

(3) No. The separate, and draft only, Offsets Credit Deed (Number DID/1123) with MDC, which has been developed over the period 1990 to 1995, provides the vehicle for MDC to satisfy its offset obligation under the contract (C218380) for provision of MMS to the RAN.

(4) to (7) Yes, IMS was involved in the Offsets Credits arrangement described in the answer to (3) above with MDC. McDonnell Douglas Aerospace—West proposed to transfer to IMS excess Printed Circuit Board (PCB) manufacturing equipment, also known as the printed wire board facility. This Deed has not yet been executed by the Commonwealth. The arrangements between IMC and MDC continue to fit the technical criteria for eligibility. However, given the facts now available, further discussions are being held with MDC on its eligibility.

(8) There are no additional costs, other than administrative, to the Department of Defence associated with the MDC arrangements. The Defence Offsets Program provides the opportunity for overseas firms to discharge Australian industry involvement obligations arising from contracts with the Department of Defence through activities other than the use of local industry. These activities, such as training Australian industry, transfer of intellectual property, sponsorship of Australian research and development or provision of new technology, are in addition to the provision of the goods and/or services under the contract and are at no cost to the Commonwealth. Valuation of offsets allows acquittal of the obligation, which is specified as a percentage of the contract value, once the Australian beneficiary firm confirms achievement of the activity. The procedure is that the offsets credits are banked against the obligation following a request from the overseas company and approval by the Commonwealth. The Australian beneficiary must satisfy the Commonwealth that the activities have occurred before the Commonwealth would award the offset credits to the overseas firm.

(9) The Defence Offsets Program is managed by the Department. Arrangements are made using a standard Deed developed by Defence in conjunction with the Attorney General's Department which is agreed and executed by the overseas company and the Commonwealth. MDC did not give terms and conditions to Defence.
(10) There are no general security procedures within the Defence Offsets Program. Defence invokes appropriate security procedures for individual arrangements.
(11) Assessment was not applicable in this instance. See answer to (10).

commercial provision of computing related services from its Sydney office to a value of approximately $A16,600.
negotiation with the Industry Involvement and Offsets (IIO) Section of Defence from November 1990 to December 1991 for the offset credit activity referred to in (3) to (11).
negotiation with IIO during 1992 for recognition of the purchase of computer upgrade kits as eligible for offset credits.
an approach to the Strategic Trade Policy and Operations (STPO) Section of Defence in 1993 requesting information on export controls.

IMS was informed by the Defence Department that, based on the information provided, the semi-conductors were not controlled goods and, as such, did not require a permit for export.

(30) The semi-conductors were assessed against the strategic goods list of Regulation 13E of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulation which is contained in the Department of Defence document "Australian Controls on the Export of Technology with Civil and Military Applications—A Guide for Exporters and Importers" dated September 1992.
(31) The Department has no record of any such contact with Ms Juliette Saliba or Mr Robert Burgess.
(32) See answer to (31).

(33) No. Defence administers Regulation 13E of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations and the ACS performs the barrier control function associated with that Regulation. Defence assesses whether the goods are controlled without consultation with Customs.
(34) As stated in the answer to (29) Defence, alone, determined that no permit was required for export of the semi-conductors described by IMS.

(35) Defence has conducted business with IMS as described in the answer to (12). During those negotiations and transactions there was no reason to suggest that IMS was other than a suitable Australian firm. Any future assessment would l ave to await the outcome of law enforcement agency investigations.

(36) The determination of suitability is either a formal evaluation during the source selection process in response to tenders or informal in other matters and based on the judgement of Defence staff interacting with the company.

(37) Yes, the CJC informed the Defence Inspector General on 31 August 1994. However, the export control administration had determined previously that the semi-conductors concerned were commercial, not military, components. All indications to Defence are that the semi-conductors were shipped to the USA and this is not in contravention of Australian laws. The semi-conductors are of Japanese origin and therefore US laws are not applicable in exporting them from Australia. UN bans, in the form of sanctions or resolutions concerning exports, are normally given legislative backing in Australia under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. The US is not a proscribed country in this case and thus no UN bans have been violated.

(38) Australia maintains an export control regime, administered by Defence, to ensure that Australia does not export controlled goods to countries subject to UN sanctions or against Australian export legislation. While Australia does not recognise the extra-territorial application of US laws we advise persons intending to re-export US sourced goods to check with US authorities on whether permission is needed from that administration.

financial viability of the new proposal; and

ANSWER.PARA: NELLY BAY DEVELOPMENT, MAGNETIC ISLAND, QUEENSLAND
Guidelines for the preparation of joint Environmental Impact Assessment and Impact Assessment Study

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has determined in accordance with Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (Impact of Proposals Act) that an environmental impact statement (EIS) should be prepared in regard to the proposal by the Queensland Department of Lands (the proponent) to construct a safe harbour and residential development with associated retail, commercial and tourist based facilities at Nelly Bay on Magnetic Island, Queensland.
The Queensland Government has advised that the components of the proposal within Queensland territory will also need to be assessed under Queensland environmental impact assessment procedures.
To satisfy the environmental requirements of both Governments it has been agreed that a single assessment be conducted in the form of a joint Commonwealth EIS/Queensland IAS.
The proposal should be assessed against the present environment at Nelly Bay (including taking into account the works on site).

Similar objectives are contained in the Commonwealth and Queensland environmental impact assessment statutes. The object of the Impact of Proposals Act is to ensure that matters affecting the environment to a significant extent are fully examined and taken into account in decisions by the Australian Government. The State Development and Public Works Organisation Act aims to ensure that, in any development, proper account is taken of environmental effects.
To help achieve the objectives when preparing the draft EIS/IAS, the proponent should bear in mind the following aims of the EIS/IAS and public review process:

to provide a source of information from which interested individuals and groups may gain an understanding of the proposal, the need for the proposal, the alternatives, the environment which it would affect, the impacts that may occur and the measures to be taken to minimise these impacts;
to provide a forum for public consultation and informed comment on the proposal; and
to provide a framework in which decision-makers can consider the environmental aspects of the proposal in parallel with economic, technical and other factors.

A draft EIS/IAS prepared by the proponent will be released for a period of public comment after which the proponent will be required to prepare a supplement to the draft EIS/IAS taking into account comments received. The responsible Commonwealth and Queensland environmental agencies will then prepare assessment review reports.
Sub paragraph 4.1 of the Administrative Procedures of the Impact of Proposals Act lists those general matters to be addressed in any EIS.

The following guidelines describe those matters which should be addressed in this EIS/IAS. These guidelines are designed as a guide and it is possible that additional issues may be identified by the proponent during the formulation of the EIS/IAS.
It is important to explain thoroughly the need for the proposal. This explanation should be supported by an analysis of the alternatives to the proposal.

The report should be written in clear, concise and analytical style that is easily understood by the general reader. It should include references and a list of individuals and organisations consulted.
Results of studies and detailed comments resulting from consultations should be included as appendices as should technical information. Relevant plans and illustrations should also be included.

It is acceptable and sensible that the draft EIS/IAS draw on information contained in and conclusions of assessments of the previous proposal on the Nelly Bay site. Relevant information should, however, be included in this draft EIS/IAS.
A glossary defining technical terms and abbreviations used in the text should be included to assist the general reader.
The report will be made available for public review. If the proponent requires any information to remain confidential, this should be clearly indicated and provided separately.
An Authority from which approval is required may request additional information.

The proponent may use suitably qualified and experienced consultants to undertake preparatory work for and to prepare the draft EIS/IAS. The report should include the names and curricula vitae of principal personnel involved.

All components of the project including its construction and operational phases should be described in as much detail as possible. In this regard, construction implies beginning with the site in its present state. Matters which need to be included are outlined below:

proposed infrastructure;

arrangements for disposal or recycling of construction wastes;
site management plan including storm and waste water management, restoration, landscaping or revegetation procedures to be undertaken;
land use plan;
arrangements for administration and control of facilities and operations after construction.

This section should clearly identify the principal environmental impacts expected to result during and from the construction of the remainder of the basin within the breakwater wall, residential development with associated retail, commercial and tourist based facilities at Nelly Bay. It should analyse the potential impacts of the proposal on the natural and social environments of the area, considering construction activities and the on-going operation of the proposal. Where appropriate, reference should be made to measures proposed to mitigate environmental impacts.
Community sensitivities to the proposal should be addressed.
