ANSWER.PARA: 8. ENVIRONMENTAL SAFEGUARDS, MONITORING PROPOSALS AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PLAN

PARA.TAB: This section should describe all measures proposed to minimise the adverse impacts, including social and biophysical, associated with the proposal and contain a clear statement of specific commitments made by the proponent and who has responsibility. Commitments which are beyond the responsibility of the proponent such as those required under GBRMPA's assessment should be identified. The mechanism for implementing these commitments will be through the Environmental Management Plan which should be included in outline in this section. The Environmental Management Plan should also describe all monitoring programs which should be designed to:
ensure safeguards are being applied effectively;
identify any unpredicted impacts requiring remedial measures;
measure any differences between predicted and actual impacts; and
provide for periodic review of the management plan itself.
8.1 Construction Phase
Safeguards should be identified to:

provide protection to community assets through performance bonds, or other mechanisms, in construction contracts to ensure that remedial work can be carried out at no cost to public resources if environmental damage occurs;
provide for the protection and management of areas of high biological and heritage values (eg. retention of existing mangrove community at Gustav Creek and marine ecosystem of the GBR Marine Park);
prevent the introduction and/or spread of exotic species;
minimise noise, vibration, dust, erosion, accidental spillage and water pollution;
rehabilitate areas disturbed areas by construction associated with this proposal;
protect any Aboriginal sites and artefacts in accordance with relevant legislation;
protect identified World Heritage values;
ensure that employees and construction managers understand their environmental protection obligations; (eg incorporation of appropriate clauses in construction contracts and permits issues); and
discuss monitoring and management arrangements which will ensure the above measures are effectively applied.
8.2 Operational Phase
Safeguards should be identified to:
minimise the impact on sensitive areas of land and vegetation;
provide continuing protection of flora and fauna of significance;
provide measures to manage stormwater during storm events and to minimise flooding during wet season;
provide continuing protection to World Heritage areas;
provide measure to minimise accidents during fuel transfers;
provide safeguards for shipping during adverse weather and tidal episodes; and
ensure proper responses to the results of monitoring programmes.

Information relevant to the EIS but not suitable for inclusion in the main text should be included as appendices; eg detailed technical or statistical information, supplementary reports or extracts from past assessments. A glossary defining technical terms and abbreviations used in the text should be included to assist the general reader. This supporting documentation should be made available during the period of public display of the EIS/IAS.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 4 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What types of financial grants are made by the department apart from those made by Austrade.
(2) What type of grants are made by Austrade.
(3) In the 1994-95 financial year, how many of each type of grant were made to Australian recipients and to Queensland recipients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A grant is non-repayable financial assistance provided by the Commonwealth to an individual/organisation to be applied for a specified purpose and is usually subject to certain terms and conditions, such as acquittal.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has made a number of grants in 1994-95, both domestically and internationally. Details are included in the answer to part 3 of the question. It is estimated that approximately $6.8 million will be paid in grants by the Department during 1994-95.

(2) Austrade provides grants under the Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme to encourage Australian exporters to seek out and develop overseas markets for goods, services, industrial property rights and know-how, which are substantially of Australian origin. The total EMDG grants budget for 1994-95 is $230 million.
Financial incentives are provided in the form of taxable cash grants, based on amounts spent on certain export marketing and sales promotional activities.

In 1994-95 Austrade received a total of 3,521 claims for a grant under the EMDG Scheme, of which 579 came from companies or individuals in Queensland. Austrade expects that processing of the EMDG claims will be completed by the end of June. To date, 2,181 EMDG grants have been processed with a total value of $130 million. Of these 472 were paid to claimants in Queensland with a value of $27.5 million.
